description:
What a great place to get your quick coffee fix and explore the Hayes Valley neighborhood! It's located off the busy streets of Gough and Fell st. A nice little corner to get your coffee to go! There's also some benches around the area for you to sit on and sip on your coffee:)

I got the New Orleans today. If you like the strong and bitter aroma of coffee with a little hint of sweetness, this is perfect for you!
author: Elle T.

description:
Cool outdoor "pop up" style venue. Average coffee will run you $4.50 but worth the quality for sure. 

One table and a few park benches outside but it's def more of a to go / pick-up and walk around Hayes valley kinda spot

Very friendly staff. Highly recommend.
author: Mo J.

description: It's my first cup of Blue Bottle coffee. We could smell the coffee from half a block away ~~ love the richness of the taste. i highly recommend it if you are a coffee lover.
author: Aimee J.

description: Dope coffee by dope people. Not a great place when you are trying to cut down on your caffeine :)
author: Han L.

description: Hello to the best coffee in www. Blue bottle made me such a coffee snob. Why do you have to be so good. My bf and I are literally addicted to Oat Nola. We could finish 2 in an hour. Yes it is that good.
author: Gwen M.

description: Coffee doesn't get much better than this. Alex and crew know my order(s), my moods, my story, and are always on top of their shit. I've been a regular here for 7 years and have been impressed countless time by their attentiveness and quality of service. Pro-tip: avoid weekend mornings after 9am-10am if you don't wanna wait.
author: C S.

description: Clean, friendly, fast and affordable. Location is great and so if the coffee. Hot chocolate is tasty, too. I also enjoy their cappuccino.
author: Juan M.

description: Yum! This place is walking distance from where I am staying and I'm so glad I found it. The location is super tiny in the middle of an alley with no seating, probably the only downside but also is what makes the spot unique and different. There was a small line forming when I got there and it got even longer behind me, so this place is definitely a busy spot. I ordered an iced latte and it was ready super fast! It was also very delicious. The servers were nice, not super friendly and upbeat like Starbucks but still pleasant. I really liked the blue accents on the cup and straw. Definitely will come here again.
author: Angelica B.

description:
This little gem has to be the best location of a Blue Bottle ever, seeing as it gives the feel of a pop up location with the exterior atmosphere of 'a quiet and lovely moment in the big city' versus a chain store. The fact that it is on this little alleyway to which you can sit on the benches or rock shaped seating, is what makes this easily the best location of Blue Bottle currently opened.

You can notice that those working behind the counter are very happy with their jobs and the work they do, you can tell they love the company they work for and the product the sell to you.

I got my typical cold brew and unlike most other coffee chains or even other Blue Bottle stores, I got an entire cup of cold brew with two pieces of ice versus mostly ice and minimal coffee. 

You surely will miss this place if you're walking the Main Street and aren't looking for it, I suggest you just stop up to the counter and order some yummy coffee from them and enjoy the unique and special ambiance the area provides!
author: J Austyn B.

description: This place is an amazing little gem in Hayes Valley. I strolled over for my morning coffee and was energized by the vibe of this place before a drop of caffeine entered my body. The vibe is super upbeat and friendly with music and workers who seem to know the regulars well. They have smiles on their face that are contagious. It's basically a walk up counter with some of the best coffee ever! My latte was divine. Coffee is expensive but hey it's SFO. Kudos y'all!
author: Megan J.

description:
This location of Blue Bottle is so cute, semi hidden in an alleyway, with a garage opening. I definitely would not have found it  have without already knowing it was there! 

I hadn't been to a Blue Bottle for awhile, and my go-to drink at every coffee shop is usually a vanilla latte. However, simple menu, no flavors here, just coffee. Which is NOT a bad thing at all, because I ended up getting just a normal latte, and it wasn't too strong or too sweet! It was perfect!
author: Vi T.

description:
De-lish!!! A little coffee place in a cute alley with lots of street art and stone benches. 
Staff could've been a little more friendly, the cold brew is great!
author: Taleen K.

description: I love blue bottle. It's the best. BEST. A latte and a waffle is my favorite way to start my morning.
author: Basil M.

description:
If you're looking for a strong cup of coffee and one that doesn't taste bitter, come to blue bottle. In college, I would frequent the Hayes valley location because you could stroll around or just chill in the location while sipping on my cup of joe. Yes it's in an alley, but it's not that sketch -just walk up a little farther and you'll find yourself surrounded by cute little shops and a small park. 

On hot days, I always order their cold brew New Orleans with that dash of whole milk. Blue bottle does their cold brew right, it does not taste at all like watered down cold coffee which I've had before. It's not sweetened either. 

Per beans I always end up getting three Africas and make my coffee via French press. I usually drink it black and it's the best.
author: Marian D.

description:
Came by for coffee the other day and was surprised that this was merely a take out joint! Blue Bottle is one of my favorite coffee shops in the city! There was a line of ~10 people at ~11 am on a Sunday morning. Staff was super helpful!

Ordered the Mocha which came out perfect. Perfect temperature, chocolate wasn't too sweet and espresso was smooth!

They also have TCHO chocolate bars here too!

They take credit cards!
author: Derek S.

description:
Were the baristas the friendliest? No. The guys working here seemed too cool to offer any happy and upbeat vibes. They weren't unfriendly, either. Just seemed like they wanted to get orders in and out. But they did a good job pulling my espresso shot- it was frothy, full of crema and smooth. It hit the much needed spot after not having access to my espresso machine which is at home while traveling out in our RV. 

We also bought a bag of their beans. They have a location in Los Angeles and I remember their beans made some pretty good espresso shots at home. 

There is limited seating. No frills and in an alley way.  I love their coffee though, it's comparable to Klatch coffee in my hometown. I can tell they use fresh beans.
author: Tina S.

description: It's alright. The location is kinda fun in between the alley ways but the prices are ridiculous and the coffee isn't satisfying. To each their own, but I would prefer Ritual or Wise Sons if you're in Hayes Valley.
author: Sahar N.

description: You can't be a millennial coffee lover visiting San Francisco and NOT try Blue Bottle.  There's nothing like having coffee fresh from the source instead of a can being sold in Target.  This particular location is in Hayes Valley in a narrow alleyway - almost like a secret location.  I honestly tried SOOO hard not to like it, because Blue Bottle has become to San Francisco like Stumptown is to Portland.  However, once again, I was proven wrong and this coffee does actually live up to the hype.  The NOLA drink was the best iced coffee drink I've ever had, and I am not a huge iced coffee fan.  It had just the right amount of coffee flavor perfectly balanced with the cream.  It was so good we stopped by again on our last day to pick up two bags of beans to take home.  I WISH they would open up a location in San Diego like Coava Coffee did from Portland.  I would be ALL OVER it! :) HINT HINT, Blue Bottle! Make it happen!
author: Ashley L.

description: Clean with good drinks. Cute environment that makes you stay longer and enjoy your Sunday. the brunch are delicious.
author: Mina R.

description:
The original Blue Bottle is a hole-in-the-wall at its best. This must have been a converted garage or something, but as we all know this is where great things usually take off from.

Blue Bottle certainly has their own flavor profile, some like it, some not. I personally swing both ways (coffee, that is) - I like Blue Bottle's but also the sweetness of Philz' mixed creations. Prices are what'd you expect from a third-wave coffee shop: Cappuccino $3, Latte $3.50.
author: Sebastian F.

description: I love Blue Bottle. It's expensive, but when I need a buzz in the morning before work, it's the go-to. The garage in Hayes Valley is better for taking out coffee, but if you want to drink it there, there are some benches on the alley and a little bar to stand at.
author: Madeleine M.

description: I loved the feel of this coffee shop. They were very quick af getting our coffee and making sure we didnt have to wait in line too long. They had several options for pastries all where great!
author: Ari D.

description: Grabbed a slow drip coffee on our long walk around San Francisco. Place is kind of hidden, the street is like a little side alley. It's not an actual coffee shop, just a place you can walk up to the counter and order. Their coffee was very smooth.
author: Karolina T.

description: There's a reason you can find blue bottle coffee in other states. It's because it's absolutely delicious and you'd be missing out if you didn't have access to it. On my 3rd trip to SF I finally made a point to check out Blue Bottle Coffee and honestly wish I'd done it earlier. I got a latte which was basically the perfect latte and a few pastries to split with my friend. Next time I'm in SF I'll head straight to blue bottle!
author: Angela Y.

description:
Ordered a cold brew and a pretzel bun. The service was great and friendly, and I got my 2 items expediently. The location is very accessible, though just off the beaten path of Hayes Valley. Hence, earning its first star.

However, none more were earned because, firstly, the cold brew was excessively watered down (perhaps I am just more acquainted with stronger drinks, but it is fair to say that this was coffee-flavored water). Furthermore, the brew itself had a distinct citrus taste, which I did not enjoy. I'm hindsight, I should have inquired as to the brew flavor before purchasing, but I took no more than 3 sips (each progressively worse) before disposing of the cup.

Lastly, as to the pretzel bun, I experienced quite a whirlwind of emotions, which I do not enjoy when eating a simple pretzel bun. Initially unappealing and unfamiliar, then somehow much more inviting and flavorful, but then, once again, becoming some sort of cheesy, doughy substance that I would not think of as a pretzel in bun form.

Considering the exceptionally high reviews for this place, I was very disappointed with my purchases and would not return here again. But, as I did notice the place was very clean and well-kept, I will give an additional star.
author: Lenin B.

description: Delicious pastries, but I wasn't a fan of the coffee, surprisingly! I came here because of the great yelp reviews. I got the New Orleans iced coffee for $5 that had a description of being the sweeter option, but it tasted very tarte. My husband got the cafe mocha which tasted more like hot chocolate than coffee.
author: Caitlyn L.

description: I don't really understand the hype of this place. We stumbled upon it after walking around the district, although I had heard the name on many "places to try in San Francisco" lists. The line was pretty long, especially for a hole-in-the-wall location. I just wanted a simple iced coffee and opted for the New Orleans style. It tasted exactly like a normal iced coffee. As in coffee, cream, sugar, ice. Yet it still cost almost $5 and we had to wait in line. This place having over 1500 reviews baffles me. Yes, it was okay, but can someone explain what this place is about and why I should pick it over any other (also cheaper) coffee spot?
author: Sally L.

description:
I have fond memories of visiting Blue Bottle Coffee. It's been more than three years since I visited, but I still remember how amazing Blue Bottle's mocha was when I first tasted it. I normally do not like handcrafted mocha drinks as they tend to be too sweet for my taste. Blue Bottle's mocha, however, tasted just like it should--coffee and chocolate. I remember the coffee having a nice, roasted flavor. The COCOA the high quality type. This drink converted me into giving mocha drinks a chance at trusted coffee shops.

Whenever I see the Blue Bottle Coffee logo anywhere, I squeal on the inside. Not being a San Francisco resident, and even moving away from California makes me miss Blue Bottle even more, even after three years.
author: Angel C.

description: Awesome fuss free coffee. They know what they are doing. Simple but flavorful. Even the regular coffee tastes Devine.
author: Dee V.

description:
I originally thought this place was overrated and tried their New Orleans iced coffee (yet again) and actually really liked it!

I'm craving it even now.
author: Ellen C.

description: This small but mighty kiosk is fast and efficient. They ask you for your order before you even get to the counter. My go-to drink is the New Orleans Iced, light ice. Their new wide lid cups are pretty cool looking too.
author: Christina G.

description:
I still can't get past the fact that the original Blue Bottle is a small little shack in the middle of Hayes Valley. How entrepreneurial of them.

I just got back from Ethiopia and after visiting strong coffee heaven for a couple weeks, this is the closest thing I experienced that reminds me of the coffee I had in Ethiopia. No cream or sugar needed, just the rich, yet very smooth, coffee!
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
Coffee quality and flavor wise - lots of people rave about Blue Bottle. I do find it fresh tasting, never burnt, and consistently thick and foamy (for texture of lattes). However, somehow my taste buds still can't get accustomed to the aftertaste. Seems a bit sour or bitter - not sure how to explain it. 

Specific to this location - I have not had good barista experiences. Today's example was my request to scoop a little of an overflowing latte off the top so it wouldn't spill as I walked. The barista rolled his eyes and insisted that the lid would still fit...
author: Amy S.

description:
I've always found Blue Bottle to be overhyped in comparison to other options (Four Barrel, Sightglass in SF; Devocion, Sweatshop, Champion, Supercrown, Toby's Estate in Brooklyn). 

Similar to Starbucks, they are heavy on sugar in any specialty drinks, including their New Orleans iced coffee, and now, cascara. At coffee shops like Devocion and Supercrown (in Brooklyn, but I'm assuming others here as well), you can get a light and refreshing cascara soda that has no additional sweeteners, allowing you to enjoy the true flavor. 

The coffee is nothing exceptional here, the service is somewhat pretentious, and there's always a line. With Ritual and Artis both within spitting distance, there's no reason to go here.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
I love this coffee shop! Each drink they offer utilizes unique brewing methods that maximizes the flavors of the beans! They also roast and serve their own coffee beans!

I am the type of person who needs to drink coffee everyday! Also, I'm not basic enough to drink Starbucks. :P During my trip to SF, my friend told me about this coffee shop that I must try! I ordered the Oji iced coffee. The cashier warned me that this is equivalent to 3 shots of espresso and I was like, no worries! Oji is a Japanese-style code Brewer coffee. They drip this overnight for around 24 hours before they serve it. Therefore, the flavors are strong and dense. The taste was more acidity than chocolatey. And boy did this coffee wake me up! I ended up staying up until 2am that night. 

I wish there is a blue bottle coffee shop in Boston! I would definitely go back and try other drinks on their menu!
author: Idy T.

description:
I'm into coffee... Not the annoying pretentious BS that goes with coffee snobbery.  Just a good execution of a correctly roasted beans and proper brewing. When you find a place that takes this art seriously- it should be celebrated (but without without being a douche about it.) Despite my preconceptions of neck beards and man buns in an exorbitantly expensive coffee shop in SFO's financial district, I loved this place.

The staff was (although very hipster) very cool and happy to answer my questions about the Siphon method of brewing. The single origin Myanmar beans that took 20 min to brew via Siphon made for  the best coffee I've ever had! Hints of chocolate and floral notes that changed into a natural sweetness as the coffee cooled on this 13 day post roast cup.  The Siphon method made for a very smooth cup perfectly filtered/pure with lots of complex flavor and no bitterness.  

The food was really good as well. Avocado toast for the wife and seasonal breakfast sandwich with locally sourced frittata ingredients- awesome!

Over 50$ for coffee and small breakfast sammies for two... maybe a tad steep.  But no complaints as I knew this from the get go.
author: Kaaba K.

description:
Not bad but not as great as everyone made it out to be on here. The New Orleans iced coffee was mediocre. Decent service. 
This is set up more like a canteen than a sit down cafe. Way overpriced for a place with low overhead costs.
author: Nina L.

description: How can you not love their espresso drinks. I got the cappuccino and of course it was incredible. Near a really cute park with a few neat sculptures. Worth a trip or daily drink.
author: Kristin G.

description:
Oh how I wish I lived in San Fransisco.

More like... I wish I could AFFORD to live in San Fran. Regardless, the sentiment stands that I love this place and the high quality coffee it produces. 

On a weekend trip from San Diego, I had a friend recommend Blue Bottle saying it had "The best Cappuccino" he'd ever had. And I'll be darned, wasn't that one heck of a Cappuccino. 

The service was sweet and quick. I'm sorta regretting not bringing a bag of coffee home... but there were so many options, I couldn't decide! No matter, I'll always have that morning walking the rolling hills of SF with my mom and my amazing almond milk cappuccino.
author: Shayne C.

description: A really cute hole-in-the-wall type spot in the hub of Hayes valley. By hole-in-the-wall I mean literally... it's a grab and go place as there is no traditional seating. There is a standing bar that can fit about 4 people. The lack of seating really isn't an issue though because there is a super cute community area a block up the street with plenty of public seating and food places. Coffee quality was great, chill staff, and convenient location.
author: Tessa M.

description:
Love small businesses like these! Very cool location, and Japanese style alley shop surroundings.

Coffee was great! I got a latte; super smooth, nice crema. The berry pound cake was also super good, and moist! 

Next time I would try a mocha!
author: Milo G.

description: Purveyors of some of the finest coffee I've had the pleasure to drink, Blue Bottle Coffee is one of those places I always go to when I visit San Francisco. At any of their locations, you'll always find delicious coffee, with only a dash of that third-wave pretentiousness. This location on Linden was a unique find, as it's basically a small stall along a narrow, tree-lined alley. Overall a winner.
author: Ho L.

description:
Love this location. It feels like it's a pop-up in the middle of an alley but that alley is a small street, Linden St. It's just a few steps from the Hayes Valley shopping area around the corner from Proxy Park.  

The ladies behind the counter were friendly and efficient, asking for my order with people in front of me before I even reached the cashier. This day I opted for New Orleans Iced Coffee with Almond Milk. Cool satisfaction, just sliding down my throat. Strong, bold and sweet, with enough cream to mellow out the strong beans but not so much to mute it's natural essence. 

Tough choices in this world.  Ritual Coffee and Blue Bottle all within a few steps of each other. Flip coin to pick and live with it. San Francisco is that kind of place. But if you're looking for iced coffee, I think Blue Bottle has the slight edge.
author: Howie C.

description:
Really loooove their New Orleans ice coffee. I don't know many places that serve New Orleans iced coffee, but I'm glad that Blue Bottle does! 

I usually love lattes, but found that their lattes weren't as bold as I usually like, but more on the creamier, milky side, which isn't bad - just not my preference. I think I will definitely opt for the cappuccino next time!
author: Christina C.

description:
Touring San Fran and decided to come here due to the high reviews. We took an uber into the area just to try this coffee only to be disappointed with their Rude Attitude!

If it wasn't for the uber ride to just try this place out I would've walked away. Coffee was good but rude baristas with poor service that seemed annoyed when we asked what their recommendations were for style of coffee. Wouldn't come back due to their poor attitude!
author: Melani V.

description: Great Coffee...nuff said.  Every location I've visited is busy.  Clearly popular.  Coffee is on the higher end price...but if you have a good product...why not?!
author: Lorena B.

description:
Well, I am slightly a coffee snob. I am not a barista (i wish) but I can appreciate a delicious, good quality, well crafted cup of coffee. Theirs is very good, but i don't know if it was life changing as some say. You still have to come and pop that bubble before you move on of course :)

$4.50 for a small Latte. Most drinks around that price. There's only one size, no room for mistakes. The shop is in a cute alley, you won't see it by driving by on Gough St... Parking nearby is hard, $2/hr which meant my coffee was technically $6.50 haha. Walk down the street to Patricias Green little park. It's so hipster you'll hate yourself for liking it.
author: Graciela C.

description:
Tucked away in an alley in Hayes Valley, Blue Bottle Coffee is really a great find. I was exploring the neighborhood and going "cafe hopping" with a few friends when I noticed this place on yelp!

I ordered a latte and my friend got a New Orleans iced coffee. The latte was smooth and flavorful, and the latte art was beautiful, but I wish that it was a little bit stronger. My friend really liked the New Orleans iced coffee, but I found it a little sweet for my taste. Definitely looking forward to returning and trying the almond milk latte that the barista recommended.

Good coffee and great ambience. Will definitely stop by anytime I'm in the neighborhood!
author: Jessica Z.

description:
I freaking love blue bottle coffee. It's so rich and strong enough to get me through a day's worth of work. Too bad I won't be in Hayes Valley as often anymore but I will definitely make the extra mile happen if I want some good stuff!

This location is seriously a hole-in-the-wall where it's in a narrow street looking like an alleyway. It's rare people linger around because it's more of a grab-n-go place with rocks and benches to hang out at. I've tried their latte, mocha, and New Orleans iced coffee. Every drink I've had here has never disappointed! Always fast and friendly staff people here. Also tried their olive oil shortbread; nothing to die for, but worth trying if you're into something different. All their other pastries look so yummy.

Coffee is a little pricey for a small cup, but quality over quantity! Great little treat once in a while to have :)
author: Kathleen S.

description:
Curiosity led me to try out Blue Bottle Coffee in Japan as people rave about its coffee quality in San Francisco. I'm no coffee connoisseur but the latte that I ordered was on the spot. It was smooth and not too bitter. I had to wait 10 minutes to order (even though it was on a weekday!) and had to keep an eye out for open tables.
They displayed how they process and filter their coffee, making it an memorable experience!
author: Linda K.

description:
So many reviews; I was surprised to find that this location is nothing more than a simple walk up window. (In an awesomely-graffiti'd alley, mind you). But it works!

I slurped up all of my NEW ORLEANS ICED COFFEE while waiting for them to finish making a cafe latte that was also part of my order. That is how good it is. I used almond milk in mine and the result was so creamy, just sugary enough and so very drinkable. 

The CAFE LATTE was straightforward and the latte art was gorgeous. My hand shook carrying it over to the car for the others to see before capping it, which was quite the challenge but this beauty needed to be appreciated. I even took a one-handed picture along the way. 

I was almost inclined to grab a bag of their homemade granola or a tiny baked good, but after a day of gluttony, I reasoned that experiencing the prized iced coffee was enough.
author: Meghan H.

description:
BEVERAGE: incredible. All the espresso goodness in my cappuccino with minimal bitterness. 

AMBIANCE: an alcove in the wall. That said, a very hip alcove :). 

SERVICE: very chill ( especially considering their unparalleled caffeine access) and friendly. 

CAVEAT: I really wish my $5 cappuccino (post-tip/tax) wasn't a dollar per star. One of the best I've had in SF and a worthwhile (occasional) splurge!
author: Helen W.

description: Nothing complicated here...just great coffee. Period! The locals must like it because it was 10 deep when I got here...but they hustle and get you on your way. There's not really a place to sit so get comfy on the rock benches out front. Recommended!
author: James M.

description:
Ahhhh ~ the original Blue Bottle location in SF. What can I say? It's small (actually, tiny!) place with a simple roll up garage to open up the store front. They're located on Linden Street (Hayes Valley) - but more like Linden 'alley' so to speak. 

This isn't a store, so seating is curbside or standing. 

Everything here is delicious! I tried the new orleans iced coffee for a change - it did not disappoint.
author: Beverly E.

description: I LOVE Blue Bottle. Favorite coffee place for sure and I was so happy that they opened one in Hayes Valley. Gives me a great excuse to walk the 20 minutes down there to grab coffee on a nice weekend morning. My absolute favorite is the New Orleans Iced coffee. I know you can get those in a carton pretty much at any boujee grocery store but trust me getting it from the tap at the actual store is way better! I sometimes will get their bagged coffee to make at home and it always smells so good. Seriously someone should make a candle scent from it and I will buy them out! Blue Bottle pretty much ruined Starbuck for me so I have no choice but to always return.
author: Alex S.

description: There is something about the coffee that makes it so satisfying. Maybe the smell? Not sure but this is my number one coffee by far. I always buy either Hayes Valley or Three Africans. As soon as I run out of my coffee bags, I need to buy more. It's a must try if you haven't been here.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Open air  shop in an alleywith street parking.  The alley runs into a main Street just a few shops down.  A gypsy was dancing on the edge of the street.  There is bench seating and a skinny standing table closer to the bar.

They only serve a blended espresso at this location, one that takes the alley as its namesake.  Served in a demitasse w logo on an oval saucer, no spoon with sparkling water.  Almost like drinking a whiskey or German beer.  Breads, wet hay, and some kind of peel, not orange peel though.  The cloudy weather may be  influencing my take on the espresso.  When looking for a bus bin, a friendly guy at the bar offered to take my finished cup and asked how it was.
author: Steven S.

description:
Jury duty brought me to this Blue bottle location. Was in need of a coffee during my lunch break.

August 2013
*Macchiato ($3) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/blue-bottle-coffee-san-francisco-8#Mp8N3_4KvqBy_Rtev5mBlg

I love my espresso strong. Blue bottle normally does the trick! And I love the cute designs they do in the foam.

Thank you Blue Bottle for keeping me awake during jury duty!
author: Elena N.

description:
This place is a gem and may be quite easy to miss!

I always get the New Orleans Iced Coffee w/ soy and it tastes perfect every time, no Starbucks bullshit. They don't load your drink with half a cup of ice and sugar like every other place and...I don't know, it just tastes like real coffee? 

Be prepared to wait in some type of line but don't worry, the Baristas here work quick and are super friendly! Now if only they had larger sized iced coffee
author: Kaye S.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by this place. 

Wait hold up lets rewind, I didn't get to tell my story yet.  

My friend wanted to get his car detailed at a shop close by and asked me to drive him back so I reluctantly agreed. We drove there and the navigation took me past linden street and I noticed the shop. I pulled round the street and parked and walked there. 

There were a handful of people but the line moved quickly and the employees were plenty nice. They asked what I wanted and originally I wanted a cappuccino, you apparently can't take that to go so I settled for 2 caffe mochas, one for me and one for my friend. 

Paid and hung around for a bit and we got our coffee. It smelled so wonderful, and they put whatever coffee art they were able to make on top of it. 

Strong delicious coffee with semisweet tcho chocolate in the caffe mocha, mmmmm delicious.
author: Harry P.

description:
Very simple shop with a simple menu but the quality is amazing!
I had a mocha latte and really loved it.
Very complex in taste and they used dark chocolate which was a nice rich and slightly sweet additional, very tasty.
Prices are fair, though I wish they had larger sizes, I could down this in one sip it's so good!
Service was nice, plan on taking it to go as there is not really any seating.
Excellent local coffee chain, worth checking out!
author: Nijole T.

description: New Orleans really smooth and nice creamy flavor with the milk. The after Taste is really pleasant. A low coffee flavor that lingers for the right amount of time. Overall great coffee spot and i'll be coming back when i'm in the area.
author: Bill Q.

description: I heard back from management and I have to say my next visit(s) to Blue Bottle in Hayes Valley were very good indeed.  As usual, the coffee is great!   They nailed the customer service thing.  Thanks so much !
author: Linda M.

description: The signature coffee shop in San Francisco. A must experience. Delicious coffee, great food items. Lemon poppy seed loaf is definitely recommended.
author: Can I.

description:
One of the most popular names for coffee in the city, and for good reason. Every location I've been to provides the same great service, barista expertise and consistent production of quality coffee. 

Where Blue Bottle slightly edges out its competition is in their iced coffee. Their New Orleans, while slightly too sweet for my own tastes, stands out against the competition for being decadently creamy with a strong coffee presence. 

Their drip coffees and lattes, additionally, are no slouch either. The Three Africans is another favorite of mine when I opt for the black coffee option. Strong and earthy

This location in particular boasts one of the nicest locations in the city. Located out of what looks to be a garage in an alleyway, it's only blocks away from linden park (that strip of grass in the middle of Hayes Valley) which provides for some great people-watching, restaurant hopping and boutique shopping.
author: Jay P.

description:
Not only do I love Blue Bottle, I love this little shop too. Such a cute location that's provides a great place to people (and dog) watch, a little park you can walk around, and close to neighborhood gems you can window shop while taking a stroll.

It's unlikely you won't find this place since there's always a line, finding the end of the line will probably be more challenging! Just in case there isn't a line, it's in an alley in a garage that's the size of a shoebox. 

Their pound cake is pretty good paired with a latte. They sell beans to go. I made French press for a week with them. 

Parking here is pretty sparse, and most streets have street cleaning. Park at your own risk!
author: Shereen A.

description:
This spot is really cool. Looks like it's coming right out of a garage. 

There's really nothing that can disappoint you when you come into any Blue Bottle Coffee, and this one is no different.

I'd recommend the New Orleans Iced Coffee with soy milk! So good!
author: Jonathan B K.

description: Au Lait is the best coffee ever I've tasted! I'll visit and get it again when I go back to San Francisco. New Orleans Style paper-packed coffee was also great to enjoy in the airport!
author: Jessica Jieun L.

description: Just excellent. I especially love a B.B. run on rainy days. Original location too- a piece of history.
author: SR S.

description: As a tourist, I would definitely recommend this place to anyone obsessed with coffee, but if you're more of a casual coffee drinker and lean more towards the pumpkin spice latte end of the spectrum, this place may not be your jam. Drinks are a little pricier if you're a Canadian like me and have to deal with that heart wrenching exchange rate, but definitely give this place a try if you love coffee. I got their single origin cold brew which was pretty standard but their New Orleans iced coffee is quite popular and unique!
author: Jenny X.

description: Quick service, and the best Latte I've had! It wasn't bitter at all, and was very light.
author: Viraj K.

description: Boo.  Do yourself a favor and go to Sightglass, Contraband, Sextant or anywhere else.  All these people care about is hype for their IPO and being the next SBUX.  Pretty low quality for people who claim that they are "obsessed with quality ingredients".
author: Charles C.

description:
Stumbled across this blue bottle location on my way out of Hayes valley. It is tucked away in the side alley of a building off of Gough street. 

Blue bottle, as always, provides quality coffee. It's not my favorite, but it will certainly suffice when it is the closest option around.
author: Mark O.

description:
Good lord this is good coffee! I asked what the difference was between Cafe au Lait and Latte since both were on the menu. I always thought they were the French and Italian versions of the same thing. They told me that a Cafe au Lait is made with drip coffee and some milk whereas a Latte is made with espresso and a lot of milk. So not so much coffee. 

Seeing as I was at Blue Bottle, it seemed a horrific waste to buy milk but it was morning so I opted for the $4 Cafe au Lait. It looked like a latte with a foamy top but it was delightful deliciousness. Like the perfect amount of coffee and milk married together in creamy harmony. 

I sat in the tiny park across the way and watched an even tinier mouse gather food and take it to it's tiny underground nest. By the time my friend joined me, a huge line had formed. 9 AM seems to be the tipping point on a Saturday morning. We lined up to get her a coffee and I ended up getting ANOTHER one! It was so good. We shared a delicious ginger molasses cookie made with real fresh ginger and not too much sugar and then strolled over to the square to look at the sculpture. Pretty much a perfect morning.
author: Angelique L.

description:
Our Nespresso machine is now gathering dust as it has lost the battle to Blue Bottle.  It's a regular stop before work or after my weekend run -- their cafe mocha is just wonderful, and the little ones love their hot chocolate.

Don't stop with the coffee -- try their shortbreads too. The Olive Oil shortbread is simple and sweet, but the real winner is the savory Parmesan shortbread with fennel flakes.

Location is a bit hidden -- it's beside a lingerie shop, on the same alley as Smitten.
author: Dawne L.

description:
The coffee was actually pleasantly good here. Went here a couple months ago and forgot to leave a review. I remember the flavor distinctly though.

The seating outside was also a welcome experience.

Also saw Ashton Kutcher and Mila Kunis here, so they got that going for them lol.
author: David N.

description:
Located in an alleyway. No line on a late Friday morning!
The New Orleans Iced Coffee was EXCELLENT!
Get your cup and walk around the area; there's a park and lots of stores.
author: Lan L.

description:
Another one of my favorite stops in Hayes Valley, where I first discovered the greatness of this coffee!

It might be hard to find at first though, since it is located in an alleyway and is very small, but you'll find it if you go past Smitten and Cityride Bike Rentals and keep walking down the alley. There are usually a couple people hanging around by it, and for good reason! 

While their menu is small, their service is always friendly and very fast, having my order ready before I even finish paying!

You can't go wrong with their New Orleans Iced Coffee or their Caffe Mocha, rich in TCHO chocolate! 

Everyone should make the effort to find this tiny kiosk and have an amazing cup of coffee while exploring Hayes Valley! :)
author: Kyrie S.

description:
Pricey, but quiet possibly the BEST almond latte ever! The price you pay for peace of mind and happiness. #CofFEE 

Treat Yoself!
author: Ellen W.

description:
As a lover of coffee I was a little underwhelmed with the straight test espresso. My wife loved her latte and others seemed pretty brainwashed into thinking they were really enjoying the coffee. 
The food selections were nice and I like the location in the alley.
author: David B.

description:
"Now why you wanna go and do that, love, huh?" Seriously. Blue Bottle, please come to the city of Atlanta. Besides being real cool (almost borderline overkill) in your alleyway of graffiti art, hipsters, etc. The little pop-up shop looking place was cute to just walk right up to.

BUT YO NEW ORLEANS ICED COFFEE IS THE ICED COFFEE OF MY DREAMS. "Our New Orleans is a sweet and thick iced coffee, cold-brewed with roasted chicory, then cut with whole milk and organic cane sugar." Yes please. It was delicately smooth and the perfect amount. I bought your coffee beans after one sip of deliciousness. The scent of them drives me wild every time the bag is open. Is that weird to say?
author: Connie A.

description: Service was warm, friendly, and helpful. Cold brew was just as good.
author: Cici T.

description: Nice coffee kiosk in a wall. This place is located on a less busy street in Hayes valley, close to smitten and Ritual. There is always a long line at Ritual and Blue Bottle, but I personally like blue bottle a little more. This spot doesn't have any chairs and tables like the other branches. There are some stones on the street where people sit and relax with their coffee. We had the cappuccino and ice coffee, both very tasty.
author: Gary C.

description: My partner and I are visiting from Sydney, Australia and didnt quite enjoy the brunch we had the other day. We found it to be a little bland and overpriced for what it was. However we were happy to know that the owner of the cafe had acknowledged our critique and has notified us that he will look into it :)
author: Rachel D.

description:
I'm so glad there's a Blue Bottle near my workplace! I always come here on my break whenever I need a pick-me-up. I've tried their latte, macchiato, cappuccino, drip coffee, and New Orleans iced coffee. You can't really go wrong with any of their drinks there. I love how they have soy and almond milk for us lactose intolerant folks too!

The reason why I can't give it 5 stars is because it's $4 for a small cup of coffee... And an extra $1 if you want to add almond milk. It's an expensive cup of coffee for what you get, but it's really good! I'll be coming back for more!
author: Vivian L.

description: Blue bottle is a cute little cafe with a very modern touch. I walked there from the Hilton hotel to get coffee during a break from our conference. I saw several people walking out with ice coffee so my first thought was to go with the locals choice. I ordered the ice coffee and I expected so much but it really was just like any regular cup of coffee to me. I also tried the espresso over ice cream. Now that was great! It was such a nice little treat, it was rich and creamy! The atmosphere is nice, kinda hipster but  def family friendly
author: My-Oanh N.

description: The place is absolutely adorable and the service was excellent. Ordered the affogato which was perfect. The espresso was super strong, which was exactly what we needed. The iced coffees were decent but nothing amazing.
author: Jessica P.

description:
First time here and the place did not disappoint! 

My friend spotted me for a New Orleans and Affogato, which were both great but towards the bottom of the drinks are where all the shot and bitterness lies, so be wary of that. The barista put whole milk in my New Orleans, which I was able to pick up the creamy sweet texture in my drink, while the Affogato  was served with extremely sweet ice cream and was not well balanced enough with the espresso shot.

Parking, obviously, is definitely a b****, as well as the parking meter. One quarter basically gives you, like, 3 extra minutes. Rip off! 

Overall, I had a great time here - didn't have a long wait, outdoor seating was the best, friendly and knowledgeable service, and great vibe.
author: Nathalie Y.

description:
Yassss! Amazing coffee, excellent espresso. 
The nicest people - totally happy to accommodate my Melbourne-esque coffee requests.
Some of the best coffee in San Fran for Aussies!
author: Victoria C.

description: The most unassuming coffee shop that I've ever been to. You will most definitely miss it if you dont' look for it. Got a standard latte and I have to say, its probably the best coffee I've had in San Francisco. Would've rated it 5 stars if not for the lack of a proper stirring station. A bigger seating area would also be definitely welcome.
author: Ganesh K.

description:
Friendly service and good coffee in a great setting. 
There aren't many places in the States that serve coffee that's considered acceptable to an Aussie like me - especially someone who takes their coffee straight (doppio espresso) - but Blue Bottle is an exception. They start with a good, palatable bean blend, and extract it expertly (and with a smile). Bravo!
author: Ash D.

description: I don't think they're the friendliest here but I do love their coffee.  I also enjoy how it is right next to the murals and the open area where people can sit in the gazebo or wander around Hayes Valley...Prime Location!
author: Monica J.

description: Definitely great espresso and far better than Ritual! Again no whipped cream on my mocha. Seems everyone's into fancy designs in the foam. But a mocha isn't about foam. But where are the blue bottles ??  :)
author: Jeanne B.

description: The cutest Blue Bottle Coffee location I've been to so far. A bit hidden in a little nook. Especially when it's not crowded and nice enough to sit outside under the trees.
author: Yad L.

description:
Just so you know, the location is in an alleyway and is a bit out of the way, so don't knock them for that because you've now been forewarned. 

While scoping out a place to have breakfast with Alyssa and Ericka, two other Yelp Community Ambassadors, I routed out Dottie's, only to learn that it was about an hour wait... um, no thanks. It was my last morning in SF and I was glad that they agreed not to withstand the wait. Erika had already went to Blue Bottle and she guided us to this gem. Luckily, it was very close to Dottie's. 

There was a bit of a line, but it only took about five minutes to give our orders. I'm not a coffee drinker, so I decided that I would experience this place on a food level. I was torn on whether to order a grilled cheese sandwich or the quinoa salad. So... I did what other foodies would do, and I ordered both. After all, I had a flight to catch and I could always carry it with me,  and that's what I did.

Before my order was ready, we stood and watched them make the picturesque espressos, and coffees. It was after they got their coffees, I still hadn't been given my bottle of water, that I asked about it. The barista graciously apologized and asked if I ordered still or sparkling water. Later as I was looking at my Square receipt, I noticed that I wasn't charged for a bottled water. The cashier must've thought that I wanted a complimentary glass of water and the barista was so kind, that he didn't even question me or ask to see my receipt. That was awesome and worth five stars alone. I'll be mailing a thank you note and and $3. 

 The grilled cheese sandwich was perfectly grilled. It came with mushrooms and onions, which was not something that I would've requested, but I'm glad that was the way that it was served. I'll be adding mushrooms to my grilled cheese in the future. 

The quinoa salad was served in a mason jar... unlike anything that I've ever had before. It was perfect for a mid-flight snack. I'm glad that the not so nice SF TSA agents didn't confiscate it. 

All in all, I recommend this place for food and coffee. Even though I didn't experience the coffee, Ericka who is also a barista too, recommended it... after she tried it on her first visit, so the coffee has to be great.
author: Heather P.

description: I love this location. It's in the cutest garage type spot and open air to the street. The coffee is of course fantastic and pastries as well. I suggest getting your coffee then taking a stroll up to the park to sit and people watch.
author: Dylon W.

description:
We stopped by while on a walk. 

I had a perfect cappuccino and then a perfect New Orleans Iced Coffee. It was slightly sweet with a perfect taste of chicory.
author: Felix C.

description:
My favourite cup of coffee, anywhere I've been in the world...and I've been to a lot of places. Coffee can have a pretty bad affect on me sometimes (shakes, anxiety, basically just too edgy!) but I just love the taste of it!! So I asked them to make me something a little less strong. They do 2 shots of coffee in my latte but made me half decaf half regular and that was just right. 

Love everything about this place, looks amazing, smells amazing and there's some really cool syphon coffee going on. There's always a line for Blue Bottle but it is SO worth it!! I don't live in San Francisco (from the UK) but if I go back Blue Bottle will be the first place I stop. Have also visited the one in the market hall right on the water which is smaller.
author: Victoria B.

description:
This Blue Bottle location is so cute and tiny. Way tinier than their other locations--it almost looks like a little pop up shop in a garage. Good thing it still brews their super yummy coffee! I got a latte and a snickerdoodle. The latte was spot on and absolutely delicious and the snickerdoodle was also pretty good--a little too sweet and dough-y for my liking, but went well with the coffee for sure. The latte is definitely on the milkier side, so if you're not a fan of milky lattes, probably not the best place to go.

Despite having a pretty long line, they're very efficient with getting the orders in. Friendly service too.

tldr; tiny blue bottle spot serving you their same delicious cofee
author: Jasmine X.

description: Blue Bottle never disappoints. Delicious.
author: Rachael S.

description:
I want to start this off by saying that my boyfriend and I are coffee people. We drink it black. We like trying new blends. We spend way too much money on it. I'm not going to go so far as to say we're coffee snobs (because that's right up there with the word foodie in my book) but we care. 

In other words, we can hold our own in the world of San Francisco Coffee Culture while being acutely aware of how absurd it is. 

Our experience yesterday though? It was like a bad Portlandia sketch. 

We rolled up to the Hayes Valley kiosk around 2pm because we had to run some errands in the neighborhood. My boyfriend ordered a coffee with a shot of espresso in it, which he has ordered at every coffee shop ever (including Blue Bottle) without issue. He's a sports writer and on nights that he has to work he needs the extra jolt of energy for the late games. 

Aloof barista guy - "You mean a red eye?"

Boyfriend - "Yeah. Sure." (When it's not listed on the menu as a red eye, he naturally does not call it out by name.)

Aloof barista guy - "Well we don't usually do that here because the coffee and espresso come from two different places." (Oh really? Do they? Fascinating.)  

Boyfriend - "Okay. I mean, if it's easier for you to give them to me separately that's fine. I can combine them myself." 

A few minutes pass while he pours the coffee and espresso shot. My boyfriend and I are struggling not to laugh in his face about how rude and ridiculous he's being. He rings the coffee and espresso shot up for $7.50ish.  

Boyfriend - "Why didn't you just charge me the price for a coffee and an extra shot? Shouldn't it be $4.50 or so?"

Aloof barista guy - "Because they're separate. I guess if I poured the espresso into the coffee I could charge you that."

Boyfriend - "Please do." (Meanwhile I'm doing the self-face smack heard round the world.) 

Okay dude. We get it it. You're so good at coffee. I'm sure your mother is proud. We won't be coming back for any of your sass though. There are plenty of deliciously pretentious places to go in San Francisco and we prefer Andytown anyway.
author: Caitlin N.

description:
Apparently I'm not a coffee person so I can barely distinguish what's so different about blue bottle.. Also I don't know why people so hype about blue bottle, blue bottle, blue bottle,...
To me.. it was just a coffee.... When I tried, maybe the first sip was a little more soft(?) and warm(?) feeling around my tongue? but then after a few second, it's just the same as starbucks.. even to me a little more bitter at the end..?
author: JS P.

description:
This is no-frills amazing coffee that gives Intelligentsia a run for it's money. Holy crap, I was lucky enough to stay at a hotel one block away and even though there was free coffee in my hotel, I bought 2 cappuccinos per day here. Happily.

I day dreamed about it. The locals are super cute coming downstairs with their coffee mugs from home! I would too if this was downstairs from my house. I girl can dream! 

Yummy!
author: Rachael M.

description:
Awesome atmosphere. Very hipster, much like. Anyway, I went with friends because I'm not a coffee person---
But nevertheless, great customer service and yummy snacks made my visit enjoyable. The Almond Lavender Pound Cake was scrumptious and the lemonade was the perfect blend of tart and sweet! 
Lovely place to open and good book and read! 
Thank you~~~~
author: Lisa Y.

description:
I hate to rain on the Blue Bottle Coffee parade, but I think their coffee is fine, but not overwhelmingly awesome like everyone else seems to make it. I got their $5 mocha and it was fine, but not super great. The chocolate flavor didn't jive with me much. It might have to do with the fact that I'm not a fan of TCHO chocolate too much, to be honest.

Also the location of this shop is odd. It's on Linden so it's kind of in an alleyway, next to a small park. This area is not immune to crazy people - we saw this woman screaming "I DON'T WANT TO HAVE YOUR APE BABY" and then just sitting next to the coffee shop with her stuff.
author: Danielle C.

description: One of the best mochas I've had in the city. Not the best selection of pastries though but it's a small place.
author: Michelle D.

description: Woke up fell out of  bed,dragged a comb across my head, found my way downstairs to have a cup and looking up I noticed that...Ritual coffee was closed.  No problem, got on yelp and found Blue  Bottle Coffee right around the corner on Linden.  It was just before they opened and there's no signage so I walked right passed it.  But precisely at 6:30 the two gray garage doors slowly opened and out popped BBC.  I ordered a large latte and a small coffee.  The stoic barista put a coffee cup on a scale, a drip system on top of the cup and intermittently poured just the correct amount of water over the coffee to make a perfect brew. While he was brewing the coffee he made my latte behind espresso machine using conventional means. When done he placed two 12 ounce cups for me on the counter. At first I thought hey where is my large latte?, then I realize this is one of those places where they only make one size coffee(A little snooty!). But hey I'm a little snooty about my coffee too.(Suck it quickbucks!) Both drinks were really good!  The cashier showed up,(very friendly)I payed for the coffees and was on my way. Now I have too many choices!
author: H H.

description:
What makes a visit to blue bottle so unique is not just their excellent and nuanced local roasts, it's mainly the chill location. 

The authentic upstart vibe that permeates the garage, the bamboo and the outdoor space of their alleyway. 

A visit to blue-bottle is clearly a vote for SF's independent coffee culture/ vs. the Disneyfication of coffee in the City.
author: Jason R.

description:
Although there's no indoor cafe and not much outside seating - it's the best coffee I've ever had (sorry Portland, it's true). That's why there's a continuous line (which goes fairly fast) at their open-air walk up shop. It's in a tiny alley way, next to a very noticeable corset shop. After your pick up your delicious Mocha (my fave), you can walk around the corner to a gluten free French macaroon shop or go shopping at all the fun boutiques in the area. 

This is the only coffee I've drank that didn't have any acidic taste or acidic effects on my stomach. I failed to ask if the beans are fair trade or locally roasted. Staff was helpful and friendly. 

The next-to-none parking shouldn't factor into a review for this shop, because parking in the whole city is awful. This little shop can't be dinged for what every other business has a challenge with, and cannot change. I walked 10 blocks to get here on a nice day. Ride your bike or have uber pick you up - it's worth the trouble.
author: Mellissa B.

description:
If you're in the area going for a walk/jog, then you should give this place a try. It has so much character. It's located in the back alley of some hotel or building. There's no parking and they serve coffee in a garage-like place with no tables or chairs. It's more of a grab and go place. 

Their menu isn't very extensive. I liked their capacinno. It was light and good. Not a fan of the mocha. Not a fan of mochas in general. Didn't get a chance to try anything else since I was here on a short visit. 

There's usually a line and it goes by fairly fast. They also sell pastries and packaged coffee bags.
author: Yelper Y.

description:
Whoa, settle down everyone. 

Prior to visiting this Blue Bottle Coffee, I decided to check out the Yelp reviews. Talk about critical acclaim! Needless to say, my expectations were pretty high.

Unfortunately, high expectations often lead to disappointment. Don't get me wrong, I really enjoyed my cafe mocha. However, there were a few things that disappointed me:

1. Cash ONLY. Fortunately, there's an ATM across the street.

2. It's a coffee stand in a GARAGE. No seating. Your hipster setup does not impress me.

3. The SERVICE. The cashier was snobbish. She made us feel quite stupid for not knowing that it was cash only. She also gave us a nasty glare when Dawn M. asked if she could grind the coffee beans that we were about to purchase. 

In all fairness, the cafe mocha was excellent. It was creamy and had a rich chocolate flavor. 

The olive oil shortbread was tasty. Olive oil on a sweet pastry? Never thought it would taste so good.

Probably wouldn't go out of my way to come back.
author: Dan D.

description:
On the hunt for coffee...with Miette in hand, we happened on this alley location.  Only outdoor seating, that worked on this gorgeous summer day in the city.

Got a .Caffè Macchiato.....strong, yummy, tiny cup of espresso and milk jolt.  Worked great for me!!

We had our snacks and headed back to BART, getting out of the city just as 2 bus accidents happened.....dodged a bullet we did!!
author: Katherine F.

description:
To be honest, the coffee is delicious and I'm a total fan of the latte art but my god it is so overtly pretentious. I understand how important coffee culture can be to some people but the atmosphere comes off as robotic. The line is odd as it wraps into the middle of the street. There are these cute, tall tabletops where you can enjoy your coffee but you'll just be in the way of everyone trying to get their beverage.

Side note, I loathe people who are like "Oh my god, I just like can't function without my coffee in the morning, like don't even talk to me before my morning java." Great, we get it. You like coffee.
author: Tommy C.

description: Every time I go to SF, I HAVE to swing by Blue Bottle. They have some of the the best drinks when it comes to their quality of coffee beans. Word on the street is that they have opened one in Los Angeles! This could be dangerous. I'm not sure where it is located (I haven't had the chance to look it up yet) but I believe it is somewhere near Melrose. Highly recommended!
author: Andrea V.

description: Just awesome coffee.  Beautiful interior.  Nice, quick service.  Delicious drinks and small bites (waffles, muffins, etc.) to go with.  Pricey as can be, but you get what you pay for, right?  This location was easy to get into, order, and get a seat at which was really nice.  I think the one in the Ferry Building gets busier.  I didn't have the chance to try the Blue Bottle cold brew, but I will definitely try it next time.  I've heard it's the best out there.
author: Jason G.

description: Regular coffee  was pretty good.  I would recommend  this over starbucks.  Would recommend  the new Orleans drink too... most locals seem to order this.
author: Casey H.

description:
Ah the illustrious Blue Bottle Coffee... I finally found you in a random alley in Hayes Valley and sampled your mocha with TCHO chocolate. And I was blown away! {then again it was quite windy that day ;)}

Seriously though I've heard a lot about Blue Bottle Coffee and I decided it was time I tried it for myself. After finding some parking in the area (no easy feat), I followed the map on Yelp and searched for Blue Bottle. At first I thought it was the coffee cart thing near the park but that wasn't it. The map led me down this alley and I thought to myself, "Am I going the right way?". Yep keep walking! I found myself standing in front of what appeared to be a garage, but it was a coffee shop! Super hipster, super cool. 

I ordered the mocha (which was one of the most expensive things on the menu but gotta have my chocolate), specifically because I was interested in trying some coffee with the famed TCHO chocolate. After handing over a five I was presented with a beautiful cup of coffee with a pretty flower design on top. Whipped out the phone, took a pic, then took a sip. WOW. I'm not sure if it was the amount of chocolate added, but this was some of the best coffee I have ever had. The combination of coffee, milk and chocolate was perfect, and I had to pace myself so I didn't gulp it down in a few minutes. SAVOR IT. 

I'm definitely interested in sampling their iced coffee next time around, especially since summer will be arriving soon. Thanks for a wonderful coffee experience Blue Bottle! You will see me again =)
author: Sam F.

description: I schlepped down from near the top of Gough St. every morning from my friend's place to buy coffee in an ALLEY. But it was so worth it as Blue Bottle's New Orleans Iced Coffee is heaven in a cup. Take my $4 (well plus tip)! Line always seems to be fairly long and the wait can be interminable, but I was jonesing for their coffee and nothing else would satisfy me. Until next time Blue Bottle...
author: Hugo C.

description:
Saturday, 11:00 AM.

Quickie:
++ Drink quality
- Friendly staff
+ Cleanliness
+ Turnaround

And then...?
This Blue Bottle Coffee operates a small kiosk in Hayes Valley. Dayuuum, they make some good stuff. BBC is in the top tier of SF coffee. 

**********
Got my drank on:

1. Iced New Orleans
   + Chicory aroma, slightly sweet
author: Chuck N.

description:
Blue bottle is hands down my favorite coffee in San Francisco. The new orleans iced coffee is my favorite. So good. 

I wish they would sell larger cups, I always end up buying two or three cups at a time cause I know I'll want more in a couple minutes!
author: Diane Y.

description: Is this the smallest of the Blue Bottle establishments? Having last been to the one in Williamsburg this one is literally a closet. But they still put on a great cold brew. I feel like Im getting something out of my neighbors garage. But then if my neighbor made coffee this good, I'd be there all the time
author: Kim N.

description: Reasonably priced coffee that is made with love.  The barrister literally takes his sweet time making the coffee despite the long line. But it's okay, because i friggin love my latte and coffee!!
author: Jackie M.

description: Tried Blue Bottle for the first time yesterday and it was nothing short of amazing. It got a little confusing to find their location but once we found it we thought it was such a prime location and it wasn't too busy. I tried the New Orleans Iced Coffee and it was perfect! It wasn't too sweet but just right and their coffee had a sweet taste and didn't taste burnt. Workers are super friendly and super quick. My first experience at Blue Bottle was great!
author: Dayna Y.

description:
A small hole in the wall with a lot of outside seating! Pretty comfy and even better when it's sunny outside! I always get their New Orleans iced coffee! It's my fav iced coffee in sf except for Vietnamese iced coffee. 

    The coffee is super strong and the milk/ sugar brings out the fragrance of the coffee even more. I just love it! Also the coffee quality has always been consistent and every cup Ive got has been delicious! 

  Also tried their pretzel, it's bready and buttery and the texture is really good! Try it!
author: Janet K.

description:
My latte was yum but not as yum as Philz coffee. The New Orleans style iced coffee is pre-packaged.. 

Doggie treats are available for your furry friends and a small selection of treats available for you too! I didn't taste either of these items :)
author: Ariel E.

description:
New Orleans Iced Ocean! YUM! 

Whenever I'm in the bay area, I always have to go to Blue Bottle Coffee to get this. This location is pretty much a stand in a very small one way street that could be an alley so this location is pretty hidden from regular foot traffic. What's awesome about that is that I barely had to wait in line. 

There is no seating area though except for some flat stones. This location is perfect to get coffee on the go.
author: Cindy B.

description:
I am speechless, and that's only because my mouth is too preoccupied with deciphering the smooth complexities of Blue Bottle's indescribably delicious brand of coffee to bother with the act of forming words.

Businesses like Blue Bottle are what San Francisco is all about. Nestled in a cozy, narrow alley, this simple coffee stand perfectly embodies the vibrant, authentic culture that defines the city; this is the intersection of artistic expression and entrepreneurial brilliance actualized.

Sitting on one of the custom-built benches while sipping on a Cafe Latte and a New Orleans Style Iced Coffee with my fiance remains one of the most memorable moments of my road trip back to the Bay Area. The entire experience--enjoying coffees together in the journey path of a soft breeze during the calm of a weekday afternoon--was the definition of the term "idyllic."

Blue Bottle, you have raised my coffee snob bar. For the love of caffeine, please open up a location in SoCal.
author: Candice K.

description: First time at this place, and I would def recommend! It is fairly priced and delicious. I also enjoyed the friendly staff--very knowledgeable about the types of beans and flavors the store front offers.
author: Lauren T.

description:
Can't go wrong with a cappuccino, latte, or New Orleans style iced coffee ($3.50 - $4.00) from Blue Bottle. Best iced coffee i've ever had -- made with cane sugar and chicory. And one of the best hot coffees i've ever had.  I understand this obsession with Blue Bottle now.

Compared to other local SF roasters, the flavor is a darker and bolder roast.  (compared to other SF roasters, the service is faster too!). 8oz bags of coffee run $9-10.  The small 'shopfront' (literally just a front) of this location is in an alley by a corset store.
author: Jennifer M.

description: This blue bottle location is pretty hidden on a little side street.  Not super distinct signage for the building/garage from a car's point of view.  Pretty unique building for a coffee shop!  The outdoor only seating is perfect for a beautiful day to bathe in the sun or to grab a coffee to go.  The baristas were chill, but it seemed like they weren't too excited to answer the questions we had, but that's okay!  Overall, it was an enjoyable experience.  Their macchiato with almond milk and Guatemala pour over were GREAT!  Blue bottle is the best!
author: Victoria P.

description:
Good coffee here for sure but I'll be getting my coffee down the street from now on. Went to get coffee here today and waited for about 10 minutes. The person behind me ordered the same coffee as I. So they called out my order and  when I went to walk up and get it, the guy says that it wasn't mine. They gave it to the person that ordered after me. 

If they acknowledged the fact that they gave my coffee away and basically missed my entire order, I would have been okay with it. Basic rules in customer service is to acknowledge your customers and apologize when it's necessary. I guess they are too good for that. 

I included the tip on their pos iPad when I paid and a tip was not deserved. Like I said, the coffee is good which is the only reason I didn't rate them any lower.
author: N C.

description:
Came here in an early cozy cold morning close to Patrica's Green in the Hayes Valley. Found this coffee stand in a garage near an alley way and there was already a line, but hey when there is a good line of people it gotta be dope right? To me indeed it was! I've ordered a Blue Bottle Mocha Latte, which was hot, sweet chocolatey, soothing, it was perfect that Frisco morning.

I wish this place is around the corner from me but here In La Habra, CA. Starbucks is my only fix. When you find this hidden stand and sip on some coffee, it will be...good find...good find...I would recommend this place for those drip coffee purist. I see why the locals come here, now curious tourist people will come.
author: Jon B.

description:
If you like strong coffees, you have to try Blue Bottle's coffee.  It's pricey but worth it.  Delicious coffee.    You can tell that the staff love coffee and know their stuff. I was also able choose the beans that went into my drink.

The atmosphere is fun and inviting, although it is a little small. That shouldn't stop you though; it's definitely worth the visit.
author: Judy C.

description:
Seriously rich coffee, seriously knowledgeable baristas, seriously enthusiastic clientele, and seriously deserved hype. Speaks volumes that such a little, super-casual kiosk with no seating to speak of (except an equally small, super-casual parklet outside) commands such a following.

Now that a Ritual kiosk has opened just a 1/2 block away, Hayes Valley must now be heaven for coffee fanatics, and this will be a must-stop destination for me whenever I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Vincent L.

description:
**Note: This review is for the Beverly Blvd. location (not the SF location, which I have not
 been to).


The Blue Bottle boxed New Orleans cold coffee is excellent. I found the store in Los Angeles recently, and was elated! I had previously found the coffee on the High Line in New York about two years ago, and had searched since then to locate it elsewhere. Now, as I understand, I can purchase this very item at Costco. I will add that three food items I bought at the Beverly Hills store further piqued my interest in this brand. The Overnight Oats ($6) contain: Almond milk, oats, sunflower seeds, maple syrup, lemon juice, pumpkin seeds, chia seeds, vanilla extract, kosher salt, and dried seasonal fruits. The polenta slice I had was sweet and substantial; the seeds and honey bar extraordinary.
author: Michelle B.

description: The original Blue Bottle Coffee (2nd to the farmers market stand which no longer exists). I always thought blue bottle originated in Williamsburg while living in Brooklyn as their location is huge with roasting machinery in the back. This is just a shack as people mentioned, the line is long but moves quickly, mostly people on the way to work or school. The coffee is excellent as expected.
author: Mike S.

description:
I have been drinking so much coffee lately, I'm pretty sure I have some mild form of caffeine poisoning, and I have no intentions of cutting back.  Although I'm obsessed with Coffee Bar, I decided to try Blue Bottle a few weekends ago because I was in the hood (and I didn't know Coffee Bar's Mission location was open on weekends).  

Love it. BBC is located in a small, unassuming garage front on Linden (in the alley).  I ordered the New Orleans iced coffee. I typically order my coffee in much stronger form, but since I wasn't sure how long it would take me to get back to BBC, I decided to try the star of the menu (via yelp reviews). I couldn't have been more pleased--the flavors were good, strong and clean--most importantly, nice and simple. It's good to see coffee (and the people who love it) moving away from milkshakes and sugary garbage (although this was never really an issue in SF proper).    

The baristas were so nice and quick. I was in and out within 5 minutes, despite a lengthy-looking line.  Don't quote me, but I believe they take payment via iPad (like most other places).  The other patrons were also nice--friendly dog folks.  

In short, I can see why people love BBC. What a smart little coffee shop.
author: Sunny S.

description:
As if you don't already know about the awesome coffee here. Some folks may my know that this location is the ultimate hole-in-a-wall spot. The coffee bar reminds me of approaching a small family run shop on the ground floor of someone's house, but they keep it professional. You'll find joggers with their dogs queued up handsomely alongside hipsters on fixies and the rare urban family somehow finding the play space to raise a child in the city.

I've typed this whole review while waiting in line so I guess it has that. Patience is a virtue and when it comes to Blue Bottle, I got all the time in the world to wait.
author: Paolo V.

description:
Located in the alley and the neighboring street walls are sprayed with graffiti, this blue bottle hole-in-the-wall is atypical.

I usually like to leisurely hop into a cafe and sip on some coffee while being on Wi-Fi either to do things for work or just relax.  This place does not offer all that seating area with access to Internet, but a good strong, clean coffee. 

A cup of coffee from this place, surely wakes me up.  However, it does not offer the convenience and ambiance that I usually tend to prefer to like for a coffee shop.
author: Tiffany D.

description: I went there on Sunday morning, and there was a lot of people waiting. I ordered a drip coffee and bought a bag of coffee beans. I like the taste of the drip coffee, which is balanced with proper bitter, sweet and smooth body. The coffee beans are good as well. It's the single origin beans from Kenya. The flavor of the beans is bright sour with light body, and you can taste mild sweet at the end. I do love their coffee, and I wish I can go there often,
author: John L.

description:
Ah coffee, one of my vices.

I've always heard many good things about Blue Bottle, especially their waffles which are apparently delicious. I wanted to judge it myself but unfortunately they didn't have any more waffles by the time we got there :(. We stopped by on a Saturday afternoon, right before the crowd hit. I ordered to New Orleans iced coffee and man oh man, it was fantastic! Definitely the boost I needed after a busy morning.

The location was pretty cool too. It's a bit small and hidden away, but I like it because the area is very quiet. They even have cool stone benches around the area for you to sit and chit chat with your friends while enjoying you delicious cup of coffee. 

No disappointments at all. I'm definitely going to try to find my way back here the next time I'm in the city!
author: Lisa T.

description: I like their latte which is creamy and not too strong. Their coffee is not considered expensive in Hayes Valley but I would say it is still overpriced for the quality.
author: Haein C.

description:
I know what you're thinking, "he's a hater."

But really, I'm a lover.  And one of the things I love most is coffee.  I love the aroma of the beans.  I love the sounds of beans being ground.  I love the sound of coffee brewing (though I usually use a French Press -- no sounds).  I love the aroma of coffee brewing.  I love the color of coffe.  But most of all,  I love the flavor of coffee.

Waiting in line for sour coffee is not something I love (sour coffee = under roasted beans...this doesn't mean it has to be charred).  Is it better than Starbucks?  Sure.  But is it better than, say, Intelligentsia?  No chance.  It's middle of the road at best.  

2.7839 stars for the coffe, -.7839 stars for the wait.
author: Corey N.

description: Not a recommended place for coffee addicts. This is a Western perspective place for coffee. Vietnamese coffee is still the best.
author: Tran M.

description:
Great coffee.  Friendly staff.  Quick service.

Can't go wrong with a Soy Latte.
author: Rose A.

description:
I was a nanny for a great kid at a school nearby, so I would stop by here pre-pick up.

The folks are great, the coffee bomb, you get your coffee as speedy as speedy gets

All coffee  is very balanced, and you will always get the caffeine jolt you need 

Fun little way to chit chat and socialize too in the quirky alley zone
author: Alanna F.

description: My favorite spot. Excellent service. The manager was right there to provide a new free replacement cappuccino when the almond milk they were trying out was not tasting well.
author: Diana R.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee in Hayes Valley is a very unique location -- coffee shop set up in a garage. I am someone who go out to grab a cup of coffee, latte, mocha, cappuccino or frappuccino. These are one of the beverages I get when I need my daily caffeine fix.

I came here today, purchased a bag of Blue Bottle Coffee branded Hayes Valley Espresso and Giant Steps Coffee Beans. Total for both bags are $16, I bought two 8 ounce bags of coffee beans of coffee beans so it was well worth the money. I'll definitely make a pit stop here the for a cup of Blue Bottle Coffee the next time I am in Hayes Valley. The service here is good and Blue Bottle Coffee is on my list of favorite coffee shop hot spots. I'm coming here when I feel like getting coffee at Blue Bottle. Downside, not a lot of seating.

Driving?
- Parking situations are similar to most areas here in San Francisco so good luck finding a spot to park your car in this area. Be prepared to have spare coins or an SFMTA Parking Meter Debit Card on you for the parking meters.

Public Transit*:
21 Hayes to Stanyan St (Golden Gate Park), get off on Hayes at Gough Streets
*Highly recommended approach

5/21/2014:
- New Orleans Iced Coffee is a very tasty beverage. Two versions of this beverage are available: 1. Hand Crafted and 2. Carton Packaging (for on the go)
- This location is definitely a garage based coffee shop (very unique) and also a neighborhood gem (treasure).
- Seating maybe limited, but good coffee, good service and friendly baristas.
- I noticed that they have adopted Square Payments now. Therefore, it looks like maybe credit/debit cards also acceptable forms of payments.
author: Bennett W.

description:
One of the better coffee places in SF.  It is waaaaaaay better than a Starbucks or Peet's coffee.  I would say it is comparable to Philz.  

It was a hot day, so I ordered an iced coffee.  I just went simple, but I was told there are different ways to order it that makes it a lot better.  It was already really good, so I'm looking forward to going back to try something new.
author: Justin Y.

description:
a friend kept mentioning blue bottle coffee during our sf trip
finally had to try it and it lives up to the hype
good coffee is similar to good men
simple, clean, strong = keeper
too oily, dark, burnt, complex = give 'em the boot
author: Clara L.

description:
Great little coffee shop! If I lived in San Fran I would here often! We were only there for two night, two days and we went there 3 times! The espresso shot was bitter sweet literally. 

They offered soy which was perfect for me and I lived how they are expanding into the bakeries in San Fran. I should've bought more at home coffees but I feel like I would be addicted and end up moving there...
author: Ivy W.

description:
Not as good as Philz but still a fan!

They serve TCHO mochas which was delicious! I'm impressed they're sourcing a local chocolate.  Love buying a drink that is purely local. 

The location is really cute.  It's down an alley with public seating.

Have a coffee and then go down the block to Smittens for ice cream! WIN WIN!
author: David W.

description:
I found this Blue Bottle on a whim--I thought I'd missed my window of opportunity to snag these beans when I left LA, but it turns out, SF has a few locations, too. 

This location looks like a bit of a pop up spot, near residential buildings on a quiet one-way street pretty close to the public library and walking distance to Union Square.

I haven't actually tasted the coffee, but bought my mom two half pounds as a souvenir. I noticed they roasted the beans that day, which I thought was totally nuts--but I guess this ain't no Starbucks. Hopefully, they'll withstand a couple weeks in their non-vaccuum sealed airtight bags.

The service was friendly, the price decent, and the overall branding elements clean and sophisticated. So far, I dig.
author: Allison R.

description:
My friend warned me that their hot drinks aren't usually hot.

I ordered the hot chocolate- taste was excellent, however, I ordered a HOT chocolate not lukewarm chocolate. 

Better luck next time...
author: Linda N.

description:
Stumbled across this walk-up Blue Bottle location while making my way to Alamo Square, and had to get my fix while in San Francisco.
