description: Love this stuff! If you love the coffee, you will love this coffee. Personal faves - Bella Donovan and Giant Steps. At this cafe, there is a bit of a wait but it's worth it. I had the toast with the poached egg and delicious cheesy sauce over it. If they had some Tapatio, it would have been heaven!!!
author: LG Q.

description: One of the most unique places I have ever visited. Situated in what looks like an alley, blue bottle is worth any amount of waiting and is a must try. Everything they do is from scratch and craft. Skip the coffee and go for a latte...no options, no soy or skim, you order a latte and they make it like it should be made, perfect! Comes ready to drink and is so smooth. Can't wait to go back!!
author: James Michael S.

description:
this place is absolutely amazing...
i was visiting sf to audition at the sf conservatory and passed this place every time i walked to the school.
i had the new orleans style coffee with soy...it was the best coffee of my life...
i dont typically drink coffee because im sensitive to caffeine and i get a little nauseous...but that didnt even stop me...the flavor was really unique and special.
on top of that i bought 2 bags of coffee to take back to orange county for my friends...

i know im addicted because i cant stop thinking about blue bottle! regular coffee just doesnt cut it anymore.
blue bottle...please come to LA!
author: Christine H.

description:
Ok, so I might as well admit it now - I'm not a coffee drinker.

But the boy is.  When he said he had never tried Blue Bottle I knew he had to, even if I don't drink it myself.  Of course, he fell in love.  So now every few weeks I buy him beans as he lives in the South Bay and has no access to the stuff on a regular basis.

I came here to buy him some bags on my way down for a visit.  Previously I had bought at the Ferry Building location. I stood in line, it wasn't too bad, then asked the barista to recommend some new beans for me to take down to him.  After telling him all his coffee quirks, we settled on what I was going to get.  Thanks for being so helpful!  He really liked the new types of coffee, however I suspect he probably will like any Blue Bottle :)
author: Jen K.

description:
I had New Orleans Iced Coffee

Nice long line so this place must be good. Very friendly service. I am just not a big coffee guy.
author: Justin I.

description:
Awesome individual drip coffee. Place has a simple and clean menu. Hidden between a small street with lines that can grow long.


Only negative is that the ordering to pickup system can be worked on. You pay and you wait along with others. Who gets what can get confusing.
author: Jack H.

description: I haven't eaten for over a day.  After the emotional trauma when my flight landed that my dog was missing on his Bday this past Sunday and then later finding out the devastating news that Charlie was hit by a car and died on his birthday... so yes I was incredibly sad and had no appetite.  But on our way to Pet Rest Cemetery in Colma, he insisted I ingest something.  And I finally agreed while driving down at Gough.  He waited behind 10 people in front of him to get what I wanted.  And I have to say it was worth the wait.  He wasn't too impressed w/ their regular coffee... but I have to say I absolutely loved my soy latte.  It definitely put the first smile on my face since my traumatic experience.
author: Myra M.

description:
So much hype. Blue Bottle has become a darling of San Francisco and it seems to be spreading.

Deserved? Yes.
Slightly annoying and entitled? Also yes.

The negative star is for the smug clientele I have to be surrounded by if I want to drink something delicious. Coming here makes me feel a little dirty, like shopping at American Apparel. I'd say it's worth it though.
author: Caitlin T.

description:
Tucked in a little alley way in Hayes Valley Blue Bottle is a treat. 

I've had the Mocha, which is BOMB.  They actually melt the chocolate right there.

I've also had the machiato, which had quite some kick to it.

Anther plus is that there aren't that many homeless people chilling around here...very rare for SF.

Recommendation:  Drink your coffee at the standing bar. Shoot the shit with the workers or whomever else will listen to you random ramblings and walk down to the park on Octavia and do some people watching.
author: Adam L.

description:
Hi, my name is Rena and I've been off coffee for four months

...before today.

We decided to check out Hayes Valley for some coffee, but our plans were semi foiled when all the closed store fronts reminded us that it was Easter Sunday (...we're not very religious). But, thanks to my coworker's constant raving about blue bottle coffee and yelp, we decided to find a blue bottle coffee cafe.

We searched out this little store front tucked away on a little street. Love the stand style of the cafe. Staff was friendly--I had originally asked for a "Soy Iced Coffee" and got a bit of a hesitant response from the person helping me. Then she suggested I get the Soy Iced New Orleans Coffee because adding soy to steamed coffee on ice makes it more bitter (i think that's what she said). Basically, I ordered a bad combo. Oops. I'm glad she spoke up because the New Orleans style (slow dripped) was pretty good. It reminded me of dark, dark chocolate. It was pretty sweet--which is the first I've ever tasted of a coffee.

I was also expecting unusual caffeine attack after such a long hiatus, but I didnt get any. Woot!

I still prefer my viet iced coffee over this, but I'm glad I got to try this type of coffee.

EDIT: Just found out they're organic. BEST organic coffee I've had--all the previous ones I've had before tasted like cardboard. This is amazing in comparison! For that, one more star!
author: Rena Y.

description:
I have to be very very careful here.  I'm one of those hyper people who really doesn't need coffee because people always ask me...without fail...if I'm on crack when I drink it. 

My one bout with heavy consumption ended my senior year of college after I consumed 2/3rds of a container of chocolate-covered expresso beans much to the displeasure of my stomach-lining and roommates. (It's only cute when animals bounce off the walls). There was needless to say an intervention and I've been clean since.

I've since lost the taste for coffee. When in Costa Rica and asked to try their famous coffee, I uttered a fairly unimpressed "meh" and left it at that.

So when asked to try a sip of my friend's iced coffee from Blue Bottle Coffee Co., I expected to be equally unimpressed.

That's not how it went down...

Now sometimes, Blue Bottle beckons to me in my sleep. The seductive logo dancing in my dreams.

Like I said I have to be very careful here...the coffee at Blue Bottle Coffee is deep, heady, and has a dark and delicious kick. Hello gateway drug to heavy caffeine addiction.

So if this place makes a me---someone who has lost the taste of coffee---revisit the possibility of addiction, you can imagine how you---the lover of coffee---will respond. Enjoy! But very very carefully =)
author: Cindy C.

description: Maybe I'm just used to better coffee but this did NOT do it for me. Average at best nothing special for a $4 cup of coffee!
author: Leya r.

description:
When I saw the line of people snaking down the Linden street, I dreaded Blue Bottle. *just breath* I waited in that beast of a line. It moved pretty fast. 

I am not a coffee snob by choice. In fact, I try to avoid all Starbucks if possible. My name is Shannon, and I am a coffee addict. I need the bean to wake up in the morning, to have basic functioning skills.

I got my latte (cash only at this location) and it was well worth the line. The low acid coffee with a smooth flavor, freshly roasted. I am a weak person. BUT its SOOO good! Now I am commuting to Hayes Valley from Bernal Heights to get a pound of beans to hold me over until next month.
author: Shannon Z.

description: i am always reluctant to go for the trendy coffee. the renowned pour over... the young crowd that goes without showering for days thinks its a new concept. well, i ordered a pour over by suggestion of the earthy barista. 12oz, 3.50 + 1.00 tip + tax = 4.82. it tastes like garbage.
author: jim b.

description: Amazing coffee and very knowledgable staff. Great place for cappuccino's, iced coffee, and quality pour over drip coffee.
author: Sam B.

description:
Is it possible to buy a perfect Sunday morning with just seven bucks? 

It is if you bring your pretty pennies to Blue Bottle and use 'em to buy a soy latte and a hot chocolate.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Hmm... I agree with Cara about the staff being kinda snooty, but I don't know if I'd say this is the best latte I've had. 

It just wasn't all that I expected.
author: Jess C.

description:
While I do like their New Orleans Iced Coffee and other coffee products, I recently had a very sad experience with some decaf coffee.
I ordered an iced decaf latte. First of all, it took forever to come out because the barista kept making everyone else's drinks. And then the taste was a sad disappointment. It tasted bitter and burnt, not at all the smooth, full flavour I have come to expect from Blue Bottle.
If you can't make a decent decaf coffee, maybe just don't offer any. What you are selling now as decaf is useless. Even Starbucks makes a better decaf!
author: Felix V.

description: Amazing coffee! Ordered an iced coffee & it was delicious! They had street seating available. Literally. Blocks of concrete & benches in a sort of alley. It worked for sure! Super relaxed vibe.
author: Molly M.

description: The coffee was good.  It was strong and had a good flavor.  I enjoyed it, but as more good coffee places come up, it is harder to stand out from the rest.
author: J R.

description: Great spot! Coffee was nice and smooth, love there Espresso. Had the snickerdoodle cookie on the side and wasnt very fond of it. But coffee and location are a plus!
author: Bianca L.

description:
I was told that this place is the best coffee in San Francisco. When people say that, I usually reserve judgment until I try it myself.

Blue Bottle is located on a quiet street and I wouldn't of noticed if it were for the group of people loitering on the sidewalk.

The menu is limited. However, I understand why. If it wasn't the line would be around the block. Anyways, I was debating to get the cafe latte, but I decided to get the Cafe Mocha. Oh my...The chocolate was very rich and the coffee is amazing.

Definitely come back again to try the cappucchino or latte.
author: Rhoda G.

description: BEST cappuccinos in TOWN. Wait it pretty long (10-15 min.), so prepare if you have to be somewhere. :) Also, their iced coffee is a rare find & they make their own. #yum!
author: Kim M.

description:
Let me start by saying I'm not a coffee drinker. But I LOVE blue bottle.

Whenever I buy coffee, I usually only get ice coffee. I have several places I buy from, but this one is my favorite.

It's a little whole in the wall. No place to sit right there, but there is a little plaza a block away where you can sit and drink.

Some weekend days me and my boyfriend wake up, walk to get coffee here an then head to have breakfast in one of the restaurants nearby.
author: Gerardo C.

description:
Blue bottle is top 3 coffee roasters in the Bay Area, hands down. They take roasting and coffee preparation very seriously, and are a true haven for the coffee aficionado. This particular location does not have ALL of their preparation methods available, but being served such amazing coffee out of what appears to be a garage is still a fun experience, especially if you are finishing your ice cream, purchased next door, while in line. 
Blue bottle includes a guide to suggested preparation methods on their beans so you can decide if that particular roast is appropriate for whatever method you use at home. The one reason that blue bottle continues to outshine other Bay Area roasters for me, is this detail. I have been burned before after purchasing beans to find they were not suitable for the methods I have at home (French press, espresso). Blue bottle's preparation guide is accurate and prevents me from making a purchase I will regret. The ONLY reason they don't get 5 stars is the price, which is higher than other area roasters of similar quality. Despite the price difference, they are still the brand I buy as gifts for out of towners.
author: D M.

description:
their coffee is great no doubt about that.

I was going to give three stars because the staff are kind of arrogant. I then realized that there are actually a couple of really nice employees and figured it'd be unfair to them.

bottom line is I only get coffee at BB when I see the nicer staff working.
author: Emmett K.

description: Coffee was yummy, selection was limited.  making the coffee pretty was cool, but I don't know what the huge fuss was about.
author: Sinnary S.

description:
Blue Bottle's coffee is magnificent and I am a coffee drinker when I go to Blue Bottle.  I do love this location too.  It's a 3 minute bike ride from where I live, and I love sitting on the chill side street while enjoying my coffee.  For those of you who aren't keen on street drinking, there's a park a block west.  Perfect spot to enjoy your coffee.

I feel like there is a Blue Bottle vs Philz war in SF.  Both places have extremely loyal followings.  But honestly, after trying Philz, I knew I'd never abandon team Blue Bottle.  So much better than Philz.  Especially when they make it for you (Philz' beans are amazing).  

Soy Mocha with TCHO chocolate is to die for.

Cash only!  And remember to tip!  The staff here works hard!
author: Karen R.

description: By far the best organic coffee I have ever tasted.
author: Rza Marie R.

description:
Still my favorite Blue Bottle.  

I'm not a morning person and my boyfriend drives me down here, orders for me, and practically pours cappuccino down my throat until I become human for the day.  And the next morning, it begins all over again.  Sucks for him, but yay for me!
author: Janney B.

description:
I was disappointed after going to Blue Bottle. I heard so many good things about their coffee and how good it was but my cup tasted a bit burnt. 

Maybe it was a bad batch, maybe I came on an off day, or maybe there was a newbie being trained- but I wasn't impressed. 

I'll try it again someday and hopefully they prove me wrong!
author: Christine A.

description: I love the coffee at this hidden gem of a cafe, so smooth and light with a wonderful texture. On a hot day, I like the iced new orleans style coffee.
author: Christy D.

description: Great local beanery and coffee shop. I had a macchiato and a cookie. Both good and I'd return. Better quality than the chains.
author: Rich G.

description:
I went to this Blue Bottle Coffee location after all the good things I heard about BBC.  Sadly, it's not at all it hyped to be.  The only thing that should be hyped about is how Expensive this is.   

The place is small, and the line is long. Not worth-it to stand in line for an expensive cup of coffee.
author: Truong P.

description: There is nothing more that can be said about Blue Bottle except for a reiteration of what so many others have pointed out. Blue Bottle is among the top five on my list of coffee shops. While I've seen competitors expand and drop in quality, Blue Bottle has been consistently delicious year after year. Great coffee made by great people. You can't go wrong.
author: Nathan E.

description:
The nearest Blue Bottle outpost to me. I frequent this one to pick up coffee beans and the occasional beverage. They always have what I need and it's a hell of a lot closer than trekking all the way down to the Ferry Building for some beans. 
I usually find a parking spot on Hayes or on Octavia. Sometimes there's a bit of a line at the kiosk but if you live in San Francisco, I'm sure you're used to that by now.
author: Lisa K.

description: Friends kept on posting and checking in at this Blue Bottle Coffee company. I never knew where it was. Funny thing is, I see this long line every morning and I knew it was some kind of a coffee shop but just careless to look at the name because looking for a parking space and not be late for work was more important. So this coffee shop I pass by it all the time. Anyways they have the best and smoothest latte I;ve had so far. Remember to make time for the line if you have work that morning.
author: Sapphire S.

description:
Yes, everyone loves Blue Bottle. Yes, there is often a long wait. Yes, it only takes cash. But dang... if you want the best coffee, latte, espresso, new orleans iced coffee, mocha of your life.... This is it. 

One downside... parking can be tough :(
author: Elizabeth B.

description:
I know they say less is more, but what is this.. coffee for ants?! 

JK, orders on the smaller size, I'd guestimate a small's about 6 oz? I love the coffee but whether there's 10 people ahead of me or just one simpleton ordering a cup of coffee, it seems to take over 10 minutes to receive my drink. Good, solid espresso nonetheless.

Operates out of a garage door, in an alley, seating's only a bench or rocks.. just your typical, run-of-the-mill coffee shop.
author: Annie L.

description: Like many San Franciscans, I too am a coffee snob.  I like my cup strong and intense, filled with flavor.  I also prefer iced coffee over anything so I decided to try the New Orleans.  It was good and you could definitely taste it was good beans, however, I wish it was was stronger.  It was rather too creamy and milky for my liking.  Compared to Philz, in my opinion, it doesn't quite match up.  Nevertheless, if you're in the mood for a cup of joe, skip Starbucks "coffee" and check this place out.
author: Alex G.

description:
I went with a group and tried the cappuccino, cafe mocha, and a cafe au lait. All were really great. The only thing that sucks was no seating, and they don't take credit or debt (saw the yelp after I already went). It's a cool place, and there are other locations around the city. 

There is a really nice park to sit at right down the street.
author: Brandon R.

description:
Nothing satisfies this girl like a nice big cup of piping hot, freshly ground, brewed coffee first thing in the morning.

Until recently, I've been going to Starbucks for my daily fix before work. While Starbucks is still my favorite coffeeshop, Blue Bottle coffeebeans is quickly gaining a spot in my heart. 

My floormate at work, Scott, used to supply a small group of us with wonderful coffee everyday, well...twice a day. He had left a month ago and I have been fortunate to 'inherit' his coffee grinder. To keep the coffee tradition alive, we decided to buy some Blue Bottle coffee.

When we got to Blue Bottle, we couldn't decide which beans to get. The staff was very friendly, asking for our preference and recommending the beans that he thought we would like. We ended up getting 2 bags because they both sounded really good.

So of the 2 beans we got: Bella Donovan & Giant Steps, I love love LOVE Giant Steps! It's sooooo delicious! It's very dark and chocolatey. And just smells wonderful!!!! I love it!
author: Marti L.

description:
i have a song i sing everytime i go to blue bottle. it goes something like this: (to the tune of moon river)
Blue Bottle, calling out my name
There's nothing quite the same you'll see, 
as Blue Bottle, their cappuccino, 
it makes me so happy, so happy to be...
in San Francisco,
the kiosk is so sweet, ferry building's where we meet
to drink 
our cappuccino 
on saaa tur day morning,
Blue Bottle and me.
author: sarah C.

description:
Its good ... cant really say to much more about Blue Bottle ... I love there lattes, espresso, and well mostly whatever they got going ...

This little Kosik in Hayes valley is always a good time, i always seem to miss the line but there are times when it can get long ... but once you get the coffee you can take a nice pleasant walk through the valley of Hayes ...

All in all service is friendly and fairly quick ...  It's a quite nice spot to get some good coffee :)
author: Anthony S.

description: So far my favorite coffee spot for latte's in the bay area, consistent throughout the locations!
author: Jeff L.

description: New Orleans Iced Coffee - best iced latte I've ever had. Add that to meeting locals while hanging at this location's only standing table - amazing local bonding experience during my 1-day visit in downtown SF.
author: Stephanie G.

description: Love Blue Bottle. When can one expect Tartine goods to start being sold here? I heard they merged, and I'm thrilled!!!
author: Mary M.

description:
Ok... so this is Review #1087. Is there any further value to adding to all the previous reviews if I concur that...yes, this is simply awesome, out-of-this world coffee?

One suggestion - It would be really cool if these guys could package their wonderful drip coffees in 0.5 or 1L bags such that I can hook it on an IV pole to get a continuous flow of caffeinated bliss into my veins! 

Lastly, discovered local checks are accepted. Now really, does anyone still carry checks?
author: Gregg M.

description: Excellent coffee, but more importantly excellent service.  This is a classic easy 5-star review.
author: Jaydee B.

description:
Fantastic coffee! 

Walked her on a sunny Saturday morning for a cup of JOE and it was exactly what I needed that morning! 
There was a bit of a line but it goes so quickly - and the service it GREAT! 

We also splurged and grabbed a snickerdoodle which was DELICIOUS!
author: Kelly B.

description: Just go here already. The coffee is ridiculously awesome. If you are not a coffee drinker, at least try a latte or mocha. Giant Steps beans recommended for home drip, make sure you have a proper grinder; check their website for how-to. Can't wait to try their beans with an Aerobie coffee press.
author: Brian R.

description: The people who work here are so, so nice! And those cappuccinos...so much for saving by only making coffee at home. Worth it!
author: Emily D.

description:
Solid espresso coffee. Never "bean" to the place as I get them shipped.

Enjoy!

Vienna is a blend I enjoyed.
author: TopChef T.

description:
Wow, I never thought of coffee as a divine gift until I had a cappuccino at Blue Bottle. Now I know that some deity has decided to bless us with a mind awakening drug and the peddlers at Blue Bottle have perfected its delivery.

This is good coffee!

Try the iced coffee on a hot day. They add sweetened milk and chicory to the chocolaty brewed coffee and they let it ripen overnight. 

Also, any of their espresso drinks or drip coffee are a delight. I just wish they would open one in my neighborhood. [hint! hint!]
author: Cody S.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee is just your typical mid-morning walk-up style crack bar, but all the while legit.

CASH ONLY

Trolloped over to the ally mid-morning...hot mess and all...trying to stay under cover. Hoping I would not run into anyone I knew, but what do you know...of course I see someone I know. 

Lucky for me there was barely a line. The baristas were just like whatever, but I didn't care because I was just like whatever too.

Ordered me up a soy latte. Wasn't expecting much, but a mid-morning pick me up so my expectations were not my usual cafe snobbery.

Ally way is like literally too dog friendly meaning the dog was literally humping me. Well maybe that's an over-statement, but you can catch my drift.

Now let's get to the important part of this review.....

MY SOY LATTE courtesy of I was told her name is "Rose," apologized for the extra foam...so she told me to take a sip before I put a lid on it. So I did as told. HOLY FU**ING BABY JESUS MARY MOTHER OF GOD!!!!!   No I will not excuse my language!!! I told Rose, "nice art." The first sip transcended me into pure coffee nirvana. As I was transcended into the coffee heavens I dismissed all prior thoughts I had of blue bottle and replaced them with glorious exemplifying thoughts. 

Blue Bottle you did this tranny hot mess walk of shame well.

CASH ONLY
FINAL ANSWER: $3.75
author: Cellina B.

description: Blue Bottle is still great.  I've just grown to like Philz and Ritual better -- in part because both those places actually have more than one drip coffee option, but also because whatever I order at Philz and Ritual just tastes better.
author: Andrew E.

description:
Wonderful little coffee shop in a garage on Linden in Hayes. I'm not even a coffee drinker, but this place could make me a believer. I do like the occasional weekend latte or capp to wake me up from my sleep-hangover, which is exactly what this place is perfect for. Too expensive for your everyday coffee, it's the perfect little weekend treat for a stroll in the park. Plus, it's next to Hayes so it's like a 2-for-1 deal. I'm in!
If you're a coffee drinker, get the New Orleans iced, like everyone else suggests. If you're not, get a cappuccino. Yum.
author: christine c.

description:
serious coffee mecca found here.
too bad the grinder was broken today and I could not taste the legendary drip coffee but I had an espresso with much crema (the foamy stuff on top). very nice flavor but a negative star for not having what I came here for. I will update next time after I get my cup of drip, DANGIT!

update - March 20, 2008
finally came back for some drip coffee.
yeah it was special.
I still prefer my trusty French press method though.
wonderful beans.
on the same level as Graffeo in North Beach and Intelligentsia.
I still prefer Graffeo as my personal choice.
author: Jeff W.

description:
When I was much younger, my teachers thought I was suffering ADD or some sort of hyperactive disorder. Little did they know that I was merely suffering from coffee buzz courtesy of the Starbucks down the street from church and the wads of Tasters Choice packets from the Korean grocery store. With an older sister drinking coffee like water for her late night cram fests, I became immune to drugs as I had COFFEE. As my fellows Asians can tell you, for some reason we love Tasters Choice.

As I grew older, my tastes buds became more developed and no longer was I a slave to the burnt flavor of Starbucks. In my quest for the perfect bean, I've invaded so many friggin' coffee houses (p.s. I heart Intelligentsia and Illy but Alterra's got my heart in Wisconsin) I thought I couldn't get any shorter. 

In comes Blue Bottle Coffee after a 3 course meal at Stacks. Thank you Blackberry for Google Maps 'cause I wouldn't have believed this location without you. In a little alley with only a garage door to  protect it from the world, it's literally a to-go kind of place. I applaud them for the creative use of space and the idea is kind of cool, but there's nowhere to sit.

The prices are decent, the cookies are tiny and inventive but the crema on these babies made me want to write a review. First taste made my mouth sing. The only bad thing about this place was that they don't grind the beans for you. Oh well-still love you though.







L
author: Jessica K.

description:
Probably the best place in the city to buy beans.  There's a wide variety, but unlike at Four Barrel, you can get your favorite kind week after week.  At about $8 a bag (instead of $14.75) it's a much better deal, too.

However, the ATTITUDE from the baristas is just ridiculous.  I wouldn't have believed some of the negative reviews (honestly, some customers have it coming to them) if I hadn't witnessed almost every customer before and after me being condescended to for no reason when I went in yesterday.
author: Sven E.

description:
Check out this chest hair, yo.

Check it out - touch it...

Doesn't it feel as if it's made of Samson's own locks?

It does - thanks to Blue Bottle Coffee.
author: Dennis A.

description:
I was having a pretty bad day and showed up to grab some coffee to try and lift my spirits, only to realize I had no cash. The amazing young lady behind the counter offered to buy me a cup, as I am new to the city and to blue bottle coffee. She truly made my day. I am heading back to tomorrow to pay her for the cup and buy more beans for the house, as the coffee is amazing!!!

 Just know it is cash only.
author: Clay T.

description: Good coffee, but really bitter.  I don't eat much sugar, so I couldn't get the New Orleans coffee, and couldn't sweeten my iced Americano. They don't carry any artificial or noncaloric sweetners.  If they are too cool for Splenda, how about some Truvia?  It was just ok for me, not outstanding.
author: Rebecca H.

description: Best mocha I've ever had.  When I'm in SF, I go to this particular coffee spot every day.  You used to sit on the curb to drink your coffee, and now they have benches and flower beds.  Their lemon rosemary shortbread have inspired my cookies with the same ingredients.  Delicious.
author: Maren W.

description:
I loved the double cap that I had.  I wish they took plastic since I would have bought two, but I only had 5$ cash.  I took me a bit to find a parking spot, and I didn't know really where I was going, or what to look for, but I stumbled across Blue Bottle without much effort.

I like the store front, very simple and unassuming.  The barista was pleasant, and the presentation of the coffee was attractive.

There wasn't a line this day, but a few more people showed up to order as we were leaving.  I'd stop by if I were down in San Fran again, but I like the ease of parking by Barefoot.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Only in San Francisco can a business be run out of a garage in an alley without any seating at all & still be the talk of the town...if the town is called Yelp. The ridiculously long line tells me three things: 
1) that San Franciscans are fiercely loyal to local brands & products (gotta represent)
2) that out of towners are looking for the quintessential San Francisco experience & have found it
3) that everyone appreciates an individually brewed cup o' joe

The best friend & I ordered a New Orleans Iced Coffee ($3.50) for me & a Mocha ($4.50) for him. It wasn't the best iced coffee I've had but it was definitely far from the worse. It wasn't bitter & it was quite smooth; it was decent but decent does not justify the long lines. I'll continue to get excited when I see BB's drip coffee being served at restaurants I frequent but I won't be coming back to the Linden St. location because waiting in line for a cup of coffee makes me an Angry Little Monster. 

Besides, I've already pledged my allegiance to Philz Coffee.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
We made a special trek to this back alley landmark. The alley is narrow, funky and had a lot of artwork graffiti. I like the Blue Bottle drip coffees but we decided on a cappucinno just to see the barrista's artwork. It was great and the art work in the cup was first class. We enjoyed that small pleasue. 

We periodically visit San Francisco to mentally decontaminate from heavily conservative Orange County.
author: Robert M.

description:
Good coffee from a garage?  It is possible!  If you didn't hear about it from friends or read Yelp you probably wouldn't be able to find this shop!  But make the trek down the alley and literally inside a garage is Blue Bottle!  It's very simple, very basic, and very tasty.  I didn't have too slow service, but I didn't go at a busy time either.  Prices are a smidge bit higher than other places.

Times visited: 1
author: Amy L.

description:
If you name a stuffed animal after this place, you know it means something.

The mocha is my favorite. There's an asian chick who's here on Sunday mornings who makes them just right. And the cutest dogs ever stand in line here. 

mocha + dogs + love = perfect
author: Min L.

description:
I hate to be the voice of descension here, but really, truly, I do not think the coffee here is all that good.  It was just very mediocre in my opinion.  All 3 time I've tried it.  Tom and Daves:  better.  Philz:  better.  Pete's:  better.  

Sorry.
author: LeSLiE W.

description:
the coffee was wonderful. no complaints there. 5 stars.

the service, however, left A LOT to be desired. the female barista who "helped" my friends and i: 
1 - did not offer me an 8oz americano like she did to the gentleman who ordered after us, 
2 - rudely responded "uhh...mochas already have espresso in it......" with this tone that says "are you a *bleeping* idiot!?" to my friend who inquired about adding espresso to a mocha. not everyone knows their coffee...that's why you're there to "help",
3 - rudely (again!? yes. again. this review isn't looking good, is it?) asked--and i use that term lightly because it was more like snapped--"...are you guys even gonna order anything?" to my friends who stood farther back in line. how about a pleasant, "i can take all of your orders if you're in the same group" or "what can i get for yall?" or "will you be ordering something as well?" 

are you seriously in the customer service industry, lady? sure, she can make a cup of joe but judging by the way she handled my party, a job that requires less interpersonal interactions might be better. i would love to give her the benefit of the doubt and say she was having a bad day or whatever but the service i personally received was a cold 180 from the service the dude after me got so there's something odd going on there...

business owners, if you read this, i'd suggest an attitude adjustment for your barista. i would hate for another group of adults looking to enjoy a great cup of coffee to receive the kind of (dis)service i did.

blue bottle coffee in general, 5 stars. this location's service, -3.
author: Jessica Lei D.

description: I'm going to give the same score as another restaurant that gave me over cooked poached eggs.  Damn it people, you can not serve over cooked poached eggs.  No matter how awesome you are because you have good coffee and it takes 15 minutes just to get inside doesn't mean for $12 you can serve me that crap.  At the time I was just happy to get some food and coffee in my system.  Looking back on it I should have sent it back.  Live and learn.
author: Bob B.

description:
Definitely fabulous coffee.
 I really enjoy lattes from here, and the ambiance is actually pretty damn cool. The wait can be a huge drag though, especially if (and I'm sure this really adds to peoples' experiences) those who are standing in line know the baristas. Awesome that you guys shoot the bull, seriously- i like that it's not a fast-foody place, but sometimes it just takes a while to be acknowledged. Considering we stop here as a treat on our morning commute, I'm not bent out of shape about it. 
The quality is outstanding, and the wait is generally worth it. If you really want to treat yourself, get one of the ginger scones and prepare to melt into a puddle of happy.
author: Nicole L.

description:
I want to give this place a 3.5

The ambience was super cute, it looked like a chemistry lab which I love.
I got the new orleans iced coffee which I did not like at all but I think thats just a personal flavor choice rather than a dig at blue bottle. I would like to go back and try other drinks.
author: malalai f.

description:
I love love this place. Kinda hard to get to but is def worth the wait. You have to 
try it at least once. 

The latte is delicious :)
author: Erin A.

description:
Well I had friends in town and wanted to take them for a really good cup of coffee.  So we ended up going to Hollow in the inner sunset.  I hate to throw it out there like that but the crap attitude we got from the moment we got there, WOW!   As poorly as tI was treated while at the back of the line you would swear they would only server pretentious 20 something know it alls.  Oh wait...  
Will I go back here.  Only if I wanted to get into a fist fight.  
Would I first go to 7-11?  I would now.
  I could be a follower and say "oh they were having a bad day." Honestly last time I came and WAS served, the coffee was good. I felt like I was being served out of pity but good.
Isnt Philz around the corner?
author: Tony B.

description:
Great coffee and good people working there. 
Thanks Blue Bottle.
author: Rondi K.

description: Blue Bottle coffee is, by far, the BEST coffee I have ever had the pleasure of drinking.  I particularly enjoy the kiosk location on Linden.  Although there is ALWAYS a line--I humbly wait for the magical coffee that ALWAYS brings a smile to my face.  The baristas here rock--friendly and the guy with the glasses (the one who looks like he stepped off the cover of GQ magazine) was extremely nice when I was a buck short after ordering my coffee and getting a couple of bags from home--I promptly repaid it the next day when I went back for some more!  Thanks Blue Bottle for bringing so much joy to San Francisco!
author: James E.

description: Great coffee served from a very trendy location in San Francisco. Don't expect to be able to hang out at the cafe and use your laptop though, because it's literally a garage with a coffee shop set-up. The only time I was able to visit this place was on a very windy day, and I was not dressed appropriately, so I wasn't able to completely enjoy my latte, but I plan on returning and updating my review under better weather conditions.
author: George T.

description:
When does coffee not taste like coffee?

When it's a delicious, hot cup of Blue Bottle - that's when.

I'd compare it to a fine liquor. When you drink a good wine or scotch, it doesn't sting or burn. It doesn't leave a horrible aftertaste. It is smooth, rich, and utterly satisfying. Take this morning for example. It's just another cool, blustery San Francisco summer morning. Mid-50's, breezy, gray skies. 

As soon as I order a cafe au lait and hear the whirring of the grinding and the hissing of the steam, I know a yummy beverage is on its way. Then it arrives, fresh and frothy, and the taste... simply heaven.

Words do not do Blue Bottle justice. It's not cheap...and when has anything good ever come cheap? Ahem. If you think 2-buck chuck is good, then you might do well to stick to Starbucks or Peet's. If you enjoy a Yamazaki 18-year scotch, a fine Oregon Pinor Noir or an Argentinian Malbec, then Blue Bottle's your coffee spot!
author: Aaron F.

description: The latte I had was prepared quickly but masterfully! A perfect blend of espresso and frothy milk. A great local find although people don't tend to linger as they would a coffee shop. There is some outdoor seating so you can sit, enjoy your coffee, and people watch.
author: Rick S.

description: Without a doubt, one of the best iced americanos I've ever had.  Yes, it's pretty expensive, but everyone should try this at least once.  I can't and won't afford this often, but if it's in my path, you'd bet I'd stop for a cup.  Let's be honest, people over-hype this place, but it does deserve a lot of credit for serving up awesome cups of not-your-average Joe.
author: Christopher L.

description: Great stop. Great coffee! And is in a nice little mini one way street. I approve with 5 stars.
author: Kyle P.

description:
I travel a lot and drink coffee everywhere I go.  Once in a very great while I find a cup of coffee that is...  different.  Richer, more complex, more flavorful.  It's always a revelation and like a whole different drink.  When I find one of the places that serves that special brew it is a landmark for me.

Blue Bottle serves that kind of coffee.

There's a shop outside the gates of Princeton University, one in Seven Dials in London, Blue Bottle in San Francisco, and (recently and thankfully) Spyhouse near the Art Institute in Minneapolis, my home.

Go, have a latte, you'll be glad you did.
author: Lee K.

description:
Snide Staff = 1 Star.

I witnessed an exchange between a customer and a "barrista" today on Linden street that totally turned me off.   A newbie to BB told the staff person that the latte he made her was room temp.  She asked him to heat it up, a reasonable request considering it was a cold and rainy day.  He repeatedly refused & then told her to go to Starbucks.  His response was immature & really uncalled for.  

Clearly the management tolerates this attitude.  OK BB... be that way, but it's a lukewarm recipe for going out of business one day. 

There's an emperor's new clothes vibe to this dopey scene.  I really like the coffee....but I won't go back.    I don't get the hipster thing, I really couldn't give a s**t.......because I'm cool like that.    I really do think the coffee is excellent but....not worth the nonsense.
author: purple z.

description: Yummmmmy coffee (duh) but the servers have an attitude problem that bothers me. Good thing they are serving delicious coffee to make up for it.
author: Lindsay U.

description:
Coffee cart on Linden:" *not* what it was several years ago. The coffee all taste like Peet's now.  It's just a strong punch in the face that has lost all of its mid-tones and depth of flavor.  

meh.

sad loss and sad change. 

meh.
author: Heather S.

description: Really cute coffee stand? Shop? It looks like a stand but it's inside a building. Hard to say. Anyways, it's really good. I had the black individually dripped coffee. The beans they used were the Three Africans. It was pretty good. We went home with a bag of beans. The latte here was amazing. They use a local milk that makes the latte a huuuuuuuuge difference from any other lattes I have tasted. All in all, this place is good.
author: Nari L.

description:
Here's what to expect...
A 15 minute line with urban hipsters and trendsters waiting for an over priced coffee that is at best luke warm with service that is part of the hipster elite AND coffee that really isn't that deck.  Brew your own mug or just enjoy the $1.80 version at peets or bucks.
author: Oliver T.

description:
Lives up to the hype.

Your lines are reasonable.  You look like you're working out of someone's garage.  Your coffee was literally roasted that day or (gasp!) yesterday.  And it doesn't take like 30 mins (ferry bldg loc) to get a coffee.  God bless you, Hayes Valley location...
author: Christine K.

description:
I think this is my favorite BB location. I've always been able to find a parking spot around, even on a Sunday. You can't fight the charm of this stand outta the garage. They're super friendly at this loc. and the line moves pretty fast. fyi, you don't even have to wait in line if you just wanna refill on a pack of beans (love bella donovan). I also got my cute 4-cup Bodum french press here...a steal @$25 

Love grabbing a cap. and walking around Hayes or sitting the in grassy square on a nice lazy Sunday.
author: Jessica h.

description:
"[L] is for the way you look at me, [O] is for the only one I see, [V] is very, very extraordinary, [E] is even more than anyone that you adore..."

I hereby give Blue Bottle my NY stamp of approval.... not better than Abraco, but still, oh so delicious--- and the best coffee I've had on the other coast (you know...the West one...). I loved how Blue Bottlers were sitting along the sidewalk, sipping their cups of love and enjoying the company of random strangers that all share in this addiction..... oh, how sweet it is.
author: Mo S.

description:
Click, clack, click, clack.
Halt.
Look.
Peruse. 
Decide.
"Caffe Latte, please."
Step aside.
Debate choice.
Observe.
Pay.
Receive.
Sip.
Sigh.
Slurp.
Satiate.
Walk.

Return.
author: Jared S.

description:
Great coffee, great people working there, and a spot to hit up if you're in the area.  The coffee's a bit lighter than I'm used to, but it smells and tastes amazing.  They put love into each drink, and you can taste it at the first sip.  
The place is a bit disorganized in a homely kind of way, but it's not off-putting.  I wish there were more of these coffee joints around.
author: Julian P.

description: I didn't want my latte to end! Good flavor, rich taste, and not bitter. This location is in a nice alley near a park. This is a neighborhood walking shop- not drive up. It has a few sitting areas for short term relaxing.
author: Marie E.

description:
Employees here rock.  Seriously.

Great coffee.  Philz has a better mocha, but these guys might have an edge over them in black coffee.
author: Erika C.

description:
I LOVE! blue bottle coffee.

I know- it can be pricey at over $2 per drip coffee, and the wait can be ridiculous-

But seriously. It's delicious. Hands down.  Best coffee ever. The only one that remotely comes close to it for me is MUD coffee from New York. 

Forget getting anything fancy in it, like soy milk, or ordering a latte. Just get a drip black coffee and savor in its smooth rich taste.

Ahh blue bottle, if only i could brew you every morning from home in my pyjamas.. then my life would pretty much be complete (or at least I'd be a lot less grumpy in the morning)!
author: Roxane W.

description:
Tasty coffee.  CASH ONLY!
Since they operate out of a garage, the only choice of seating you have are stones and benches outside in the alley.
I would skip on the cookies though.  Was not a fan of the snickerdoodle.  Tasted herb-y.
author: Nancy C.

description: An excellent cup of coffee. I bought a half lb bag of coffee beans for $7.00 and it's just great. I also tried a cup of black coffee from them that my friend purchased and it was hot, fresh and tasty. What more does one need from a coffee shop?
author: Jordan C.

description: The coffee beans are NOT burnt and you can drink it in an alleyway. Its sooooo effing good.
author: Rockie N.

description:
This became my go-to coffee spot this summer while subletting around the corner from someone who (insanely) had no coffee-making supplies, and I have to say, it often made my day to go here. 

The guys who work here were pretty quick to start remembering that I always get a drip, which makes me want to give them five stars but I'm subtracting one because: a) I can't go here when I'm in a rush and b) they open at 7 on weekdays, which is just too late for me many days of the week.

They do have a square setup now, but I've yet to try paying with a card, after getting so accustomed to grubbing up cash.
author: Allie H.

description: Regularly walked over to Blue Bottle from civic center with several of my co workers for our afternoon coffee break.  I swore this place off because although the coffee is excellent the staff members think they are superior to their customers.  Regularly saw employees roll their eyes at customer questions.  Now we go to Philz on Van Ness.  If I have friends visiting from out of town and they say they want to go to blue bottle I always recommend Philz, Four Barrel, Ritual...anyplace but here.  If you insist on blue bottle, go to the SF Shopping Centre location...staff is less rude from what I hear.
author: Lola D.

description: Great coffee and great service even under the pressure of always having a huge line. Best hot chocolate in the City!
author: Sophia L.

description:
A booth in a garage in an alley. No, seriously. Oh, and a bench.

Who needs crack when there's New Orleans Iced Coffee?!

This is one of those times when the reality lives up to the hype. I've been seeing blue bottle expand all over the place since I first came here.  The lines here are better than the ridiculousness that now occurs down at The Ferry Building location; yeah, both of those locations.
author: Ken L.

description:
This place is little hidden which is cool.  

Pumping good coffee in a little garage.  

The main guy there makes really good coffee. 

i usually have the Drip.  

One thing is with different staff, different flavors.
author: Rei S.

description:
I find myself making up reasons to be in Hayes Valley so I can stop in for Blue Bottle coffee.  

This is the gold standard for well balanced coffee - everything else must be benchmarked against this.

Lines are long, but not as long as the ferry building.
author: Mark F.

description:
I will always have a soft spot for this location - this was my very first stop in San Francisco when I first came to visit in Jan '09. I fell.. in love. Strong, full bodied coffee with a beautiful aftertaste.. it had been a while since coffee made me feel that way.

I will forever love you for reminding what good coffee tastes like, Blue Bottle.

Oh but WHY did you stop stocking Bacon Gruyere Brioches?
author: Asha S.

description: First time trying this place. I've heard good things. They only accept cash so that's not great with things like square around. I got an iced coffee.  It was good.  Next time I'll either try a drip coffee or go to the Mint location and check out this crazy science experiment looking brew process.
author: Elvin T.

description:
My Seattle friend had heard all about the BB coffee and wanted to try it, so we traipsed across the city to the original garage stand.  Great coffee, served by friendly baristas.  No fuss, no muss.  Well, there was a bit of fuss, as we waited in the line for 20 minutes in the sunny-but-oh-so-chilly SF morning.

I treated her to coffee, which was so good that she promptly bought ten pounds of coffee to take home as souvenirs for her friends (luckily, they didn't make us stand in line AGAIN for the beans).  Now, that's a souvenir I can appreciate!
author: Patty W.

description: Love the alley atmosphere in the middle of downtown and parklet to sit at right across from this yummy coffee stand.
author: monica s.

description: I LOVE this place!  If you are stolled down the street a little too quickly you might miss it though.  It is tucked away down a fancified alley that couldn't have a better ambiance.  The baristas here are always in good spirits and the coffee is ah-mazing.  A macchiato (comes Italian style...no carmel!) is the way to go!  Smooth, delicious with a design in the foam to boot!  This place is all outdoors so if its a rainy day this might not be the best choice...but on a nice day, PERFECT!
author: Liz B.

description: Small & hidden. Smooth tasting coffee. Nice place to just relax. Had a small piece of their snickerdoodle, not bad.
author: K X.

description:
I always get a latte here, and absolutely love the location of this place! Also, they have the best snickerdoodles :) 

The only thing keeping me from giving it a 5-star review is that it's cash only, and I'm one of those people who never have cash. Us non-cash people deserve some great coffee too!
author: Gloria Z.

description:
Back in the day, at the Blue Bottle on Linden...

This is the BBCC that I frequent. The Mint Plaza spot just gets way too crowded from all the Westfield/Union Square shoppers. Sure, the Linden spot doesn't have the fancy Doc Brown coffee bongs (which I have yet to see them use btw), but they do have doggie treats. And nothing goes better with a cup of Bella Donovan than dipping a Milk-Bone in it and pretending it's biscotti. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D763aWigu_0#t=5
author: Len L.

description:
I usually dont like or drink coffee but wow, the mocha is awesome!

But that might be the anti conformist in me talking.
author: David O.

description: Don't believe the hype. I had the pour-over coffee. It was not hot. Instant deal breaker. It was $2.75. At that price it should be strong and delicious, and it would still be over-priced. It was neither. It tasted very acidic without being robust. I think they need to work on the roasting, or the water temp of the pour over water. Good luck to them. I like the notion of brewing within 48 hrs of roasting, which seems to be one of the major selling points, but I am not a convert, and will try the next place next time.
author: Gabriel F.

description: new orleans iced coffee with soy and nothing else. this makes me quite happy! ohhh and there's not much parking down the little alley. CASH ONLY!
author: Ann T.

description:
I can't help it, I heart Blue Bottle Coffee.  I make the trek to this spot located in an alley, and find that there is an awning and a line.  The things better about this place than their other location (by the old SF Mint):

1.  You have a semi-decent chance of parking (vs. double parking or yellow zone parking)
2.  You can avoid the craziness of downtown/Union square
3.  There is a more relaxed Hayes Valley neighborhood feel to it.

So go already!
author: Janet H.

description:
My new favorite coffee comes from a coffee stand in an alleyway looking street in Hayes Valley.  

My cousin isn't much of a coffee drinker, but he took me here when I told him about my cup a day addiction.  I had the drip coffee on my first visit.  I was won over with my first sip.  I wish I could remember the name the blend, it was sooooo good.  Very smooth and flavorful, not the overly roasted stuff that tastes borderline burnt (Starbucks).  Each cup is made to order using the pour over method, so it takes a few minutes, but totally worth it!  

So good, in fact, we headed straight here the next morning.  I had  a good cappuccino, which they made a little wet.  My cousin tried the mocha which he said was good and pretty rich.  Pastries looking interesting - a lot seemed to have a bit of a flavor twist.  I tried a biscotti infused with saffron flavor and almonds.   

We came late morning on both visits and there was a short line.  I can imagine it gets much longer during the morning rush.  My only complaint is that I wish this coffee stand in an alley was in Chicago.  I'd settle for even just the coffee...
author: Raana A.

description: 2nd best espresso. Intelligentsia and Waking Life Espresso and tied for number one.
author: R R.

description:
I mean, come on. The coffee is great quality, and they serve it with simple style and panache. I had the drip, which was frankly one of the best cups of coffee I've had in my life. They make a latte like they only can make them in San Francisco; with reverence and love.
Huge fan: want to go back now.,
author: Darya T.

description:
Now I'm not a big fan of coffee, but after my friend brewed me a delicious cup of Blue Bottle Coffee using her home drip coffee maker, I absolutely had to pay a visit to good ol' Blue Bottle himself. 

What can I say about Blue Bottle...simple menu, simply spectacular. If there is such a thing about "fresh, smooth, clean coffee" you'll see Blue Bottle's label.

The best part about the BB coffee is it doesn't give you that crash like other coffee's do. They serve all their regular coffees double shot that will give you a gentle kick and will have you coming back for more (even for the non-coffee drinkers out there). If you don't like coffee and you're interested in trying what great coffee tastes like...give Blue Bottle a try and let me know what you think.
author: Andrew S.

description: The perfect gem on a Sunday morning. Makes me want to move to SF just to have a coffee here every morning. Incredible coffee and really kind baristas.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
I have a dilemna. The quality and flavor of the drip coffee depends on who is making it. I'm sorry to say that today's drip was one of the worse that I've had from here, and I've had many! I knew it was going to be bad when I got my cup of drip coffee so quickly, definitely not made with care (the grinds need to be stirred and steeped slowly to get the most flavor). I'm happy for the most part, but every once in long time, I get a bad cup. I had thoughts of tossing it after I sipped it for a few blocks, but I decided to torture myself back at the office with it anyway. :)

maybe next time if my favorite barista is not doing the drips, I should keep walking...
author: Warren T.

description:
I really wanted to like this place since I just moved right by this location and had heard such great things... but Blue Bottle was just not what I was expecting :( I tried to like this place a couple of times; I really like the location, and the staff was pretty nice, but I just don't think i want to wait in that long line again for the coffee.

I know it's bad...but the one thing not to miss here is the granola.
author: Laura P.

description: You would think it's surprising that this coffee shop can thrive in a small garage space in an alley. But this is no ordinary coffee shop. Latte's are very good, very smooth. Their off-menu Gibraltar (#28 on 7x7's list), a double shot of expresso with foamed milk, is a great way jump start any day. Strong coffee, not too bitter. Will definitely be back to try more!
author: Tina T.

description:
I've walked into Hayes Valley a million and a half times before finally finding this place everyone's been talking about. Today I put my mind (and by "my mind" I really mean iPhone GPS map) to it and discovered my new jam.

I didn't start drinking coffee until I moved to San Francisco, and even then I still only really liked Wawa coffee from Philly. Oh, Wawa coffee...how I miss thee. But my Wawa supplies have since run out and I've been looking for something good enough to replace it. I think I've found it in Blue Bottle.

I got a latte today and it was perfect. I didn't have to add anything to it. And that's coming from someone who literally dumps sugar into her coffee. Will definitely be visiting often and probably grabbing a bag of beans to take home next time.
author: Jen M.

description:
umm don't tell my Starbie's barista I would trade my daily dose for a BB soy cap. I make it a point to get my fill every time I make it up to the bay area. bummed does not even express the amount of disappointment when i ordered my cappuccino and asked for a bag of the drip coffee beans to find they were sold out.

I LOVE the flavor of BB's drip coffee. For some reason, I am reminded slightly of blueberries....random I know, but the flavor is so unique not to mention their non traditional store fronts. This location seems to be inside a garage, down a graffiti filled alley. I would never tell anyone to walk down a crowded, gratified alley, but for Blue Bottle, I'll make an exception
author: Audrey L.

description:
If your opinion is that Blue Bottle coffee is "decent" then we officially can never be friends. 

You can call me whatever you want, but I am a coffee snob and this places serves it up. Perfectly, every time.

Almost everyone that works here is super friendly. It's my almost-daily treat to myself to take a break from work and stroll over for a cappucino or an au lait. If there are fresh snickerdoodles, I highly recommend getting one. They're made with Tahitian vanilla & saffron. Shazam!

I'm not as in love with the Recchiuti chocolate cookies - they're a bit too rich for me. However, if you're a rich cookie/brownie person, you should go for it. 

Perfectly brewed, never-bitter, frothy heaven in a cup.
author: Alli J.

description:
This coffee is fantastic and the baristas are top notch. I tend to go with a soy mocha or a New Orleans style iced coffee if it's a nice day.

My favorite feature of Blue Bottle coffee is that when you receive your coffee, it is the perfect temperature to start drinking immediately. My taste buds have never been burnt by a fresh mocha.
author: Leighton W.

description:
No joke, this itty bitty garage-turned-coffee vendor on Linden must have about $5,000 worth of my money! 

I've been coming here since 2006 and what more can I say?! The coffee is AMAZING, the baristas are top notch (and easy on the eyes) and the experience is just truly unique. 

I recommend the drip coffee or their cappuccinos. Each drip is prepared individually just for you and the espresso drinks are fantastic! It's definitely not the place you go to if you need a coffee on the go. Just be prepared to wait patiently in line and enjoy the moment.
author: Dean R.

description:
Not having had good experiences coming to bb and posting my lukewarm review previously, bb was good enough to contact me via email and apologize for dropping the ball.
I revised my review of them for this reason & because they seem to be making an effort to be friendly at their hayes valley location. That is really all we need; just a friendly authentic smile will do it.
Thanks bb for trying, it's appreciated!
(Of course your coffee is the absolute best!!!!)
author: Elle S.

description: still wonderful flavorful coffee but not so impressed the second time around maybe due to philz?
author: Char Y.

description:
ah, Blue Bottle Coffee Kiosk in Hayes Valley, you're the perfect stop after (or before) getting your hair cut at Oxenrose and a quick bite to eat at Frjtz.  I don't find myself in Hayes Valley all the time, but I get my hair did near here, and I've been known to meet friends in the area for dinner from time to time and attend the occasional DYL near here.

Their mocha is amazing, and it still feels like you discovered a caffeinated secret in an obscure alley, even if it does have 900+ reviews.  Definitely worth a stop if you're in Hayes Valley.
author: Joe B.

description:
Sorry, but I dont understand the hype.  Is it because their locations are located in urban "secret" alleys filled with bridge and tunnel types? Coffee is decent, but whats with the ridiculous line?  Maybe its the way they brew each cup individually, which i find a little pretentious.  

Anyway, coffee is decent if the wait is resonable.  Lattes actually look tasty.  Go if you have a long lunch.
author: dion c.

description:
Blue Bottle was part of my Saturday morning ritual in SF. I would have a cup of this super strong stuff first thing in the morning at there outdoor stand at the Farmer's Market by the Ferry Building. 

It's available in New York now - thankfully :)
author: Little C.

description:
Amazing coffee. If you are going to spend $2-3 on a cup of coffee, skip Starbucks and Coffee Bean and run, no sprint to Blue Bottle.

Don't be swayed by the exterior... it's not a place you can meet a friend and spend an hour chatting.... it's out of a garage and the line sticks out of the garage a good 10 feet but get in line cause it's worth it. 

What I love about Blue Bottle Coffee Co is that the menu is not filled with fluffy frappe's and fancy lattes. Simple coffees. The coffee here is so rich and smooth, and not bitter at all. I have only had drip coffee from here until today. Too hot for a hot cup of Joe so I went with the New Orlean's Style Iced Coffee and it's just as good as the regular cup, possibly stronger, and refreshing. 

Blue Bottle you start my day wonderfully, thank you.

5 STARS
author: Ashley M.

description:
This place is really great in every way. I took my father here when he came to visit and he took one sip and looked me in the eye and said "This is the best cup of coffee I have ever had." They always have top notch cafe au lait and Cafe Latte, and the people behind the counter are business like, but not rude. There is always a line and they know how to handle it well. 

I stopped by today to buy some beans and one of the porcelain drip things for my Dad, and the guys working were more than happy to give detailed instructions on how to use it to produce the best possible coffee. Ended up buying a second drip thingy for myself. Good Job, people. I highly suggest this place to any one who is out for a sunny walk in Hayes Valley. Oh, and the New Orleans Iced coffee is amazing.
author: Thomas E.

description: Best coffee chain in SF. The latte was unbelievably smooth but not too sweet.
author: Yiwen X.

description:
I was in town for the week and I had to try this place out. and I absolutely loved it! The menu doesnt have much of a variety although the coffee is really fresh/strong. 
I love the way this place is set up I find it to be very unique (it looks although they are serving coffee out of a garage) you line up in the alley. Definitely something different.
author: Kathy N.

description: sour coffee- I don't get it.  Seriously, what's the fascination with this bitter coffee?
author: Scott L.

description: Probably my fault, but I didn't realize it was just a coffee stand. Don't go there if you want to sit in a coffee shop.
author: Patricia B.

description: Best cappuccino ever!  Better than Italy.  I said it.  Didn't even need to add sugar or sweetener which I usually do.
author: Rob R.

description:
This is good coffee? I finally caved in and went there, but I was not blown away. I drink coffee like it's water, but not because it tastes like water. I personally feel blue-bottle goes down too smooth.

I'll have to try it again some time. The atmosphere is spot on, though.
author: Stephen C.

description:
So good.  So worth the wait on a line that stretches from a nondescript counter into a side alley in Hayes Valley.  

Remember to bring cash because they don't take credit cards.
author: David A.

description:
I. Love. Blue Bottle.

If I'm in the area, I must stop and have my Blue Bottle. I've been known to drag my ass down to the Ferry Building to get me some Blue Bottle on the weekends. Also, in the Potrero Hill/Dogpatch area, you can get Blue Bottle at Piccino, a lovely cafe in that area.

After seeing that the Gibraltar was on the list of Big Eats, I had to go for it. It's basically a shot of espresso with heated milk, about a 2-to-1 ratio of milk to coffee. I'm lactose-challenged, so I went for a soy version. It's a really lovely way to enjoy to smooth flavors of Blue Bottle beans.
author: Joel A.

description:
Whenever I'm in the area to go to Isotope Comics on the opposite of the building, I come to this Blue Bottle. It's always close to closing time, overcast -- maybe even raining -- and one or two customers who look like they live in the neighborhood stand around whenever I walk up and order a simple cup of whatever they've got going that day.

It makes me feel like I'm in on some sort of cool, snobbish coffee secret as I pass the hip piece of trash behind the counter a wad of cash -- no cards here -- and he slides me that little paper cup and a bag of the finest beans known to man. But I'm not. It's just Blue Bottle and I'm just another dork who thinks it's classy to drink expensive coffee.

Hooray!
author: Nicholas M.

description: It was pretty good coffee.  I was told they were the best, but I strongly disagree.  They are good, but not the best!
author: Isai C.

description: Coffee doesn't get any better than this!!  When this kiosk first opened up,  I was working nearby and was preggers some had to drink mostly decaf, and it was still friggin awesome. Now I make a trip across town to buy the caffeinated stuff which also helps me keep up with my little guys.
author: Ronnie T.

description:
I suppose this is where I reveal myself to be a simple-minded creature with unrefined tastes.  Here goes: I wasn't all that impressed by this stuff.

I felt compelled to try it because of the rave reviews, but honestly...it didn't leave me with desperately obsessive thoughts (which a good cup of coffee typically does).  Granted, I didn't order my usual latte, so maybe that was it; and it's not like the stuff isn't strong, because I couldn't sleep for the next 18 hours. But in general...it was all right.

I've had the individual drip coffee and the cafe latte; I'll give the cafe mocha a shot, but then I might throw in the towel.

One other thing: upon my first visit, a tasty-looking snickerdoodle beckoned me from the pastry shelf.  I read the little sign next to it--it said something about Tahitian vanilla and saffron flavors.  This was a warning; I ignored it.  I'm no stranger to saffron, and in fact enjoy it a lot, but let me just say this: it needs to stay the F away from any snickerdoodle that I'm eating.  That's all.
author: Shirin H.

description:
Let me just say this: I don't think I truly appreciated good coffee until I tried coffee in San Francisco. These people have a passion for the stuff that is unrivaled in most other big US cities. 

The coffee: Quality with a capital Q and so flavorful that FORGET sugar & creme. Just trust me. It's smooth, it's rich, it's well blended & roasted to perfection.

The Mini Gingerbread Loaf: DIVINE. It was so perfectly cooked, still moist and fluffy, well flavored, with little bits of candied ginger inside. I'm drooling a bit just writing this. It's a MUST try. 

Oh San Francisco, you spoil me with your coffee perfection.
author: Kristin G.

description:
DUDE... this place serves serious coffee. I was so amazed at how amazing it tasted. But it did not stop there!  The design that was created by the extremely nice lady on the head of my latte was down right gorgeous! 

Tucked in a little nook of a side street you could walk by this place 1000 times and might not even see it.  

I stumbled upon this place with a friend after having a great lunch up the street. This is a must visit for anyone with a interest in good coffee.
author: Ryan B.

description: I haven't a cup of coffee in at least 5 years, but the sumptuous aroma wafting from this little walk-up shop almost made me fall off the wagon! I ended up picking up a bag of the
author: Carter H.

description:
My boyfriend, who claims to have been drinking espresso since the age of four (which neatly explains his "height issues") and is a die hard fan of Peets, can be somewhat discriminating when it comes to his coffee.  So last Saturday we puddle jumped our way through the streets to reach this little back alley shop, all in search of what many say is the city's absolute best.

In the end, it was worth the effort- he really liked the individual drip coffee, and I, while not much of a coffee fan, did love that they had organic Clover milk, organic sugar, little chocolate macarons, and a completely non-corporate San Francisco vibe.

A perfect pick me up for an unrelentingly rainy day!
author: Joanne G.

description:
Dear Blue Bottle,

I miss you. Terribly. Probably more than I should.

Maybe one day ((soon?!)) you'll consider opening a little shop up out here in Fremont? Even just a stand at BART or one of the farmer's markets would be nice. Until you do, I guess I'll just have to see Peet's for my fix.

yours,
t mc-t
author: Tiffinie T.

description:
Best Coffee Ever!!!

 Each cup of coffee is individually made in front of you, once you try Bluebottle coffee, you never want to drink anything else. There is usually a line up, since all the drinks are made one at the time. Definitely worth the wait.
author: Kim C.

description:
Finally! A cup of good coffee and one very satisfied customer!
Much, much better than the one in Ferry Building. Service is good, coffee is great. 
The line was not that long, but it definitely took some time, which is a good thing. They actually take some time and effort to listen to their customers and answer all the questions we have. 

This location, I will definitely go back. But this is just a kiosk, and they do not serve the waffles that I want to try. This means I'll still have to go to their Mint location. But now I'm a happy customer of Blue Bottle Coffee, this place is definitely my must-stop-by spot in Hayes.
author: Cupie M.

description: BEST COFFEE I HAVE EVER HAD! The first time I had Blue Bottle Coffee was in New York and it was very good, but in San Francisco it was even better! Although the line is very long! Get the cappuccino!
author: Ava S.

description:
I don't know what it is about the alley, but I swear this is where you'll find the best cup of blue bottle in the city. Like other's have said (and I hate to give away my secret) early is key. Minimal line, if any, and there isn't much better than a warm cup of coffee on a cool damp morning. Bonus is parking isn't quite so tough either.
It's the right way to start your day.
author: dance f.

description:
The best cappuccino I've had outside of Italy. Take one sip and you'll feel like you're back in the streets of Italy. 

It's the perfect size. Despite what most American coffeehouses sell you, traditional cappuccinos are supposed to be smaller than lattes.

It's the perfect temperature. Forget the coffee cup sleeves and say farewell to burnt tongues because everything is served at just the right temperature for immediate consumption.

It's the perfect froth. Smooth, velvety, and to top it off, the baristas pour some pretty sweet designs.

It's the perfect flavor. Rich, deep, and complex. It leaves your mouth wanting to come back for more.
author: Donald F.

description: The original. Good coffee. Loved the small cute store. Very SF.
author: Christopher K.

description:
My lovely gf loves this spot. We go whenever we visit sf. 
It's cute and popular. A garage door opens up in an alley. It gets crowded. There are a lot of cute dogs that come out to this area. I look forward to seeing what kind of dogs will be there.
The coffee is quality and I don't know much about coffee. I just know that the mocha tastes like pure chocolate, not too sweet at all and over powering. 
I recommend this place.
author: kiomi k.

description:
My boyfriend loves this place. He loves it so much he brought me here on our first date. He loves it so much he ended up moving a block away from it. Coincidence? I think not. 

It's ok. I love it too ;-)
author: Abbey S.

description:
Like others have said before, there isn't much more that I can add about how great Blue Bottle Coffee is. I usually buy their drip coffee as I am rapidly becoming a sort of coffee "purist" and although I am still an amateur coffee geek at best, I will say that they make some of the best drip coffee I've ever had. It is incredibly smooth, flavorful, and to me it is just the right temperature. I don't like scalding hot beverages although I know some people do enjoy their hot beverages that way. For those who don't enjoy their coffee black, I have also tried their cappuccino and New Orleans-style iced coffee and I can say with confidence that these are equally excellent. They also have an excellent selection of roasted beans for those who want to brew their own coffee at home with a variety of single origins as well as their own custom blends(which are quite good). As mentioned before by others, the baristas are very friendly and efficient. 

Now I would like to address something that has probably been addressed before here but I'll go ahead and address it anyway. I'd like to emphasize once again that I am no expert on coffee brewing and I am still learning but I can say that I probably know more than the average person. I've read some reviews where people found the coffee at Blue Bottle to be bland and lukewarm. While I heartily disagree I can see why Blue Bottle coffee may taste this way to some people. When brewing coffee, the three elements that are most important aside from the particular beans used are the grind, water temperature, and brewing time. If you use water that is too hot, you'll likely end up burning the coffee grounds and destroying the flavors. If you allow too little time for "steeping"(the part in which the coffee grounds are mixed with water) then you'll come out with bland, flavorless coffee. Allow the coffee to steep for too long and you'll have coffee that is much too bitter.  

At Blue Bottle and other boutique coffee shops, the baristas closely monitor the temperature and steeping time of the coffee and probably use other methods of which I am unaware of in an effort to produce the smoothest and most flavorful cup of coffee. From what I can tell, it is the relative lack of bitterness in Blue Bottle Coffee that causes many to perceive Blue Bottle Coffee as "smooth" while some might perceive it to be "bland." Also, the baristas here tend to brew coffee at a lower temperature than other places so as not to burn the beans. To an individual accustomed to coffee being scalding hot or at least close to it, the coffee at Blue Bottle might seem lukewarm in contrast. I'm also certain that since the baristas are humans and not robots programmed with advanced coffee brewing algorithms, they do mess up once in awhile and produce unsatisfactory cups of coffee. 

Anyway, I'd be surprised if you took the time to read all of that but either way, go and check this place out! Even if you don't end up liking the coffee, Hayes Valley is a cool little neighborhood.
author: Michael C.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee with a Pocket Park right there or Patricia's Green down the alley.

Woohoo! As good as it gets!
author: Stelio C.

description:
Coffee: Great.  Out of all local competitors, Blue Bottle is my favorite.  Do try the iced coffee. It's some of the best I've had in the city.

Price Point: More reasonable than Ritual.  

Location: Most pleasing.  A walk-up window type operation running out of what looks like a garage - you can see ladders, tools etc behind the espresso machine.  There's some outdoor seating - a charming little parklet of granite benches and sparse but intentional vegetation, and its all on a little side street away from noisy traffic etc.  In short, a sweet oasis of a filling station.

Service: Impeccable.  None of your pretentious asshole barista attitude here.  My bf goes often enough that when we walked up to the window, the barista greeted him and predicted his order.  Who says you can't have artisan coffee AND great service?? Turns out, in the plot-twist of the year, that the two concepts are not mutually exclusive.  Shocker!
author: Jane F.

description: It doesn't get much better than this coffee place for me.  I'm a dedicated customer  at least twice during the week and every Saturday morning.  It's just good friggin coffee and worth the wait!!  I always get service with a smile.
author: Theresa A.

description: Superb quality espresso and nice latte art. Awesome place! I would give 10 stars if I could.
author: Anthony L.

description: I felt hip coming here. I got my usual Americano. The staff were nice and efficient. There was a line for this delish espresso. I heard this place is the best in SF so as a Seattlelite I of course had to go and have nothing but the best. It reminded me of my favorite coffee places in Seattle.
author: Jennifer B.

description: For Valentine's Day, I ordered an espresso bean subscription for my husband who drinks lattes fanatically. He has already received two shipments of espresso beans and both have been excellent (reminiscent of Black Cat and blends found at CCC). BBC sends the freshly roasted beans via two day express delivery and ships the beans every other week depending on how often you want your beans shipped. I really like the idea of BBC's subscription service as a gift for a coffee lover and I especially loved how the quality of the beans met my husband's high expectations.
author: m y.

description:
As part of my inadvertent SF coffee tour, my friend and her husband wanted to grab something warm before setting out on the chilly day. They asked me where I'd want to go, and I told them to lead the way, considering my knowledge of the city is more lacking than theirs. They named a few spots, including Blue Bottle, and I had remembered hearing good things about the place. So off we went to BB.

We approached the literal hole-in-the-wall kiosk, which was interesting and unexpected. There was quite a line, but it moved fairly quickly, so I didn't take much notice. There were three efficient baristas working, with all three taking orders. A girl popped out from behind the counter, and while there were a good three or four people standing ahead, she made eye contact with us and asked for our orders. Apparently her hearing is of super power strength too, because we practically muttered our orders from where we were standing. Yet, she got everything easily.

It didn't take long before our coffees were ready, and when I took the first sip of my soy latte, I was very pleasantly surprised. It was exceptionally smooth yet bold, and there was a tinge of sweetness despite the absence of sugar. The soy milk probably gave it the subtle sweet edge, and whatever type they used was pretty perfect.
