My soy latte was so good, that I actually finished the entire cup in a span of 15 minutes. This is a quite a feat for someone like myself who, for whatever reason, is the ultimate babysitter of drinks.
author: Karen T.

description: A Hayes Valley institution. There's a reason why there's always a line out the door. Excellent coffee, professional service and attention to detail in every cup since day one. Still my standard in which all coffee shops can be compared. Read James Freeman's book, The Blue Bottle Craft of Coffee and be inspired!
author: Summit S.

description:
I feel slightly hypocritical saying this, but in the past I've never thought a brand of coffee could be so superior to others.  I've always had my preferences, but Blue Bottle really takes the cake. Every cup of coffee is delicious, and I love how they make each cup to order.  The Hayes location is my favorite because they offer soy milk and now have snacky snacks.  

Another plus about Linden lane is they recently remodeled the street so the sidewalk is wide allowing for you to sit and enjoy.  

The coffee is a more pricy than other places (it's $3.5 for ice coffee compared to $2 at standard locations) but I found it really worth it.
author: Laura H.

description: Yum. Love your handmade coffees. But not your attitude. Im here on business, with an Amex. Don't tell me you discriminate ( their words not mine) just because we are in suits.
author: Crystal K.

description:
Great drip coffee, definitely worth the wait!
The staff is nice too, they recognize me sometimes and call me out of the crowd for my morning caffeine fix. Especially since I started bringing my red to-go cup (you should too, it's good for the environment :)
author: Matthieu T.

description:
Excellent coffee at Starbuck prices, but with the skills of the baristas being more evident! Yes, the simple leaf drawing is enough to get me kicking around in excitement!

Okay, I'm exaggerating, but still. If you're here, at this hip coffee shop in an alley that's more of a street (hence not an alley), then do yourself a favor... GRAB THE NEAREST BAR SPACE AVAILABLE! There's no stools, tables or even chairs unless if you're a yoga master who is willing to sit on the sidewalk with the dogs and commune with a single tree that's in front of this place (unless if I missed another tree - I wasn't really on a look-out for them).

Another thing... stick with the coffee. Hot chocolate didn't impress. Apple juice... organic, nice. But... freshly made - no. Maybe I'm being too picky here, but still! They're trying to raise the bar, and I'm pushing them to do it even more because I think this place CAN do it.

Also... the french macarons are a nice touche, but... I've got news for you - they don't taste as good as they should. Throw them out and get a better batch or just get them from someone else! Poor Liz or whoever made them (there's a "made by" sign next to the macarons - talk about bad publicity).

Ah, the leaf in my cup!!! Now if I could just have a tree instead of one stinkin' leaf....
author: Jordan N.

description:
I wasn't expecting to actually walk up to a booth in an alley.

The coffee, iced coffee, and mocha are really good. Espresso has a good rich flavor with a smooth aftertaste. 

Service was okay. I had some attitude from the barista but I came for the coffee and it is delicious.
author: Linda S.

description: I want a double latte' in a large cup, just like I have ordered and drank for the last 22 years. Blue Bottle Coffee has decided that they know what I want, not me. Lattes come in small only and you get as much espresso as they think you need. If you ask for anything like flavorings, I heard you get a smirk and no. I avoid all coffee shops that sell blue bottle coffee now, which sucks because I have bought coffee from one guy for 22 years. But he went blue bottle and now I won't go in his shop.
author: Keyser S.

description:
Yup, try the N'oleans iced coffee ( I'd compare this to the Vietnamese version of iced coffee, -sweetened, makes you question if you've just consumed rocket fuel) 

Discrete location, hidden off the beaten path but this is Blue Bottle and it always score an A+ in my book  so not much else to add on top of the thousand's of other reviews...

This is what good coffee should taste like so line up folks.
author: Jodi R.

description: I don't even like coffee but the stuff was pretty legit.
author: Pauline M.

description: I played hookie with my friend on a sunny San Francisco morning and this was our first stop. I'm not a big coffee drinker but have had it and it's great. I was hankering for some breakfast and they were nice enough to make it for even though service ended half an hour ago. Poached eggs on thick buttery toast were tasty and perfectly seasoned. The wait staff frayed from the morning rush were still friendly.
author: William H.

description:
I roll out of bed and stare into my eyes. 
"Unngh," says the voice in my head, my lips are dry sponges.
This sandpaper face needs a mythic revival.

My boots kick the pavement and I curse the fog.
Signs appear, a garage opens, and I smell the bean,
The grinder's song my anti-coma.

A haze lifts, the aromas bring me closer to clarity.
The barista asks my head where the rest of my body is?
Still in bed. I've been sent on ahead.

He has my medicine - a single-drip IV to my brain.
It goes down, down, down, pouring into my soul.
The gremlins behind my eyelids pry them wider.

Liquid gold, I shudder and sigh at its perfection.
Fresh, bold, rich, warm and life-giving,
Each cup is unique, mine and mine alone.

Coffee? Yes, that is my mood,
But only Blue Bottle pours nectar of the Gods.
Caffeine, my beloved siren, don't ever not be there.
author: Nils E.

description: Cafe Mocha to die for!  On a side alley, a line formed - why? For amazing coffee, that's why!  Everything is brewed per cup- that's quality and service.
author: Alex G.

description: The coffee is so tasty, but a little bit over strong to me. I love the smell of its coffee beans. Bottle design also very fresh. I don't mind to wait for my coffee in there because it is special. I don't think they have decaf coffee. Maybe next time I will go for asking.
author: Katherine Z.

description:
Excellent espresso drinks with disappointing regular drips.

Here is the biggest issue: 

Barista argued and refused to serve my espresso for To-go, 
stating something like, "Believe me, It won't taste good," and
"I can only serve in a ceramic cup."

Excuse me? 

I said, "I do not mind, please make it for To-go." 
She insisted it for several times and refused to serve. 

How many times do you have to hear me saying, "Please!" before I could have it To-go!? AND the place DOES have small espresso cups for take-out: No clue about her attitude....

**Please note that it happened a couple of years ago.**
author: Yoshiko M.

description: Always a line, no ambiance, but great coffee.  The service is prompt, though not friendly, and oferings are very limited, but it is a great place to go for espresso or cappuccino.
author: LeftCoast R.

description:
They tout serving coffee within 2 days, max, after it's been roasted. Sometimes, it's those little things that makes a tremendous difference. A coffee fanatic, I get my fix at Blue Bottle.

They're in multiple locations but I recommend 2 specific ones: Hayes Valley & Ferry Building in the Embarcadero. 

Hayes Valley is somewhat of a hidden treasure with a string of unique shops. It's a small patch of SF, which you can scavenge in 20min.

Ferry Building in the Embarcadero is an upscale food market. Here you'll find "organic", "locally-sourced", and "artisanal" in every food stand. Step outside of the marketplace and you get a beautiful view of the Bay Bridge.
author: Regina A.

description:
OH EM GEE

My first sip tasted as good as the first breath of life.
author: Kasie V.

description: relatively simple settings, but great coffee and service. I ordered Late and enjoyed it!
author: S K.

description:
Rain or Shine this place ROCKS!! I'm closest to the Hayes Valley kiosk so I'm almost always here on my day off, restocking with a few of the 1/2 pound coffee varieties & a vegan mocha, not because I'm a devout vegan I tried the non vegan local chocolate that they use and found that the vegan one tastes better! Big fan of the double chocolate cookies they offer as well, as hard as I try I always end up getting one ;) as far as I can tell they're only secret is the caraway in some coffees & select pastries. My multiple check in have made my non-coffee drinking friends say, Hey I think I really need to try this place, I don't think they'll have the painful cravings I do for BB....but I'll bet that there's something on the simply limited to perfection menu that will tickle their fancy! 

PS~ The organic beans are sold in a compostable bag....
c'mon what more can you ask for!
author: Courtney D.

description:
Coffee is great, but anyone else feel like this place drips with pretension? 
I felt completely uncool here!
author: Irene P.

description:
I have tried BB a couple times, and it is the most wretched coffee I have ever tasted.  This coming from me, a coffee snob who has been drinking coffee since I was 5 (my Asian grandparents thought coffee was a great afterschool drink).  I don't get the buzz.  It's gotta be clever marketing and that "underground" feel that all them dirty looking alkies and junkies are into.  Getting coffee in a dirty alley way...so cool, right?    

Try Philz instead!  They also do the one cup drip coffee, but their coffee is far better and a tad cheaper.
author: Kandi K.

description: My soy latte was more warm than hot but it was still delicious.  I had a sip of the New Orleans Iced Coffee which was great too.
author: Joe K.

description: Overated!!!  $5 for a drip coffee?  Newsflash:  Drip coffee is the same as that old coffee machine that has graced office  break rooms since the mid 80s
author: M S.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE!
Finally a place w/compostable cups + lids!!!

My 1st & I couldn't be more happy.
Totally surprised NO line at 7:40AM.

Latte: $3.75
Ginger molasses cookie: $2

Only critique- had to fish out stringy ginger pulp each bite of the molasses cookie; overload!!!
author: Keiko C.

description:
The Road to Acceptance is long and hard and I'll be damned if I'm going to start walking down it now.

I like coffee.  Great coffee.  Coffee that has distinctive flavors from the regions it is cultivated from and that does not just taste just like burned black water.  I like this sort of coffee so much that I need it at any cost.  Blue Bottle provides this product exactly.

The coffee is good.  The ordering is simple.  The vibe is chill.  Order, wait and enjoy your coffee.  The menu is like 14 lines long and there are just a few bites in case you're hungry.  And for those of you who are a little jumpy, don't worry; in my experience the baristas are quite good at making sure everyone gets their cup of coffee.  Speaking of baristas, John and Ashley make a great team behind the counter and definitely brightened my otherwise huge letdown of a post-holiday Monday morning.

The quality and service have been so consistent it's not even really a question anymore; if I'm nearby during operating hours I'm getting a cup of drip regardless of weather or line.  I'm sure eventually I'll admit my addiction to great coffee but that day isn't coming anytime soon.
author: Steven R.

description:
Not only the best coffee shop in the city...the best place for anything in the world!  
That might sound dramatic, but try it and see.  MMM...
author: Azeem K.

description: So I just moved to SF and some one once told me, there are two types of people here. Blue Bottle people and Four Barrel people. Well I've now experienced both and I'd have to say i'm on the blue bottle side.
author: Dan F.

description: Just had my first cup of Blue Bottle and the coffee was so good. I didn't believe anyone better than Philz, I am wrong.
author: Elizaveta C.

description:
Blue Bottle has good coffee, probably one of the better selections in the Bay Area, but I've had better.

Regular black coffee - it's good, smooth, nice and bold flavors. However, it's a bit foo foo for my taste. 

Mocha - tasty, but a little too fluffy. I can do without the heart shaped foam designs, just give me a good cup of mocha. I felt like the proportion of milk, espresso and chocolate was off. For the one time I had a mocha, there was too much milk in my cup.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
Blue Bottle is great.

This location is awesome because it's so unexpected. The artwork along the alley way is really neat too. 

My friend, Anoush, lived near here so I always came here. The employees are super cool and chill. None of them are mean or rude. They make great coffee. The line tends to be long and I have to wait from about 10-15 minutes total from the moment I get in line until I get my coffee. But it's worth it! It's a popular place and since there are only 2-3 employees on usually, it's hard to keep up with the demand. But they don't sacrifice the quality of their coffee drinks by rushing so I really appreciate that extra care they put into it all.

I highly recommend the New Orleans style Iced Coffee. It's truly out of this world. I have a gastric orgasm everytime I drink it. It is perfect for a warm day. The flavors are just out of this world.

Grade: A
author: Thomas N.

description:
This is specifically a review for the Linden St. kiosk. 

I have a laundry day tradition: put in my stuff to wash, go get a cappuccino from Blue Bottle up the street, and completely forget I'm doing something as mundane as laundry. 

Between the high quality of the espresso, to the friendliness of the people who work there, to the way each drink is freepoured/strained/steamed, is amazing. I especially love the fun foam art they can do! 

Whenever I go, I swear I'll get something besides a cap, like maybe a cup of individually fresh brewed coffee, or a latte, or a rich mocha, but I remember the last cap I had and I get the same thing again. Whoops.
author: Jenna H.

description:
had my bi weekly manicure at creative nails then on to blue bottle kiosk on linden in hayes valley....

i am a 69 year old hipster...i feel really hip drinking my nu awlin's iced cawfee in linden alley....really good stuff
author: Brent P.

description:
"Sir, you can't park there...." 

Yes, I parked squarely in front of the "Don't Park Here" sign that BBCC places across the lane from their doorway. 

Rationale: Caffeination trumps Obedience, and my small car is passable in that little lane. 

Razoo: "OK, thanks for the pointer" (smiling) 
...and yet, I continue to stand in line, behind the 10-or-so other eager patrons. 
Lady Barista: "No, really - you can't park there" 
Razoo: "I'll move in a bit" (still smiling, now a bit more arrogant than is polite) 
Barista: "I won't serve you." (now, also smiling) 
Razoo: "that changes things" 

...Because I think swallowing a little undeserved pride is the least I can do for the privilege of chasing it back with a wonderfully bitter cappuccino ($3) from Blue Bottle Coffee. The mix is light on the milk, at least compared with competing preparations, so the drinker is rewarded with a coffee taste that reminds you that BBCC makes the good stuff. 

And.. as I've discovered since making the leap from that gateway drug that is the soy-chai-tea-latte (guilty pleasure) to the leaded gasoline that is a coffee+milk drink, it helps that BBCC also serves treats to absorb the acidity. Yes, I'll pay $1 for a saffron snickerdoodle from Piccino's kitchen - it's worth every penny. Those go GREAT with cappuccino. Either that or the Bacon/Gruyere biscuit-like creation ($?), which is my alternative when they run out of cookies. 

Note: while they may look like cutely-shaped biscotti in the "sample tray", those are indeed dog biscuits. Don't eat them.
author: Razoo D.

description:
I believe the hype. Their coffee is good and pure. Doesn't taste overly syrupp-y like Starbucks. 

We got there around 10am and the line was about 6 people deep. We wanted to grab some pastries for breakfast, but everything was sold out. Got 2 mochas with the cool design on the top and enjoyed every sip. Pair it with some Paulette's Macarons around the block and you're set for a good day in the city.
author: Jeffrey L.

description:
I'm so happy that I work just a few blocks from this Blue Bottle. It's a great spot to take a break... on a nice afternoon, you can't beat a new orleans iced coffee and a few minutes in the sun. 

This block of Linden Street was recently converted into a "living alley"--a landscaped space where cars, pedestrians and bikes have equal run of the road. A  sign on the Patricia's Green end sums it up well: Caution, coffee zombies a head! There is bench seating, and also low slab seating created using stone dug up during construction. There's bike parking, too!

I do wish Blue Bottle would accept plastic, though. I don't always have cash on me.
author: meg h.

description:
Fragrant, Smooth...yet Bold.

Qualities for the man of my dreams, Joe...as in my morning cup of joe

I stopped by Blue Bottle Coffee on a Friday late afternoon. Who wouldn't stop by when you're so ready to face the weekend music.

I've had to ask where this popular coffee shop was because it was nestled in a cute little alley away from the commercial shops & restaurants at the Hayes Valley area. I felt relaxed after spotting this woodsy, cute stand surrounded with plants (indoor & hanging)

Definitely an on-the-go joint judging from the non-existent seating area

They brew your coffee crystals straight to the cup...I test via the original coffee taste test. No need for a coffee machine unless you buy a mocha, latte or espresso (which I would come back for at the next try)

Results were Great...like I said...fragrant, smooth and bold.

Blue Bottle Coffee is unlike Starbucks or other chain coffee shops because there's not too much media surrounding this coffee joint. Only in yelp did I hear about this place and their coffee is as strong but not similar to Pete's coffee which I find stronger & occasionally frequent when there's a need to read the bible & translate in Latin in one sitting

Blue Bottle did the job on Friday afternoon.
author: Charmian D.

description:
I feel an addiction coming on... 
I bought a bag and they kindly ground the beans for me. I drove home in my car (10 minute drive) and a week later I can still smell the deliciousness of the coffee. I need to get MORE! MORE! MORE!
author: Dee C.

description: Wanted some coffee in San Francisco.  Looked up my Yelp app and Blue Bottle Coffee showed up.  I ordered the New Orleans style iced coffee and I enjoyed it very much.  Just wish I had more for my drive back to Los Angeles.  The coffee tasted good and had felt balance.  Nothing was too overwhelming about it, it just tasted right.  Next time, I might have to buy a bag of beans to go.
author: Steven U.

description:
I'm open minded when it comes to just about anything, and I do enjoy a good cup of coffee, but the level of pretentiousness pouring out of this place leaves a bad taste in your mouth.  OVERRATEDDDDDD!!!!! Hipster D-bags.
A better Hayes Valley coffee joint?  Cafe Corbas.
author: Andrea B.

description: Believe the hype! I don't even drink caffeine but I love Blue Bottle! Best part of living in San Fran is being able to find this coffee anywhere I go (almost).
author: Kellie N.

description: In my humble opinion, Blue Bottle is the best coffee in the city, certainly the best single drip.  What I love about this coffee stand is that it is no bullshit. It is in an actual back alley garage, there is no space for any of the typical fanfare. No sad adult alternative music or name writing on cups. No douchebags on laptops or teenage girls in aprons. Just three dudes and some truly rad coffee. Also you get to feel like you are scoring crack, which is appropriate given the location.
author: Jessica C.

description:
OK I'll be short & to the point:

Pros:
Amazing coffee
They don't charge extra for soy milk
Coffee is strong
The have New Orleans style coffee
Affordable

Cons:
No parking
No whipped cream for mochas
Very limited selection
On hot days they run out of the New Orleans style coffee
Usually long lines
No seating
author: Molly M.

description:
I was new to this kind of place but I stood in line for about 20mins in the pouring October rain just to see what all the hype was about... man was I impressed!!

I live in Boston and for the fast paced environment that us "northerners" live in, we really lack good quality coffee that keeps us going.  The best that we have around these parts are the Clover machines at Starbucks locations or Peets.  

Not only was I fully impressed by my coffee but enjoyed the fact that it was organic and roasted to perfection.  Every sip was completely enjoyable.  The staff is urban and friendly.. very down to earth on all aspects of this experience; from the people to the product!

When I am back in these parts, I will make sure I stop back on Linden St. to get another cup... its a long truck from Boston but I'd do it again given the chance!!
author: Melanie P.

description: It's like a stand.... no place to sit.. just a place to pick up coffee.   Coffee was good but I was hoping for a place to sit and hang out.
author: Albert W.

description:
Just adding to the 600+ reviews...

One word..AWESOME!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Delicious, strong coffee without the bitter taste. 

I DIG IT!
author: Inga B.

description:
What is this madness?
I was fantasizing about my next Blue Bottle Coffee even before I started Yelping. How was it I never wrote a review? Was I trying to keep it a secret? I have no idea.

Rather than write about how I seem to float 1" above ground after a few sips of a drip coffee with Clover cream, I will relate a funny story of this location's cult following: A few weeks ago the road was being reconstructed. Blocks away dust and noise made pedestrians wonder where the construction was occurring.

I looked down Linden street and saw a line down the sidewalk of people waiting for coffee while only feet away a tractor ripped up the street, dust everywhere. Need I say more?

At peak coffee craving times the lines are long. It's mostly to-go.
The Mint St location or Ferry Building are best for hanging. This location is perfect for an afternoon pick me up.

Based on the other 1000+ reviews I needn't say more.
author: Susie W.

description:
I wanted to introduce my brother to Blue Bottle because I was such a fan, and we were going to breeze through Hayes Valley on the way to somewhere else. I don't live here in SF anymore, but I can still remember how delicious their coffees used to be; and I would try and get a cup of cappuccino or a drip brew on my biweekly visits to the Ferry Building Farmer's Market. 

Getting parking around this place is not that easy. I drove by and could see the line forming, so I let my brother out to wait in it. I drove around the block a couple of times till I finally found a metered spot, which happened to be broken. SCORE!  When I walked over to the kiosk, he was still in line.  I ordered a latte for myself and a "Three Africans" brew for him. When he saw that each cup of coffee was individually brewed he said, "whoa. That's going to be a good cup of coffee." My latte was nice and creamy, but not exactly what I was hoping for... I think they may have scalded the milk just a wee bit, which affected the taste - but the flavor of the coffee itself was nice and smooth. His coffee was full-bodied, and rich. A dark roast, so very nice and strong. Service was friendly and surprisingly quick, considering the line.

I went there a second time in the same week (this time with my best friend) - trying to get in as much as I could before I had to head back to lala....  my latte was much better this time, and the ladies behind the counter were quick and really helpful when I was looking over beans to see what I wanted to take home.  They were really descriptive and asked me what kind of flavors I liked in my coffee.
author: mariel v.

description:
I don't know why people keep talking about a Philz vs. Blue Bottle rivalry.  I mean please.  Nothing against Philz, but I only go out of my way to get coffee at one place; so in case you need a reason to visit Hayes Valley, here it is.

Ignore the 1-star haters: you know how hard it is to successfully pull off the pretentious vibes with a kiosk in a random alleyway?  They deserve it.
author: Chris H.

description:
Overhyped: Snow forecast. Not overhyped: Blue Bottle Coffee.

More praise here http://www.yelp.com/biz/blue-bottle-coffee-co-san-francisco-8#hrid:8iHPQJU5magysApCiv312Q and here http://www.yelp.com/biz/blue-bottle-coffee-co-san-francisco-7#hrid:2BR4Zy0hCajykQ4w0gCd9g.
author: Jason B.

description:
Pretty good.  Delicious coffee: some of the best I've had in the city.  Beautiful location; Linden street is amazing, and watching the line clear out for traffic is amusing.

But not really worth the wait for grab-n-go when there are so many other excellent cafes in this city.
author: Nils J.

description:
i can't quite put my finger on why I love this place so much.  Is it the whole hipster, earth loving feeling you get from ordering coffee from a garage?  Is it the pretty leaf patterns in the foam of their lattes?  I do know it's not cuz of the long line trickling down the alley.  Every cup is served piping hot and strong, the way good coffee is supposed to be. Every sip sends you to that happy place.  You know - a relaxing stroll, breathing in that crisp Sunday morning air and the warmth of the sun kissing your skin.  ahhhhhhh. really.

Minus one star for the limited options, the not so fresh baked goodies, and the furrowed eyebrow look when you ask for any kind of customization.  Hey, I don't expect you guys to speak Starbucks (i.e. a tall soy, 2 pump sugar-free hazelnut latte.  no foam and extra hot), but don't make us feel like asses when we asking for a lil extra something.
author: Steph N.

description:
Forget the coffee, it's all about the double chocolate cookies. As an avid dessert lover, this is my newest obsession. I used to think Specialty's had the best cookies in the city. 

Boy was I wrong. If Specialty's were like the cute girl next door with a great personality, cookies at Blue Bottle are like the super hot chick across the street that everyone wants to bang. Mix a bite of one these unbelievable cookies with a sip of some Blue Bottle coffee and you'll seriously feel like there's an orgy in your mouth. I can honestly think of no other way to describe how great this feeling is.

6 stars!
author: Joseph F.

description: Took a sip of my friend's coffee just to try and at the moment i didn't want coffee but afterwards wanted to buy my own. located in an alley, the urban-ed out coffee shop that looks like it was set up in a garage gives customers a very great cup of coffee. I would recommend this place to others.
author: Russell I.

description: Wow, interesting to see how the prices have really crept up over the years.  We don't go out for espresso drinks at all anymore after having gotten an espresso maker at home, but the last time we were here I just thought that it was a long- if pleasant- wait for mellow, smallish mochas that are now expensive.  Philz' growing popularity is almost certainly a reaction to this.
author: Dave N.

description:
YUMMY COFFEE!

I love coffee. Really, I do. I'm always drinking coffee and if I have the time, it's always from Blue Bottle. The Hayes Valley location is my favorite. It may just be a small kiosk, but the people are friendly and it's in a cute little alleyway with a small park at the end of it. Great way to start my day.
author: Garrett C.

description:
This is my favorite Blue Bottle location. I love showing up early in the morning on a drizzly day to commiserate with the line of people who don't mind a little fresh air and a small wait for a great coffee. 

Pro tip: order the Gibraltar
author: Lion G.

description:
Oh god. I am one I THEM. I usually turn away from anything the masses who act like they are in the know snobbily call the best. I equally avoid any place with a line of hipsters and/or pointy-toe shoe and blazer wearers in front. Not because I'm better, but because it's tedious. Hell, I have pointy-toe shoes and even know a couple hipsters.  So til Thursday I have avoided Blue Bottle like the ignorant avoid hamthrax. 

I should have tried this coffee sooner. Thursday AM I stopped by (read waited in line 15 mins) the mint plaza location. I had my doubts, then the coffee amazed me. Sooo good. Now it's Sunday and I walked 3 blocks in the rain for a cup of drip at the Hayes Valley location. I am in love with this coffee.  It has a berry after taste. It cost too much. It's not hot enough. It has crack in it. I'm hooked.
author: Ian M.

description: I starting making it a routine to grab my morning coffee from here, since I started working for a new job just blocks away.  My usual order of a soy mocha never fails to impress, and the boys that run this place are super friendly..  I haven't experienced any snobbery from them being a soy drinker; as previous commenters have made mention of..
author: Ty T.

description:
This is my favorite coffee ever! It is individually dripped, i.e., when you order a cup of coffee, they pour hot water into a coffee filter, and that goes right into your cup of coffee.  It takes a little longer to get your cup of coffee (even a latte or cappuchino is faster...)..but it's well worth it for the flavorful awesomeness that you get.

Additionally, there's an experience that goes with Blue Bottle Coffee Co., at least in Hayes Valley (haven't been to any other location, except the Market @ Ferry Building).  The Hayes Valley location is literally coffee out of a garage.  The line extends into the street (it is not a high traffic street, or it would not work so well.)  They have added benches and people can talk and enjoy themselves, and wait for their coffee.

At least one other Yelper posted that you should check if people are waiting to order when you approach the line.  Because of the wait after ordering and before paying and accepting liquid goodness, people tend to hang around...almost where they were when they ordered.  It's okay, it's a good way to start a conversation and such.
author: cyndi t.

description:
Disclaimer: I'm not a coffee drinker.

I came to Blue Bottle Coffee Co twice in one weekend. WHAT? Yeah, really I did. The first time we were so excited but nervous at the same time because we didn't know what to order. I was excited to find out that they serve HOT CHOCOLATE! So I ordered me a cup of hot chocolate for $4.50 (expensive!!). I think I was more excited about the design they make with the foam than the hot chocolate itself. Mine came out with a mini heart, I was quite saddened since I've seen some people with HUGE hearts. Why, Blue Bottle, why?? 

I took a sip of this and OMG it was NOT sweet like most other hot chocolates I've had! For once, I had to add SUGAR to my hot chocolate. Go figure. I was excited that I was able to sweeten my hot chocolate to my own liking and not have a cup of hot chocolate that was way tooooo sweet to sip on. I didn't get a stomachache after finishing this unlike most other hot chocolates.

I tried the New Orleans Iced Coffee, the Mocha and the Latte this past weekend too, and my face shriveled up as I took sips of it because I don't like the taste of coffee. Maybe one day I will, but for now, I feel like I have to chase coffee with something else since it's way bitter.
author: Heidi C.

description: Coffee Mocha my Fav. But I believe others are also good too. I didn't know I love their coffee so much until I came back to LA and I do not want to drink coffees from everywhere except Blue Bottle. I miss it so much that's when I realized the coffee magic of blue bottle put a charm on me.
author: Jude L.

description: I went to the one near the Mint in downtown SF.  What a great place!  The staff are amazing and truly seem to love what they do. One sat next to me during his lunch break and we talked about the company.  He obviously loved it and that said a lot.  And oh yea, the coffee was incredible too!
author: Melanie H.

description:
Delicious. 
Blue Bottle is definitely a great part of Hayes Valley.
The wait is long, so its much better for a Saturday afternoon with friends rather than a break to grab a cup while at work.

I was so happy when I first had Blue Bottle, then I met Phil.
author: Theresa B.

description: Had to see what the hype was all about. Now, I'm not much of a coffee drinker but I have to say that Blue Bottle has the best coffee I've ever had. Sorry, Stumptown, you've been beat. I had an iced cafe au lait since it was a slightly warm day. I enjoyed it very much and wish that they had larger sizes. When I'm in the city, Blue Bottle is my go-to spot. Wish they had more locations throughout the Bay Area.
author: Allison M.

description:
What do the Blue Man Group, the Blue Dog, blue berries, Jet Blue, blue skies, blue eyes, blue moons, blue jeans, blue jays, 'Merican red white and blue, Bluetooth, Blu-ray, aaaaaand Blue Bottle Coffee have in common? 

They all ROCK!

I confess, I'm not part of the 54% of daily coffee drinkers (aka addicts). However I love going to Blue Bottle coffee and getting Bernie's Best apple cider, or a mildy sweet cup of Rechhiuti hot chocolate with the artistic crema. My girlfriend loves the mocha here, and I was amazed at how delectable the espresso shots looked as swirls of coffee and cream billowed to the bottom of the glass, like the foam in a pint of Guinness.

The storefront is tiny and looks like they're squatting in an unfinished warehouse. The long line out front indicates getting a delicious cup of cream and bean is emphasized over ambiance. That's what the park nearby is for. The servers are incredibly friendly and look like they're enjoying the artistry of their brew bottle.
author: Brady K.

description:
Their coffee is good for sure.   Their location is unique but uniquely annoying as well.  

recommendation BB, put up some ropes or spray paint the sidewalk/road to keep the queue organized.  Feeling like you are in an angry bread line in russia does not make most people feel happy and free.

OH and why can't you grid the whole beans for the to go bags?
author: Aus B.

description: The coffee is good but I miss my artificial sweetener.  Sorry
author: James D.

description:
It appears that extremely short Blue Bottle reviews are the thing.

So, here goes.

Coffee in an alley garage...how New Urbanist.  It was hot so I had the New Orleans Iced.  Devilishly rich, yet refreshingly delish.  Is it #1?  No, that would still be Philz.

But I think I'll stop by on my ride to work every once in a while, just because I can.
author: Wes M.

description: The New Orleans iced coffee is so yummy and refreshing on mornings after a hot night of partying. The staff at this location are so much nicer and less stuck up than the staff downtown.
author: Mark S.

description: How can you not love Blue Bottle? I'm not a coffee-drinker, but the New Orleans iced coffee has changed all that.  It's the best if you like your coffee a little sweet and cold.  My husband is a connoisseur and hasn't yet tried one of their coffees that he doesn't like.  It's totally worth the wait in line.  The last time I was there, everyone was getting the Gibraltar.  Not sure what it is exactly, but they serve it in a small glass and it's not on the menu. Looking forward to trying it during my next visit.
author: Julie P.

description:
Blue bottle coffee is rocket fuel.  So much so that even an Au Lait jolted me out of my Sunday lethargy to clean my place.  Bravo!

So far, I've had only Au Laits and Lattes.  Both are in a class of their own.  This is coffee heaven.  Make no mistake about it: the coffee is extremely strong... but it's also extremely delicious.  I look forward to further adventures at this tasteful kiosk where even on a rainy day like today was (imagining that 1:30am is not part of the next day for a moment), the line ran down the corner.  

I have yet to try the much-touted New Orleans iced coffee. When the weather warms up, it will be a welcome experiment.
author: Jaime R.

description:
I often wonder if my love for blue Bottle is due to the amazing reviews or because I really like the coffee and every time I have a cup I'm reminded, no its not the hype its the coffee.

I really enjoy just a simple coffee from Blue Bottle, it is rich, and dark and still manages to be tasty.  

It has me considering buying one of their contraptions and loosing my drip coffee maker.  

Things to note:  
It is located on Linden street which is a small easy to miss street.  

If you have never been to the Hayes Valley location its not so much a store but a stand.  So don't expect to sit down for an hour to mull over your amazing coffee.  They do have some seating next to Blue Bottle and a few seats right in front of the stand.  

Its a few dollars more than a regular cup of coffee so keep that in mind but also remember you are paying for the quality blue bottle offers.
author: Sabine A.

description:
Yes this was the most amazing latte ever! I did not add sweetner which I would normally do. A must go to again and again!!!
Cheers
author: Patricia L.

description:
My friend was raving about how great this place was and how there was nearly always a line of 20 people minimum. So I went with him to check it out, and sure enough, even in pouring rain there was a line of shivering people outside this literal hole in a wall in an alley.

I don't drink coffee so I got a vegan hot chocolate - always glad to find non-dairy options. It was a bit pricey but quite delicious, and nicely decorated with a leaf pattern as the artistic baristas are wont to do.
author: Pax G.

description:
"Hello--how are you doing today?"  

*shudder*

Can you custom slow drip my coffee in the cold, windswept alley of Linden, and make sure it's lukewarm in 5 minutes? 

 You do that anyway? Great!
author: Peter A.

description: Went here over the weekend while traveling with friends familiar with the area. I enjoyed the coffee (cafe latte), it was not sweet, as they don't as additives but there is sugar available for you to add. Since dab Fransisco is trying to be a very green area (which is wonderful),  they used paper cups that became wet (after 30+ minutes) if you didn't drink your coffee right away. Everyone enjoyed their coffee, and location was great.
author: Meghan P.

description:
I came up to San Francisco to look at potential schools and one of my friends said that I MUST visit the Blue Bottle Coffee Co.

This place is super small. It's literally inside of someone's garage tucked away in an alley in Hayes Valley neighborhood.  I am SO glad we woke up at 6 in the morning to get coffee because there was absolutely NO WAIT when we got there.

Yeah, it's pricey, but its soooo worth it.  The New Orleans style iced coffee is a must try... It was ultimate perfection that has graced a biodegradable coffee cup.  It was orgasmically delicious.  And I don't really drink a lot of coffee to begin with, but I would drink that New Orleans style iced coffee everyday if I could.  Yes.  It was THAT good.

I should have bought more bags of the Bella Donovan beans to take back to OC...
author: Christine K.

description: First time to this location in Hayes Valley, a Blue Bottle Kiosk, thought you would avoid the lines.  Well not likely, there's a line here too.  Staff is quite friendly, there's no seating and parking on the streets.  Love the New Orleans Iced Coffee and the Soy Latte.  The coffee is great but the downside is the long lines.
author: Ronald L.

description:
Strong coffee served from a garage, with a perpetual line of hipsters outside. I don't mind calling this emperor out on their lack of clothes; I found the coffee to be wholly unremarkable.

Staff are efficient and courteous. Facility is clean; the "fixin's table" is well-appointed and tidy. Line moves slowly and the wait was always about 5-10 minutes before I could order. On a nice day, it's forgivable, as the garage is on a quiet side street and it's enjoyable to loiter (or "stand about").

For a while, I went here with a friend that was a big fan of the place. I should mention that I prefer rich, smooth coffee (French-pressed medium roast all-Kona) but because of the cost and time involved, you can't find it in coffee shops; you must prepare it yourself. This makes me somewhat particular as to what shops I purchase from, as I've noticed a move towards stronger coffee in the city's non-chain coffee shops over the last two or three years.

I only purchased coffee at Blue Bottle, not espresso, so I can only comment on same. Blue Bottle coffee tastes like a finely-ground dark roast, made with 2/3 the regular amount of water. Aroma is unremarkable; taste is rich and strong without being bitter and over-extracted; it is, however, a little astringent ("gritty") in the mouth. That texture is somewhat unavoidable in strong coffee; cream helps soften it. The coffee seems to be a dark roast, which I don't care for; about the best I can say is that it doesn't taste burned.

The place didn't do anything for me except give me an excuse to leave the rat maze for 20 minutes on a nice day. If you like strong coffee, businesses operating out of garages, and/or hipsters, check it out.
author: Asa D.

description:
Fun little piece of local flavor in the Hayes valley area. Good coffee, cool patrons and friendly staff for an indie coffee shop. And it's all served out of a converted garage with no indoor area to speak of. Great for quality, reasonably priced coffee on the go.

Philz Coffee has a better selection, and Barefoot Coffee (in the south bay) still has the absolute best coffee I've ever tasted. Just saying.
author: Philip W.

description: Blue Bottle has the best coffee ever. It's well worth standing the line to get a sip of their delicious lattes or cappuccinos. They can't be compared to your regular Starbucks or even Peet's. For those who want a taste of high-quality coffee beens and not sugar in their drink, this is a place to get your coffee at.
author: Marienne L.

description:
The chocolate they use in their coffee is completely out of this world good. It inspires those moments where you look at the sky and say, "You know God, I doubted your existence because of the Holocaust, President Bush, and the fact that, though I have a BA from a great school, I'm still unemployed, but when I take a bite of a Blue Bottle chocolate cookie and a sip of my Blue Bottle cappuccino  I think that you might just be out there after all." 

The only minus about this locale is having to wait in a long line outside in the cold. Said minus may not be so relevant when the earth is on it's way to self destruction and we're all wearing short shorts and grade 300 sun block. And when that happens I am sure blue bottle will make a mad good super duper iced coffee...hopefully they'll make a stellar frozen cookie too.
author: Alexandra M.

description:
Seriously wtf? I don't get it
I took my boyfriend here so we could try something new and ended up having to drawn my tasteless bitter latte with sugar
my boyfriend took one sip of the coffee and had to throw it out
then they made me feel like I was a total snob for asking if they could make a "vanilla latte"
Sorry....didn't realize I was asking for much!
author: Kat G.

description: 3.5 cant really appreciate coffee since I dont drink much. I can say that the iced coffee here though was quite refreshing, and brisk. Not too sweet with strong coffee flavor. It seems they use organic products and compost also. Located inside a garage inside an alley, $3.75 for a iced coffee might be a little on the high side,but on a nice sunny day I wouldn't mind getting it again. They also have cookies for $1 which were fresh and not too sweet also.  I think its worthy of a recommendation to the coffee lovers I know.
author: Robert Y.

description: At first sip I thought I wouldn't like it bc I was so used to starbucks and blue bottle was so different. But I soon fell in love with it. Great coffee! My only concern was that there's no decent sitting area to enjoy.
author: Ellen L.

description:
Drinking a bad cup of coffee is an awful feeling. I hate how in most major cities, your only option is to drink Starbucks and it totaly sucks a cheetah's balls.

I've been known to buy a bag of freshly roasted beans from here and there and grind it at home per serving and brew immediately after in our coffee maker.  I'd rather do that than drink Starbucks (ever).  Pete's Coffee is no better.  They're just more sly about being a national chain and the coffee is slightly better than Starbucks.

For a real cup of coffee you have to try Blue Bottle Coffee Co.  They're literally located on a quiet street and they are operating inside of a garage space.  The coffee is creamy and made to perfection.  Every single cup is drip-style and will melt your mind.

For those who have a strong passion for coffee or a nice palate and want the real thing, you must go to Blue Bottle.  

One of the girls who works there totally wants my balls so badly.  She saw me and was all trying to get a piece of this sweet buttery ass but I was like "nah girl, I wouldn't want to make this awkward" because I want to go back here all the time and drink the coffee.
author: Sameer N.

description: Secret alley location = shorter lines than the Blue Bottle downtown. Imagine the latter, but in a secret alley with a big dog bowl of water for all the poochies. They have some pastries too.
author: Laura F.

description: New Orleans Iced Coffee..............BAM!!!! How come you are gone even before I get to the corner? I need a bigger cup!!! I don't even mind I'm paying a little more. What is that magic you are pouring on the ice? I don't care. Just give me some more please. Drip coffee. Ok, time to slow down. Life is too fast. Sit back and relax and soon you will have an amazing cup o joe. Enjoy!
author: Jay B.

description: I just don't get it....how can coffee taste so different, so smooth, so pleasurable.  It's just another league.  The wait is annoying...as they say "all good things come to those who wait".  Hope they don't sell out to the big boys like La Boulange.
author: Greg R.

description:
This review is for their coffee beans, not for the actual kiosk. Although, I'm guessing you can probably buy the beans at the kiosk. I buy the beans online, since I'm not a city-folk.

Blue Bottle's yirg beans are probably the BEST coffee I've ever had. Yirg is amazingly deep and rich in flavor. The aroma after grinding them is awesome, definitely has hints of dark chocolate in there. It's the best part of waking up!!
author: Kathryn B.

description: Love the coffee, love the random outdoor area as well.  Sip the coffee and ponder life.  Love!
author: Jessica L.

description:
Love this place, love the people who serve, love the hidden back alley secret feel... take your coffee, walk up to the park and tell your girl you love her...
perfect...
author: Nathan H.

description:
Dear Blue Bottle Coffee Co., 

I wished I'd never met you... because now I can't stop thinking about you. I can't have another coffee ever again unless it comes from you! What have you done to me... Mochas, lattes, New Orleans Style Iced Coffee. Bastard.

P.S. Whatcha doing later?
author: S K.

description: Worth the wait to get one of the best lattes in the city, and *the* best snicker-doodle. It's also nice to relax in the seating area across the alley.
author: Captain B.

description: The best drip coffee I've had.
author: Steve R.

description: The best lattes in San Francisco...or perhaps the world?
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
I was brought here before heading over to nearby Isotope Comics. Blue Bottle Coffee Co. is an interesting place, operating out of a garage door in an alley. It also had a crazy long line, probably even worse than Starbucks. I was told that the drinks here were amazing and the wait was well worth it.

I ended up ordering a macchiato while the boyfriend ordered a mocha. The macchiato I had was extremely strong. It was as if I got slapped in the face multiple times a la E. Honda of Street Fighter fame. It was really good, though! I needed that since I was in for a long day. The boyfriend's mocha was really delicious, too. Very creamy, bursting with chocolate, and went down smooth.

Blue Bottle, you made my day. Bonus points for the cute heart that adorned my macchiato.
author: Mylene A.

description:
Some of the best coffee that I have ever had outside of Central America.  The coffee is absolutely delicious and the staff is extremely knowledgable and really know their stuff.

I really like the venue with the really high ceilings and big windows.  Don't forget to try the food, cause the grub here is really good as well, particularly the sandwiches and cookies!
author: Hungry D.

description:
Really good coffee and I am soooo picky.  The baristas were friendly and smiled, not like those snobs at Ritual.

Very good pastries and great hot chocolate too!

Very satisfied with the service, a bit expensive, but it's a once-in-a-while treat.
author: Deb J.

description:
mmmmmmmmmmm.......Bella Donavan beans in my press pot. I may have overdosed this morning....Just noticed that I'm barely blinking my eyes.....couldn't stop......it is so delicious!

I buy the beans because I don't have the patience to wait in line.
author: Bleep S.

description: Literally the best latte I've ever had in my life. Smooth. Not bitter. Try the molasses ginger cookie.
author: Julee S.

description: no lines when I wandered by midafternoon, midweek-ish and got a latte.  Didn't realize it was kind of a big deal until now.  It was so good that I sought out another location near my hotel the next day and was really disappointed.  Coming from Portland, OR I have a very high yuppy/hipster/snob tolerance level but their sit down location was ridiculous.  At least PDX can usually do a little tongue in cheek laughing at it's pretentiousness. Let's just say, I almost faced the day coffee-less. Since that is pretty much my main food group, that is a serious insult.
author: Kristine A.

description: Supreme coffee. Love the location which is a hole in the wall, rather, a hole in a garage. Cool location with an efficient crew but be prepared with cash in hand. Also, the efficient crew doesn't take too kindly to the indecisive.  They are pretty pricey. My friend ordered a mocha at $4.75. Great coffee place to experience while in the city.
author: Kim S.

description:
Really, really fabulous drip coffee...

That's really all that needs to be said;)

(lines can be long and parking is a pain in the bum, but all is worth it if you have the time)
author: SLH H.

description:
Upon first sight you think "WHY IS THAT LINE SO LONG????" 

Then when you take your first sip of blue bottle coffee, and from here on out- nothing else will do....you'll be in that line again and again, with a smile on your face anticipating your next sip of this rich, delicious experience in a cup.
author: Beth M.

description:
You have to try this place! My friend took me there and I did not expect that. .. you have to check this place

Got a perfect latte!
author: Lauren C.

description: Best coffee place ever. They really know their stuff, and they serve up some great coffee. I like the one with the chicory, as it reminds me of the coffee we had growing up in New Orleans. If only I still lived in San Francisco...
author: Sean H.

description: Better than Starbucks but doesn't hold a candle to the cup of coffee laced with love from Philz Coffee
author: Ottis M.

description:
I hate to admit that I am the biggest fan of Starbucks, but when I step outside the corporate bubble, this is by far, the BEST coffee that is around the bay area. 

I LOVE this place. I'd been drinking some bitter and acidic coffee at Ritual and Four Barrel for some time now, and Blue Bottle just hits the spot so well. My friend and I had discovered this place on the whim, and it was our best discovery yet. We decided to get some coffee at the Ferry Building, and waited in a fat line; we were both so impressed by how well their coffee tasted. 

I usually purchase soy lattes at Starbucks, and haven't found another coffeehouse that is even comparable to the taste of Starbucks's, but corporate Starbucks has finally met their match. The coffee at Blue Bottle Coffee is really whole-bodied and rich, it is amazing.

I also love that they brew their black coffee on the spot, so even though you wait forever for a cup of joe, it is worth the freshness of the brew. And after you have their coffee, you'll taste the difference between freshly brewed and coffee that's been sitting for almost a good hour.
author: stacy c.

description: Run don't walk and get yourself a cup of Blue Bottle. Probably any coffee drink from here will rock your socks off. I myself get the individual brew. Just a solid amazing cup of coffee. I've also been to the one at the Ferry Building and the line is usually out of control.
author: Anastacia B.

description:
Remember when Buddy (Will Farrell) in Elf walks into the coffee shop that has the sign that says World's Best Cup of Coffee and says, "You did it! CONGATULATIONS! World's best cup of coffee! Great job, everybody! It's great to be here."

This is that place.
author: Joey S.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee is by far the best coffee I have ever had. I have such an appreciation for their drip coffee, cappuccinos, and whole bean blends that I felt the need to write a poem.

"An Ode to Blue Bottle: A Haiku"
Luscious coffee drips
Blue bottle- fragrant, smooth, bold
Brings me happiness

Overall, a fantastic establishment, with great service and a marvelous product. Even my mother, who lives in LA, has a Blue Bottle addiction and orders the whole bean blends online.
author: Nina S.

description:
This is the only espresso in the world that I would wait in line around the corner and down the block for.  
It's so good, I've even ventured from my standby mocha.  For those who are addicts, you would understand that you just don't deviate from your "usual" once you've found that one special recipe that floats your boat just right.  The cocoa they use is just so dang good...no, I have to take that back...there are no words to describe it.
Hands down, the best.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Hidden on what seems to be an alley sits an espresso lover's gem. Blue Bottle is not your typical coffee shop, but a garage-turned concession stand, and people were lined up at the counter to get their fix. 

I'm one who needs coffee with a lot of stuff in it; the closer to a dessert, the better. However, they do happen to make the smoothest double espresso I've ever tried. No taste of charred cigarettes with the "bite" at the end. The mocha I had was some other-worldly magic potion of which I couldn't tell where the coffee started and the chocolate began. Gotta love the extra touch of artistry with the swirling of the milk to create a heart or leaf.
author: nikki s.

description:
Absolutely the most, umm, intense coffee I have ever had. I can usually only drink 1/2 cup at a time before I start to sweat. And, that is exactly the way I like it. Delicious every time. 
Downsides: A wee bit pricey to have daily and the Linden Alley spot staff can be rather aloof. 
Still, I am a fan.
author: reverend d.

description: The cappuccino is absolutely delicious - never had anything better. The counter staff is just 'ok.'
author: Jake B.

description:
Is there anything better than Blue Bottle first thing in the morning? Blizzow! The caffeine hits your blood stream and you're ready to return to the land of the living. A shot of much-needed sanity after long nights of excess and eccentricity. 

I like ordering my coffee "for here" and standing at the counter, watching the neighborhood wake up. Today I discovered the Gibraltar, basically a double espresso with a little steamed milk. RAWR.

These guys are purists, too. No, you may not have a single shot -- we only pour doubles. Fitting that you're located in a back alley. I feel like I just smoked the crack pipe.
author: Nicole G.

description:
I've worked at independent coffee houses for a grand total of eight years.  Both places were some of the highest rated and busiest per sq. ft in all of Arizona.  I feel I've earned the right to truly evaluate other indies in the coffee industry.

BBCC hits it out of the ballpark.  Many of these posts mention that they are not sure of what makes this place so damn good but I think I have a beat on it.

Simplicity.

Do a couple things.  Do them well.  Be stoked that you do them and do them well.  Be stoked that not only you think that you are doing well but the general populace lines up to shell out hard earned cash to vote you've done well with their wallets.  

The baristas and employees see that they have liquid gold here and are actually nice to you.  That is a rarity in the holier-than-thou psuedo-hipsters of coffee house world.  Ordering here is a pleasure in of it self.

The beans and roasting are spot on.  There is not an over roast here and the flavor comes out wonderfully.

They serve in porcelain if you are standing around.  Cardboard ruins the taste of the espresso to no end.  Thank you.

The prices are right on line.  Thanks for not gouging us.

No asinine frapacchinos or any of their ilk.  I like espresso.  I came to get espresso...at most, I may want a small sweet nosh, oh, that is exactly what you have...brilliant.

This is a blueprint for all aspiring coffee house owners.  I've seen it work several times.  I am very glad to see it work for them.

Go...it is worth the wait or the detour.
author: Chris D.

description:
Update:
Dear Grumpy PMers:
I am a native of San Francisco residing in Seattle, so yes, it is MY CITY, and yes, I AM A coffee snob

Hypey McHypeintosh

The first morning of playing tourist in my city by the bay, I tried a french press Blue Bottle at Boulette Larder.

It was good, but not as good as the french press I make at home from Pegasus or Torrefazione beans.

I thought that by going to the source, I would surely reach SF coffee nirvana.

So I grab the huzbeau, who does not drink coffee,  and head on over to the dismally yuppified Hayes Valley.  

Bleech - I think I liked the freeway overhead and the crack whores better, but that's another review.

When we arrive in the early afternoon, the garage door is down.
Yes, a garage door - "hip and cool" and such dontcha know.

There is quite the ruckus of crockery clanking and silverware banging.

MMAD:  (Talking to garage door)  
     Ahem. Hi. Are you open??

"Hip and Cool" BB Coffee Dude: 
    (clank, bang) schnurgle gurgle snort grunt

MMAD: 
     (still to garage door) Hi! Um, Okay. Hi. I came all the way from Seattle to try your coffee.

"H&C" BBCD: 
     (cla-banging suddenly stops) "all the way from Seattle" schnargle grunt snort. Heh. Seattle.

....

....

bang clank clank clank

....

bang

MMAD:
     so no coffee??

"H&C" BBCD: 
     we're closed (bang bang bang)

MMAD: 
     ....
     ....
      uh, um....
      all the way from seattle!!

"H&C" BBCD: 
     (clankety bangety) snort grunt uh, arrh (clunk)
     ....
     ....
     ....
     ....
     ....

MMAD: 
     (still at the effen door) all the way ... I thought that was charming.

"H&C" BBCD: 
     yeah, me too
     we're closed

Huzbeau:
     let's go.

MMAD:
     harumph!!


I am a stubborn lady (shut up) so I returned sans huzbeau a few days later. This time the door was open and I got my drip coffee.

Clankety Bang Clunk
Clunk
Clunk

Line down the block + Oh SO serious baristas + no place to sit and sip does not = San Francisco's Best Coffee.

"Five Star" coffee in San Francisco is only worth three stars by Seattle standards.

I think SF can do better.

Oh yeah - they do:
http://www.yelp.com/biz/OJXTGm0hXBcqV4iJfIpMdA?hrid=VqTGIMwiJjD6eW0eQeRm3w
author: MissMaryAnn D.

description:
I'm into it. This was my first experience with Blue Bottle after hearing about them in GQ magazine. The line wasn't too bad (3 or 4 people in front of us). The drip coffee was delicious - definitely the best I have had in a long time. We waited a couple of minutes for the coffee as they make each batch by itself which was nice.

My dad ordered the Hot Chocolate and scone and said they were the best two he has ever had (he has used this 'best ever' line before, so take that for what it is worth).

I was very impressed and the lack of seating allowed us to walk around Hayes Valley and check out the bookshops and other places. I definitely will return to their sit-down location and buy some beans for home.
author: AJ G.

description:
MOMMY? 

is that you? no really, they should call it coffee boobie cos it's more like the original oral pleasure than being bottle-fed -yes that much better than the other caffeine you can suck down around town.

no parking to speak of, but worth crawling to, babies. put your diapers on and just get there.

once you're there, you won't be distracted by the atmosphere- there really isn't any- Yeah, it's clean and well designed, but hey they're behind a hiked up garage door in an alley.  Be prepared that often you have to join more of a clump than an organized line up to the counter and sometimes the nectar givers are too busy talking to each other or their regular favorites to really notice you for a while, sometimes they're a little snootyboots about whether or not you know that their coffee beans simply can ONLY be ground just before brewing so NOOO they won't grind it for you, but WHO CARES?!  THIS IS THE BEST HOPE YOU HAVE NOW  AT SUCKING DOWN PLEASURE IN PUBLIC  uh

I mean it's uh really good coffee. yeh.
author: Squinka C.

description:
In actuality, this location is 5 stars but in general Blue Bottle Coffee gets 3 stars. . .

I had some time to kill before meeting a friend at Blue Bottle Coffee so I sat in the little park that lines Octavia Street and watched the foot traffic going in and out of Linden Street.  It looked like a scene out of Night of the Living Dead - zombie like masses converging on this little alley street.  They all emerged from the same street bearing cups of coffee and what I mistook for blood lust in their eyes was merely caffeine deficiency (or I guess caffeine Lust).  Everyone left that alley with a little more pep in their step and a look in their eye akin to that of a junkie who has just scored.  

Now, the crack euphemism has been done to death here on Yelp . . heck, I am even guilty of it.  But crack is so much more accessible than, say, heroin 'cause when I think of a crack addict I can picture Whitney Houston in my head (and who can forget her angelic (yet bony) little visage in the "Dance with Somebody" video?) as opposed to heroin which brings up the mental image of John Frusciante in that sad and scary documentary when he was FUCKED UP.  Whitney all peppy and cute vs. John all wasted and wasted.   Anyhoo. . .so this stuff is at least related slightly to crack.  It is really, really good coffee that packs a caffeine wallop of love.  Coffee made with passion and exacting standards.  

So why only three stars?  Well because I have had Blue Bottle Coffee at other venues and if it's not made by their highly qualified and wonderful baristas, the coffee just isn't the same.  Anytime I've had it any where else it's been "meh" it's all right. . nothing special.  

It really is only made well when Blue Bottle employees make it.  But then again, I totally understand why they distribute to restaurants, etc.  While the passion for truly great coffee is there, it's also a business and businesses need to make money.   However, the caveat is that distributing it to other venues lessens the appeal in a way because had I not gone to the kiosk on Linden, I would have never known how truly good this coffee is.  

Also, it's a small world. . . and when you own a company you have to watch your actions as your actions will impact people's perception of your business.  In fact, I hate myself for even liking this coffee but I have to be honest and say that it is damn good coffee as long as you get it from one of their kiosks where it's made by people who most likely will get to know your name and ask you if you want your regular. . try getting that from Starbucks!
author: Lainie L.

description:
Really good coffee at a premium price.
However, it's a long wait behind the euro-trash in line here. During jury duty, I risked contempt of court for this mid-day caffiene fix...worth the wait if you're a trustafarian with an open datebook.

For better or worse, they're so busy being coffee artisans here, they may not notice if you accidentally walk away without paying. I did. They didn't. I returned and did, once confirmed.
author: Andy R.

description:
What's not to love? If you've been drinking the burnt FiveBucks coffee for too long, then you know.  You get older, and you just don't wanna waste any more life drinking dreg.

I appreciate finding the Chiapas at Tacubaya on 4th St. in Berk.  It only tastes supremo when I make an espresso with this bean, regular drip coffee is meh.

I need to make a BBC run, and found that there is a primo chocolatier place somewhere around there, so 2 for 1 !!!
author: Julia W.

description:
Blue Bottle coffee is strong and delightful.  I discovered this place through my brother who probably likes even stronger coffee than myself. I had to come here on Sat AM while waiting on our table at Stax.

Ordered the Gibraltar, which is #28 on the big eat list.  It's basically served in a shot-glass and is like a mini latte that's super duper strong.  I mean after taking two big swigs, I was chatty mc chatterson! 

I like how the shop is in the middle of Hayes Valley next to the custom corset store (wooo-ho) on a small alley way.  The line is always so long, but it moves pretty quick.  The coffee is awesome; had I had a bit more time, I probably would've purchased some coffee beans for my French Press!
author: Jenny W.

description:
In case you don't have enough reasons to go to Blue Bottle, here is reasonably real review #373.

If you are in a bad mood, if you had a really bad yoga class down the street, or you know you can't afford those perfect jeans at Azalea, or Bulo doesn't carry your large(a)ss shoe size, or people aren't looking you in the eyes and you feel disdained... 

There is nothing a latte from Blue Bottle can't do for you in the good 5 to 8 minutes it takes to consume it. Their coffee lifts me up - I think they put crack in it.
author: Holly F.

description:
I wrote one review for Blue Bottle already but, that was for the coffee cart at the Ferry Plaza Farmer Market where the coffee guys are incredibly friendly and nice. 

You would think with all the tourists and impatient locals, complaining about waiting 15, sometimes 20 minutes for a drip (the best freakin drip coffee ever), the Farmers Market Blue Bottle coffee guys would be really cranky but no, they're really cool.

So, every time I go to Blue Bottle on Linden Street in Hayes Valley, the people are not nice.  Is it because I order nonfat milk with my cappucino?  Why the eye roll when I ask for nonfat?   Enough.  If someone says 'thank you', it doesn't seem hard to say 'your welcome'.  

I like manners.  I like nice people.  Being friendly is not lame, it's cool.  

I like the coffee, I don't like the grouch.  That's all.
author: James M.

description:
As far as drip coffee goes.... this is the place!!! Expect to wait a good couple minutes for your coffee. They literally grind the beans in front of you, put it in a filter, add water, and let your cup fill up. They do this same repetition cup by cup. 
The coffee I got was great. I am not a big fan of drip coffee (i prefer lattes) but gave it a try due to a group of my co workers going. They had talked it up so much and I was not disappointed.  The coffee itself was smooth with just a slight boldness to it. I will defiantly be coming back.
author: Wes P.

description:
Cool little spot in an alley.  The latte was smooth and tasted good.  It's a really nice touch that they make a heart out of the foam.

The cafe is street level.  looked like it was a garage that was converted into this cool and modern cafe.

there aren't any seats so you can't hang out there.  it has one little bistro table that you can hang out at, but it would have to be good weather to do that.

The quality of the latte was great at $3.50.
author: R M.

description:
Wannabe baristas stand aside! 

The women and men of Blue Bottle Coffee Co. know what they're doing. They are artists with the espresso machine -- those who appreciate pretty things should order a hot drink and check out the cool designs they make with the froth. Yes sometimes I'm easily fascinated. 

Operating as a street vendor, this area around the kiosk is always bustling with people lined up to get in on some GOOD quality coffee, RAIN or SHINE. The wait can be long but quality doesn't churn out in a second's time. The coffee is fresh, espressos are strong, and lattes are creamy/smooth-- not doused with sweetness like the Starbucks/Peets/Coffee Bean drinks. 

The coffee here is slightly pricey for the atypical poor college student like myself but it's worth it to indulge yourself once in awhile.
author: Stacy Y.

description: Best coffee I've ever tasted and I don't even like coffee.
author: Helen Y.

description:
Let me start out by being absolutely clear that coffee is like oxygen for me...I love the stuff more than is probably right - I am a coffee junkie!

All I need to say about Blue Bottle is that this is where Jesus would go for a latte...it's just that f'ing good. A cuppa from here took me back to the days before corporate coffee was king...Great place and even better coffee.
author: Todd E.

description:
Came here during Capsule. I was a bit irritated with the line at first. A line?! To get coffee?! Plus, everyone in SF crazes over Peet's and I think Peet's sucks. So I was thinking Bluebottle Coffee would be the same. Boy was I wrong! 

I got a latte. It was yummy. The art is really cool and they do it so quickly. And the thing I like most about this place is that you don't need to worry yourself with temperature. They don't steam their milk piping hot like other cafes. They steam it to the perfect, ready drinkable temperature. 

Yum, Yum, Yum.
author: Jen D.

description:
Rue rottle is straight crack off the block.  Cutty alley spot smashed out with graff with a cutty secret yard! holmes. Come get some!!!

Ps shout outs to Jon & Alex
author: Corey G.

description: i used to frequent blue bottle for the 8 years that i worked in the neighborhood....sad that it wont be right near my new job!  love love this place!  their coffee is delicious....americano, drip, new orleans iced (SO good), and lattes and mochas!  theirs are some of the only soy drinks i have tasted that taste like delicious coffee and not soy. love the baristas here too!
author: Diana R.

description:
The drip coffee is spectacular - worth waiting in line in an alley for.  The espresso drinks are equally great, and the kind and indulgent barista taught me how to make a leaf in my cappuccino foam, and that's just super cool.

The only place I know with better coffee than Blue Bottle Linden, is Blue Bottle by the Mint.
author: Joe C.

description:
Why make another review of this little place?  Because it's that good.  What can I say that has not been said before?  Brewed by the cup, it's always fresh.  It's worth a trip across town for me.  A small selection of cookies prepared by Miette are also available.

Tucked away in a little alley, you will not find any chairs, tables, or annoying music.  What you will find nearby is a nice, quiet park to sit, watch dogs, and enjoy the peace.

Next time I'll get a latte ... 4 shots.  

It does not look like beans are available, as I briefly considered buying some for the office.
author: Michael M.

description:
I just moved to SF a month ago and chose my apartment in part because Blue Bottle is right down the street.  Back in DC, I loved my fantastic coffee shop (Murky), and I was hoping Blue Bottle would be something of a replacement.  Accordingly, I've gone at least four days a week in the hopes of starting up some kind of nice relationship.

WHAT IS WRONG WITH BLUE BOTTLE
a two-part series.

1.  The coffee quality is much lower than the snobbish attitude.
The coffee itself is fine--and I guess relatively high for the Bay Area, considering the other options. But aside from the general employee attitude, there's nothing telling you what beans they're using for any drink on any given day.  I understand they may have some uneducated coffee drinkers who don't care, but please, for the rest of us, a small sign would suffice.  It's already insupportable enough that they don't have sizes or other things that make life pleasant for consumers; at least let us make educated decisions about what to order.

In case you were wondering, I *would* like to just ask the baristas what I'm getting, but that's rarely an option, due to the fact that...

2.  The service is bad.
They're busy all the time.  I get it.  But there are simple ways of making customer experiences better even when you're overworked, like allowing customers to pay when they're ordering (thereby increasing facetime and allowing customers to ask questions close to the register, something they may not feel comfortable doing shouting from ten feet away).  It would also help if the baristas spent time with each customer, instead of chatting away with one or two people while shouting at customers further back.    (It would also also be nice to get a glimmer of recognition after the twentieth visit in thirty days, but sometimes that can be asking too much.)

Aside from these two key points, I've had a lot of negative incidents where I've been ignored, brushed aside, made to wait while conversations were finished, and otherwise treated like a particularly obnoxious customer while waiting quietly for my drink.  I can understand this happening once or twice, but as I mentioned, I've got many a time since moving here and their attitude remains the same whether busy or slow, in the morning or near closing, and no matter who is working.  It's puzzling at best and infuriating at worse. 

I'll continue to give Blue Bottle my business since none of the other cafes around me have remotely good coffee. But I wish I didn't have to.
author: timoni g.

description: blue bottle is my favorite coffee place, it's a shame they don't have more around my neighborhood.. but if you're ever in the hayes valley, do definitely stop by. It may be hard to find as it's kind of in an alley, but they provide quality coffee.
author: Howard C.

description:
Ok, so after the yelp talk thread about the best coffee in SF, i woke up Sunday morning with a major jonesing for a good cappuccino.  Accordingly, i hiked all the way to Hayes valley from soma just to try blue bottle because i had to try this place for myself (yelp has never steered me wrong before).  Boy was I impressed!  The cappuccino here surpassed all of my goals, dreams and aspirations of what a coffee beverage could taste like.  It wasn't even the taste that did it; the smell, texture and temperature were all sublime.  I had to pinch myself to make sure i was actually awake and not just dreaming about this perfect drink.  It seriously made my weekend.  I am almost considering selling my soma loft and buying something in the neighborhood - just so i can get coffee at this place more frequently.

Thanks again yelpers... I have now found my favorite indian restaurant (lahore karahi), bloody mary (zeitgeist) and coffee thanks to all of your hard work.
author: D S.

description:
Somebody hand me a steaming hot cup of happy.

This dirty little shack of a coffee place (okay, seriously, it's somebody's garage) serves a fantastic cup of coffee.  After transitioning myself from coffee to tea a couple years ago, I now only allow myself a single cup of coffee on the weekends (because I can't kick it completely).  Blue Bottle is one of the only places in the city that I'll take my single weekly cup.  The cappucino rocks, their lattes are fabulous, and their iced coffee is excellent on a warm day.
author: Diana Y.

description:
I admit it, I'm a total Blue Bottle whore.  I will go well out of my way to experience a Blue Bottle orgasm in my mouth.  In fact, I quite enjoy multiples.

 I don't even really have words to describe how much I love this coffee.  I actually got off the liquid crack for 5 years, and Blue Bottle was the reason I fell off the wagon.  At this point, there's no turning back.  

As for the menu itself, the New Orleans iced coffee is perfect on a warm day.  On the rare days it's cooler/windy in the city (you know, the 360 rare days we have every year like that) the Michael Recchiuti mocha is amazing.  It is the perfect blend of delicious blue bottle coffee beans and semi-sweet chocolate.  These guys definitely understand the importance of great flavor over excessive sugar.  

Blue Bottle, I'll be your bitch any day (and oh, how I am.)
author: Michelle M.

description:
Once you go blue, you never go back.

Seriously, tread carefully. It will ruin you for all other coffee.
author: Chris M.

description:
I'm ashamed to admit this but I am not a coffee drinker. Blasphemy, huh? In a society where coffee is king, I drink the lowly peon...water. My boyfriend is a coffee addict, although not exactly a connoisseur. He'll drink anything. But he did really like his cup from BB and was happy to find a smooth aftertaste rather than the usual bitter. 

I had a cafe mocha ($4.5) and was delighted to see that it and the hot chocolate ($3.5) are made with Recchiuti chocolate. I think BB used to use Guittard's Sur del Lago. Both San Francisco chocolatiers! Also, while we were there, a friendly dog was enjoying his treat and let me pet him. That made my day.

ETA: BB is leading the pack in the hot chocolate wars! Once you get down to the bottom of the cup, you get clumps of actual melted bits of chocolate, and not powdered sludge. So really, it's like a drink AND snack at the same time. Mmm...
author: Nathalie L.

description:
Brought over some friends from Japan and they were just in awe of one of their most genuine SF experiences all hidden away in lil' ol' Hayes Valley.  The baristas used to be artists but decided to become professional froth sculpturers and i just couldn't help but get all caught up in the moment when my friends recieved their drinks and noticed incredibly, meticulous hearts and leaves etched with cocoa-- all we heard for the next 2 minutes was KAWAII!!!

Yeah, props to Aaron I., Jason A. and Jebidiah J. 4 sending the memo on this fantastical Mocha/Soy Latte heaven =)
author: omar b.

description: Best. Soy. Latte. E-V-E-R! I don't even mind standing in a hefty line in an alley. Love the feel, makes my coffee taste a better after standing in the cold haha.
author: Melissa T.

description:
Imagine the scene, I'm 28 years old, sitting in a drafty paper robe on a doctor's table at UCSF.  I've been suffering from migraine headaches and a recent bleeding stomach thing.  The doctor comes in, eyes cast downward, reading my chart, and informs me, matter of factly, that I am ALLERGIC to CAFFEINE!

NOOOOOOO!!!  But, alas.  It is true.
