That's why I appreciate Blue Bottle Coffee Co.  They make a nearly perfect decaf.  Sure, decaffeinated coffee has trace amounts of caffeine, but the bleeding ulcer is worth the roasty-ness.

Four stars because they're often out of decaf, which leaves me feeling cheated.  Stock up on decaf, Blue Bottle!  The sickly and weak among us need a coffee fix, too.
author: Bert M.

description:
I think it's ok to be a coffee snob if you actually serve good coffee. And this is a fine product, proudly serving hipsters their favorite drug from a converted garage (did I see Vespas in the back?) At one point I realized I was probably the only person in the line that did not own a turntable. I kind of wanted to order a "grande caramel frappucino" just to see if anyone's head would explode. 

Loss of star for efficiency problem: don't assume that the hipsters get their coffee before you because they are cooler. My friend's order (drip coffee) was forgotten and she had to muscle through the messenger bags and vintage wool coats to talk to the Wizard Behind the (espresso) machine and get it sorted. 

Espresso = strong and sweet. If the drinks here were like sex, it would be the kind that the next day you feel really satisfied, but also a little dirty.
author: Pumpkin K.

description:
Things I take seriously:

Local businesses: Hookers in Taiwan don't do me any good.
Businesses in alleys: Where else would Mr. Peltzer have found a mogwai?
Coffee: Mess up my coffee and I will shank you.
Coffee culture: The bean breeds revolution.

Bluebottle has the local business thing down. They're the sort of local that has spread all over the Bay, but whatever, they're homegrown. Bluebottle is in an alley...one that the cast of Friends would have hung out in, but an alley nonetheless. Bluebottle holds alchemical secrets to the perfect brewing of coffee. If there was a hotel that charged by the hour right next to this place, I could set up a perfect experience. Also Bluebottle is, at best, ancillary to coffee culture.

Bluebottle has the craft down, but that's all it does...create a product. The story of coffee is about ideas brewing in the minds of caffeine fueled patrons. It's about providing a space for free thinkers and bad art. A little stand doesn't cut it. Bluebottle provides the beans for places that provide the substance. For that, I salute them, but the fifth star is for those who join the cause.
author: Matthew V.

description:
I've been drinking coffee since I was a little kid.  Well, I started with Sanka and moved up.  Surprisingly, it did not stunt my growth.  Or maybe it did, in which case I might've reached my ideal height of 5'10.  Today, I'm kind of ok with being shorter since the professional  beach volleyball career I envisioned for myself back then did not pan out. 

Even though we always had coffee in the house and at Frank's Deli (RIP), it was never fancy coffee.  To this day, my parents enjoy Taster's Choice the most.  When my mom comes out here and I try to take her somewhere notable, she'd rather have those individual packets of coffee already laced with cream and sugar from the Korean market.  While I don't drink it, I find it comforting that she's consistent.

I am a bit more picky about coffee but it's the caffeine I really need.  The taste is almost secondary but I have to admit Blue Bottle is wonderful. The drip coffee, the iced lattes and the doggie treats Ishi enjoyed were great.  Unfortunately, the service is not always so pleasant and I like it better when people are nice to me.
author: Seong P.

description:
freshly roasted, blended, grinded to precision.  loved it loved it loved it.  

I'll be back whenever around Hayes.  :)
author: E P.

description:
Um. YUM. 

I don't know if I have anything else to say. Other than I doubt I would go out of my way to get here. But I sure will stop off when I'm feeling it.
author: Alexis B.

description: The only thing negative about this place is that it will ruin every cup of coffee you have after going here.  Glad to see they are in NYC.
author: Laurence K.

description:
Believe the hype...best damn latte I've ever had.

*update 6/9/06*  The latte was as good as ever but today I discovered the joy of the itty bitty peanut butter cookies that they have.  I'm not a known dipper but I made an exception for this cookie.  Go get yourself one, hell, get two...they're small and you're worth it.
author: phil h.

description:
Coffee is pretty good, but the five stars are for the beans.  Short of roasting myself, these beans are the best.  Yemeni, Temescal, Honduras, who knew I would ever be able to taste the difference. 

Their coffee beans have even prompted us to buy an even better espresso machine just so we could do it justice.  

No wait, the Yemeni, Temescal, and Honduras is awful. Don't buy it.  Get something else instead.  Really.  No, I'm not just saying that so there will be more for me.
author: Tangerine L.

description:
This wonderful coffee brought me back from the World of Tea.  grrrrrrrrr.  Just when I thought that I was not longer drawn to the coffee habit, I found this delicous sweet mellow brew and I am back with renewed lusting for my morning java.  

Since we live in Marin, that means that I have to find some lame excuse to trick my hub into driving into SF on Sats....then it's OBTW as long as we are here, how about going by Blue bottle and grabbing a cup.  

But it is nice to find a wonderful treat that isn't a national overexposed product or teeth grinding bitter.  Lovely Blue Bottle coffee is a treasure.
author: Barbara W.

description:
#28 on the Big Eat SF list

I don't remember seeing the Gibraltar on the menu but still asked for it since I knew it existed. It's very pretty. But VERY bitter (coffee lovers swear by this place. the people who used to live in my apt miss the beans and I'll buy them bags now and then.... too bad i'm not a coffee lover!).....Someone else saw me get it and by looks alone also asked what that was and if he could get it too!

note about finding this place: I tried a few times unsuccessfully when I first moved since I didn't pay attention to hours of operation. When closed, it's impossible to find; it looks like another metal garage door, no labels! I thought I was going insane...When open, there's a board on the corner of Gough & Linden, and from either side of the street you'll see a line (and possibly a few dogs =)
author: S V.

description: This has to be one of the best places to get coffee in SF. Today was the first time I tried the place. Unfortunately the power was out on the whole street, so the only option was the ice coffee. I must say that the ice coffee is awesome. I'm not much of a ice coffee drinker, but this place is an exception. Although it's not a sit down kind of coffee shop, there are benches outside to enjoy your coffee. The customer service is also nice and friendly. Finally, I had one of their gingerbreads, and I would definitely recommend it. In all, I am going to come here as often as I can.
author: Nick L.

description:
Drug addiction is a serious issue, so if you're going to do drugs, do the best. Not only do they brew each cup individually but they GRIND the beans to order as well. The only way I can imagine getting a fresher cup of coffee is if me and Juan Valdez spent the morning picking beans, carefully roasting them ourselves then grinding the still warm beans to make the perfect cup of coffee. And to be perfectly honest, dudes with mustaches just don't do it for me.

Grab some beans while you're there so you can make incredible coffee yourself. Yes, this is good shit. Now if you'll excuse me, I'm going to rub some grounds on my gums.
author: Josua P.

description:
Well Hells Bells! 

I am not a coffee drinker so it's no small feat of Blue Bottle that I immensely enjoy their New Orleans Iced Coffee. It's the only iced drink offered at this little kiosk so, after hearing a succinct description of the beverage, I ordered one. The flavor was both uncommon and uncommonly good, with no ruinous bitter edge.

I think I can give the place five stars based on my appreciation of this one drink, the quick-moving line, the awareness that they use Valrhona chocolate in their mocha and hot chocolate, and for getting to enjoy the blare of ACDC from the shop speakers during my last brief stay in the alleyway.

*Returned yesterday and the New Orleans Iced Coffee was on the house because I agreed to be the taste tester. They were messing around with the recipe which, turns out, was featured in last week's NY Times' Magazine. A messy, long ordeal for the home kitchen, I'd wager.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Five stars for really good coffee - medium roast and strong brew does the trick, people! The bitter sludge at Starbucks is burnt and weak and pretty much undrinkable. 

Five more stars for good design on low resources - the translucent plastic used to finish the Blue Bottle walls is by no means expensive, but works perfectly for a clean Dutch-design look. Once again this proves the point that designed spaces have little to do with the extent of available cash and more to do with creativity and aesthetic sensibility. . . which also explains Hotel Vitale, and the Coi dining room.
author: Liza P.

description:
Cult coffee that exemplifies everything good and bad about gourmet cults: 

* Effusive love and passion for the product   
* An absolute commitment to quality over quantity   
* The experience of being exclusive, in-the-know and above-the-fray   
* High prices   
* All contributing to a certain degree of placebo effect that perhaps amplifies the perceived quality beyond what it would earn in a blind tasting.

The brief menu, a ristretto of its own kind, is a study in extremes: Light roasted drip-to-order coffee, which I found bland, and a double-ristretto espresso that offers the full flavor of the bean. Worth a stop for a fine espresso if you can spare the time to wait.
author: Tom L.

description:
This place just keeps getting better and better everytime I go. 2 words: CAFFE MOCHA. It's like heaven in a cup - it's THAT delicious. I was raving so much about it the other day that my girl friends decided to come and try it out :). Suffice to say, my saturday was complete. 

Because of Blue Bottle, i've become a daily coffee drinker - one that I never thought I'd be since I don't even like coffee all that much. I might even move to the Hayes Valley so I can have this blissful cup of coffee everyday of the week.
author: Jocelle A.

description: This place makes you feel like someone opened up their garage door and serving you coffee on their driveway.  If you are able to find parking, and can wait in line for 10 minutes, then the coffee is really quite good.  Not as strong as Four Barrel, but definitely has some kick.  The foam is done just about right.  Not thin at all.  The flavor will make you happy.
author: Byron L.

description:
Honestly, I'm not that picky about coffee. You might even call my taste unrefined. I do like the coffee they serve here, though, and every time I've been the people have been super friendly. Today I changed my mind about my drink a minute after I'd ordered it, but it had already been made. I said that it was fine, I'd just take it, but the guy insisted (in a friendly way) on making me the other drink instead. 

And maybe I go on off-peak hours, but the wait hasn't been long--I know I've waited much longer at certain corporate coffee chains.
author: Rachel J.

description:
come early in the morning when the alleyway is peaceful and quiet. the mochas here are amazing (for some reason, it tastes better here than their other cafes). be careful not to sneeze from the mocha powder!

after ordering, take a seat and enjoy your mocha at the benches over at hayes square. the scenery is quaint... except for that burning man sculpture? really good conversation starter though!

a sip or two of your mocha should be enough to disguise your morning breath, then you can exchange a few kisses under the morning dew until the sun comes up (i had shoegaze music playing in my head). sigh... (:
author: krys s.

description: Come here 3 times a week...love the mocha! It taste better then Starbucks or Peet's! The only thing I don't like is the long line..
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I never thought I would justify waiting 25 minutes for my coffee, but I have no problem doing that with Blue Bottle. A little hidden shop in the alley way next to the Custom Made Corset Shop (dont act like you dont know the one), I ordered just a small coffee - Small and Super Strong. I dont even add anything to it just because I am crazy like that but also because it tastes good already! 
Reason for 4 stars is for the unusually long lines, Definitely a 5 for those lazy day weekends when all I am doing is spending my day staring at the sky or walking around with my iPod, Blue Bottle is perfecto!
author: Jordan V.

description:
I know my coffee and for me to haul myself from the Marina to this hole in an alley every Saturday morning speaks volumes about the quality of their joe.

 Some come close but none are quite as perfect.
author: Chris Pennington ..

description:
No doubt, one of THE BEST coffee in the Bay Area. 

'Nuff said.
author: Ree S.

description:
This is the best brewed cup of coffee I've ever had.   I could mark them down for the whole process being painfully inefficient, but then again if I wanted efficiency, I'd go to Starbucks.  If you view it from the perspective of watching an artful preparation of the best cup of coffee in town, then the wait is not only worth it, it's part of the experience.

I still prefer Trieste's espresso, but this place has my 5-stars for brewed coffee without a doubt.
author: Val U.

description:
Disclaimer: I've only been here once and have only ever tried the soy mocha so I'm open to trying this place again but....
  
There was waaaay too much soy and too little espresso.  I mean, it tasted like a (very good, cocoa-y) chocolate milk.  Which is cool and all but I really enjoy that caffeinated kick to my mocha.  

I really wanted to like this place, I really did - I mean I heard so many great things about it from those self-proclaimed "coffee snobs." Also, that swirly thing they do on the top of the mocha - a real work of art I haven't seen since living in Portland this past summer.  All that along with the utter devotion the barristas show to their craft...awe-inspiring.  But alas, it did not float my boat. 

Remember, this is just my opinion so please don't come after me Blue Bottle cult devotees!
author: Sonia F.

description:
Excellent coffee & double chocolate chip cookie
Totally made my day!!!
author: Spoon K.

description:
By far one of the best cappuccinos in the city! Having just returned from Italy I can attest to the flavor. Overall we Americans add way too much volume in terms of milk, however Blue Bottle does make a perfectly balanced cappuccino, embellished with the design in the foam at the top. 

Bought some of the whole bean coffee to use at home. Will also try to make a coffee gelato using Blue Bottle beans and Straus milk.  Delicious!
author: Mariangela S.

description:
I just wanted to write a quick review for the folks working here. I live in the neighborhood but have never stopped by because I tend to drink tea instead of coffee. However, my girlfriend requested I go buy a few bags of beans for her relatives as presents. I swing down there and they're very nice about giving me cards explaining how different drinks are made and which beans they sell. When I made my decision the total came out to $22.00. Having never been here I didn't realize they didn't take cards. I pulled out the $21.00 in my wallet and told them that I was a little short and needed to run to an ATM. Both baristas started saying 'no no it's cool, don't worry about it!' So they spotted me the extra buck and I was on my way.

Although it's a small gesture, I'm still a big fan of good customer service. So 5 stars for being nice guys.
author: Rob D.

description:
This is San Francisco's hidden coffee gem! It has all the features to make it a place to tell your friends about: 
- it is hidden in obscure alley
- it has very little advertisement, so you need to KNOW about it to find it (makes it perfect to be INTRODUCED to your friends)
- has best espresso in the city (that's what I get here, but I hear all the other drinks are great as well)

Also highly recommend their NOT ON THE MENU special - Gibraltar
it is similar to capuchino, but with different proportions tied to the certain type of glass - Gibraltar glass. Can be ordered only "for here" cause it comes only in Gibraltar glass. Isn't this fun?! 
In the way, if you order Gibraltar it makes you the INN crowd...
author: Terry A.

description:
don't get me wrong the coffee is great but could you charge anymore??
$13.50 for enough coffee to make 2/10 cup pots! sad- online I can get the same peaberry indonesian coffee beans fresh roasted with free shipping in a 5lb bag for $34.66.
Also went to buy a bag at Cibo in Sausalito and their fresh roast coffee on Feb 4th was roasted on Jan 27!!That's fresh to you huh?
author: SJ O.

description:
Wow.  What a difference a month and a half makes.  Typically I'd only update a review after a couple of return visits - so as to be ABSOLUTELY sure, but I was so utterly blown away by the change in tack on my visit to Blue Bottle today that I couldn't wait.

Long queue, as per usual.  Fine.  But man, did it move.  As did the staff.  Friendly and fast, they took orders and executed the drinks as if they were on a mission.  Then the cherry: once I'd been served my drink, they thanked me for waiting!!!

Probably both misguided and egotistical of me to think for a second that my cantankerous last review had anything to do with any of this, but they seem to have corrected the one thing that gave me cause to gripe.

Well done, BB.  Five stars indeed.
author: David K.

description:
Tastes like it was made in a garage.  I've never licked the floor of a MUNI train, but I imagine the flavor to be similar.  Did I order a mocha or dirt mixed with lukewarm water? Sweet jesus, I want my 5 bucks back.

Two stars because I wish I was hipster enough to appreciate it.
author: Katie H.

description:
How to Become Tragically Hip in 3 Easy Steps:

1. Make your way on Some Sunny Sunday morning to Blue Bottle Cafe in Hayes Valley.  
2. Wait patiently in line for your brew.
3.  Let all that caffeine goodness flow from your oral orifice into your pleading soul.  Repeat as necessary.  And try not to become overly addicted.

Seriously, I'm giving it 4.5 stars but rounding up to 5 "just because".  There are a few caveats, of course:

- You've gotta like (no, LOVE) coffee.  'Cuz that's pretty much all they serve here, 'cept for some hot chocolate and cookies.
- You've gotta like said bev-er-Ahge hot, dark and flavorful (y'know, like some people like their.... soba....)
- You don't mind searching for a parking spot and then hanging out on some Hayes Valley side street.

And seriously, who wouldn't?  Damn, I felt my Inner Kool Kwotient kick up about 5 notches just by breathing the same air as some of these SoHo BoHo types.  Never has the "just-rolled-outta-bed" look been more perfected.  I swear, even some of the DOGS milling about were having a BHDWA (Bad Hair Day With Angst).  

Jokes aside, it really felt like I was kicking it on some side street in Copenhagen or Amsterdam, marveling at the wondrous smells wafting from this virtual garage.  The demographic was a serious sub-set of caff-inators (great people watching material), the service was brisk, they had the wherewithal to serve their concoction in actual ceramic cups AND saucers (for those who choose the "for here" option), and the local park for hanging out was just a stone's throw away, to wile away the hours and read the Sunday rag of choice.  Oh, and BTW, Hayes Valley is without a doubt a haven for all things hip.  Where else could you find a corset shop next to a coffee bar? And any 'hood that has a place like Stitch Lounge automatically hits 10 on the Kool Meter.

My two cents?  The coffee's crucial.  A tad on the strong side.  But really crucial. In a good way.
author: James O.

description:
Over 250 reviews so I'll keep it short.

This may be some of the best coffee/espresso in San Francisco but this place is definitely not the high temple of the coffee world. I can only give that to Espresso Vivace in Seattle so far:

http://www.yelp.com/biz/9TYB0ZcWzYK3E5MiyKzGvA

I'm thankful that this place is here but can't give it 5 stars. Brag-worthy in San Francisco but not outside the Bay Area.
author: Shawn T.

description:
I've been a regular @ BB for over a year and some change. Ultimately the best coffee I've ever had. But I think what makes it better is the community at BB. The people that I've met there are truly a unique group that have touched my life in so many ways. This is no Starbucks (thank GOD) or Peets and that's why I go. Don't go there if you want your Grande Caramel Macchiato no whip in less than 5 min. Instead, order a Gibralter (not on the menu) and strike up a convo. with someone in line or maybe with one of the FABULOUS baristas. Yeah...  the people behind the bar are really cool and interesting. Some have come from all over the country and landed at the Kiosk and the other half are locals. 
So I urge you to go, order your drink,be patient, socialize and enjoy your cup of perfection.......it's an experience.
author: Erin L.

description:
i really liked the coffee (drip) and the mocha. the coffee was very smooth, low acidity but full bodied, which i like. the mocha was also very smooth and tasted perfect, not too sweet, and not bitter. i liked the ambience as well, will definitely come here more often. 
oh, and the people who work here are the best! one of them actually told us that if we like good coffee, we should check out another coffee shop that has recently opened, even though they are their competitor :D and she gave us the name of a few good places around the city.
author: Arezou K.

description:
Best place to really enjoy the taste of blue bottlle.

Its on a different level than Blue Fog no Green street.
author: Peter G.

description:
Amazing Blue Bottle, how sweet the taste, 
That saved a wench like me! 
I once was lost, but now am found, 
Was sleepy, but now have coffeeeee.
 
'Twas work that forced my heart to sulk, 
And boredom my soul gripped; 
How precious did that sweet latte appear, 
The minute it first was sipped! 

Through many dangers, toils and snares, 
We have already come; 
'Tis Blue Bottle has brought me sane thus far, 
And will still lead me home. (Where I will curl up in a fetal position...) 

Blue Bottle hast promised good to me, 
Its beans my hope secure! 
It will my strength and portion be, 
as much as this paper cup endures. 

When we've been here ten thousand years, 
Straight wired like a score, 
We've no less days to sing Blue Bottle's praise 
At its metallic garage door.
author: Carrie R.

description:
The quality of the coffee is fantastic although slightly over-priced compared to the sizes you'll receive at Roger's and Phil'z for single drip. I really dig the atmosphere and Linden street rogue coffee stand vibe that is evident, even though they are obviously established. 
Very full, drinkable and bold coffee. It comes a little on the warm side, as often is the case with single drips.
recommend.
author: Jeff S.

description: mmmmmm blue bottle new orleans coffee.  I guess what they say is true, its one mighty fine cup of ice coffee.  theres no other way needed to describe it.  the flavor is there, the precise amount of sweetness.
author: Vincent K.

description:
Why must I purchase the best coffee in San Francisco standing in an alley, shifting from foot to foot, surrounded by dubious mooks like I'm buying stolen suits out of a truck terminal from Robert DeNiro in Goodfellas?

Can we get a freakin' coffee house around this operatioin so we can have somewhere to sit and savor your precious liquid of the Gods?  Please?  So I don't have to drink this out of nasty paper?  Please?
author: Kevin S.

description: Delicious, as always. I love having a Blue Bottle in my neighborhood, and the location is really unique. There isn't anywhere to sit except a bench or two. I wish there were a few outdoor tables.
author: Geena B.

description:
I like to think I'm a discriminating coffee drinker, and well, I've only been to Blue Bottle (Linden St) once, and what I got was a cappuchino, which was disappointingly lukewarm and rather on the bitter side.  Well you can see where I'm headed:  I hate to disagree with the throngs of five-stars but --- this place didn't do it for me.

I hear your shocked gasps, now comes the gut-punch:

I think what makes this place popular is its over-the-top hipster "cool" factor. .... In other words, the "trendy = good" crowd loves it.   But if it would make you feel really special to wait 10-15 minutes in line just so you can say you buy your coffee from a ramshackle stand set up in the corner of furniture warehouse in an alley off of Gough in Hayes Valley, well, then this place is for you. 

Sorry folks. 

(BTW Is Yelp dumping together reviews of several different locations here?  Doors?  Farmers Market?  East Bay?  Come on, can we localize please?)
author: Steve O.

description:
If God challenged Blue Bottle to a coffee making competition, God would lose. It wouldn't even be fair. I can't even begin to understand how those barrista magicians do it. All I know is, they put euphoria in a cup. And then you get to drink it. Unreal. 

Remember that scene in Office Space where those dudes drag the printer out into a desolate field and beat the shit out of it with a baseball bat? Remember thinking to yourself 'God that must be the most amazing feeling ever?!' Yeah, well imagine drinking that feeling. That's Blue Bottle.
author: Tom C.

description:
I was excited to try this place and finally did at the Encapsule street festival. The coffee was good, but nothing like people had raved about.  

The line was so long (to be expected during a festival) that we decided to puchase a bag of beans, so we wouldn't have to stand in line again.  

When we asked what was being brewed the barrista had no clue (um, isn't that her job to know?) and recommended a roast. When we got home we were a bit disappointed in the bag of beans flavor. We were so dissappointed we threw it  away half empty.  To be fair, we currently use a blade grinder and just ordered a burr grinder, so hopefully that will make a difference for next time.

Update 7/2/07:
Bought another bag of coffee and one of the Beehouse drippers that they use at the Kiosk. The burr grinder made a huge improvement on taste and the dripper works well, but it's hard to get rid of the rude aftertaste of the barrista's out of my mind.  With coffee there's a lot to be said for customer service.
author: Kim S.

description:
So everyone says that if I'm addicted to Philz, I need to try Blue Bottle.  Ok fine, I drag my sister along on a Saturday morning to give it a try. 

We pull up and apparently it's located at a homeless shelter.  Oh no wait ... that's just all of the hipsters.  Disregard.

The coffee itself is better than average; however, it is not as good as Philz.  I gave it a try but I won't be coming back.
author: Ankur P.

description:
Blue Bottle coffee is hugely successful, they have lines down the alley constantly, and people will wait for half an hour to get a latte - and they have accomplished all this success even though they don't always give the customer everything they want. How is this possible? Because they actually care deeply about the quality of their product more than they care about honoring every silly request made by every customer who walks up. For this, they often get accused of being snobs, and I think this is just sad. What a shame that anyone who is not willing to compromise quality to please the masses is seen as arrogant. You can't both admit that the coffee is good and then fault them for doing the things that make it good, people.  What to know about Blue Bottle before you go:

1) Yes, the wait can be long. Don't come here if you are in a hurry. There are plenty of other coffee places that can give you quick. Blue Bottle gives you delicious.
2) They don't have flavors or silly ice cream drinks masquerading as coffee. 
3) They will not grind your coffee. If you don't have a coffee grinder and are not wiling to spend $15 on one, take it to the grocery store and grind it there.  These guys are serious about freshness. They don't sell coffee beans more than 2 days after it was roasted. 
4) There are no chairs or tables or wifi. They don't have a lot of pastries. This is not a cafe, it is a coffee stand.  If you want to sit and hang out, go somewhere else. 
5) You should try the ginger scones. They are pricey, but worth it.
author: Claire B.

description:
Apparently if you order one little teeny ass coffee drink in the little prissy cups you hold with a pinkee up you can just do whatever the fuck you want when you want another. Screw the line! In my completely ridiculous 10 minute wait for a fucking... deep breath... drip coffee... I had one extreme sandal and black sock wearing yuppie start-up douche and two Crate and Barreled old queens jump the line and go right back up to the counter because " They simply MUST have another! Ohhh!" 

This aside from the massively insulting displays of favoritism from the prick staff in the swaths of american appareled masses makes this place just about as much fun to wait in line in as Ritual is if not worse. No coffee is worth this wait, and quite frankly I feel anyone dumb enough to stand there for up to 20 minutes isn't there for the coffee anyway.

This city is becoming a scene that is at times just too hard to stomach.
author: Farallon Living I.

description:
i gave up coffee about 5 years ago.

i went totally overload during high school and at the beginning of college where even with 4 shots of espresso - nothing. A large cup of everyday at starshmucks got expensive and ridiculous. so i cut it (including all other forms of caffeine) out of my life and only drank hot chocolate or ice water. i then became a social coffee drinker, but every time i'd have the smallest cup, my hands would start to shake and i wouldn't be able to sleep. my rule then became caffeine only before 12PM, but then a friend introduced me to this place, i ordered a cup of cappuccino... and now i crave the delicious aroma of fresh brewed foamy airy smoothness of comfort. this place is only a couple blocks away from my work, and i sit at my desk wondering, "i can make it there and back in 20 minutes..." but do i want to return to those dark days again? ooh so tempting.. but you know what.. in the great words of Janet Jackson, " Cause it's all about control ...And I've got lots of it."

thumbs up: the coffee, care in every cup, great for grab and go
thumbs down: a coffee shop in a garage.. i just hope its not illegal and forced to close.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
I'm the 440th reviewer for BBCo..

Nothing new to say here~  only to just add to their already wildly large fan base!!

I had my first Blue Bottle cup of drip coffee last week at the BBCo kiosk  at the SF Ferry Building Farmer's Market (located next to the right entrance doors, outside of the building). Very creamy and quite possibly the smoothest cup of coffee I have ever tried. The taste was bold and distinct, without the usual acidic aftertaste many people are sensitive to. 

Fantastic coffee/espresso shots. Super service and friendly helpful staff. Definitely a joy to visit on weekends!!
author: Elaine T.

description:
Blue Bottle is another one of those "Look what opened since you left, schmuck!" establishments that I got to experience last weekend. Hell, I didn't know Blue Bottle even existed, until my buddy (or my former ultimate Scrabble foe at Farley's) brought me here because he knew how much I appreciate a great cup of joe.

The whole working-out-of-a-garage-in-a-Hayes-Valley-alley seems more New York than San Francisco for some reason, but it works. I didn't mind the line. Maybe it was because it was a Saturday afternoon and I was in no hurry to get anywhere. I didn't feel humiliated at the counter either - which seems to be a consistent gripe among many Yelp patrons. My barista was friendly and not condescending in the least. She looked tired, yes, but that was about it.

My soy latte was a work of art. Yeah, yeah, the whole latte art make a leaf in the foam thing is cool, but they managed to do foam with soy milk that I've never seen anywhere else. The taste was amazing. So many baristas are half-hearted or unknowledgable about making good soy drinks, that it's hard not to be impressed. This seriously might just be the best soy latte I've ever had. 

We stood there by the counter and shared our little open-air ledge with a few other strangers and slowly appreciated our coffee. 

So the place isn't somewhere where you plop your butt down for hours so you can stare into your laptop. Who cares? There's enough of those joints in the City. You're outdoors, for the love of naan from Shalimar. And at least on this Saturday afternoon day, the outdoors were amazing. Sunny sky, cool and crisp.

Disclaimer: I've been gone long enough that I don't even know what standing in cold, fog and rain are anymore. Move me back and I might be writing a different review.

5 stars. No complaints.
author: Mr K.

description:
Yea Yea Yea...I know
Since moving to the city from Seattle I have noticed that certain places have a ridic amount of reviews, but this is my morning coffee shop and therefore I feel entitled to Yelp about it....plus I feel I have enough coffee cred to do so as well (I did live in the Emerald City for three years).
I stick with the Drip or Americano....nice, consistent pulls, fair crema, and perfectly adaptable to my cream and sugar explosions.  There is occasional barista eye candy and at other times there is straight up rude attitude, but I can take most anything people can dish.
Oh and the little peanut butter cookies from Miette....little bites from heaven...I swear God endorses both BlueBottle and Miette...yep...simultaneously!
author: Sheila Y.

description:
During pride I did my solemn duty as a gay and hit up the Castro during the chaos that is Pride Weekend.  I quickly found myself in the only Castro bar that I frequent - Lucky 13.  Okay, so it isn't really gay in the strictest sense of the word, but they ARE in the Castro, so you've got to give me that.

Amid the free popcorn, good tunes and generalized merriment emerged Drunk Steve (aka Hipster Steve).  I had been playing the "stare at you to figure out if you are the only other queer guy in here" game with Drunk Steve for a while until he finally told me to make sure I say hello before I leave.  On my way out I said hello and Drunk Steve slurred "I want to get to know you, I'll give you the best blow job of your life."

Well, that guaranteed a date.  We exchanged numbers and a few days later arranged to meet for coffee at Blue Bottle.  A wise decision as the only things I knew about Drunk Steve is that he gave good blow jobs.  Considering that Drunk Steve could have also been a psycho/murderer (good blow jobs non-withstanding), I decided to meet Drunk Steve in typical craigslist/internet dating style, somewhere public and with easy escape routes.

Blue Bottle's alleyway location seemed perfect for my needs.

The macchiato (the coffee with which I judge all coffee shops) was overextracted and far too bitter.  Also, my barista overfilled my tiny mug with milk giving me a sticky saucer.  Perhaps my expectations were high, but I've had better coffee in lots of different places.  I will try again as per the excessively good Yelp reviews, but another bad coffee and it is gone.

Pros: Drunk Steve = Not a Murderer!
Cons: Still haven't found out about the "Best Blow Job Ever"
author: Mat K.

description:
Would it live up to the hype?

This is what my friends and I wondered as we took a quick detour from our scheduled 7x7 drink crawl tour. We were a few drinks in and thought, hey, the Blue Bottle Gibraltar, recommended as something to try before we die, would give us a nice jolt to carry us through the rest of the day.

We were not expecting to be struck by lightening! 

The Gibraltar is not on the posted menu, but just ask for it. The little shot glass couldn't pack THAT much of a punch, could it? Um...why, yes, yes it could. It was a little more bitter than I would have liked, but I didn't want to admit defeat and go get a little sugar. That would have made it perfection to my taste buds.

I do not recommend having this in the afternoon unless you enjoy being wide awake, still, at 3am.
author: Annie F.

description: I forgive the pretentious baristas cause the product is just too good.
author: Dan H.

description: I don't know if it's the experience or the coffee -- or most likely the whole milk they use in the cappuccinos, but I love this place!! I also like most of the fruit-cake places that they distribute their product to (pizzetta, ferry bldg, etc..) and I think that a blue bottle cappuccino in one of their little brown cups (complete with the heart-shaped swirl) sipped while sitting in the sun on the sidewalk of the Linden is heaven... pure heaven.
author: C'est La V.

description: Come here every single time in SF.  Absolutely my favorite coffee, if you like coffee, go here, now.
author: Adam N.

description:
Oh so good! The first time I went I was a little overwhelmed, long line, no idea what to order, fast paced... I was lost. Despite my mess of an order the coffee was so amazing! I have been a loyal consumer of their delicious blends ever since. 

The staff there are great, but it's a fast moving Kiosk so know what you want and be sweet. Not only will you get a perfect cup of coffee, but the foam art is exquisite!

I'm 81/2 months pregnant and haven't been able to partake in my caffeinated love (The Gibraltar or MMmm their Soy Latte.) Oh how I miss them so. Yay only 2 more weeks and I'll be back!
author: Jessie J.

description:
There are few things in life that money cannot buy. I'm so glad this is NOT one of them.

LOVE YOU BLUE BOTTLE FOR ALWAYS BEING THERE FOR ME WHEN I NEED YOU. 

I HEART YOU
author: Shriya J.

description:
I like to find any excuse to go to Hayes Valley just to come here.  Best latte in the city.  No question.  I wasn't floored by their drip coffee though.  Don't shoot me, I'm just saying.  The line can be super long in the morning, so that cup of coffee on your way to work might take you a good 20 minutes.  

This place also has something that looks like the set of the New Yankee Workshop right behind it, so the coffee might absorb some of the wood flavor.  Mmmmm.  Pine.
author: James M.

description:
Whoa.  Yeeeee-uhhhhm.

I came here for the first time not fully knowing what to expect other than hearing from a friend how tasty the joe is and from reading a handful of uber-positive Yelp reviews.  Oh man, frothy goodness!  This place blew my bobby socks off!!  If you consider yourself a coffee connoisseur, then this is THE spot for you to check out in SF.

Also noteworthy:  Get the peanut butter mini cookie treat!  It's a perfect compliment to a frothy cappuccino.
author: Katie C.

description:
the original Blue Bottle location, a quirky charming spot toward the corner of an alley in Hayes Valley which in itself is a fun little neighborhood treasure trove. .. it's kinda like Cheers where everybody knows your name. .. can't believe this is where Blue Bottle Coffee's lovely beginnings all began. .. 

+ :  good coffee. .. Snickerdoodle that is fancy with saffron and Tahitian vanilla. ..

- :  wrapping lines into alley street. .. cup at the Ferry Building tasted better. ..
author: Y I L I W.

description:
There's no arguing with BB's quality coffee. It's one of the few brews I can actually drink black (though I don't). 

Love the science project-esque displays in their downtown location. 

But their brews are strong, so prepare to get wired.
author: Christina S.

description:
Had one of those individually prepared drip coffee's from the Blue Bottle, which was quite good, however, really tested my short patience.  It was a Thursday morning around 11am, so it wasn't exactly busy, (2 couples in front of me), and it still took about 15-20 minutes to get my fricken caffeine fix!

I got places to go, people to see.  Get the coffee beans to go, and pour some hot water over it at home!

*******

the New Orleans Iced coffee is very good.
author: shaun l.

description:
Hi can I help you?

Yes I'll have your house crack, errr, I mean your house drip.

this place makes hand made, made to order drip cups of coffee...very strong and very good!

I also like their New Orleans style iced coffee drink with soy.

sue me I'm lactose.

Update:

Service with a smile!  these guys rock!
author: A P.

description:
I missed this place when I visited SF...literally! I tried to find it and walked right by! 
I found the infamous hole in the wall earlier this week and it was definitely worth the wait. Best coffee I've had since I left Seattle.
author: Esme W.

description:
Best coffee I have found in the Bay Area so far; when I come home from a trip abroad or Fresno for that matter, this is the first place I come; good solid drip that doesn't require cream and sugar; espresso that is life altering...and their Hayes Valley location is around the corner from the best comic book shop ever (AND right  next to a pretty groovy yarn store...what more could you need!)
yeah, the uber-cuties behind the counter can have 'tude, but whatever, I'm not there to get my ass kissed.  They know their stuff and if you ask they will share their knowledge.
author: tanuki c.

description:
Hesitant to jump on the bandwagon, but these folks have served me (consistently) the BEST coffee I've ever had. The lattes are picture perfect, literally. The barrista takes the time to make those milk foam patterns on your cup. But they're not just pretty--they're delicious!

Their lattes are never too bitter. It has a delicate, almost chocolately taste to it. The perfect balance between milk and coffee. Also, they don't blast it with too much heat--I have no problem drinking it right away. No burnt tongues here!

Their iced coffees are also great. A hint of chocolate, chicory, and cinnamon. Cold-brewed so it's never too bitter or acidic.

Walk here, get a few Miette cookies to go with your drink, and enjoy the bamboo or the Hayes Valley green. :)

My only reservation with this place? No seats! Lines! It's probably for the best.... otherwise I might never leave. A little sad to read the stories below re: cranky barristas, so I really hope that was more an exception and not the rule. Maybe I've just been lucky?
author: Richie K.

description:
Best. Espresso. Ever. (and hot chocolate, and everything else).

I wish I lived within walking distance. I would get my espresso there every day. If only they had to-die-for pastries to go with the espresso, I would be in heaven.
author: Lauren H.

description:
Generally, If a place have 9 zillion reviews, I'll take a pass, but when I saw a three star rating for Blue Bottle, I felt compelled to write a review.  

Blue bottle represents some of the best American style coffee.  Lighter than its European brethren and supper caffeinated.  

I have never had a bad cup of coffee here.  Constantly good is important when I have to walk 10 blocks from the office for a coffee.  The service is good, the Baristas care about coffee, and the customers seem to care about the product being served.

Why not five stars?  There is no seating, the lines are a pain, and its in the middle of nowhere.  That said, if you want a consistently good cup of Joe, this is the place.
author: Anthony K.

description:
Yeah, it's good, yeah it's served in a shady backalley in Hayes Valley out of some guy's garage, yeah you'll feel a little cooler for having had a cup. Be sure to bring your skinny jeans and artistic sense of disillusionment.

Oh yeah, and there's little rhyme or reason to the order in which they serve you. Since they make every cup of drip from scratch, it's anyone's guess as to when yours will arrive in this world.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Holy crap.  I was warned this might just be the best coffee ever but WOW.  A friend of mine was raving about it, so I decided to set out on a Sunday morning to find this coffee shop that looks like it was set up out of someone's garage.  It was hard to find, it's on a small side street between Gough and Octavia.  Just drive down Gough and keep an eye out for it - it's near that restaurant Absiente a block up on the opposite side of the street.  There are only one size fits all here, and it's $2 dollars for drip coffee...about $5 dollars for a latte.   It reminds me of the great coffee that you can find in Europe.  It's amazing.  You don't even need to add cream to your drip coffee.

**warning ** This is not a "small -half decaf - half skim - soy latte" kinda place.  They will laugh at you and tell you this ain't no Starbucks.  But trust me.. that's a good thing.
author: kimberly k.

description:
I'm being told (by sources in-the-know, on the couch next to me) that I'm giving Blue Bottle a whole five stars because I'm "obsessed."

This is probably true.  I haven't found better coffee in the city, though.  Driving down to the tiny alley in Hayes valley, and waiting for my drip coffee (amazing) or my latte (incredible) is a ritual I savor.  

A note of warning:  habitual visits may expose big-chain joe for the swill it is...

A note of deliciousness:  You can also find BBC setup with a booth on the south side of the Ferry Building during Farmer's Market.  But save some for me.
author: Rob W.

description: Blue Bottle changed my coffee life. I now compare all other coffees to Blue Bottle and that means most other coffee tastes awful now. I love you Blue Bottle. So much. I buy you for home brewing and I go out of my way to purchase you way too often.  So smooth, not bitter, just perfection. The perfect start to my day.
author: Rachel P.

description:
Worth the wait (if there is a line)- Yes.
Eye candy behind the counter? - Yes.
Good location- Yes.

If you are an avid ice coffee drinker... hit up the New Orleans coffee. It's the best you will ever drink on this side of the coast. Seriously. 

Sighs, I miss the guys that work there already. Always made my morning struggle worth the 1+ mile walk. Also, the history behind this specific one is pretty rad considering what it used to look like. ha.
author: mister b.

description: Mighty good rocket fuel for a compliment fairy.
author: Compliment Fairy F.

description:
Am I missing something here? It was an OK cup of coffee. We did get through the long line in the cold quicker than I thought, but it still wasn't worth standing in line. The customer service wasn't that friendly or educational. My friend and I both left disappointed.

After reading some reviews here on yelp, maybe I should try something a little more fancy next time.
author: Melissa A.

description:
I kind of feel like they can get the Dillz.

I'm split right down the middle about these guys because, yes, while their coffee is sooooooooo dang good, I don't feel that it warrants an attitude.

I understand that the Barrista is a really cool guy. I understand that he's able to sculpt his moustache to perfection and drape his keffiyeh just so. 

 I can even kind of understand that my drink request is not on the menu, and they don't do anything not on the menu as a matter of policy, if that is the issue.

Or whatever.

But he didn't have to snicker.

He didn't have to be so prissy about it.
author: sofia p.

description: This coffee is overrated and or maybe it's just not how I like my coffee to be drip in the cup since it's always not warm enough for me. I also hate waiting in line for just okay coffee in which may take half an hour.  I don't see the hype, taste like their coffee is just average, the only difference is that they just seem to drip it in a cup (OoOoo) instead of brewing it.  No thanks, I drink coffee everyday and can brew a better cup of joe myself.
author: Reviewer Y.

description:
My friend took me here for coffee. I don't like this place. I don't like coffee, except for maybe an iced one on a hot day.
The concept is good, i guess, a stand for people who want coffee to go, but something rubs me the wrong way. 

It's in an alley way far from anything, this is a good thing.
author: wayne s.

description:
OVERRATED.

word. i get it. love dank coffee, but this spot can be such a freaking scene, filled with thirty-year-olds holding little dogs on a leash, talking about internet gossip on their iphones. 

i guess it's just the hood and i'm glad the spot's raking in cash hand-over-fist, but if i walk by and see the line has more then 6 people in it (which means i'm going to have to stand around that scum for ten minutes) i'll probably go and get perfectly passable from any of the other cafes in hayes val.
author: Henry G.

description: Great for coffee lover.  There is usually a line.  There is no seating.  It is a grab-n-go type of place.
author: Ka P.

description: The BEST COFFEE and I am a picky biyatch when it comes to my hot, steamy, dark and mysterious drug of choice (and I still mean coffee here).  I discovered their beans when dining at Slanted Door and am totally hooked.  I'd mainline the stuff daily if I lived in Hayes Valley.
author: Julienne G.

description:
Love in the form of a latte.

Fortunate enough to be staying with friends who live mere blocks from this blessed caffeine peddling garage, I had the pleasure of enjoying Blue Bottle during a recent weekend visit.  Although my family is staying on the Embarcadero during our trip to SF later this summer, I'm already plotting out how many times I can go back in those 10 days.  A girlfriend claims that it was Blue Bottle that sealed the deal on her move from DC to SF.  Now that I've tasted it, I will admit to pondering the same thing...
author: Diana K.

description:
One of two destination coffee houses in The City, Blue Bottle has dramatically improved the consistancy of their roast since bringing in a new roasting machine, making Blue Bottle arguably the best beans produced in the Bay Area (though I am still a Ritual fan for the luxury of their cappuccinos).

Blue Bottle has made me start to hate to-go coffee. If you don't have a few minutes to get a gibraltar or cappuccino and talk with the barista, enjoying a perfect coffee out of a proper ceramic cup - you probably shouldn't be allowed to have one. Spend your time in line contemplating what you are going to have, wait with exhilirating anticipation as you see the barista making your drink, and spend a couple of minutes in pure contemplation while you enjoy it. Such a drink shouldn't be rushed - sloshed into a paper cup and chugged as you rush to your next appointment. As they do it in Italy and France, slow down and take a quick pause with a coffee and actually engage in conversation, or read the newspaper, or just take a minute to enjoy a perfect cup.

The consistancy issues that plagued them initially seem to be gone with the new roasting equipment, but at the same time, the individual character of the beans haven't been impacted. For coffee purists, it's Mecca, Medina and the whole Magillah.

If you think that coffee only deserves hot pressurized water and a little whole milk foam - get ready to stand in line with the rest of the coffee junkies. If, however, you want an eggnog-cinnamon-dolce frappuccino coffee-type beverage, go back to Starbucks.
author: Avery G.

description:
This is the best coffee i've had in SF.  I can't nail down what exactly it is about the coffee but it's just damn good.  The staff is super nice and the location is great.  I always grab a cup and sit at the park down the way and return the cup later.

btw I always get a Gibraltar here from a recommendation from a friend and I've never gotten anything else since.  I don't know what's in it.  Somehow if I knew exactly what is was it would spoil it for me but you HAVE to try it.
author: Chris H.

description:
After reading some reviews here, I thought I would seek out the what it is that makes Blue Bottle Coffee so go. My friend and I ventured out early Sunday morning to the little storefront int the alley to find a several people hanging out there, solely for the coffee. My order was simple, 2 regular drip coffees. They took a long time to come out as they were made in individual drip cones but the wait was well worth it! Definitely a full-bodied flavor without all the bitterness that accompanies some others dark coffee. Yeah, you know who you are. 

The only thing I didn't like about the coffee was the after affects. I have never been so jittery in all my life! I had to have a drink with Sunday brunch just to even off the caffeine, which left me with a nice, serene feel. I highly recommend it.

Update: I went to the stand at the Embarcadero Farmer's Market and got an iced-coffee this time, which was fantastic as expected. Reminded me of the wonderfully strong iced-coffee I used to get at Hi-Rise in Cambridge. Dark, bold, strong and lots of flavor with little bitterness. Had to walk off the coffee jitters again! Zoom!
author: Scott T.

description:
I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place!  I've ordered way too many cappuccinos in my life that are burnt tasting and bitter.  So much so that I end up having to put sugar and more milk in them to make it drinkable.  Heck, I've had bad cappuccinos where I taste it and throw the whole thing away.  Thank goodness for Blue Bottle Coffee!  

While the locale is a bit remote for someone who doesn't live in the neighborhood, it's definitely worth the trek if you've got to have that PERFECT cup of coffee, be it an espresso drink or drip.
author: Anonymouse C.

description:
Ditto Ditto Ditto!  I think there are enough reviews here to convince you...this place has FABULOUS coffee hands down.  And in my expert Yelp opinion (teehee!) comparable only to Ritual and Frog Hollow Farms.  

I've been by this place tons of times. There is always a line, no matter what time of day. But well worth the wait! I love their mini little sugary treats and the fact that they use only organic milk for their coffee drinks.

PS...  i do not have a dog, but i took notice the blue bottle dog friendliness for sure.  They have a cute little glass candy jar of doggie treats on the counter and a nice fresh bowl of water outside too.  so no impatient pooches while you wait!
author: Isabel C.

description:
I just stumbled onto their coffee about 2 weeks ago after a recommendation from a friend. I must say the coffee is pretty damn good. The way they pull their shots will make you never want to return to anything less. There are likely some that are equal or better, but you'll likely have to go to Seattle or the East Coast.

I bought some espresso beans and have been enjoying them ever since. Oh, I hear they often run out of beans, so make sure you get there early enough to get the latest shipment.
author: Dan M.

description:
blue bottle coffee is a leap above most other coffee in the city.  I hardly ever, actually never give 5*, but blue bottle deserves it. In my humble opinion, the only coffee that comes close is Ritual on valencia, which makes a mean machiatto.  Definitely would recomend blue bottle to anyone who has become dissilusioned with the uber-sweet, no-body coffee served up at starbucks and most other coffee shops.


also, they just opened up a second kiosk at the farmers market on the north side. fyi
author: greg B.

description:
As an espresso enthusiast (aka coffee geek) I have tried many of the cafes and roasters in the city, and rank Blue Bottle among the top.

I've heard people rave about the coffee in North Beach, and other places in the city.  Until I discovered Blue Bottle, I had been very disappointed.  The people here really know their coffee, and do it right on so many levels.  I could rant on and on about their technique, roast etc, but I'll just point out a few things I have noticed that sets Blue Bottle Coffee apart from the other coffee places I've tried:

The Beans:
Fresh, well roasted (not burnt.)  They sell blends and single origin selections to accommodate everybody's tastes --- mostly organic, shade grown and free trade.  Also, they won't sell beans roasted more than two days ago.  That's the benefit of being a "micro-roaster."  Try going into any other cafe and asking when their beans were roasted.

The Machine:
I was very surprised to find that they have a modified La Marzocco with PID from which they make all of their shots.  The La Marzocco is a great machine on its own, and the PID helps maintain the machine temperature stability with great accuracy.  Espresso requires a very specific temperature (194-200F), outside of which the shots will become bitter or sour. This is often overlooked by many other cafes. 

The Grind:
They grind for each drink, vs grinding at the beginning of the day and dispensing pre-ground coffee.  Since espresso is sensitive to the freshness of the grounds, this is an important thing.

The Shot:
The sign says that all of their shots are double-ristretto, and they remain true to that.  This short shot of espresso brings with it all of the aromatic flavors and full body of the coffee.

The taste:
Wow.  Smooth, woody, caramel, nutty goodness.  Of the four blends I have tried so far, each has its distinct personality.

It's definitely worth the trip across town, or a long wait in line for this good coffee experience.
author: Shea G.

description:
This is my Friday treat-- the lines are shorter on week days and I can get my drip coffee without waiting half an hour or more.

This coffee has, quite literally, made it harder for me to enjoy other coffee. It's chocolatey, not astringent or bitter. I have run into people i know here, but despite my regular patronage the barista guy still doesn't smile at me when I arrive and order. *sigh*

It's hard to get the coffee to come out quite as good in your own home, but a pot of Bella Donovan in a press pot is pretty damn good.
author: Sara G.

description:
Maybe my taste buds are not as attuned as everyone else's in the world but...

Coffee is coffee.
And burritos are burritos.
And pizza is pizza.

Sure you can have really bad coffee/burritos/pizza, but once you get over that hurdle it is an ever-so-slightly upward sloped trend (Y Axis: Quality, X Axis: Distribution of worst to best starting with worst on the extreme left).

I mean, this Blue Bottle stuff is alright, and it's cool that everything's all chrome and in an alley way and in Hayes Valley, but... It's just coffee.

Good coffee, but not worth the ridiculously slow and long line.

They usually have good music pumping in the background though! Built to Spill ("There's Nothing Wrong with Love") the last time I went...
author: Trey F.

description:
My husband and I always pass by this place on our way to work and every single time, I can't help but wonder why is there a long line in a small alley.  To satisfy our curiosity, we parked our car and walked into the alley.

It turned out to be a coffee stand.  Since we made such an effort to make our way to this new find, we treated ourselves with some coffee.  After my first sip of my mocha, a smile was brought into my face.  It was the BEST mocha I've ever had!

Past Monday, I had such a bad craving for Blue Bottle's mocha that I asked my sister to pick me up from Financial District during my lunch break and drive there for some coffee.  It's great to have family.  = )
author: Trang W.

description: Tried a cappuccino at the farmers market, smooth and delicious. What can I say, the guys are very passionate about their beans.
author: Jeremy S.

description: A friend turned me on to Blue Bottle, and I'm so glad they did. The coffee is wonderful, so fresh! The line is a little long, but it goes by quick enough.
author: Tiffany R.

description:
Caution: The following review is written by a non-coffee drinker.  Read at your own risk.

I thought it perfect to drop by for some famous coffee while I was out shopping in Hayes Valley.  If it weren't for the sign on Gough, I totally would have walked passed the narrow alley that is Linden.

A steady line had formed, but it wasn't long.  The kiosk was literally just a store-front without any seating, but people didn't mind just chillin' on the streets. 

I got a drip coffee for $2 and it wasn't too bitter, though I did spike it with some sugar and half&half.  I love how they served the coffee at a temperature that wouldn't scald your tongue (get a clue, Starbucks).  

And, of course, I was uncontrollably jittery for the rest of the night and my head was all in a fog.
author: Jun H.

description:
This place exemplifies "you get what you pay for."  Slightly more expensive than the other coffee outlets, but WAY better.  This is a usual stop for me and its no wonder there's always a line out front and people do wait patiently ... definitely worth the wait.  

There is definitely a grunge factor to this location, so if that makes you feel uncomfortable, you should go to their location in the Ferry building.

It's all good ... drip is excellent, caps and lattes are superb, iced coffee is unrivaled by any other place.
author: Rod C.

description:
I love this place. The mocha's and americano's are to die for. Enjoy with a delicious short bread cookie. 
I make their coffee in my french press almost every morning. It is really the best coffee.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
It was actually by mistake that I ended up at this location.  I was supposed to meet someone at the Mint Street location, but stupid me as the organizer, got the locations mixed up and ended up at this one.

Totally wasn't expecting it to be like a literal hole-in-the-wall establishment, but it was actually quite cute.  No lines here when I arrived (it was around 5 PM).  I got the mocha and wow.  Delicious.  I mean, it was rich but still tasted like espresso.  If you like the taste of coffee (and I do), this is your place.  None of those sugary dessert like mochas here.

I only wish there was one closer to where I lived...
author: L Y.

description:
A place that has 455 reviews reallllllllly doesn't need another to tell you it's pretty freaking jump java and wailin' good, does it?

Well, I'm here to be your redundant yelper. Yep, it's why the lines are so long.

And nope-- I've got nothing new to add. The au lait I had didn't cure cancer, get me pregnant, help me lose 15lbs  or turn the man in line ahead of me into Johnny Depp in a smoking jacket, but it was GOOD.

That cup of joe was like a late night radio dj....smooth and mellow yet giving me that little "oomph" to keep movin' on...

Supply and demand, folks. The lines will always be long, but the customers will usually leave smiling and licking their lips.
author: Jessica P.

description:
These people are some SERIOUS coffee people.  Fantastic!  I had a latte to go.  What a fantastic cup of joe.. The flavor of the beans rode my tongue like a tidal wave, and stayed there longer than an unwelcome in-law.  Just straight up WOW.

The line was long, but it moved reasonably fast, and the blue decor was very cool in a environmentally conscious way.  I liked the look of it, and I thought running a coffee shop out of a garage was kickass in both concept and execution.

Speaking of garages, did anyone notice the Fort Knox garage door across the street?  That thing closes like it's protecting the First Family; it's AWESOME.  Hell, it's worth visiting BlueBottle just to see that thing open and close!  Somebody should get a video and post it on YouTube.

All in all, very San Francisco, phenomenal coffee (and I mean the coffee is literally a phenomenon), a cool vibe, and the Garage Door of Power all in one place.

Werd.

PS - Cash only!
author: Alex C.

description:
I don't claim to be a coffee expert- I only drink mochas.  

However, this place rocks.  Yes the line is long, but hello.... then you know you're in for some good coffee lovin'.  

My mocha was A. pretty (yes pretty), B. creamy/rich/delicious, C. addicting.

Cash only.
author: Sarah F.

description:
I had one of the best lattes ever here. Soooo yummy! Yes you do wait, but that's why I only go here on a Saturday when I have nothing else to do except be leisurely. 

Check it out!
author: Ericka A.

description:
A coworker took me here after I took him to Philz. I have gone back to Blue Bottle a dozen times since. BB has such a good vibe...and great coffee. I like the strange alley location nestled in hayes valley, like a coffee shop playing hide-and-go-seek in San Francisco, this sneaky location ads the charm. Blue Bottle has given me a reason to get up a little bit earlier and scoot down for a morning treat.

Professor Tips:

1. The New Orleans style Iced Coffee is a must for a first visit.  I used to hate iced coffee until I had BB's. I don't know why, its just really good.

2. Drip Coffee is made one cup at a time. 

3. It's worth $2 a cup.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
7x7 Big Eat List: #28 Gibraltor

I was always proud to say that I enjoyed my coffee but didn't need it on a daily basis.  Then someone introduced me to Blue Bottle...

"Hello, my name is Melissa, and I am a coffee-aholic."

Now when I stay in the city, both me and my enabler find any excuse to get a fix, a hit, some sweet sweet cappuccinos and soy lattes.  I will even be tempted to wake up semi-early on a Saturday and JOG *GASP* there just to taste that sweet nectar.

Now when I am unable to get a capp with the oh-so-pretty leaf designs, I have caffeine withdrawal headaches.  Will I ever stop now that I've tasted heaven?  

As they say... rehab is for quitters!!!
author: Melissa L.

description:
Smelled Nice

Warning: I don't like coffee, I don't like coffee, I don't like coffee!

I like to try or retry things every once and a while and having not drank any coffee in 10 years, I tried BlueBottle Coffee with some co-workers who swore it was the best.  I tried it and I still don't like coffee.  Funny to me is too see so many people who complain about global warming and the like at places like this.

I don't know how anyone can drink coffee if the say they believe in global warming.  There is no excuse for cutting down the forest, building a coffee plantation, fertilizing/ pesticiding (petro chemicals) and use a fossil fuels to ship the stuff half way around the world so you can drink it.  You don't need coffee!  You could drink water.  With that said, I don't believe in that global warming hogwash, so I can enjoy my drink of choice.  If I see you there, I'll know you don't care about global warming too and we can toast to our fossil fuel SUV's with abandon or even worse the earth destroying Prius.  (read the down and dirty on the Prius here http://clubs.ccsu.edu/recorder/editorial/print_item.asp?NewsID=188)  

Too bad they didn't have any Tea for me.  Luckily, I carry a plastic bottle of water with me everywhere I go.  I little Skoal and couple sips later I forgot I had once again let the coffee bean into my life.  The reward for avoiding the bean?  You can truly taste the flavor of wine; almost impossible if you drink coffee. 

I based the rating only on the coffee.
author: jack w.

description: Very STRONG coffee! They have a cult like following. Always a line, so don't think you can just "swing by".  Simple menu, excellent service, fantastic coffee.  If you consider yourself a coffee connoisseur, it's definitely worth a try.
author: Aaron B.

description:
Fortunately I don't live too far from the Hayes Valley location, because the coffee here is a new breed...and I can't be happy anywhere else.
I learned of this new style of coffee at Cafe Organica, which is sadly gone now. I believe it's the micro-foamed milk that isn't too hot and stays sweet and creamy in combination with wonderfully sweet espresso brewed perfectly that characterizes this "latte art" style of coffee. Examples are few and far between around here, and Blue Bottle is definitely the best.
author: Donna B.

description:
Blue Bottle is a GIGANTIC magnet drawing people from all over this city.  Who knew that coffee could be so delicious.  Seriously.  I was just talking to someone about how she got in an accident just to get across town for her coffee.  I think that about sums it up, right?  

There is always a line...but it's always worth the wait.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
I made coming here for coffee my new Saturday morning ritual.

It's just a kiosk, no seating, and there's a long line every time. The first time I walked around the corner and saw the line I thought "I hope it's worth it." It definitely is. The lattes are delicious and for some reason this is the only place that gets it regarding the milk temperature. It's exactly right and I can drink it right away, instead of having to wait 10 minutes until the drink cools down.

There is a small selection of very good pastry to go with the coffee, you should try the Snickerdoodle.

Highly recommended!
author: Marc L.

description:
3 Stars at best

Coffee: I've had better it is nice a smooth but not strong enough for my taste for sure it is better than Scarbucks though.
Service: Slow and forgetful (that is if you are ordering more than 2 things)

This place does need a hygiene check. They use the milk pitcher over and over again without washing it before use.

What is good about this place is drip coffee. It is a bit faster than the milk base drinks.
author: Justin L.

description:
My mother, who has lived in the Seattle area for the last 16 years, is going to die and go to heaven when I take her here..

Maybe I can get her to stop bugging me to move back and bribe her with this coffee - heheh.
author: Yelper A.

description:
Blue Bottle started off my last I heart SF day, complete with trip to Palace of Fine Arts and Stinson Beach.  Sometimes this city gets me down, and I need a pick me up.  Well, Blue Bottle came through for me last Saturday and I realized maybe I should start my day more often with them, and I'll be a happier person.  I don't mind the lines, it goes fast and everyone is friendly and happy, hello it's Blue Bottle, they're all feeling like me.
Thanks Blue Bottle!
author: Sarah M.

description:
Good beans make a huge difference when it comes to coffee.  On a hot summer day, a friend and I stopped by the Hayes Valley location and I opted for the NoLa Iced Coffee.  Mmmmmmmmm.....

Kiosk is awesome!  Service was great.  The chocolate cookie was muy delicioso!

I love Blue Bottle!  If it weren't midnight, I might be tempted to drive out and get some!
author: Annalynn C.

description: A friend in the city recommended Blue bottle and boy was I glad. I had the mocha and affogato and my friend had the macchiato. The line was huge but we were adamant in trying this buzz place. Once we got our drinks we were curious to know what the glass cylinders were in the back. The staff was super awesome they explained the process and gave us a bit of background the company such as all local roasts etc. I can't wait to visit again.
author: Kam S.

description:
I'm not a coffee drinker, as many of you may know. However, when there's no line I will pop by and purchase Blue Bottle to have on hand for those overnight guests, the ones that deserve a cup of coffee in the morning that is, and mind you, some people do not need to be caffeinated in the mornings!
They clearly serve up a solid cup of joe here and when I make the coffee at home in my french press, it seems to bring a smile to the face of my guest. Recommened - Three Africans!
I'm just glad Hayes Valley has an eau de cafe instead of the nasal assault of my neighborhood offered up.
author: Colleen B.

description:
Update: I was in the area and out of my usual beans at home so I gave the Blue Bottle a try, thinking if I make the drip brew it might be more to my liking.  Boy was I wrong, it is among the worst tasting coffee I have ever had - the flavor from those beans is sour and nasty, undrinkable.  I honestly thought the milk was sour, I was convinced it had to be that, and shocked when I found it wasn't.  Ug, horrible waste on overpriced beans, another star off.
------------------------------------------------------
It would have been funny if it were named Blue Bottle after a bottle of  NOS, because, you know, the coffee does to your brain what a shot of nitrous does to an engine.  Okay, that's not amusing at all and just lame and geeky - I blame the wine.

The coffee was good but I still think my dark bean Graffeo made at home is a better balance of strong flavor sans bitterness. Other then that the mocha I've swigged off the husband's cup has been nice, but mochas always taste like some hot chocolate confection to me and it is hard to say how good the coffee is underneath all that.

Points scored for using organic stuff, creating pretty designs in the foam, attitude, and an earnest effort.  Prices are high and parking is a bitch, but that is a given with the area.  As others have stated, the lack of seating is a negative and it forces you to get coffee to go (paper cups are never as good for the joe in  my opinion), and then the stores hate you coming in with your beverage and will even ask you to leave it up front.  Best to go when you can actually sit there or are not planning on shopping, otherwise you might as well just skip the coffee and head to Suppenkuche for a pint and a schnitzengruben.
author: GIR ..

description:
Best coffee in the bay area.

You'll have to wait in line but its very much worth the wait.

If you like the sweeter drinks, the New Orleans iced coffee is really tasty, especially on a warm farmer's market Saturday.

Check em' out - GOOD STUFF.
author: Aaron B.

description: Tasty espresso, interesting drip, and nice shortbreads. But it wasn't hot (4 times), so what's the point?
author: Arjun K.

description: This place is located down the street from where I live and is amazing! Excellent coffee and lattes, to be honest pretty much everything is great here.  Top 5 best coffee places I have tired, I would highly recommend stopping by and grab a cup.  If you come during biz morning hours expect a line.
author: David K.

description: Best coffee in the world.  I just wish the alley was the way it was a few months ago, or better yet, a couple years ago.
author: Matthew W.

description:
The best cup of coffee I've ever had.  Better than cups I've had from a Clover machine.  We waited a good 15 minutes and then another 2 or 3 for our individually prepared drip coffees to be made.  Amazing.  Like tasting coffee for the first time.

Also, I love that this place is all about the coffee.  No tables or chairs or wifi or music.  Just coffee, equipment, and friendly staff to prepare it all.
author: Stephen H.

description: F@#$$%%$##@ing Fabulous. I finally found this place.To my surprise I am glad Tartine is closed on Sunday as I walking from my work in desperate need of good coffee I asked the lady at Walgreens where I can find good coffee and she said some alley up the block. I didn't realize Tartine carried Blue Bottle Coffee, no wonder it's so dam good! . Great service and I am now in love. I asked if they carried spenda and the guy told me about what they have to offer (some type of natural sugar), after one sip ...F-That I don't need sugar ...Dam good coffee.I just wish they offered bigger cups..Super Size my ass!
author: Dee D.

description: Strong coffee. Got the Mocha that came with a dazzling design on the top! Boyfriend got the iced coffee. Both really good. & Biscottis to top off the coffee! I do noticed that a lot of people get the 'Drip' coffee though. I will be back &is going to try that next time. Btw, the place is in an alleyway so it may be a little hard to find. Total was $10. ($4.50 for the mocha already.)
author: Vivian L.

description:
Have some hype with your coffee? 

I don't know what all the fuss is about.  I'll take Capricorn Dark French any day over this stuff. So fecking what if BB has "subtle overtones of.." and "goes best with..." "served at 130 degrees...". I dont need someone to tell me what coffee goes best with - I was looking for the one that says "goes best with Marlboro".

It's okay but at $7 a 1/2 pound it isn't 200% better than Capricorn ($7 lb).  I know I'm "supposed" to like it because I did see many cultists there (translation: indie persons, mac-ophiles). Fortunately I brought my brain with me that day.

All aboard for the next stop on the trendy express. Sucka's!

edit: I upped my review to 3 stars. I recently was in the area and needed a cup, BB was around the corner. The Latte I got was almost as good as Starbucks.
author: Matthew C.

description:
The best cup in San Francisco.   The best beans in San Francisco.  The longest wait for coffee in San Francisco.    

All worth it. 

I used to tell my friends about this place and bring them for a taste of coffee nirvana, but they kept ordering skinny no foam soy latte's with Splenda and ruining my coffee street cred.    

From now on I go to Blue Bottle on my own.
author: Jim Z.

description: My most recent trip to Blue Bottle just didn't fully do it for me.  Maybe it was the hype or the crowd, or my first time seeing a siphon bar...but it's just too damn expensive and too much like an assembly line production to make it a 5 star affair.  With this kind of craziness behind the bar you lose the nuance of a perfectly pulled shot and poured macchiato.  Or perhaps it's the public cuppings available at other specialty cafe in the city...or the ways in which my palate develops the more I cup, explore, and converse about coffee.  Still good, don't get me wrong, but even when it comes to taste and quality, I'll take a pound of Ritual's Sweet Tooth espresso of Blue Bottle of late.
author: Sarah G.

description: In an ideal world I would start each day with a barrel of Blue Bottle's New Orleans Iced Coffee.  Unfortunately, that would cost about as much as my rent.  But every once in a while, it's perfect.  So smooth tasting that you can go with almost no sugar.
author: BringMy C.

description:
Awesome coffee (espresso and milk drinks). 
Awesome coffee (whole beans).
So-so spot.
No seating, not at all.
Long lines.
Somehow the line goes faster than in the place on Mint st, 
I'm not sure why, but that's how it is.

I'm far more interested in the coffee beans than the drinks, and 
Blue Bottle seems to have the best espresso roasts in town. Ritual 
has more interesting stuff for the french press (at far, far higher prices), 
but for espresso blends there is no better option.

Once a week, I stop by, buy beans (thus avoiding the line), and go. On 
the rare occasion when there is no line, I get a cappuccino. And then
I am happy. Yay.
author: Max R.

description: I've heard so much about this place. I ended up trying the New Orleans Iced Coffee and a Gibraltar (because that's what people were saying on Yelp) and I loved them. My favorite was definitely the New Orleans Iced Coffee. I'm not an expert by any means with coffee but you can tell that they brew some amazing coffee here. And after coming here, I was just in such a great mood. There was just something different about this place. However, if I have to compare I still love Philz Coffee more.
author: Brent C.

description:
