Seems like I'm only joining the masses when I give this place a 5 star review and am reviewer # 914, but you just gotta love to see it when people create a good business that takes off.  It can't be easy to keep it like it was in the start once you go big time.  This was my first visit here, and will become a regular stop when I'm in this area again.  I wish I remembered the name of the beans used for my drip coffee, but damn were they good.  And the temperature?  Perfect.  

I kinda peered around the counter and saw what looked like the nerve of the Blue Bottle Co shop, a lot of coffee roasting action going on.  This reminds me of why I won't go to Starbucks.  I pay 2+ dollars for a scolding hot cup of 'coffee' and dreadfully, I'll see another Starbucks appear in the landscape somewhere with my investment.  Here, I'm MORE than happy to spend $2.50 for a cup of fresh coffee, and can only hope to see another Blue Bottle Co. somewhere else!  But please not in San Carlos...We already have The Plantation.

Keep up the good work and look forward to my next cup!
author: Matt R.

description:
Blue Bottle I've loved you a long time. 

Organic milk, excellent espresso! But when It's cold outside I want my coffee at least a little hot. I understand you may have your reasons for not making it too hot. But when I ask for extra hot, can you please make it at least normal hot for me?
author: Moni M.

description:
Some strong coffee, 
inexpensive,
usually long lines,
no parking,
but damn good coffee!!!
author: Myron J.

description:
I would probably have given this place 4 stars if I didn't feel I needed to compensate for, in my humble opinion, the undeserved 5 stars it gets from so many people. 

Whats to love;

- The drip coffee is done right...it truely is a great drip, much better than most out there - it would fall into the 5 star category easily.
- The hot chocolate/mocha is what every true chocolate lover should demand - its not sickeningly sweet like many out there. Though I wouldnt call it bittersweet it is real chocolate flavor, fantastic if you are in the mood for chocolate!
- Organic ingredients always score points, especially if you can make them taste great!

Whats not to love;

-The line is not worth the finished product. If I have to wait 30 minutes for my coffee it better be the best damn coffee I've ever had in my life!
- The mochas and lattes I have had there are not especially hot. I am convinced they have an aversion to hot milk.
- No pride in presentation or cleanliness. I always wonder ...if they are okay with serving me a cup with grounds stuck to the bottom of it or coffee dripping down the side, what are the general cleanliness standards of everything else? 

All in all a good cup o' joe, and let me tell ya, there are plenty of places who serve something resembling sludge from the murkiest of Louisianna Bayous. 

Stick with the drip, have time to kill and order your mocha extra hot (which means it wont be lukewarm when you get it) and you should be pretty pleased with your purchase. Just be aware, going in, of the shortcomings...all of these 5 star ratings and I think I put this place on a pedastle before I tried it, only to be mildly disappointed.
author: Drue C.

description:
5 stars for great coffee! Even Blue Bottle Decaf is great!

- 1 star for lines that can go on forever and employees that do not try to speed things up ... aren't they on caffeine???? Move faster!

- 1 star for the dining room being messy and crowded and not well organized - where are the newspapers?

+ 1 star for letting us get your great Blue Bottle coffee in Oakland at our local coffee and chocolate place

+ 1 star for dating every bag with the roasting date! That is fresh!
author: Lee R.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee Co. is not for everyone, for sure.  But it serves a purpose, and might I add, a "higher purpose", at that.  

You'll find the original storefront in an alley, a 1/2 block south, and parallel to, the eastern end of the Hayes Valley strip (x Gough St.), and the location feels a world away.  The street is tight, and a bit dirty, but nothing overwhelming, given the nature of SF, and it has only gotten more and more cleaned up over the past year or two.  Blue Bottle is simply a kiosk - well, a large one with all the fancy grinding, espresso-making, etc. gear required for high-end drink preparation -  in an open garage, but some seats have been set out on the small sidewalks.  And somehow, this has helped foster a sense of community, like you're all out here in the street, drinking some great coffee (or hot chocolate) together - or something.  

Whatever.. it's a good scene.  And the chance to strike up conversation with a stranger is higher than you might think.  

To continue, I am not a coffee connoisseur, but I do understand the concept of connoisseurship, in general (beer anyone?), and know that in such company, the coffee Blue Bottle roasts is held in high regard.  Check out a few of the beans, from various origins around the world (roasted in Oakland always not more than 2 days ago), and definitely ask if you would like some advice (although on a busy weekend, you don't want to be monopolizing everyone's time, I think). 

Of course, your service varies by barista and the amount of folks in line, etc., but in general I've found every interaction to be friendly, running the gamut from efficient (but pleasant) to extremely chatty (and I'm not a chatty one to begin with).  A smile gets you places, even in an alley in Hayes Valley. 

When I wanted to get some beans as a gift for a friend - with a more discerning palate than mine for coffee (although I guess, "more discerning taste buds" would be more accurate) - I mentioned her preparation method (moka pot) and maybe something about the general qualities I knew she liked ("creamy") and one of the gentlemen hooked me up with spot-on beans, and a leaflet to take home, describing others I might be interested in for the future. 

Yes, so give it the benefit of the doubt - get over any hipsterness and/or snootiness you might fear  - and just give it a go.   For sure, you can find those things here (or anywhere in SF for that matter), but here you'll also have the opportunity to meet your neighbors and maybe learn a thing or two about this mysterious coffee drink (in several of it's most common forms).. 

If you are in a hurry, or aren't into dirty-ish alleys, needing to be outside with your coffee.. or if you're looking for WiFi!.. I'd recommend a few other places.  No problem.  Otherwise, check out Blue Bottle; it lives up to the hype.  At the least, appreciate that it is there, even if it's not for you, because variety is the spice of life (yo).. 

And remember:  A smile gets you places, even in an alley in Hayes Valley (and maybe even moreso).
author: Eric H.

description:
I'm about to get off work and I still feel like shit after a long week.  
mmmm...nothing like a good cup of coffee to keep me from being a walking zombie.  I sat through rush hour traffic to get to this place.  With all the positive reviews, I had to try this place out and I wasn't a bit disappointed.  The coffee was strong and smooth. Will definitely come back to try the cappuccino and mocha.
author: hello k.

description:
The best coffee, imho.
I love the cute little alley location.
I get a bag of beans and a latte and I'm set.
It's not really a place to hang out, but there is a park near by for that.
I know that I'll be back.
over and over and over and over again.
author: Marin V.

description: So what is all the hype with Blue Bottle Co.?  I checked out this location because it was so close to work...so what the hey, it's a nice day...I'll treat myself to some expensive coffee.  I've been drinking iced coffee for the past months, so I tried out their New Orleans iced coffee.  I've read some yelp reviews about this coffee too.  But to my dismay, the iced coffee was just bland.  I could not tasted any hint of the coffee...more like the milk and ice.  And the little cup of coffee costed $3.75!   My venti iced coffee from Starbucks costs $2.85.  The staff are nice.  But too bad, I'm just not a fan of their coffee.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Somehow, we got there in between rushes, so we only had to wait five minutes to order our coffee. 

And it was AWESOME. Totally worth the wait. Totally worth waiting in the down-the-block line that we saw as we were leaving. If you don't like Blue Bottle's coffee, you just plain don't like coffee.
author: Rednikki G.

description: You know the coffee is damn good when you get a drip coffee, don't add anything to it, and it tastes FANTASTIC! I highly recommend Blue Bottle for coffee and beans for your home brewing!
author: Andria N.

description:
Superb coffee out your front door. I have woken up so many mornings to walk down and cross the street to get my coffee at Blue Bottle.

I like to think of it as my (our) secret place for great expresso (and hot chocolate). It's no secret, there is always a line.

The flavor in Hayes Valley pours from this hidden gem. Don't forget to bring your wallet, premium coffee comes at a price.
author: Bruce A.

description:
I can't believe the journey to search for the Best-Roasted-Coffee- Beans-In-the-World would take me back to my own backyard... from Jamaica Blue Mountain, Hawaiian pure kona, to coffee roasting joints like Intelligentsia, Zabar's and others across the country... once you taste the sweetness of Blue Bottle Coffee, SEARCH NO MORE.  

Note to self: switch to decaf after a few cups...
author: Shirley F.

description:
Hands down the best coffee in San Francisco.  

Everybody waiting in the long line in the alley is talkative, friendly and patient.  

Definitely worth the wait.  

The cafe down on Jessie Street is a great sit down experience too.  :)
author: John H.

description: This is one of the first reviews I've written.  I am so enamored with Blue Bottle that I can no longer withhold my praise.  I've been going here for about two years due to my addiction to their soy mochas.  These are, hands down, the best mochas I've ever had.  I grew up near Seattle and enjoyed the fruits of the coffee boom in the early 90's.  I've since searched all around San Francisco for the best of coffee in various forms and my soul has been arrested by the espresso quality.  I must also offer my praise to the staff, who is always friendly and engaged, and for the lovely location with the quaint seating area outside.  Lastly, have you all noticed the art installation on the alley telephone pole? Look up!
author: Tiffany M.

description: Cute little kiosk off the street. If I lived here I could make this a habit. Friendly staff. I had an Americano- excellent, friend had an Iced Coffee that was so yummy and flavorful (maybe cinnamon? chickory?). Location is perfect for petting local dogs and striking up short conversations with strangers while waiting in line. Highly recommend.
author: LORI F.

description: I'm sure Blue Bottle works for those who just want what is given to them. I ordered a doppio macchiato with extra foam, extra dense and got a latte, along with a lecture "that is not how we do things here". No problem, but I ding you three stars for the experience.
author: Mike B.

description:
This coffee-bar-out-of-a-garage-in-a-remote-alley impressed me.  It's one of those places that no one would know about, except however, thousands of other people DO know about it b/c of Yelp.   What struck me besides the long line, was what looked like your regular SF homeless people on the street.  Upon closer inspection, however, they were just hipsters who were sprawled all over the sidewalk with their espresso cups.  Bourgeois bums, I say...

Had their New Orleans iced coffee.  After having read all the reviews, I expected it to be sweetened already b/c everything in the South comes sweetened or battered in a ton of fat for you to put in your mouth like on auto-pilot.  Apparently, though, you have to add your own sugar to your coffee in New Orleans.  Who would've thunk?
author: S K.

description:
As a relative newcomer to the City I like exploring neighborhoods on a free day.  I like to smell the neighborhoods.  Yes, some smell like pee but others smell like yummy ethnic foods wafting through the air.  I like to hear the sounds of people's lives  happening in the dense streets of the city.  I like to see laundry hanging in the windows because everyone has to pay for laundry in this city (I miss mom's FREE large capacity washer in the 'burbs!)  I just like being in a new world, discovering how other people live.

On a walk through Hayes Valley I came across an alley.  I noticed there was a long line of people patiently waiting for something addicting, something amazing, something I must find out for myself.  I walked by the line at first pretending to be passing by (hard to do in an alley with nothing else going for it).  Then I decided to just get in line.  I could have been in a soup kitchen line for all I knew.  It could have been a really good crack dealer at the end of this mysterious Must-have.  I didn't care, I wanted in.  This seemed like a spot where locals "in the know" go and I wanted to be part of the "know".

To my pleasant surprise at the end of the line was a coffee kiosk.  It looked like someone just opened up their garage door and started dealing cups of coffee.  As a long time Starbucks fan (I am from Seattle after all) I was happy to see the  individual cups topped with single cone filters.  This is a long process for an instant world, but the results are so much better (vietnamese coffee also falls into this category).  Any coffee place that would take the time to care for each cup like that was worth my money and curiosity.  (note that's why I'm pissed Sbux went automatic with their espresso, no more artistry).  

I ordered a simple small latte.  The foam was good, the coffee was great.  Strong in flavor but smooth in finish.  I'm a fan of dark bitter coffees, but the smooth finish on Bluebottle was refreshing.  I looked it up when I got home and was even more pleased to find out it's organic and shade grown.  

I love surprise discoveries in the city!
author: Sonic D.

description:
By far the best Caffe Latte I have had in California.  I love the cookies they sell as well.  I do wish there was a place to sit even if it was just a few benches on the side of the street. 
I would definitely keep going back again and again.
author: t s.

description:
I've always wondered where this place was because I never saw it while driving through the area.  Well, Linden is almost like an alley and that's why I've never driven by and that just adds to the coolness of this place.

I love how each cup is individually brewed and I agree - some of the best coffee I've ever tasted.

I wish I either lived or worked in the area.  I'll just have to settle on having this as a treat when I'm in the area.  That will make it even more special.

If you're in the area, seek it out.  If you like your coffee black, you will not be disappointed.  It's fantastic.
author: Josh L.

description:
It's fairly simple:  this is the best coffee in San Francisco, and the kiosk is a great hookup spot.  There's something about the little back-alley that speaks to my addiction to BlueBottle crack.

Hit it up on Tuesday morning and get a fresh half-pound; I recommend the various Ethiopian roasts or Giant Steps.


Update: The "100% Yemen"  is probably the greatest thing I've ever tasted.
author: Jon B.

description:
I went there yesterday after hearing all the yelping about this place.  
 
+hole in the wall location
+music being played
+high-quality espresso

-no seating
-attitude (i'm not expecting a sunny "how are you today blah blah" but they were snitty "we WONT put ice in our coffee (to the guy in front of me) but we will give you a cup of ice if YOU want to do it"
-poor cappuccino ratio...CMON GUYS, IF YOU ONLY HAVE LIKE 3 COFFEE DRINKS ON YOUR MENU, YOU HAVE TO GET IT RIGHT...CAPPUCCINO = 1/3 ESPRESSO, 1/3 STEAMED MILK, 1/3 FOAM...its a latte when you fill the cup to the brim with steamed milk...it doesn't matter that you put pretty foam art on the top...the ratio's wrong and it isn't a cappuccino
author: Mike B.

description:
Blue bottle coffee is awesome!!!! This particular coffee place is a walk up and doesn't really have a place to sit or a restroom.  It's in a cute area of SF to walk around and its perfect if you are with your dog.  They even have free dog biscuits available.  

The employees are friendly, knowledgeable, and take to the time to answer your questions sincerely.  

CASH ONLY
author: Leticia H.

description:
No Doubt...Blue Bottle is my favorite coffee in the town. 
No Doubt...the Hayes Valley one is the best among other locations. 

Their latte is the best one I have had so far. 
I am a latte addict...trust me, I have tried so many cups of latte in this country. My conclusion is: Blue Bottle is the best! 

In East Coast, I would recommend you Gimme Coffee, Joe's Art of Coffee, or 9th Espresso Cafe, but here, Blue Bottle is the best!
author: YT T.

description:
Gddamn, this is good coffee.  No sugar or flavor syrups needed.  I'll let you in on a little secret, too . . . buying their Hayes Valley Espresso beans, grinding them up at home, and making them in your mokka pot at home is NEARLY ALMOST JUST AS EQUALLY DELICIOUS as trekking down to their alleyway kiosk and having them cook it up for you.  I was shocked after I made this stuff at home for the first time and it tasted just as good, except that I was still in my pajamas :)

Can anyone tell me what they do in the back of the shop?  It looks like wood working of some kind... maybe stencils or patterns?
author: Emmy Y.

description:
Judging by the 130 reviews and counting, I'm gonna say this place 'may' have already been discovered. 

There is pretty good reason that this place has devoloped a 'moonie-like' cult around it. The coffee from this woodshop looking streetside stand is more lovingly crafted than a joint in an amsterdam coffee bar. As a result, you'll always be guaranteed a wait, but rest assured that it's worth it.

And I'm not even a big coffee guy!!
author: Andrew L.

description:
I've never been to a cafe whereupon tasting the coffee, I uttered the phrase, "Wow, that's f*cking good coffee!" This is what good coffee should taste like, what you ought to get when you pay a professional to make it for you. Unfortunately, I think a lot of other cafes would be better off secretly replacing their coffee with Nescafe, which can't be burnt and which can be made as strong as desired by just adding some more crystals. These guys make drip coffee but putting fresh grounds in a filter which sits atop your cup, pouring in the water and serving it piping hot and devilishly black. You may have to wait, but the barristas try to stay efficient by asking people in line what they want so by the time the get to the counter, all they need to do is pay.

I've since gone back a few times and should add that their coffee, though still the best tasting I've had, is also the strongest I've ever had. If my tummy's not full, I'll feel like I've taken an illegal upper. No joke - anxious tummy, disconcertingly altered state of mind, dancing bowels...
author: Noah M.

description:
I'm not even a coffee person and I love Blue Bottle Coffee! It's screaming with freshness and flavor, and I swear it raises my IQ. 

They have a stand at the Berkeley farmer's market  for you East Bay people.

Four stars instead of five because I don't like standing outside waiting in a long SLOW line while being illegaly parked.
author: Ms K.

description:
Stop taking over MY coffee spot!!!  Yes, this place makes the warmest, richest, frothest latte in town but now I have to wait in this line full of yuppies & hipsters to get my favorite beverage.  
Its also nice to take your coffee and a ginger scone up the street to the Hayes Valley park and watch the cute doggies & kiddies in the sun.  Mmmmm, what a perfect morning.
author: Trish K.

description:
I knew I was in trouble when I finished my ENTIRE Latte on my walk home (a mere 5 Blocks). 
So smooth yet so very strong...oh how I love you (damn latte) and wanna lick the bottom of my cup cuz it would be a sin to let a drop of you go to waste.
author: Anna S.

description:
I'm completely not a coffee connoisseur, and have never been much of a coffee drinker anyway. I mean I drink it, sometimes, but mostly decaf, and always with soy milk instead of dairy milk, and unfortunately most places provide soy milk as an afterthought. It's sometimes vanilla favored (why would they do that? If I wanted a flavor shot I would've asked for a flavor shot, ew), or they switch up the brands they buy all the time so the resulting drink has no consistency even if you get it from the same place every time. So I've never ever savored the flavor of coffee; I pretty much just drink it when I'm with a friend at a coffee shop, just so I don't feel bad about taking up space. Sometimes I also drink it because the other people I'm with are getting coffee, so I just roll with it and get one too. That's how I ended up at Blue Bottle on a visit out to SF.

I have never in my life had a coffee that is so delicious! Until now I would never have even used the word delicious to describe coffee. This is despite the fact that I go to both Gimme and Cafe Grumpy occasionally, which are similarly cult-ish coffee spots in NYC. The two cups of coffee I had at Blue Bottle during my weekend visit to SF were astounding. Mellow and sweet even without any sugar added, thick and creamy even with soy instead of dairy milk, and almost chocolatey in taste, even though I had decaf instead of regular. I really honestly didn't know coffee could taste this good. I feel like I just discovered a new food group.
author: Julia L.

description: Love the Mocha!!!  I don't know if this mocha is so amazing because of the coffee or the because of the chocolate, but it is truly amazing.  It is not syrupy sweet like others and the full flavors are there to experience and to appreciate in complex layers.  Organic milk, friendly servers and there is usually a dog or two in the line as well.  There is a wait, it is pricey ($4.75), but worth it for me.  Make new friends in line every time and I am more than willing to forgo all other mochas and save up for this once a week!  Amazing.
author: S T.

description:
i was in sf last week.
yelp around and found a this coffee place...
went there mid am to check it out..line wasnt bad, service was good, and i like the idea of sitting on the giant stones liming the little street.  
however, coffee is little on the acid side. i stilll prefer Jone's coffee in Pasadena much better....
author: Jane S.

description: You must have something wrong to get in line in a middle of a road for 20 minutes minimum, get an burned-tasting coffee, tolerate stuck up attitude of the people, be forced to drink it in the middle of the same road and then even have the crazy idea to come back again.
author: Luca R.

description:
What can I say? I love this place! I love the alley it's in and the feel of the whole enviroment which makes it unique. You can bring your dogs to this coffee shop and you won't get the boot, because it's outside, actually they have free treats for the little ones. But what makes it best besides the amazing, not over burnt coffee is the people who work there. I go
pretty much every morning. I love even seeing the other loyal blue bottle drinkers it makes it a nice experience. Yes the lines get long from time to time but if you go at 7:00 like me you'll rarely wait plus that's when they have the best selection of beans to buy. Oh so coffee wise I love it all. I 
am kind of simple I get the expresso and americano
to go. I get the lattes sometimes and i love it
author: Jennifer M.

description:
I normally starting bouncing off the wall if I have too much coffee but Blue Bottle happens to be the only place that really soothes my nerves. Although the coffee there is among the strongest I have had, it is definitely the smoothest.

If you're in SF, go try out the latte. I have tried other coffees such as Ritual Coffee, Amici's, etc. Blue Bottle is in a different league.
author: Kunal S.

description: Really?  How do you serve coffee colder than my ex-husbands heart? How does this place get so many good reviews. Way too much milk and less than luke warm result.  San Fran you have made me sad thus far.....until tomorrow.
author: Chick M.

description:
You'll know you have found it when you see a line on the alley! Seriously though, blue bottle keeps this neighborhood gem operated by their senior staff barista's and consistent quality is all they produce. I have tasted through every coffee drink available and not one has been a miss. Blue bottle along with Ritual set the standard for coffee in San Francisco. Stop by and give it a try to see how they did it.

I had the macchiato today and in the afternoon sunshine it was perfect.
author: Michael M.

description:
If you can make it through the line without killing any hipsters, poseurs, or any of the other annoying urban archetypes known to frequent this fine establishment - you are in for a treat - the best damn espresso/coffee around.

A few years ago when I got my own machine and grinder they were awesome about talking me through how to pull a great shot - and while I can't quite recreate their shots, with some fresh Hayes Valley Espresso beans I get fantastic results at home too.
author: Glenn V.

description:
There aren't words that express my love for blue bottle.  I am well known for having lots of opinions but few feelings...but believe me Blue Bottle...I love you.  

I used to be a very loyal Intelegencia drinker being a Chicago gal at heart, but ever since my first weekend in SF when i got a cup of coffee from the stand at the ferry building farmers market I've been hooked.  Thank god for mail order service or I would be S.O.L now that i'm back in Chicago.

I recently got a trainer who told me to cut out the caffeine so i recently ordered decaf-- we'll see how that goes
author: Janna V.

description:
Damn it, Blue Bottle! Just when I think I have kicked my java habit, there you are, so small, so unassuming, so......PERFECT IN EVERY WAY, and, I must have you. Seriously,  I really AM a bonafide tea drinker. And not those pansy grandma herbal teas, either. Dark, rich, Russian, etc. But, this coffee warms every fiber of my being, my essence, and, turns the darkness into light. 
This joe kicks tiny little tea leaf ass. 
Well done.
author: A. H.

description:
Perhaps my expectations were too high?  Whatever the reason, I felt like my experience was somewhat lacking at Blue Bottle Coffee.  Sure, it's a quirky setup, pretty much inside a garage on an alley off of Hayes street, but by the time you finish waiting in line and finally taking your cup of coffee you'll probably have expectations just as high as mine, and may come up short.  The mocha I ordered tasted like a hot chocolate, the only difference being I felt like my heart was beating faster than a rabbit by the time I finished (two shots of espresso for a small cup).

Meh...
author: Corey C.

description:
I'm not a coffee snob by any means, but for my money, this is some of the best coffee in the city. Yeah, yeah, yeah, it's all been said before.

But the fact that it's effectively a coffee STAND run out of a converted GARAGE in a piss-soaked & graffiti-covered ALLEY makes it have that much more cred as a down-home, no-frills establishment. 

Say what you will about it Blue Bottle -- there's gotta be SOME reason people keep making the trek down Linden St to fetch themselves a cup...
author: Pete J.

description:
GREAT COFFEE. 5 stars for the coffee, minus 4 for the service.
Terrible service. SO SLOW...keep hot water on hand, pour it over grounds...should that take so long? get over yourselves...
But the coffee is great, just buy it and make it in the comfort of your home.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Their coffee, at least their double ristretto shot is good--thick and creamy.  It probably is the only choice for me since there's no place to sit and I doubt if they'd let me take the porcelain with me to the park.  At least with espresso I don't have to hang around for longer than 15 seconds.  Probably for the best since sticking around can be pretty expensive.  I could be wrong but I think I paid $1.75 each of those bite-size Parisian macaroons, and I had two, plus $2.50 for a bottle of water.

BBCC is pretty darn serious with their coffee, and I respect that.  They don't stock up drip coffee, rather brew each cup to order using nothing but hot water, plastic cones, filters, and gravity, and grounds of course.  I just wonder though if they do the same during business mornings.  They also sell beans on site (of course) at about $6.50 per half-a- pound.   I've had their Chiappas weeks ago and just bought Alma Viva yesterday, and they're pretty good.  I look forward to sampling another blend in maybe two weeks or so.

Thank you, Blue Bottle!!!
author: Erick ..

description: On the downside, this place is difficult to find and if there is more than 1 person in line ahead of you, expect to wait a good 10 minutes. On the upside, it's one of the most unique coffee shops/stands/garages/woodshops I've ever seen! Loved the smell of sawdust with my coffee but my heart is still with Philz.
author: Susan L.

description: Foamy, creamy, chocolate heaven in a cup.  It was rainy, and hence, not as busy as usual apparently.  The barista was so friendly and accomodating- like a truly good host.  He wiped a wet chair and table so that I would be comfortable, and made friendly banter with everyone who came by.  I like this place :)
author: CAKE E.

description:
Bacon is the new chocolate- lets face it. Yeah, Chocolate is pretty tasty- and for the ladies, it seems to be even better. But really, its so 2006. Bacon is the new chocolate- trust me, its true- I read it in a fortune cookie at San Tung.....

What does that have to do with blue bottle coffee? Nothing, except for the fact that its coff-ity crack-ity goodness transcends time, and almost space (I know that's not true by the necessary trek i make to Hayes valley to get more beans- ohhh, how i'd die for a worm hole right to their door....dangerous! but I digress).

Sure, everyone gives BB a 5 star, but seriously, its worth it. The cappuccinos there are insane, and the beans I take home- regardless of the variety- are so good, I've stopped going to other coffee shops alltogether...seriously...(except for Alvins- I still loves ya guys :) )

Anyways, go, get addicted, lookout for friendly wormholes. that is all.
author: Tim V.

description: Worth the wait - i now drink drip coffee because of blue bottle. New Orleans iced, mochas, and the capps also wonderful!  I frequent this spot and always feel welcome. The savory shortbread is good, but wish they still put pinenuts in them!
author: C B.

description: Blue Bottle pulls a tasty, smooth espresso, but it's impossible to me not to get a New Orleans Iced Coffee. The iced coffee is cold brewed for about 12 hours, packing it with a serious caffeine punch that makes the hairs on my neck stand up. And because it's cold brewed, it avoids the most common iced coffee problems (bitterness and ice cube dilution). As far as beans, Blue Bottle coffee beans are a little on the steep side, but worth the purchase if you're feeling particularly fancy.
author: Jordan Z.

description: the methadone clinic of coffee shops: A long line of dejected people waiting for their fix in the cold SF morning. Had countless cups of drip and cappuccino here, and each of them has been fantastic.
author: Giacomo F.

description: hands down the best cup of coffee I have ever had in the State of California. It might seem pricey, but it is worth it! :-)
author: Daniela A.

description:
I really wanted to like this more.  I  would give it 2 1/2 stars if they made halvsies.
I notice that a lot of people commented on the espresso drinks but I stuck with the drip as that is my daily preperation albeit french press is my favorite.  So when I first went I was pschyed that they took the time to prepare it this way.  The wait was excrutiating both times and I kinda felt a little bad energy from the baristas.  It's just coffee dude, chill.
Both times I never even finished my cup!  That was the biggest sign for me that it ain't all that.
author: Sasha K.

description:
Best coffee in the city and most definitely the best coffee in Hayes Valley. It might be pricey but not pricier than a lot of other places in the city and they don't charge you extra for soy milk! I also get my coffee beans from them. The people that work there are friendly and the chocolate macaroons are to die for (though, those are *really* expensive). 

I get my morning cup here almost daily. Half of my grad student stipend goes to this place.
author: Jen M.

description:
This is good coffee; it is worth your time to hunt this place down.
It blows Ritual away.
author: Ky W.

description:
What to write, what to write.  Here are the bottom lines:
I like Lattes
These lattes are beyond description.  

The milk is steamed to perfection with the tinest bubbles that for a thick yet smooth consistency,  The roast is very tasty indeed, not too bitter, smooth.  Truly a perfect blend. . . 

I'll go back, I'll go out of my way, I'll drive to the city for it.
author: C M.

description:
I finally went there this WE and let me sum it all up: believe the hype.

Want some details? the coffee is roasted just right, the capuccinos are the closest thing I have found in this town to what one can taste in Italy. They do take their time, but when it comes to coffee (and other things...), it is a *good* thing.
author: Frederic B.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee Co. should be so grateful for all the rave reviews, and let me tell you they can just keep piling on.  I was reading up on Hayes Valley preparing to explore it over the weekend and read such great stuff about BBC that I hollered mid-Saturday morning at 5 of my compadres to come and join me on this little excursion for a great cup of joe.  Thankfully I found the small alley way where its located, my palate was pleasantly served and my tad bit cranky friends were satisfied.

Simple menu.  Excellently prepared coffee.  Knowledgeable baristas.  If its raining bring an umbrella because there's not much of a covered sitting or standing area.

Enjoy!
author: Sienna G.

description:
There is a god of coffee and he/she hath created Blue Bottle Coffee to satisfy our our earthly cravings.

Yeah, there are a lot of places that can make a good cappuccino or other coffee drink.  The real test is when you strip away all the extras and get down to the core.

Espresso and Drip coffee.  If you've never tried one of their individually prepared drip coffees then head down tomorrow and get one.  Bold, strong. PURE!

Need whole beans?  Get a few bags, they were probably roasted in the past few days.  

If you go to Linden St location be forewarned, there is 1 table and one bench to sit on.  The 'shop' is located in a garage so this is not the kind of place you go to hang out and sip your drink.  The line can get pretty long late in the morning but be patient, it's worth it.


You can also check them out on Saturday Mornings down at the Ferry Plaza farmers market.
author: Kyle R.

description:
OK. Here's the deal my fellow yelups...
I love thee Blue Balls coffee...
Move to the front if you are at the kiosk for beans.
Assume your position at the back of the line for coffee and bask in the trendyness of your two hour wait.

I reccomend you buy some of these most fantastic aromatically-charged BB beans to prepare at home.  OK OK, So it is a little intimidating to ask for a reccomendation with a zig-zagging line of caffeine-deprived yuppies behind you.  Therefore, randomly point at the coffee display and ask for a half pound of beans.  You won't be sorry the next morning when you embark on preparing coffee the authentic Blue Bottle method... while juggling a coffee grinder, a paper filter, a porcelin coffee drip, a coffee cup, a water kettle, a spoon, some cream and your last bit of dignity for having spent 10 minutes making a cup of coffee.  Resolution: Next time tip those betches, coffee is hard work, ya hear?
author: Stanley E.

description:
Legal junkie heaven. The morning drizzle of the mind is pulled inexorably to this li'l place on Linden in search of jet-black jolts of life individually filtered through richly ground fresh coffee beans.   The scents are intoxicating and the results are divine, evidenced by the amicable patience for which devotees display in search of the Ultimate Fix that is rarely displayed at Peet's or 'Bucks.

Impress your friends.  Wow your family.  Enliven your pre-noon hours.  Go to Blue Bottle.
author: Jim W.

description:
5 + stars for the coffee and cookies.  -1 star for the service.  Blue Bottle has the best coffee in the city in my opinion, that alone (should) give it a 5 star rating.  My favorite is the New Orleans iced Coffee, I am addicted to it.  The treats are delicious too, and the house roasted coffee beans make a great gift.
The service however leaves much to be desired.  You often have to wait in a huge line while the guys behind the counter blab on an on to each other on the most inane of topics without actually serving anyone.  As an example last time I went there on my lunch break the guy eventually asked me what I wanted (with 5 min of my 30 min lunch break left) and I told him the New Orleans Iced Coffee.  He stared off into space for about a minute and then said.  So you want a Cappuccino?
author: Michael D.

description:
The first time I saw this place I thought it was a needle exchange or methadone clinic. The long winding line of people in knit caps originating in a garage all looking like they're waiting for a fix...really...what would you think?!?!?!
 Luckily for me, the only drug served up in this unconventional joint is caffeine and when it was mixed with yummy chocolate goodness it may as well be crack.
 With Dark Garden Corsets right next door, it makes me wish I lived on this block!
author: Heather P.

description:
I had heard so much about Blue Bottle that I had to drag my girlfriend out of bed, drive half way across town, circle Hayes Valley until I found the right entrance onto Linden, and then wait in line for coffee served out of a garage.
It seems that there are three types of people when it comes to Blue Bottle. 1) They love it, and can be a bit snobby about it, or 2) they act like they are too snobby for snobby coffee, or 3) they have no idea what the hell blue bottle is.
Blue Bottle is great. I cannot think of a time when I have had better coffee, at least within driving distance. I was worried that it was going to be a case of the emperor's new clothes, but it wasn't.
I give it 5 stars because I think it lives up to the hype.
author: Ben S.

description:
No one can defeat the QUAD MOCHA.  Seriously, this drink would be a class A substance if the feds got a taste.

(nevermind that you can't get a better espresso shot anywhere in the city)
author: Asher F.

description: Always dependable for excellent coffee.  A nice mid afternoon Blue Bottle drip helps finish off the day!  Service is always good.  Love both the Ferry Building store and the the Mint Plaza shop.
author: April M.

description: Went to this place on a visit from Texas. Loved it. It was hip and fresh. The food was classy and the place was lively. Check out the fun old coffee machine, which has a dramatic view of how the coffee is made.
author: Lindsey B.

description:
I'll review what I've had:
1) New Orleans Iced Coffee: they sweeten the coffee and add the milk, all in the right proportions. It looks a little small when compared to your typical iced coffee, but alas this is no run-of-the-mill coffee. This cup was brewed to sip as you slowly revel in it's glory.

2) Cafe Latte: Pretty tasty, packs just the right punch, though I think there is room for improvement on the foam.

3) Drip Coffee: Just a fine cup of coffee, but not "blow-yer-socks-off" good. I'd recommend grabbing a bag of their beans and brewing some at home or work rather than coming here for just a cup o' joe.


Everything's a little pricey (relatively speaking) but worth it.

So grab yerself a cup of some Nawlins Iced, walk down to the park, bask in the sun, and sip slowly - realizing you've never had a coffee this tasty.
author: Matt F.

description:
Living a couple doors down from Blue Bottle has its priveleges.  In exchange for the lovely perfume steadily wafting by our back door and those heavenly lattes mere steps away in the mornings, there's just one downside.  

It sounds a lot like, "oh, I'll just be a minute" and looks like a car blocking the driveway I share with 12 other people.  If it's been your car, then you can stop wondering where all your good parking karma went.

Enjoy your great cup of coffee, and if you have to park your car, please do it on the sidewalk rather than blocking the locals' access.  Either spot might elicit a ticket from the local meter maids, but the sidewalk isn't considering investing in a paintball gun.
author: Denise B.

description:
Hey you guys ITS ZOE  ( THE ICED COFFEE GIRL) I miss you guys and the coffee !!!!  I have been making my own but it is not even close to the coffee you gave me every morning ! I want to thank you guys for the bottle of coffee you guys gave me for the road  trip it was the best  and it came in very handy! I hope you are all well and i miss ya  O yeah whenever i hear of someone taking a trip to SF i tell them they have to come check you guys out and get the best coffee ever!!!  


This is the only place to get coffee in the city!  You can't get better service and coffee any where else. I have been drinking Iced Coffee for a while and this is the best I have ever had I am HOOKED....I go  everyday and the great thing they get to kow you the more you go and you always see the same people there so you know that means GREAT COFFEE!
author: Blythe R.

description: Having recently moved to SF from Seattle, I'd been struggling with finding "my fave local coffee" until I was introduced to Blue Bottle. Best Latte in SF.
author: Jaime H.

description:
Believe the Hype. 

This is absolutely the best coffee I've found anywhere in the city - and I'm always on the lookout for good coffee.  (seriously, if you know of any other greats places, let me know)

Only problem is it's so small so the throughput isn't great.  Expect to stand in line for a while, but if you've got a few minutes to spare, it's worth the wait.  

The coffee's good enough that I'm not knocking off any stars for the wait..
author: Jonathan K.

description:
Hands down, the best. My favorite coffee.

Though we never feel hip looking enough when we stop there in the morning on the way to work in our conservative office clothes. The guys working there seem to look down their noses at us...
author: Cheryl M.

description:
Yum! Great coffee. As good as it gets out here in America... or that I've had.
Someone said it's better than Barefoot (http://www.yelp.com/biz/barefoot-coffee-roasters-santa-clara). Maybe a little bit, or maybe they're about the same... 
I guess I just didn't dig the literal hole-in-the-wall style of this place. Maybe I'd like the real-cafe location a lot more. I just felt kinda bleh drinking my coffee quickly and getting out of there.

But I had a nice conversation with the other people in line, so quit bashing the hipsters you guys!! I hear if you're nice to them, they're nice to you. Try it sometime.
author: Sasha W.

description: Bring a coffee snob here from anywhere in the world and they will think you're hella cool. This stuff is hand dripped goodness -- rich, dark, simple, and lovely. Organic milk and sugar only enhance the flavor sensation. Uh-oh spagetti-O's the coffee snobs don't seem to love it.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Their 8 ounce drip coffee is perfect for me
It's the right size a coffee should be

That aside, there are many reviews about how Blue Bottle brew is black gold.

- Temperature is good and flavor is average.
- No bitterness and light on the tongue; a plus as Peets is too strong for my tastes.
- Service was pleasant.
- Would like to see a wider variety of roasts.

My review is based on experience at the Ferry Building cart. Visit it during Tuesday's market to avoid a long line.
author: Adam W.

description:
Update: October 18, 2008

Simply heaven in a cup.  I love all of the coffee shops, restaurants, and kiosks that sell Blue Bottle coffee/beans, but this location makes me all gooey inside.  Talented, talented roasters and baristas.  
-----------------------------------------------------------------


Wonderful, tasty coffee.  Not over roasted like some other coffee giants (hint: they end in "bucks" and "eets").  Funky (in a good way) location.  I always feel like I'm part of an underground movement when I buy my coffee beans there.  I love the Ethiopian Yirgacheffe.  

When are they going to open a stand in Oakland?
author: Tamiko J.

description:
I am a coffee drinker at heart, pumping caffeine into my little body since early high school when it was cool to be a barista where all the high school girls went to feel like adults. 

Let me tell you that this java packs a punch. I finally took a sunshine stroll down here to try what everyone has been raving about and it was a delightfully satisfying experience. I love the bustle of the alley, the fact that people hang out there to sip on their espresso shots while commingling with strangers and regulars alike. I love that the staff shares the passion for delicious coffee and they provide top of the class service. They offer something different and I will be back many a Saturday mornings to start the day off right. 

Next time I am trying the Gibraltar.
author: Alicia J.

description: I have lived in this neighborhood for 3 yrs. and watched Blue Bottle go from cool and great cup of coffeel to ridiculous. The staff ALWAYS skips my coffee and gives it to the next person in line. I'm sorry, but the long lines are SO NOT WORTH IT either. It's really not that great of a place in less you have no job, no life, or have massive time on your hands. Sure, the coffee is great, but at what a cost! Every time I go there, and it's only in times that I've run out of coffee completely, I dread the fact that it takes 30 min to get my coffee, and I leave totally irritated.
author: Brooke A.

description:
Great coffee due to small batch roasting of the finest organic coffee beans. The best lattes ever and the drip is pretty awesome too. This location is pretty bare bones, just a garage with coffee and few munchies. 

A note on the lattes: if you like your lattes so screaming hot that you can barely taste the roast then this is not the place for you. They heat the milk just right so that the drinker can experience the balance and warmth of flavors between the coffee and the milk.
author: cora j.

description:
Generally I can't stand the hipsters, BUT the coffee is that good.

It was a real conundrum for me, as I  only like iced coffee and I like it black. Blue Bottle's only iced drink is a New Orleans style iced coffee, which has a bunch of milk and sugar.

I decided to order one anyway, and a macchiato just for the hell of it.

This was about 3 hours ago. I'm still shaking now, but it's a good happy shake. I drive an hour with that buzz, but the taste was so damn good I want to drive back to the city now and have another one.

The line was half way down Linden with a variety of Mission chumps, lesbians, a couple of Suicide Girls and a bunch of middle aged lefties talking about the Oscars. As much as all that sucked (besides the Suicide Girls) the bean juice made up for it.
author: Jason R.

description:
AWESOME.

I usually get a cappucino.
Sometimes I get a mocha (when I want to get a pre-sweetened drink, so I don't have to ruin the beautiful pour)
When it's quiet, I get a gibraltar and relax.
author: Ben S.

description:
not much of a line, I guess we got there in time.
the folks behind the counter were friendly, until a woman parked across the street where she shouldn't.  They yelled to her that she should move, and she did, but while she was gone, they joked about her being a breeder (as if that is why she parked there?)
At first I thought he said breather, which is funnier.
so yeah, the coffee is good, but the staff could actually appreciate that people want to purchase their coffee, no matter where they park or if they have kids.
author: Zachary S.

description: Always enjoy stopping here for a Gibraltar and pastry when I'm in Hayes Valley- nice laid-back  spot in the alley to sit and enjoy your coffee and take in the ambience.
author: JOHN S.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said?  

Well, I am a fan of Peet's as a regular at the 3rd/Mission location.  But tried this today as our friend was driving us from Kezar Stadium, he had to make a stop.  He asked if it was ok if we stopped for some coffee...I chirped up (instead of my non-coffee drinking husband) and said, no problem here!  

So we actually found parking only one street over, which was great for a Saturday afternoon.  There were a few people in line, so my friend explained to me how popular their coffee beans have become.  He suggested that I get some beans to go, so, I did.  He's a coffee person, so I can trust him.  

I ordered a cappucino, which was a bit more like an extra foamy latte...but it was damn good!  Oh, the sweet, creamy milk and the aromatic freshly ground espresso was just the combination I needed to relax on our way home.  

My friend is also bringing me a grinder he doesn't need, so that will be good...I got rid of mine as I usually have my beans ground (yeah, yeah, I know).  My french press will be so happy with me on Sunday!
author: Anne O.

description:
Ok, everyone's crazy about blue bottle, I can see why and I can see why I'm not.

1) Nice coffee, really nice, but still not great. With the price they charge you for the beans, you get much better beans at House of Coffee on Noriega. I don't know if they roast their beans daily, like Henry at the House of Coffee does, but the staffs don't seem to know their beans fully. 

2) Best iced coffee I've had. They add this "chickory" to their iced-coffee that makes it taste amazing, especially on a hot summer day at the ferry plaza farmer's market. 

3) Good cappuccino. Very nice and creamy. A bit too creamy for my taste actually. If you like it creamy, place to go. 

4) Hot chocolate. Very nice with the marshmallow from Recchiuti, so chewy but soft after soaked in the drink for a while. But I'm spoiled by the MarieBelle in NYC. This is just not as good.

5) Latte like the cappuccino, nice and creamy.

Overall it's a very neat place. I can see why people love it so much. The tiny booth that's artfully hidden in the alley of Hayes valley. Doesn't try too hard, which I like. I like the customers too that they just randomly sit on the ground, chat with each other, enjoy the coffee. I love the feeling of carelessness and randomness of the scene. Wondering where it is? You'll smell it when you are close, then the line will tell you where it is. 

We need more coffee shops like this so people know better, not to appreciate Starbucks. Just by thinking about starbucks makes me want to puke. Yuck!!

Why 3 stars only. I'm just picky and spoiled by good food, especially when it comes to coffee and pastry.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
The best coffee I've ever had, hands down.  Thankfully I work only a block away so I can wander over on one of those mornings that require a little extra caffeine.  On weekdays the line is usually not that bad, at the most I've had to wait maybe 10 minutes my coffee.  It's only 75 cents more for a latte than Starbucks, and if you're going to pay for coffee you might as well pay a bit more for the good stuff.  Sure it's not a fancy coffee shop, it's a kiosk in a storage room with a roll up door in an alley.  But it's a nice alley, not one of those seedy ones.

The latte is my personal favorite, that thick, delicious Clover milk and a smooth and rich espresso with a hint of chocolate.  It really makes those cold winter mornings so much more bearable.  Also, the milk is steamed to the perfect temperature so you don't need one of those cardboard holder things, so you can tell yourself the extra 75 cents is for being green.
author: Jason R.

description:
Yeah, "Woohoo! As good as it gets!" hah. 22 people in line and worth the short wait. It's to me the perfect cup of coffee. I got a Soy Latte (as recommended by other yelpers, thanks) not to over hype it, it's just perfect, not too strong, great coffee flavor, the soy milk was slightly sweet so I didn't have to add any of my own. Looks beautiful with it's light and dark swirls. 

I recommend making the trip over here if you like coffee.  and I too wish they were in LA, altho I don't get the vibe that they want to take over the world. Just a humble, hole in the wall, coffee place, with a great vibe.
author: david s.

description:
Blue Bottle puts out some quality coffee, but there are many factors working against them that the coffee cannot make up for. I rate the coffee at 5 stars, but the Hayes location at a 3, therefore meeting in the middle at 4 for this review.

I've only had the Espresso drinks on location, which have been consistently good. The New Orleans Iced Coffee is heavenly on a hot day. I find it a refreshing way to get my caffeine fix.

I have also bought whole beans from them. The Chiapas is a nice well-rounded coffee that I prepare in my french press or melitta cone, and I very much dig the Espresso Temescal as well.

Plus, they have many beautiful people that work there... nice eye candy while you wait for your coffee (which can sometimes be quite a wait). The lack of seating almost always makes me get my drinks to go.
author: Courtney P.

description:
Update!! 
My roommate is a genus. She advised me to buy a pound of their beans and make the coffee myself in the morning. I have a little french press and some fancy vanilla syrup, ohlaa its just as good as the cafe's!

--------
This place is responsible for my recent coffee addiction. Which has gotten really expensive lately. Damn addiction!
author: Kelly F.

description:
Line can get long, but it is worth the wait.  

Rich, caramel-like crema.  Non-acidic, smooth flavor.  The froth is creamy and swirled to perfection.

I break my rule of a 1pm cut-off for caffeine when I get here late.
author: Jan S.

description:
Ah, there's nothing like waiting in line for 10 minutes to get a drip coffee in order to feel "in" and "cool" at this coffee kiosk in a garage in an alley.  It's an experience!  I can't judge, I did it.  And the coffee was strong, just how I like it.

And yes, people -- if you let the line go into the street, cars will honk at you.  Jesus.
author: Tamara M.

description:
Oh, it's GOOD.
It's REALLY good.
In fact, it's SO good, that I'm perfectly willing to shell out $4 a cup AND drop a buck or two for my oh-so-talented barista. 

The lattes are dreamy. The coffee is bold and refreshing. The mochas are to die for. 

I don't eat here though. Why? Because if I'm already in Hayes Valley, odds are I'll be spending money like I've got it. See exhibit A.

Oh well. Thankfully BBC (hah) is far enough from my house to make it a treat instead of a routine. The perfect lazy bum Sunday stop.
author: Megan B.

description:
The Blue Bottle is one of the reasons I constantly miss San Francisco. Sometimes I wake up in the morning and sleepily plan my day while lying in bed and mumble to myself "I'll just grab a latte from the Blue Bottle and then head on over to...oh wait...". Their espresso is excellent and could actually be mistaken for the stuff I drank in Italy which is no mean feat. Incredibly rich and smooth and scrumptious, and my favorite latte in the world.

This place was great when it was just the walk-up stand, but then they opened up in the Mint and I really love that spot. But what really makes them unique is their Japanese siphon bar, which is the only one in the world outside of Japan. It brews regular old coffee very very slowly over some insane period of time, I think 36 hours. When I was there they had just opened it and were running around giving out free samples in little beakers. It was very smooth, not bitter at all, and definitely unique. A must-drink for a coffee snob.
author: Leanna G.

description: James is da man. And Blue Bottle owns me. No crazy roasts full of burn. No sickly milk coladas. Just coffee done well. Coffee where you can actually taste the coffee. Such a simple and beautiful concept. Macchiato please!
author: Mike W.

description: Had the New Orleans iced coffee, wife had the siphon experience - the coffee was unlike anything I've ever tasted, and man do I have a coffee addiction. Worth the line, if you're in the shopping district or South of Market. Heard a review dissing the clerks, but the two that practically jumped the two of us were cool, patient and knowledgeable. One might even say the tall blond girl was adorable.
author: Terrence D.

description:
This was my first coffee experience in SF, and coming from a background of home-roasting coffee, I was very disappointed.  Perhaps the hype surrounding this cute little shop got my hopes up too high.  

When I try a new coffee shop, I try a latte first, and if that's good, I'll go to espresso shots.  The latte is so I can determine whether the cafe knows their espresso, and can finish a moderately enjoyable drink, even if the coffee is bad.

Whether they had poorly-roasted beans or just needed to clean the espresso machine, I couldn't tell, but the espresso was so incredibly bitter, I couldn't even drink it with its nice foamy mask.  No way would I go back and stand in a line for 15 minutes for straight up espresso.

I did go back 2 times for lattes and drip, out of sheer appreciation for the literal hole-in-the-wall coffee joint, and out of wanting to like their coffee, but each time it was so bitter, I stand by my initial take.
author: Lucca C.

description:
Yummy Latte'!
Even yummier guy making it, I will return.
author: Douggers M.

description:
Good Idea:

I want the Blue Bottle people to push their cart right behind the Tamale Lady.

They'll get my fifth star when they do that.
author: Patrick A.

description:
Blue Bottle has got the darkest and most milk palatable roasts in SF that I've found.  Ok, I've only been here 10 months but it's still the best.  If you want better then try Rituals blends, much smoother and matched for a simple espresso or French Press.  But if you're a milk lover you can't beat Blue Bottle's coffee.  Starbucks is similar in their over roasting but Blue Bottle knows how to do it right, leaving an earthy flavor in the beans rather than that charcoal, blanched taste you'd get at Starbucks.  

I dig.
author: Troy S.

description:
This coffee is so good I saw Juan Valdez and Howard Schultz (dressed as a homeless person) waiting in line behind me.  

I usually have two sips and I'm bouncing off the wall.  If I could have this in an I.V. drip I would be set every single morning.
author: Dennis M.

description:
I had the latte.  Nothing spectecular.  The milk quality was good, the foam was well made.  The espresso though did not have that permeating and lasting lingering finish that I like at Ritual.  The whole drink was a little too milky - the balance seemed off.  

There was a line at 3pm on Sunday but the wait wasn't too bad, even in the cold windy alley. 

I'll reserve judgement on their coffee next time...
author: Hanson L.

description:
OK. This place is good. Really. I'd sit here ranting and raving about how it was the greatest coffee I'd ever tasted. I really would. 

But I can't. I've had better at Barefoot down south.

I think the main difference is that Barefoot does such a great job with the interesting single origin coffees (including lots of pea berry), something that seems lacking here.
author: Joe D.

description: In short, one of the main reasons SF is a better coffee town than Seattle. Love the recent alley upgrade (cool little micro-park). In the years since this place opened, I've never had a better cappuccino or macchiato... anywhere.
author: Aneel C.

description:
The super-trendy Uglerati* of San Francisco have spoken.  And in this case they know what they are talking about.

Blue Bottle is one of those insanely good, anointed, unbelievably pretentious "kiosks" where they sell you coffee with their attitude.  Even growing up Catholic did little to prepare me for the guilt and shame they want you to feel for even ordering something.  The height of the counter suggests a visit to the Wizard of Oz, so don't go questioning the man (or lady) behind the curtain.  

OmG the customers are *so* tense and judgmental.  In line, not even a long line, things were quite awkward.  I actually busted a stage whisper to my friend "This Must Be Really Good Coffee" before the other people standing around, glaring, were shamed into pretending it was okay that I came there.

So (for me) the regular temperature of the beverages served seems to be lukewarm.  I was grossed out and disappointed. Recently decided to give it another try.  This time I CAREFULLY inquired about the temperature of the beverage when ordering.  Don't say extra hot, that's what they say at (gasp) Starbucks ... say extra haute!  No seriously, don't make jokes.  Not there.  But everything they make seems to be tops.

* New Orleans Style Au Lait (for all that chicory goodness)
* Café Mocha (contains an *entire* bar of chocolate)

Presentation 10.  Flavor 10.  
Seriously can't wait until they open one in Ferry Building Market!
--
* def. Uglerati (noun/adj.)  [Sm]ugly transplants to S.F. who reside mostly in gentrified areas.  Dress bad on purpose, presumably for an poser-modern ironic effect.  Still really superficial, uhh just not so easy on the eyes.
author: Herb C.

description:
I know it's pricey but if you like to make your own coffee/espresso, this is THE place to buy your beans. I've shopped all over town (The Castro, Noe Valley, Fillmore Street, North Beach, etc.) since moving here in 1981 and Blue Bottle has the best quality and variety by far.

Try the Chiapas 3 blend in your Bialetti stainless steel stovetop espresso maker if you don't believe me...
author: Tweaty B.

description:
Divine. Lattes.

I even like standing in the street on a Saturday morning -- there's a sense of camaraderie in line, the baristas are friendly and smart, and there's a sense of excitement in the air.

I love it.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
WOW!  Every time I go to SF, I hit up this place at least once a day for coffee.  The mocha's are absolutely amazing.  The espresso alone has such a rich flavor, and they use only the best chocolate.  The mochas are rich and creamy, and always served at a perfect temperature.  
PLUS, the design on top of the drink is always a surprise, and always very impressive =)  
BLUE BOTTLE I heart you.
author: L S.

description:
Do you like drip coffee? If you are in San Francisco, west of Civic Center, east of Hayes Valley, make sure you stop in this unique coffee shop. 

The drip coffee is quality, strong yet aromatic. 
The latte is truly the crème de la crème, nice foamy top, makes you wanna just have some breakfast. 

I wish they have chairs to sit and chat. Cute location, quality coffee in SF.
author: Jack C.

description:
It is true that the coffee is excellent.  

What amazes me most, though, is that despite the long lines that form outside of Blue Bottle Coffee Co. on Linden Alley, the baristas manage to politely engage all the patrons while devoting their full attention to producing an amazing cup of coffee, latte or mocha.
author: Michael P.

description:
A friend from work brings in the beans from here.

Plain and simple, it's the best coffee I've ever had.  Full of complex flavors.  I like "3 Africans" the most.
author: Matt W.

description: Picture perfect latte! Thank you for Clover Organic Milk. Yum!
author: E H.

description: Best coffee in the city in my humble opinion. Great neighborhood gathering spot - during the day it is the Van Ness professionals who line up, but in the weekends, it's all Hayes Valley folks and retail gurus. Everyone knows your name and they know what you're getting. I like to go Saturday afternoons to chat with neighbors, and to get advice on which new roast I should try out. I buy fresh beans every week and stick it in a vacuum sealed bag into the freezer in between daily grinds. At $7.50 for 8 oz. it seems like a lot of $, but for the quality of coffee you can get out of a french press at home far exceeds that of any espresso drink you could acquire at other coffee shops, which, if you drink a cup a day, this bag should last you about 2 weeks, and that's like less than 40 cents a cup. Well worth it.
author: Y K.

description:
Just moved back to San Francisco from Seoul, South Korea and what an awesome surprise Blue Bottle Coffee is. I had always heard rumor of its excellent taste but was a bit skeptical as I have long been devoted to the brew of Philz Coffee. 

However, since Philz left its prime location next to the epic gathering place that locals city wide love- Dolores Park- Ive been searching for a new alternative. 

And so Ive found it. Blue Bottle Coffee in the Hayes Valley neck of the woods is located in an out of the way alley and draws an interesting assortment of people that characterizes what makes this city so great; we have the hip, the lesbians, thin framed glasses wearing baby boomer generation, and assortment of northern Europeans speaking barely recognizable languages, and of course everything else in between. Drawing this group together is the excellent coffee selected by Blue Bottle Coffee. 

They keep it simple. Keeping it simple works for them as the coffee is excellent and delightfully unadorned by a clusterf**k of seasonal teddy bears and silicon trivets. The coffee here will run you average to or less than average than most other spots in the City and is far better. 

Im looking forward to trying their new spot on top of the MoMA.
author: Thomas P.

description: I can officially say that this is the best back alley latte iv'e ever had.
author: Sean D.

description: I bought your coffee, ground the whole half pound at another store on my way home, and then I brewed it in a Mr. Coffee. Muahahahahahaha!!!!
author: Genevieve H.

description:
I've died and gone to coffee heaven. Just another reason to be addicted to fuckin' AWESOME coffee. 
Well worth the sometimes 15 minute wait in the cold Linden alleyway. if you can't find the place just walk to Hayes and Gough then follow your nose.
The Baristas are always attentive and efficient, some times taking your order when your still at the back of the line. You'd think these guys would be all hopped up on caffeine, far from it , it's more like a state of coffee zen for them.
Consistency Consistency Consistency.
That's what you'll get here along with the fuckin' BEAUTIFUL coffee.
author: Brian J.

description:
For someone who doesn't drink too much coffee and picky when I do this is it!!!

Cappuccinos are the s##t!!!

Yes slow service but how do you rush something so good? If you hit it at the right time and only get one or two strangers in front of you you're set. 

The one in the alley in Hayes Valley is the only one I go to.

AB
author: Anthony B.

description:
Thanks for always giving me a little latte art in my breve.
And every once in awhile I'll get that Gibraltar, I promise!

Even the apple juice/ cider is amazing! Unreal!!
author: dj z.

description: For not being my favorite coffee shop which is in the Seattle/Tacoma area, this place is really great. Coffee and that is it. I love the location there in the downtown San Fran area. When I come back I will definitely be going there again
author: Aaron C.

description:
What would I do without Blue bottle? It gets me through the day.
The iced new Orleans is my fav!

Blue Bottle is a little too strong though. If I don't drink it at a snails pace I end up like a crazed lunatic for a good hour. If you see me acting all jittery, please don't talk to me. Its for your own good.
author: Trina H.

description: It's worth the wait in line! The drip coffee is amazing. If only I could wake up to this every morning.  I can't wait to go back and try it iced!
author: Sarah Z.

description:
5 star coffee with 5 star ambiance to match.  Along with my Sunday NY Times, I'm transported back to the City for the morning.

Definitely check it out.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Coffee Nirvana!

What more can be said about a place that has a permanent line, dispite the fact it is located on a small alley between 2 very busy street. The drip is the way to go. Smooth, full-bodied, and sublime. If I had to cap on one thing, it would be their poor selection of food items. But who the hell is there for the food?
author: Jim B.

description: Cute hole in the wall kind of place. Excellent espresso, excellent drip coffee, friendly staff!
author: Danielle A.

description:
every time we queue up for coffee my husband always talks about BB's business model.. how they are making so much money bcs of the ridiculous mark up.. how they are running the cafe out of a garage.. how the menu is so simple.. its a given, the founders are geniuses in their own right.  

i always get the iced coffee and he would always get the brewed coffee... nothing fancy.. but then why the fancy prices? bcs each cup is freshly brewed? hmph...  i overheard the barista telling a customer that the beans for the ice coffee were "rejects" and "left over" beans.. she said to not buy new beans to brew ice coffee.. to just use old left over beans.. bcs that's what BB does.. O RLY??? then why am i paying 3.50 for some old crusty beans?? 

anyways.. the coffee is good.. but philz is much better.
author: Mon C.

description: A little stand hidden in an alley with a line at 8AM on a Sunday morning! Must be good coffee, right? The coffee was good indeed! Blue bottle's drip coffee is smooth without that bite at the end that some coffees may have.  The milk is perfectly frothed, creamy and fluffy.  The macchiatos are served in tiny cups to drink there, but the only problem is there is really no where to sit.  The coffee shop roasts great beans, but it would be better if there were places to sit and enjoy the coffee. Wish they had a LA location =(
author: Judy H.

description: Iced Chicory Coffee, perfection, go when the lines are less...ie not the prime hours and there is no reason to not love this unless you like coffee from a drive through, a gas station or Starbucks...
author: Kacey H.

description: this mornings meditation - dark crema, warmer than blood. Bittersweet petals unfold; caught up in my reverie I get up, walk away. "Stellah", the barrista, calling my name I turn, so enchanted was I, that I'd forgotten to pay.
author: Stellah D.

description:
It's in a garage. The coffee is high quality. They have a vintage La Marzocco. That's all pretty neat.

There's no sign. The traffic is purely word of mouth. It's in an alley. Basically, the only sign that it's there is the line waiting (sometimes 25 minutes or more) for a cup of coffee. (The wait -is- an issue. It costs the place a star.)

The mocha is very good (they use high quality chocolate, for certain). They make one of the best cafe Americanos ever. So what's the deal?

It's just too damned cute. From the apparent vespa parking lot in the back to the unfinished styling that is just too carefully designed; it's a bit much.

...But, the coffee is really good...
author: Aiden B.

description:
After hearing so much about Blue Bottle Coffee, I had to try it myself.  After an upsetting hunt for it at the Ferry Building the night before (apparently, they only have the stand when Farmer's Market is set up) we went to the Hayes Valley location Sunday afternoon.  I was a bit shocked with the long line, but was determined to wait in it.  I thought the $3.50 latte was good to try, but for some reason, it didn't wow me as much as I would have liked it to...maybe I was too hyped up about it?? I can definitely taste the difference in the milk they use- good quality, organic stuff that left a smooth finish. Loved the little design topped off on my latte. 

Will definitely try the mocha and cappuccino here...perhaps these will win me over...?
author: Lisa C.

description:
I consider myself a bit of a coffee snob. I'm the kind of person who has four different coffee making devices in the kitchen, the kind of person who takes the extra time to use a manual drip cone because coffee just tastes BETTER that way. I digress.
The best coffee at Blue Bottle is the New Orleans Iced, and the espresso. They make all of their drip individually, but Philz excels in the drip coffee game. Blue Bottle is just a little kiosk, but the espresso is so, so good. It's rich and dark, without being bitter, and it isn't ever overpowered by the addition of sugar or milk. The baristas even make little hearts in my foam. I love that! It's the little things, really.
author: Steffany F.

description:
They treat the coffee with respect. I like that. 
Sadly, for me, their coffee wasn't dark enough. But that's a personal preference. 
Surprisingly they have a New Orleans blend iced coffee. As I worship a certain Nola coffee, keeping mass quantities of it stocked in my home and office at all times, I was delighted to see this. 
This monster of a drink was something else. Nothing like an iced coffee one might get in NO, but still amazing. It was thick and creamy, and I marveled at something so liquidy, being so filling. I only wish I liked their hot coffee as much as their iced.
author: Dixon T.

description:
Hot damn hot damn! Hands down the best shot of espresso that has ever crossed these lips. Well worth the 10 minute wait in some alley. Grab your coffee and tiny Miette cookie, take a seat on the sidewalk and watch the rest of the patrons. A fun and eclectic mix of SF residents will have congregated by the time you are done sipping the rocket fuel they call a Gibraltar. 
According to my all knowing friend...its a shot of the good stuff topped with steamed milk... so like a mini latte? She rolls eyes as if on cue. I would have been offended had I not been hopped up on caffeine.
author: Stacy T.

description: Blue Bottle was a cool spot to check out on our visit to San Francisco.  We grabbed a couple of americano misto's and sat on the rocks in the alley on a fine morning.  I wasn't blown away by their espresso, but enjoyed checking the place out.  Would I go again when in town again?  Sure, why not.
author: Chris G.

description:
Mighty fine cuppa joe..

a neighborhood phenom..
author: aynne v.

description:
My brother in law took us here for the first time.  When he started down the alley, I thought "oh crap! he finally snapped and I am going to die here."  Then I saw the line coming out of the garage.  He ordered for us and while we waited, we talked:

"There's no place to sit"
"We'll sit in the park"
"The cups are so small"
"Wait till you drink it"
"What is this pastry?"
"Ginger scone"
"I don't like giner"
"Try it.  You'll like it"
"But.."
"TRY IT"
"Yeah, its good"
"How much longer?"
"Shut up!"

The coffee here is good.  And they make pictures in your foam.  The guys aren't very friendly but I would rather they get the drinks out then chat me up.  

I wanted to dislike this place but in the end, it's better then okay, its four stars.
author: Angela A.

description: You can't go wrong with Blue Bottle. It is a SF standard, worth the wait, and never disappoints. I have been to most of their locations but the Hayes Valley one is my favorite one. I think I just like the alley!
author: Katherine B.

description:
I work nearby and never realized this place was here until I saw the a-frame sign walking down Gough.

I love coffee. LOVE LOVE LOVE. But I can't wait in a line 12 people deep and then proceed to wait another 6.5 minutes for a drip coffee because they brew each cup individually with a filter suspended over the cup while they pour hot water into it and use a spoon to mix up the water and coffee grounds. 

After all that, my cup of coffee was just alright. I think it was the Bella Donnovan blend. MEH. Muddy and flat. Perhaps that is why so many people in line ordered coffee drinks. I just like a good and simple cup of coffee. There is just too much fuss over this coffee. The way everyone clamors up to the line, you'd think this was mind-blowing stuff.

It's not worth the waiting time and not worth dealing with the pretentious atmosphere.

Conditions will have to be just right for me to try this place again. And maybe at another location if I happen to be nearby.
author: S. S.

description:
Mixed reviews, huh?  Yeah, well the wait can be a pain in the @$$... and sometimes I think you're there on the honor system, because you have to throw a fist full of money at them before they move onto the next customer.  But ladies and gents, the coffee is like pure cocoa.  Its dark and chocolatey.  I - to be fair - have never had a latte, or any other espresso drink, cause the drip is plenty for me.  And its lovingly prepared!

I say yes!

Love,
Sara
author: Sara W.

description:
1.  Put baby in car seat and carry her down two sets of stairs.
2.  Place car seat in back of car.
3.  Drive from Potrero Hill to Hayes Valley.
4.  Circle for parking, or find a spot in one of the alleys.
5.  Pick baby out of the backseat.
6.  Open the super complicated Bugaboo Chameleon stroller and attach all components.
7.  Feed meter.
8.  Walk a few blocks to Blue Bottle for the New Orleans style iced coffee.
9.  Do the reverse of all of the following and head home.

IT'S THAT GOOD, BABY!!!
author: Poker B.

description:
It takes a special place to compel me to come out of my self-imposed Yelp exile, but Blue Bottle is so got damn beautiful that I'd never forgive myself if I stayed silent.

For you see, I write this review on behalf of my fellow coffee lovers.  I'm a simple man, and I have a handful of simple goals.  End racism.  Bring peace and prosperity to the world.  Find the perfect cup of coffee.  The first 2 will likely consume the rest of my life.  The last one?  Well, it might not be "perfect", but I have to say that it's pretty fucking close.

I love iced coffee.  I drink it by the gallons.  Blue Bottle's iced coffee?  Fucking amazing.  It has a rich, smoky, roasted flavor.  It lingers in your mouth after you drink it.  Like the afterglow after good sex.  Yes, I'm comparing Blue Bottle coffee to sex.  

Even more amazing?  I hate milk in my coffee.  I think it ruins the flavor.  But somehow, Blue Bottle has figured out some magical combination or formula where milk in your iced coffee actually tastes good.  

So please, racism and poverty may not end anytime soon, but at least I can point to a place where everyone can go to experience magical awesomeness in a cup.
author: P. I.

description: I don't know a whole  about coffees but if I can taste the difference, I'm sure it must be something magical.  I should move to Halley Valley solely so I can grab a cup every morning.  Don't mind the Soy Latte, but even the drip coffee tastes amazing.  And there is the Gibraltar, which I've never tried but I guess is kinda cappuccinoish? maybe stronger?
