Stop by don't mind the line, and if you are from out of town get a couple bags.
author: Summit S.

description:
OK so the line is totally ridiculous, especially when you are in front of/behind jerks (which it seems like I can be a lot), but once you get  your cup of joe all the world's problems are solved, at least until you reach the bottom of the cup.

These are the freshest beans I have ever encountered, they are even fresher if you care to take a ride to the oh so exciting Emeryville and pick them up (for about a buck cheaper) from their warehouse.

The only thing is once I get hooked on a blend, they run out (oh how I miss you Misty Valley), but they always seem to amaze me with the next recommendation.
author: Nicole S.

description: Had my first blue bottle coffee experience here while trolling Hayes Valley with a my cousin from DC. It was a straightforward coffee-stand experience (like the lemonade stand reference below). The baristas were pleasant and mellow. My cappuccino was petite but perfectly tasty.
author: Jojo L.

description: Ordered coffee online and got my shipment! Totally friendly customer service and no hidden shipping charges. Great in person and great Internet store, the only drawback is that they ship twice a week, but that's easily understandable since they only send freshly roasted beans...
author: Jeff C.

description:
realllly enjoy their latte (not their lines of course) and also prefer this location.

why only 4 stars? I prefer philz and their mocha tesora. Also, they need to step their barista skills up.  I like my latte HOT, not lukewarm. Thanks.
author: Josie A.

description: If you've ever been to Australia or New Zealand and have that lingering hankering for a flat white, here's your answer: a short latte from blue bottle. It's the best cuppa I've had in this hemisphere! I look forward to one every day that I'm in the area. The staff are friendly and efficient and their line, though often long, moves quickly.
author: Mick C.

description: I hesitate to equate coffee with spirituality, but Blue Bottle Coffee is a religious experience. This coffee, espresso, latte, macchiato or whatever you have is beyond expectations. Every time I go I'm amazed at the simple, uncomplicated facade of the establishment, the truly kind and courteous staff and java that will make you cry.  How I wish they could just magically replace every Starbucks in SF, that would be heaven. (But there I go again with the spiritual imagery.)
author: Nicolas E.

description:
blue bottle coffee uses only organic coffee beans and organic milk. the best ingredients. their menu is super-simple, with only a few items on it. they are the In-N-Out Burger of coffee.

not only is their coffee really good, but the best part about it is that they serve it warm, not hot. which means -- get this --- you can actually drink it right away! you don't have to wait for it to cool down first.

and the fact that they take up so little actual real estate (at their linden street location) is a testament to their efficiency.

in short, great coffee, simple presentation, friendly service.
author: Sam Y.

description:
The coffee here is stellar.  It was pretty hot out last week, so my girlfriend and I both got iced coffees, mine a latte, and hers a New Orleans style iced coffee.  While both were rich, creamy, and strong, we both preferred the latter, it was sweeter and good to go out of the box.

Given that there are a lot of cute specialty shops in the area, I definitely recommend checking out Bluebottle.  Plus, if you're a coffee connoisseur, they seem to have a bean for every taste.  Once I'm out of beans, I'm gonna come back and give them a spin.
author: Tony L.

description:
If I lived down the street, I'd be here every morning. Period. Single-cup coffee brewed to the T. Love love. Moreover, the location is great. It's right by the dog park and a walk between the alley away from pretty much anything in Hayes. I do wish, however, that they were opened MORE hours, but I'm not going to hold it against them. For that coffee, at that price, um, totally worth the five stars. 

A tip: Look down Linden and check for the line. That's Blue Bottle Coffee.
author: Cristy M.

description:
After hearing all the hype I had to try this place. I happened to be in the right place, Hayes Valley, and asked somebody in a book shop where it was. They said "see that alley over there, it's down there." 

Cool. So we popped over there and there was a crazy line, about 10 people single file, standing in the street. While we waited, I saw people get dropped off to buy coffee...talk about a destination coffee place!

Anyhow, I order a double espresso, which they automatically served in ceramic espresso cups(italian style...I'd almost give them a star for that!). The espresso was OK. 

After the fact, I realized I should have ordered a drip cup of coffee, which they make to order,  to properly evaluate the quality of the coffee beans. Espresso is touchy and if you don't make it right you can make even the best coffee beans bitter.

So, I'll be back from a cuppa drip coffee.  Until then happy coffee drinking!
author: isaias J.

description: Amazing coffee! I had the iced coffee and savored every drop. Love this place.
author: Cari S.

description:
This is one hard place to find, especially with the busy-ass traffic on Gough Street.  Interesting set-up that they have being at the front door of a wood shop.  The coffee is up there with my other favs- Cafe Organica & Coffee to the People, but unlike most people- I need a place to sit down and catch up on stuff on-line or do some homework.  They have like 4 chairs in this alley way.  Other things they sell are a few select deserts from Miette.  

Blue Bottle also sets up outside the Ferry Building on Saturdays as well.
author: Jason A.

description:
Super cute little stand in an alley in Hayes Valley.  There is almost always a line there I am told and it's very basic in it's offerings: coffee, machiatos, and maybe 3 other coffee drinks.  They also have 3 sweets: a peanut butter cookie, french macaroon and shortbread.  All tiny pieces, that taste incredibly yummy.  Their coffee drinks are basic and don't make the mistake I made and ask for anything customized in your drink: I asked for a caramel machiato, and the guy said they don't do flavors.  

So for the taste of my drink, it was stronger than I am used to since I always get my drinks with flavors, but it wasn't bad.  The french macaroon helped.  

Service was slow, but it is crowded behind the counter and that might have played a factor.  Also they weren't super friendly.  Obviously though these things do not deter people from coming back.  

I am told this is amongst the best coffee in the city, so I would bring people here, but get my drink elsewhere as I like caramel in my machiato.  :)
author: Denise B.

description:
If I was rating on taste alone, this would have gotten FIVE STARS no problem.

Too bad it's my review, and other factors come into play.

It's a little pricey for coffee; not more than other pretentious coffee joints around town, but it is more expensive for those of us just looking for a good, solid, caffeine buzz.

Minus a star (or two) for pretentious, holier-than-thou customer service. And the fact that it's no more than a garage in Hayes Valley (way out in the middle of nowhere for me; I'm never out that way). There is no seating, but there is a "hip" counter to stand by.

This coffee place is for those hipsters craving to be "different" and "knowledgable" about espresso.

Yes, it's good. Really good.

That's it.

The rest of the experience is crap.
author: Danyell K.

description: My boss got me a Mocha. Chocolaty tasty goodness and the coffee was fresh and brewed to perfection! They dont burn the beans like some other places i know!
author: Brent W.

description:
delicious brown water. drip and latte all day e'ry day.

just be prepared to wait.
author: Nate R.

description:
The New Orleans Iced Coffee is amazing! I get this everytime I'm around, and it never lets me down.
The service is touch and go though, sometimes they're great and really friendly and use the right milk...and somedays they dont bother to even smile a little or use the right milk in your coffee even though it's not crowded...
But it won't stop me from getting my fix on occasion, the service just makes it less frequent. 

It's a little kiosk on a tiny street, so you've got to kind of look for it if you've never been, it's a roll up door, they dont have all the things MINT of Ferry building have, but who needs anything else when you've got New Orleans Iced Coffee!?
author: Blaire B.

description: This place has some of the best espresso-based coffee I've had in the States.  Only problem?  It's just a kiosk, with two chairs and one teensy table -- something I didn't realize from the rest of these rave reviews.  I'm still sipping at my soy latte, even though I shouldn't be, since it's a double-shotter and I can't quite take that much caffeine -- but it's so good I can't put it down.  Wow.
author: Nori H.

description:
Look, they made my lattee foam in the shape of a heart. 

If I had a camera I could have taken a black and white photo and made a million dollars.

Oh wait- someone did that
author: Danielle V.

description:
I work a few blocks from Blue Bottle. When it's only 2pm and you still have a few more hours to go in the day and you're about to fall asleep because you ate too much at lunch...what do you do?? You go to Blue Bottle. 

The barristas are hip and they do know their coffee. Sometimes I feel like I'm out of place bc I'm in my business casual attire and they're wearing their hipster chic clothes that they made themselves.   The art kids sit across the street smoking cigarettes just chilin' at the corner  during their break.  The world music is in the background and you can't help but look at what looks like a fancy garage business operation.  

 But yes, their coffee does have a kick. Wakes me up every time, and I do feel myself shaking....bc I've realized that I finished my whole cup of Giant Steps...yum.
author: Kris O.

description:
They need to put a sign on the corner of Linden and Gough warning motorists of the addicts dashing across the street.  Like those signs next to the freeway in San Diego with a family of three in sillouette fleeing the border patrol.

I've risked life and limb many a morning getting to the stall from my apartment on the other side of Gough.  Can't be bothered to walk up to Fell and cross with the light and then backtrack up to Linden.  

It got so I finally started buying the beans and just making it at home.  A lot warmer than waiting in line.  And damn, if it ain't the best coffee.   Roasted fresh every week.  Seriously, y'all, stop double parking your SUVs over here and just buy some damned beans.  It's totally worth it!

I do go for my Americano or capuccino on the weekends.  Word.
author: Leigh A.

description:
As far as the coffee goes... it gets well over five stars.  The latte my coffee-addicted boyfriend bought for me was absolutely delicious.  Super creamy and easy on the palate. Not a burnt bean in sight.  

Though the setting lacks ambiance, and it seems there's always a line, the warehouse/garage alleyway setting is pretty fun.  It only sucks waiting in the cold San Francisco winds & rain.  

However, if you can get your boyfriend to wait in line for you, you can browse at the super cool corset shop next store, stay out of the cold, AND enjoy your coffee!! (I know this from personal experience...)
author: Jennifer K.

description:
Simple the best coffee in San Francisco. Ritual Roasters is 2nd...but it's not really that close. No gimmicks, no seating, no nothing. Just great coffee and espresso. Slightly pricey, but you pay for the level of quality they present with you. It's professional, it's beautiful, it's art. 

Oh...and they are the only place west of New Orleans to actually make New Orleans Ice Coffee...the greatest ice coffee on earth. Go and try this place now.
author: Tolga E.

description:
The double shot espresso was incredible. Really, I mean it. I was skeptical and didn't want to ever go here, but we went last weekend and it was fantastic. I also had a cappuccino. 

I didn't get to sleep until 4am. I power walked up Hayes Hill and then cleaned our entire apartment. My neighbors think I am a speedfreak now. Oh well.
author: Mitsi M.

description:
Disclaimer - I don't drink coffee very much.  

A friend of mine in London is crazy about Espresso.  So as a house gift when I went to visit him, I brought him quite a bit of BlueBottle espresso from this shop.  He loved it. 

Also, they have really good iced coffee.  *yum*
author: Hilary K.

description: The barristas may be a little pretentious and the prices a bit steep, but the mochas are unparalleled.
author: Kelli G.

description: I can actually gulp this coffee. I'm halfway down the block and it's gone.  I've never tasted it's equal.  Mmmmm.
author: Jennifer O.

description: Drip coffee done well!  Located in a quaint alley (just follow your nose) in the heart of Hayes Valley, this is THE place for great coffee.  Friendly service. I always bring some beans back home to enjoy.  Bring your cash.
author: Angie N.

description: My favorite coffee place!  It's so good it makes me want to move back to the bay area! I love the mocha lattes and I buy the chiapas coffee to make at home.
author: Andra J.

description: Really good, unpretentious coffee is hard to come by these days. Thankfully the Hayes Valley location means that it's the same stuff as the Ferry Building, sans crazy lines and annoying tourists. It's quiet, pretty, and there's clearly a neighborhood/regular rapport between people who work there and the patrons who swing by for their fix.
author: Erin T.

description: Do I even need to say how amazing the coffee is? However when it is your first time going you can get a bit of a snotty vibe from the baristas. If you ask for a different size or any alterations in your drink you will look like you are speaking another language. But as a regular now, I realize you just don't need to change how they make the coffee. They know what they are doing. And it is quality over quantity at this place. Unless you bring in your own cup and you may get a little extra.
author: Brittany T.

description: I used to come here every weekend before moving out of the neighborhood :(  Best coffee in the city bar none.  Definitely beats that motor oil stuff concocted by Starbucks.  Philz is good, Ritual House is better, Four Barrel is fantastic, but Blue Bottle is the best!
author: Jasper J.

description: The coffee here is outstanding. They take a little time to make sure each drink is made to their standards of excellence. I must say though, this is the best {New Orleans} iced coffee that I've had ever. Even the ice cubes are amazing. If you've never been here before, just keep an eye out for the long line in the alleyway.
author: Saskia S.

description:
Awesome little location with interesting seating and a great view of the statue on Patricia's Green.  I go here pretty much every morning for a drip and a shot and find it to be a perfect start to a day and a lovely group of people making your coffee for you.

Only caveat is cash-only. This confuses some people since the other BB's take card.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I would go back to San Francisco just to get a cup of coffee from this place. In SF, they sure know how to treat their coffee addicts well. I went to this place twice during my week-long spring break and mannn was the coffee delish. The best part was that there were little leaves and hearts stirred into the foam of the lattes. So cute.

Someone should teach the baristas in Starbucks how to do that.

My only complaint is the price. But, I guess it's worth it when you're playing for the beautiful atmosphere. Huge windows=great lighting for reading & photos.
author: Joann P.

description:
Attention Whitney and Lindsey 

This crack is not wack and it's legal.  

With many dealers popping up you can get your fix in a hurry.

Oh oh my hands have stopped shaking I better hurry off.
author: Lulu M.

description:
I can't say any more good things about Blue Bottle that haven't already been said. I just love their coffee. More than that, I love a place that cares about what they do. Yes, they are coffee nerds, but that is definitely a good thing.

I used to enjoy going to Ritual when they first opened, but then they got overly crowded, the crowd became annoying and I couldn't justify enduring that "scene" just to get my coffee.

My discovery of Blue Bottle is like a welcome-back-to-coffee hug. I mainly go to Blue Bottle to buy beans, and brew at home, but of course get myself an espresso to sip in the alley, and bring the experience full circle. I like that they ask you how you're brewing your coffee to best recommend which beans go with what method. I've found service to be genuinely helpful and informative. Purists yes, but never patronizing.

I, too, wish they had seating, but I'm so focused on getting my coffee I'm never bothered by the elements nor the alley. I wish at least 10% of the coffee houses in this city would aspire to Blue Bottle's standards.
author: Antoi C.

description:
Sometimes when I don't want to get out of bed in the morning I bribe myself with a latte from Blue Bottle. 

ME: Get up, Lazy Ass! 

ME: Nooooo.

ME: But if you get up you can walk down the street and get a coffee!

ME: But I can make a cup of coffee at home.

ME: But it won't be as delicious and it won't have a pretty design in the foam.

ME: Good point. Okaaaaay. I'm up.

ME: Now do something about your hair. Don't embarrass me in front of all the urban chic kids.

ME: Ehhhhh, they can suck it.

The long lines on the weekends are daunting, but it's soooo worth it...even if I have to pack my own Sweet&Low (I LOVE YOU NUTRASWEET!) and doctor my coffee up in private for fear that the coffee purists will see my little pink packet and shun me for preferring to chemically sweeten my coffee instead of using the hippie sugar BB provides.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Oh. My. Yes, this is an expensive, small place. But there is a reason why it has a cult following: no frills, just outstandingly good coffee. I have been recently indoctrinated in the last few weeks and went here yesterday. I was not underwhelmed. Latte for the missus, mocha for me. I usually hate all coffee products since they are too acidic for my wussy stomach. But this. Oh my. Just right. And good, rich coffee flavor. And chocolate by Reccutti, whom I also adore. Perfection. 

In short: don't tell anyone else about it. Let's just keep it our little secret, OK? C'mon, I know I can trust you with a secret.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
UPDATE: Perhaps it's just me, but their mochas are not as good anymore. The past three times I've had them, they've only been good, not amazing.

-------------------------------------------------------
My fiance grinds & french presses his coffee on a daily basis with such love, that it's actually quite heart-warming to see him go through this morning ritual. I've always loved the smell of coffee more than the actual taste... until I found bluebottle. It's made me a believer.
author: G Z.

description:
IT'S JUST COFFEE!!!!!

yes it's amazing
yes it's worth the wait
yes it's the best coffee in the city

but remember.........IT'S JUST COFFEE!!!

pretentious and coffee should never share the same thought, yet they have found a place to do so in this wonderful, little garage.

PS.......my mom and I jokingly refer to James (the owner) as the coffee nazi!!!

PPS......remember, this is a 5-start review, no hatred meant, i wouldn't wait in that AWFUL line if it wasn't really worth it!

but please PLEASE people remember, IT'S JUST COFFEEEEEEEEEEE
author: Eric O.

description:
Finally had a chance to find out what's the hype about. The coffee is individually brewed and it was awesome!  The lattes were also good and the coffee barista's goes the extra mile by making a leaf design with your milk foam.

It cost more than your Starbucks but you get what you pay for! It's a bit out of the way and parking doesn't exist in the area. There's always a line but it does go fairly quickly.
author: Gilbert D.

description: ** In protest of the Dolores Park cart debacle, I am giving 5 stars to all the Blue Bottle kiosks where I get coffee.  Three Africans all the way!  Sorry you had to deal with the haters Blue Bottle. **
author: Tullia F.

description: Yeah yeah yeah...it is pretty good.  The line is worth it.  I love the latte.  It is like a posh version of Peets on an extremely good day.
author: Duanne G.

description:
I am by no means a coffee snob nor a coffee connoisseur. In fact, when I drink coffee, it's usually more for the social aspect or to take a 15 minute break from work. I rarely finish a whole cup because even the best coffees are too strong for me to drink a whole cup. 

that said, Blue Bottle coffee is like CANDY to me. Every weekend, I go there both days to stand in line and get excited about my sweet, creamy, delicious coffee that i will drink down to the very bottom of the cup and wish there was more. I think I'm spoiled for life!
author: Ryen A.

description: This cute hipster joint knows what its doing.  The coffee is amazing and the iced coffee is insanely good...it doesnt even need sugar!  Ive had a few pastries, and those are excellent as well.  Such a great locals only gem!
author: Jessica B.

description:
Great coffee in a city with some really good coffee. 

It does have a cult following so OF COURSE there may be a line during peak hours and on Saturday mornings but why hold a places success against it?

Friendly staff taking pride in what they do.
author: Stacey L.

description: If you are not specifically looking for this place, you'll totally miss it since it's basically a stand in a small alley way. However, the line of people will be a red flag as to something great is here.  Based on the rave reviews from my cousin, my friends and I ordered the New Orleans iced coffee.  It was sooo good--- lightly sweet with a chicory taste.  Blue Bottle also had patries that looked amazing, which I unfortunately didn't try since we were on our way to brunch.  I'm so glad that I can buy Blue Bottle coffee in LA (at Forage).
author: Leslie C.

description:
I absolutely love coffee. Since I read a lot of great reviews on the New Orleans Iced Coffee, my coworker and I decided to come here one day after a business meeting. I felt slightly disappointed that mine wasn't as flavorful as I hoped it would be, and to be quite honest, I felt a bit gypped after we stood in line for 15 minutes. 

Looks like I will resume my search for the best iced coffee drinks in the Peninsula yet again...
author: Ruby L.

description: Good coffee, good .  There late was superb.  Thanks for the cup
author: Doug S.

description: Excellent coffee at excellent prices in an interesting location.   I visited San Francisco and was lucky enough to stay near this excellent hole in the wall. The coffee rivals any European coffee or places in Melbourne and Sydney (excellent coffee cities). Lattes are perfect in every detail, including the artsy milk designs (always exciting to my simple heart). the simple assortment of cookies and pastries are nice additions to the menu, and alll are very affordable.  Location wise this Blue Bottle is a small place located in a quiet ally covered in graffiti.  Occasionally cars will get in the way when there is a large line, which happens from time to time. Cash only may also be a problem for some, but any problems are well worth it because this place has five-star coffee which is not found everywhere.
author: Dan H.

description:
OK, so yeah. It's true. This coffee is damned good. In fact, I hate to call it coffee. It's some kind of futuristic elixir of life-force. It's delicious and complex and viscious.
I'd give the place five stars if there were someplace to sit (it's basically an architecturaly designed opened garage door), if the cups were larger, if they were open longer, and if I could afford to go there everyday.
author: Jason D.

description:
Blue Bottle makes great coffee. 

In fact, the only other place in town that makes coffee as good as Blue Bottle is...

Fayes Video on 18th and Guerrero! Seriously.
author: Jacob L.

description:
Blue Bottle coffee is a tasty treat, but probably not worth all the hoops you have to jump through to get it.  Standing in line with lots of cool people waiting for a cool thing is a universal good.  Standing in line with lots of pretentious foodies waiting for a plain ole cuppa coffe is not.

That said, the coffee is mild, tasty, and fresh.  Get a pound, take it home, and brew it there.  Oh, but don't expect the barista to hook you up on the grinding - either they or the coffee is too good for that, I wasn't sure which he meant when he snootily turned me down.
author: Jess S.

description:
Amazing coffee--seriously the best in the city.  

The reason this place doesnt get 5 stars is because it moves at glacial pace, the lines are long and sometimes the employees give you 'tude.
author: Katie Sue A.

description:
Why am I on a coffee reviewing binge? 

Why do I never feel cool enough to drink here? 

Why is it I can't validate spending almost twice the normal price for these (quite good) coffee beans?

Still, they may pull one of the best shots in town, and the fact that it's a counter in an alleyway is pretty okay, too.
author: Geof M.

description:
Hands down the best coffee I've found in San Francisco. I go out of my way to come here, and even patronize restaurants around town simply because I see their "Blue Bottle served here" signs. The mocha is deliciously creamy and rich, though not overly chocolatey. Throw in a chocolate macaron and it's a chocoholics delight!

Drip coffee is great also, but you've probably heard that enough already. Anyhow, whether new to sf or just visiting, you've got to try Blue Bottle. It's just that good. 

Be warned though, there isn't any seating, just a small standing table; you can, however, head half a block to a local park and enjoy your cup there, or drink it while perusing the stores on Hayes Street.
author: Daniel M.

description:
I can't give more than 3 stars for coffee served at the small alley kiosk, so the three star is the five star in a way. 
first time I went there I tried brewed coffee. Amazingly good. That coffee touches every part of my tonges and has a pleasant linguering taste and fragrance, like a really good burgundy.
My husband's latte was just ok. Rather bland I thought.

I picked up the 'Retrofit' bean according to the barista's recommendation to try at home in my espresso machine. 
For a home coffee, I liked Barefoot's Espresso 114 better. 
I guess the "hand drip" is the best way to enjoy Blue Bottle.

Worth the driving if you're not nearby? 
Well, it depends on the additional activities after/before coffee, but not solely on the coffee, I guess.
author: Angie Y.

description:
I adore Blue Bottle. I work next door, and every morning on my way in, there's a long (but moving) line outside this walk up coffee hotspot. After a trip to Paris, I became addicted to cappuccino.. and this is the first place in the US I can count on for such a tasty beverage. 

My caffine addiction shall be their boon.
author: Margotelyse C.

description:
Seriously good. 

Worth the wait. It's perfect every time.

Plus, the little treats from Miette are superb.
author: J B.

description:
Oh sweet mystery of life!!!

I have been a Barista on and off for a total of 3 years.  I would not say that I have an advanced palate, but it is a little picky.

Blue Bottle is the best I have had thus far.  I will keep this brief so I can post on the Blue Bottle pages, but let me say that their cappuccinos are heaven in your mouth.
author: Becky T.

description:
The People's Republic of Blue Bottle.  I consent to the propaganda and agree that they have the best cup in the City . . . sometimes!

I drink their drip exclusively and it can be divine, depending on what blend they're brewing.  I've never actually figured out which one I like.  I should probably do that.  They do hang a little sign that says which way the wind's blowing at a given time.

But the fact is that sometimes they're brewing something other than the ideal cup.  It's good even then but why not make the best cup when you can?

I find no problems with the lines or the service.  Face it, there will be a line.  Don't cry, it moves fast.  They don't always smile when pouring.  They usually do.
author: Stef A.

description:
You'll like this place if you are treating yourself to a good cup of coffee and have a leisurely morning to spare...

As all the previous reviews have hyped, yes, this place has great coffee.  However, I suggest that you buy the beans and brew it yourself.  For one cup of coffee, I stood in line for 20 minutes (that's -1 star for me, sorry!).  No cup of coffee is worth a 20 minute wait.  And when they mean drip coffee.... it is S-L-O-W drip coffee.  Good things come to those who wait!!!  For those of us who don't like lines, buy their beans and buy a drip filter.
author: Nutmeg Y.

description:
A great little hole-in-the-wall here.  I waited in line about 2 minutes or so, and another few for my macchiato.  Very tasty coffee.  I am by no means a coffee connoisseur, but I thought this was better than most other places I have been to lately.  Prices aren't bad either.

If I was closer, I would definitely come by more often.
author: Chris R.

description: Not much to add to what others have said. Basically, they have fantastic coffee. I usually just pick up some beans here for my daily morning coffee (Bella Donovan = SO GOOD), or I'll get their drip or their yummy Nawlins Iced Coffee. On a nice day it's fun to grab a drink and wander over to the Octavia Green and people watch. This is one of the places that makes me happy to live in SF!
author: Alexandra L.

description: I don't know if it's because I ordered my mocha into my 16oz personal mug, but the mocha was lacking. I like my mochas stronger in chocolate and in espresso. Also, the snickerdoodle sucked! No taste whatsoever. Definitely no cinnamon and very little sugar.
author: Christine B.

description: Best coffee ever..or at least tied with seattle's Vivace.  I think they put some sort of aphrodisiac in their brew, though I'm not at liberty to say why....
author: Sean W.

description:
I try to limit my coffee consumption.  This has become much harder since finding Blue Bottle.  BB is the best coffee I have had in the city.  The lines are really bad at peak times, not too bad otherwise.  

Not much else to say..
author: Paul L.

description: I really don't drink coffee, but when I make an exception, its for blue bottle.  I really like their soy lates.  It's a nice treat for a stroll around the city.
author: Doxie M.

description: Wow -- ridiculously good coffee.  Worth the wait in the line...that backed up into the middle of the street.  Best cappuccino I've ever had.  Next time trying the iced coffee.
author: Jason C.

description:
The best mocha in the city and otherwise good coffee, but the wait is too long and the stand on Linden is in the shade so bundle up on a busy day.  The pastry selection is disappointing.

On a Saturday morning, it's a great place to stop at the Ferry Building on your way to the Farmers' Market.
author: marie m.

description:
*UPDATE: Thanks to "Kate A." I've been updated on the "iced-mocha" issue; Just thought I would mention that the reason that Blue Bottle can't make iced mocha's is that they use real chocolate pieces, not chocolate syrup (like you might get some place like Starbucks). Melting chocolate requires heat, so making an iced mocha would be impossible. Of course, you can always ask for a cup of ice and pour your mocha over it if you really want it to be cold.  

Thanks go to Yelp for helping me get to the bottom of this.

END UPDATE*

What an amazing little coffee shop!  Due to its nice little alley location, you'll need to know someone or have read this review to find this place.

The coffee is some of the best San Francisco has to offer.
author: Anthony B.

description:
Love this coffee.  Love the latte, love a fresh bag to bring home!  I usually put Bailey's in my cup, then pour my fresh made coffee (grind the beans right before you're going to make a pot...no pre-grinding and placing the grinds in the freezer) over the creamy caramel color and a beautiful thing happens.  Nothing like Blue Bottle Bailey's every Saturday and Sunday morning.  

If you're not purchasing at the Ferry Building and you're going to buy at their Linden location...bring a friend to watch your car (there's no parking) or walk over if you live near by.  Always good to go to the Ferry Building location so you can grab some pancakes next door.
author: D C.

description:
(I put this on the Farmer's Mkt location when it should have been here. Still true though!)

Alright people, get it together. There's little point in writing yet another review about whether the BBCC coffee is good or not. Overwhelmingly, it's pretty damn good.

Some other thoughts:

1. Don't sweat that they don't grind your coffee for you. Buy a grinder. Or bring it somewhere that will. Or buy it elsewhere. You've got options. Use them.

2. What kind of 'experience' should you really be expecting? Having more than coffee is what Starbucks purports to do. Let BBCC do one thing and do it well. Go elsewhere for free wireless. Or learn to crack WEP/WPA so you can lean against the wall opposite BBCC while you sip your brew.

3. Your version of bad service can happen anywhere. At a place like this, where the workers are standing for hours on end, you might stop to consider that they're not going to get down on their knees and blow just because you're there to get your latte. They may not be happy automatons you've come to love from your mall shopping trips. They're just regular people who have good days and bad days. You might be there when one or more of them has a bad day. Whatever. It's coffee. It's an interaction of only a few minutes. Plus, I'd wager that if you smiled and said hi, they'd likely smile back. Just be nice. And damn, no business or customer service person is perfect. If you've ever worked in retail or a restaurant you'd realize this and adjust your attitude accordingly.

4. It's going to be a bit expensive. You generally have to pay for quality. It's not more expensive than Peet's or Starbucks anyway.

5. Face it: the neighborhood is bourgeois and hip. Complaining about a coffee kiosk is pointless. If you really cared about the social effects of so many hipsters and yuppies in SF, you wouldn't be voting for Gavin Newsom press release politics that amount basically to the status quo. You'd figure some other sh*it out. Talking smack about style is fun sometimes, but it gets old.

6. It's a line that probably won't last longer than 20 minutes. Talk to someone else in it. Share standing duties with a friend. Or just get some coffee elsewhere. Whatever.
author: Ian M.

description:
Best part of my Sunday morning is heading down to the DMV Famers' Market and having a Blue Bottle Double Capp.  mmmMMMM!  

Special thanks to Ashley, John, and Sarah who were super busy (what's new?!) at The Market today.
author: H J.

description:
BBC is in Linden Alley.  It operates out of a garage behind a roll-up door.
It will be the most amazing coffee you have ever tasted.  It will re-frame other brown liquids passing as coffee immediately into an 'other' category or possibly 'inferior'.  Those who remember what Starbucks did to elevate expectations for coffee when it expanded across the country will discover a similar impact with Blue Bottle Coffee.  Starbucks will never taste satisfactory again, as it is evident not only in the quality of the beans but also in the roasting how rich, complex and flavorful the coffee is at BBC.

There is a sign at the end of Linden and Gough.  Follow your eyes towards the gangey line of customers waiting in reverie for this amazing experience.  It is something of a secret among the cognoscenti , fueled by word of mouth rather than any marketing.  Check it out for yourself.  Prepare to be changed.
author: Gugoda ..

description:
THIS COFFEE ROCKS!!!!

I accidentally tried their coffee last weekend at Mission Beach Cafe.  I say accidentally only in the regards that I didn't know that I'd be drinking Blue Bottle Coffee. My boss had been telling me for months to try it but i was ignorant.  I don't like a lot of American coffee blends.  they are too weak and bland.  Well not Blue Bottle.  It was love at first sip.  

Most coffee doesn't really have too much of an effect on me.  Turkish coffee will give me that buzz, otherwise coffee is just a beverage to me.  something that I drink.  BBC however knocked my socks off.  I was riding the caffeine train all day, and loving it.  I went to this Hayes Valley shop this weekend to get some more straight from the source, and I may go back again today.  Seriously great coffee.
author: Andrew r.

description:
Five stars for really good coffee - medium roast and strong brew does the trick, people! The bitter sludge at Starbucks is burnt and weak and pretty much undrinkable.


 Five more stars for good design on low resources - the translucent plastic used to finish the Blue Bottle walls is by no means expensive, but works perfectly for a clean Dutch-design look. Once again this proves the point that designed spaces have little to do with the extent of available cash and more to do with creativity and aesthetic sensibility. . . which also explains Hotel Vitale, and the Coi dining room.
author: lizok

description:
I don't usually drink coffee, but I do love hot chocolate, and the hot chocolate at Blue Bottle is delicious.


 However, the line out the garage door is not delicious. It's a bitter, nasty, weak cup o' WAIT. Be prepared to be in line for a while for your java fix. They do not rush when they're creating their caffeinated masterpieces.


 Don't get me wrong. It may be worth it, but it depends on how high your tolerance level and/or patience level is.


 I actually prefer Philz coffee to Blue Bottle, but that's a personal taste.
author: sfKristina

description:
After hearing so much about Blue Bottle, I was prepared to be disappointed; luckily, it lived up to most of the hype.  My macchiato started with a good shot of espresso: dark and syrupy with a thick cap of red-brown crema.  The foam wasn't stiff at all, and was hot without being scalded.  My individually made drip coffee was also good, though not quite as impressive as the macchiato (it may have been that the blend being brewed was a little bland).

I was a little disappointed that this location doesn't have one of the siphon machine, but it's a great addition to a nice neighborhood.  The pastries from Miette are also excellent...
author: Akshay S.

description: I ordered a soy latte and it was AMAZING.  It was smooth and lightly creamy.  It was a perfect balance of flavor.  I would go here every morning just to have a little more happiness in my life.
author: Jenn D.

description: strong rich coffee drinks, i love it!
author: Valerie N.

description:
The best coffee in The City and I drink it on the ground leaning up against the handmade corset boutique, or I wander over to the Burning Man sculptures on Octavia.  

Warning, the lines are long but whatever, this is ALL about the perfect bean roasted and dripped and served to perfection. 

Close your eyes and sip.
author: John V.

description:
The coffee was excellent. I am a coffee nerd, and have bought their beans before and tried them here at home in Cambridge. They know what they're doing.

The baristas had an attitude. Maybe that comes with the territory but it didn't endear me to the business. It makes me not want to come back.
author: Aaron C.

description: Smooth coffee. Awesome for a simple drip style coffee. You won't find a trace of bitterness or burnt blechiness in this coffee. If you are a vanilla latte girl like me, you might not be prepared for the simplicity of a simple smooth cup of coffee. I'd still choose my Peets Vanilla Latte Machiatto, but I think that's because the coffee is so strong there, it balances the sweet. The alley vibe was interesting. The wait wasn't crazy, and the service was pleasant.
author: Laura D.

description:
I was totally jazzed to try this coffee as i had read about the fellow who started it in the Chronicle.  I thought it was good but not amazing.
The coffee I find truly fantastic is Phils one cup at time in the Castro
Area and in the Mission.  There is an actual selection, amazing staff,
and the several ones I have tried are incredible.  I would go to Phils
long before I would bother with Blue Bottle Coffee.
author: S.C. H.

description:
For all the hype I've heard about Blue Bottle coffee, I don't really get it. Maybe people just love hipster girls making stupid little hearts on your lattes, but in reality, the coffee was pretty average.

The menu board does say that they use double shots of espresso in all their drinks, but the latte I had wasn't strong at all. It also wasn't very hot -not "cold," mind you, but not "hot" by any means - which could have something to do with it not being "zomg delicious."

Barefoot Coffee in Cupertino is hands-down the best coffee I've ever had, but to be quite honest, the whole bean Starbucks I get at Costco and make at home with my $50 espresso maker was better than the Blue Bottle latte I had today.
author: Alexis C.

description: Such a solid place and a hidden gem that I wish I could take this listing off of Yelp.
author: Edwin F.

description: The ONLY Place I go to for coffee! Their cappuccino is simply excellent. My friends drink latte here as well and they love it. The staff does a great job of moving a line along during the rush hour.
author: Andrew B.

description: Here is the deal. They have one of the best coffees in town. Drip, cappuccino, latte... all good. But... If you don't tell them "can you make sure it is hot", they do not make it hot enough. I get it, you don't want to burn the milk or mess up with the flavor of the beans but come on! I don't like warm coffee. I would give lower rating but I just can't because it's freaking good! Also, line becomes annoyying at times but it does not lower their rating.
author: Mike S.

description:
I walked the dog by this place maybe 3 months ago and was thrilled to see the crowd it attracted and the SF friendliness of a local place.  I remember pre-dot coms when this city had mom & pop coffee shops all over.  I am glad that I finally got back to this place.

I guess it doesn't shock me that some bitch about yuppies and freaks but that is part and parcel of living in a city...get over it people.  The alley is kinda cartoonishly urban in that there is graffiti all over but there are a few Melrose (WeHo) style shops and a mixed crowd milling around.  One could think they are walking through a Mouseketeers  "urban" set before they rap about sunny days and ice cream.  Nevertheless, I think both sides of the clientle spectrum try too damn hard but that is another story.  

The thing to really yelp about is not the line nor the location but rather the product, i.e. the coffee.  Pretty damn tasty!  I did a meeting outdoors with this as our stop off.  We sat in the Octavia park and held our meeting over a couple cups of coffee.  

The coffee was smooth, well balanced and very flavorful.  I am suggesting this type of meeting again!
author: Aberdo G.

description:
I am not much of a coffee connoisseur... went on account of 'he said she said' messages about this being good local coffee spot...

Intriguing coffee garage - easily missed if not particularly looking for the place.  Simply had the expresso at the bar - was very strong rich and creamy  -- i wish i added a lot more sugar.  That's how I like it!  Would be back for more!
author: Melody Y.

description: Blue Bottle Coffee = liquid crack.
author: tvham

description:
One of the few good--no, great--espresso shots in town. (And I've tried a lot!) I brought an Italian friend there, from Sicily, and he enjoyed their espresso. (And Sicilians are damned hard to please, especially with something as Italian as coffee!) 

Well-made drinks, by people who care about their product. Friendly staff, who didn't even ream the poor clueless guy ahead of me who asked for a vanilla latte. (Instead. they gently steered him to a mocha, without giving him attitude). 

I've never had any "snootyness" from them, unlike what others here have reported. (Then again, I've found a lot of what we perceive as "attitude" from others is only our own attitude coming up). 

I take off half a star for their prices--$2 for an admittedly good espresso shot is still damn pricey--and half a star for the near-constant long line. I guess the smallness of the place is part of the charm and something they can't change, and they do try to keep the line moving, but still--a 10+ minute wait for an espresso is awfully long.
author: Mike Y.

description:
I obviously don't have to review Blue Bottle because like the reviews written they are the best.  I was happy when I found these guys almost 3 years ago, and I'm still a loyal customer.

Why its good?
Fair Trade
Organic
And it tastes awesome!
Each Barista is trained properly and has their own style of shot making skills.

If you want to be a true coffee drinker get the Gibraltar.  A miniature

Late, that lets you actually taste the coffee instead of just drink milk.

Find other organic places like this one on my website www.iheartorganic.com, "Your resource to healthy living."

Be Well,

Mr. O
author: Mr. O.

description:
Brevity.
The coffee is great (5*). So is the line (too great, in fact, -1*). Don't bring the SO if she isn't a coffee drinker. Mine just doesn't understand.

Big fan of N.O. Iced Coffee. Three Africans and Giant steps are my favorite beans.

Cheers!
author: Ryan F.

description: At first had a hard time finding Linden St., but once I found BBCC it was worth the trouble. I ordered the iced coffee, not to mention the quick service...the ladies there are wonderful. Don't expect a drink selection like Starbucks. Oops!...did I say...
author: Dan P.

description: This is a small location to queue up to a get a quick latte.  It's Blue Bottle, so they know what they are doing.  Great stop in the morning, or afternoon for a jolt.
author: Richard Q.

description: Puhleeze.  I fully understand and respect the cult of coffee.  It's an art.  But if a customer has the reasonable request of a long espresso, it's a bit dramatic and unnecessary to flat out refuse.  How is an extra half ounce of hot water going to bring about the end of civilization as we know it? I don't think so.  I mean, if I were asking for a half caf, half decaf skinny latte with vanilla flavor and extra whip, by all means politely decline.  But hot water isn't gonna kill anyone, now is it?  Get over yourselves, Blue Bottle.
author: Kyle F.

description: Finally made it to blue bottle coffee co.! I had the drip and wifey had the latte. Both were very tasteful. I would definitely go back for a cup and enjoy the 80's music they were playing!
author: Vincent M.

description: Wow. I mean I'm a coffee enthusiast but wow! I'd take a shot of Gibraltar over a shot of patron any day! Amazing! Basically a mini latte with who knows how many shot equivalent in a shot glass. I was really sleepy but damn a shot of that and I felt refreshed and brand new. Thank you Blue Bottle Coffee. Now I realized all that I've drinking was crap water before you! The latte was really smooth and good too. Can you please have a shop out here in Sac too?
author: Wendy L.

description:
3 Stars

Started the day over here.....even though I usually don't drink coffee, I had a long day ahead of me and needed the energy. 
The alley/street this spot is in is real cool.....murals spray painted or paintbrushed on some of the walls......people hanging out sitting on the sidewalk drinking their coffee and enjoying the day....and a great overall vibe. 
The shop looked like a converted garage, and was just a walk-up that you order your drink from and either take it w/ you, or like I said, sit down on the sidewalk and enjoy it...
I ended up ordering the New Orleans Iced Coffee ($3.50) after the girls in front of me in line explained that it was like liquid crack and doesn't make you jittery. my girl ordered a mocha. 
Staff was cool and friendly like they usually are at independent coffee shops....and they even had comp. doggie treats (and NO I didn't try any). 
The Iced coffee I ordered was pretty strong. It tasted ok, but I'm not a coffee drinker, so I prefer my coffee to taste more like hot chocolate...so i probably wouldn't order it again (it did wake me up though!).
The Mocha was very rich, chocolaty, and good.....they even did some art (I'll post a picture soon).....That I could have again as it didn't really taste too much like coffee. 
We ended up hanging out on the sidewalk for a little while...to get the whole experience....then walked down the street to a little park for a while w/ our drinks. 
I really do recommend this place....not just for the drinks, but for the overall experience.
author: Ocee D.

description: Yowza! Blue Bottle = Coffee on Steroids! I LOVE IT!!!!!
author: Sue L.

description:
totally worth visiting and waiting in the line...and i'm a person who hates lines.  cute little kiosk with an amazing amount of employees crammed in a small space.

they make their coffee too strong for my taste so i actually bought beans and a grinder [only $2 more there than at target, and it's worth supporting their small business] to make my coffee at home.  i'm now a bigger fan of blue bottle.

if you don't have a dog, but wish you did, this is a good place to socialize with a dog while waiting in line.
author: Mary S.

description:
One of San Francisco's best coffee companies.  True artistry at it's finest.  I had my first experience last week.  A very polite and friendly barista greeted me and answered all of my questions.  The Hayes valley espresso is expertly pulled, and absolutely delicious.  My friend ordered a soy mocha, which was beautiful.

Blue bottle, you have won my heart when it comes to espresso...and I work at a coffee shop...
author: Luke G.

description: I froze my ass off waiting in line, but it was so worth it. Another drip coffee from here, still the best coffee I've ever had.
author: Jen D.

description: I've never tried it before but I really like siphon coffee now.  Besides Looking like the coolest bong you've ever seen, the shit is tasty and STRONG!  I was feeling noticeably wired for hours!  I had their poached eggs with prosciutto too.  Perfect lite breakfast.  Staff is super cool and very knowledgeable.
author: Ramon L.

description: The coffee at Blue Bottle is really really good because it is hot water poured directly into the coffee grounds.  Service is slow for the drip because it's an actual drip.  It's not some machine that the coffee sits in and tastes horribly Starbucks-ified afterwards.  It is always well worth the wait.  There are a few locations but I like the one on Linden because there are always lots of people hanging out and talking.  They have just finished a beautification project on the street and there are benches there for people to sit down and chat.  I have been going here about every day and will be sad when I will not live within two blocks of it.  I really like how friendly the servers always are.  If you want to actually go in to a building and get coffee and you think that is what coffee is about, then you will probably not like it.
author: Jack T.

description: This is my favorite place to get coffee.  The coffee is so good and it's made by people that are fanatics about what they're doing.  These people are not just making coffee cause they need a job and this place happened to be hiring.  You can really tell that it's their passion.  I'm a big fan of the regular drip coffee, but also love to get the New Orleans Iced Coffee when it's hot or a shot of espresso when I'm in the mood.  The line can be a little long, but it's totally worth it.
author: Aaron L.

description: Nice hidden coffee gem in the city. Awesome Coffee!!! Parking might be a little hard so park far away. It's worth the walk. Will come again. Iced coffee was deeelish!
author: Joseph G.

description:
Cute location, and when it's warm and not windy in SF, I guess it's ok. When you're prego and would like a place to sit, not the best. 

The baked goods looked tasty, and my decaf au lait was excellent, with a cute heart design. Octavia Park is close by to sit, and you can take a stroll through the Hayes Valley corridor.

Parking can be difficult. If you're local, I'm sure it's an excellent place to walk to.

The overcast afternoon might have contributed to the lack of hipsters, but I'm not sure waiting longer than I did -5-7 mins- would have been worth it.
author: KD D.

description:
LOOVE LOVE LOVE blue bottle.
i'm lucky enough to live in Hayes Valley and walk there, which is cluth b/c if you're trying to find parking around the area good luck. 
 
you know how San Franciscans loves their coffeeee, well this is the reason why. 
And i've learned to embrace the line that accumulates on the weekend, as a good way to catch up with your friends and listen to other people's conversations about the night before or who loves blue bottle more. 

i love that its a garage door in an alley with sleek sustainable design.

i like that they do individual drip coffees.

the capp. is delish.

the soy latte is probably one of the best in SF.

great mocha and the vegan mocha is REALLY f'ing tasty.
author: Chelsea O.

description:
Espresso is an art that very few master, but the baristas at Blue Bottle know what they are doing. Do yourself a favor and try a shot here if you haven't been converted yet.

Their beans are also quality, I'm still working on the two 1/2 lb. Ethiopians I got.
author: Aaron F.

description:
6 out of 5 stars for phenomenal coffee made perfectly every time. Their blends are really distinctive and all worth trying. The staff are coffee geeks and happy to share their expertise.

4 out of  5 for the long wait in line, but what can they do? The baristas make time for everyone and seem to stake their reputation on each drink.

It averages out to a merely perfect 5 out of 5. Just remember, if you're alone, to bring something to read while you wait.
author: Rainbucket B.

description:
To me Blue Bottle is the perfect cup of coffee.  

The first time I tried it was the first time I realized I didn't need that much milk and sugar in my coffee to enjoy it. 

Sure, it's a little stressful trying to order because they call for your order a good few feet away, and you have to answer back loudly and decisively.  Indecision causes everyone else to wait, and what were you doing during the twenty-minute wait anyway??  Then when you finally get a cup of coffee, you have to edge around the small counter space and hope that there are still clean spoons, enough sugar and milk for the coffee.

I don't mind the twenty-minute wait.  I go when I have the time, and there is usually a genial air about because people are happy to get their coffee.  It's not like when you're waiting at Starbucks or Peets, where people feel impatient-hurry-hurry-grouchy-crabby-jittery because, let's face it, people go to those places for the caffeine fix.  They're all a bunch of drug addicts!  People who go here may be as well, but Blue Bottle IS...because it's so good,  because it's such a treat.  Addicts forget they're addicted and think they're going for something more than a boring cup of coffee.  And I think that's why it's not hype and why people go back again and again.

Because once I've got that white paper cup with the black lid in my hands, I'm totally blissfully wonderfully happy.
author: Nancy K.

description:
how did this place get out to the public?!  The wait can be painful, but always met with a pleasant smile.

The coffee is serious.  My family only orders and drinks shipments of blue bottle coffee.  Might i add they are living on the east coast.
author: J R.

description:
A stroll down Linden Street during a Saturday or Sunday morning can yield a lot of interesting things. Seeing a line out of a garage is what ends up making me smile in the end. 

You have great personalities from the baristas, an awesome view of a Walgreens sign on Franklin Street, unique people patiently waiting in line, and killer coffee that can't be replicated anywhere. 

I'm a huge fan of drip with some milk and sugar, but there are some days that a New Orleans Ice Coffee is in order. 

Order wisely, as this juice will keep you going for a long time.
author: Mario G.

description:
i was under the impression that these people were snobs based on my visit to their mint st. location.
wrong.
blue bottle is all class and cheer.
author: Chase O.

description: After a 10+ year hiatus, I recently returned to San Fran for a nice Sonoma infused extended weekend, as well as to catch up with a cousin I hadn't seen in years.  This was the place they took us too, and just like the movie, Blue Bottle Coffee Co., is 'As good as it gets!'
author: Osvaldo P.

description: I will go so far out of my way to hit this place up for a cup of coffee + the  rosemary pine nut shortbread, that I take Lombard to Gough instead of 19th Avenue to pick up the 280 from Marin. That's how good it is.
author: Cinnamon F.

description: The coffee is superb! My only deal is the lines are long but that comes with the territory. We all love it and I can't hate on anyone who loves great coffee as much as I do.
author: liana l.

description: I don't get the vibe but the coffee is great. Philz has a much friendlier staff.
author: Walter M.

description:
Hate the line with all the Hayes Valley hipstery douchebags but I'll give 'em their due. They got a damn smooth Latte.

It's a bonafide San Francisco scene and you can make that scene for just $3 bucks and be in the know of this trend.

Tip or die because they do the hand made thing so just let the quarters and nickels and dimes slide off the top of the paper money in to their cup.
author: ny s.

description: One of my favorite places to grab an espresso and catch up with a friend on a (sunny) weekend afternoon.
author: Heather R.

description:
I don't know what to say..... totally speechless with the best coffee ever.

Made another cup; melitta single serving pour over. Three Africans. Wow.

I'm speechless (and totally buzzed). Great caffeine content. 

Someone's gona hafta hold me back or I'll start walking to SF for a fresh bag of this stuff.
author: nate e.

description: Hands down the best coffee I've ever had, both the soy latte and the iced coffee...and we never foregt to get beans for the week...
author: Kaitlin K.

description:
So over-rated. I really don't get it. 

I only order Americanos and it is the drink to really know the quality of the beans and skill of the barista. No fat to mask flavor.

I have been twice and have never had a good shot pulled but the baristas still serve it. Do they not know any better? Any barista worth the job would say, "oh, the shot didn't pull well.... let me make you another." 

There's this thing called crema and if Blue Bottle could serve drinks with it that would be sweet.
author: let's c.

description: A 5 star rating for this place is well deserved. My gf brought me here and this is a place that cares about coffee. There was a long line which is normal from what i hear. The line does go fast. The brew each cup of coffee!!!!!!! Amazing. This is how coffee should taste. Not watered down or not like a giant wooden stir spoon. This by far is the Best coffee I have had in the entire bay area. I will be coming back very often.
author: Chuck G.

description: The location's not a shop at all, but what seems to be an adjunct to a warehouse, a little hole in the wall where you can walk up and order some great coffee drinks. Steep for just plain coffee, I would recommend ordering a more specialized coffee drink, such as the beautiful cappuccino I had. Complex and so flavorful, much more so than many other brews I have sampled. The kiosk also offers some great treats such as cookies and biscotti from other local businesses. And yes, I will say Blue Bottle's not for everyone, as some people aren't coffee aficionados and would think otherwise of the price--I wouldn't exactly put myself in the class of coffee snob, but for sure, I enjoyed the subtly and crafting put into the cup I had.
author: Ryan T.

description: 3.5 stars. maybe i just went into it with super high expectations, but i did not love my new orleans iced coffee. bf liked his cafe au lait, but it wasn't love at first sight. philz still rocks harder!
author: Suana W.

description:
best coffee ever. period. better than Peet's. sorry. better than Milan. sorry. better than St. Tropez. sorry. I make it at home in the morning in my French Press, grinding just enough for each day. There's always a line, and it's worth it.
Some friends from LA are now totally hooked. They're buying it online. 
Do the Blue Bottle folks put some kind of frickin' drugs in this stuff? 
it's so much better than other coffees. 
here's why:
not bitter
super flavorful
myriad subtle flavor characteristics
it's an art form
serve it warm, not hot
rich, and chocolatey almost
like wine
or chocolate
or bare skin
intoxicating
fragrant
wow.
makes me glad to be alive
author: Liz B.

description: What up New Orleans Iced Coffee, wanna be best friends or something?
author: C J.

description: When the ex and I broke up, we had to carve up our belongings.  I kept the dishes, she kept my Elton John t-shirt.  I kept a few of her books, she kept my heart.  And so on and so on... this continued right down to the cities we love, and the establishments therein.  I'm keeping most of the bars in San Diego (she can have Nunu's, it's only fair), she kept most of San Francisco.  That's fine, for the most part.  That city is too full of itself for full-time enjoyment anyway, but not having Blue Bottle in my life anymore has made the world a more life-less place.  I just may have to sneak in to The City pretty soon and gulp down some joe, just to make it through 2010...
author: The T.

description:
I go here every day, simply the best latte around...

Line? Grow a spine! Anyplace good has a line!
author: Geordie V.

description: My neighborhood coffee treat. I never go when it's too busy, so I actually enjoy the whole waiting in the alley with the scattered line routine. The employees are friendly and organized. The drip coffee is always good, but I usually opt for a soy latte. Good espresso, and I'm usually skeptical of ristretto shots, but they do it well. They use yummy Pacific Soy, and always a perfect amount of creamy foam. And yeah, they pour some boss latte art.
author: Isabel L.

description: The best single drip coffee in SF (and now in NYC). They have a great selection of roasts, including the chocolate smooth Giant Steps. They also have the most amazing cafe mocha. I like the simplicity of ordering from the garage/storefront in Hayes Valley.
author: teatzar s.

description:
Its a good thing this place is in an alleyway, because i loved this coffee so much i wanted to get down and make sweet love to it. Ol' Socks LaPeePants didnt seems to mind..he must see this shit alot. It looks like other Yelpers complain about the time it takes to make coffee....its a single brewed cup of coffee. Lets first adress the fact that this is not fast food coffee....it would be like bitching that a burger at Absinthe "isnt ready the second you order it" and "Doesnt come in a paper wrapper". Its a different echelon. They brew the coffee FOR YOU. Like...for you. You know? Not in a fucking vat like Peets, or a bucket like Charbucks...your VERY OWN. And then some of you complain about paying $2 for it? WTF? How much are you paying for an effing small or medium at the other places? Usually $1.60-$1.70, plus the obligatory tip we leave The Baristas for working a spigot handle. "Good job, Tyler! Wee! Way to fill that cup and ask if i want room for cream!"" This place, they work for their money. The coffee is roasted BY THEM, not some warehouse in Carracas and pretty much is the closest thing to the coffee blends that i have roasted at home. Oh, and one more complaint to address, you cant find it....Google Maps.  Ill even help you...its off Gough, between McAllister and Market. There. 

Oh and the best part? Its a place to buy coffee and yet not one iBook or Powerbook in sight. Made me tear up for joy a little bit.

Now if youll excuse me, i have some business to attend to....

*Hands paycheck to Blue Bottle* 

"So, were good for the month, right?"
author: Mick F.

description: Coffee makes my ass explode, always has and always will.  When I drink this stuff though I at least get some hipster cred to go along with my explosive diarrhea.
author: Luis M.

description:
I've been struggling with this review for days.  Blue Bottle is a tough call for me.  The verdict is kinds still out on these guys.  There is technically nothing wrong with the coffee.  The latte was good; no harshness, good temp, good froth; kinda expensive, but still alot better than some other coffee I've had.  The thing about it was that it didn't stand out, it just wasn't bad.  

I actually walked around abit to figure things out.  So I went back to see if adding more espresso will do.  So I asked if I could pay a little extra to have more espresso put in.  And the man kindly obliged.  So I asked where they got their coffee to which he replied, "We get our coffee from all over the world."  This had to be the most pretentious and canned answer I've ever received.  No shit freak'n Einstine!  We all get our coffee from all over the world.  So he proceeds to ramble off a list of countries that they get their coffee from:  ".... chiapas.... honduras.... indonesia...."  I only picked up a few because he as talking very fast.  What I did figure out was was none of the origins he spoke of is really known for making good espresso beans.  Typically, African coffees provided the best flavor for espresso; but most of the time it's a blend of african and beans from everywhere.

He also mention that they do a "East Coast roast which is different from what everyone else is doing in the City."  East Coast roast is also known as a cinnamon roast, which is a light roast.  A cinnamon roast is totally different from a espresso roast, which is a very dark roast.  You would never make espresso out of a cinnamon roast.  This explains alot.  If you use American coffee, also called milds for their flavor, you're not going to get alot of harshness or alot of peaks and valleys in your flavor profile.  So when you drink their latte, there's really nothing wrong with it, it's just very mellow, non-offensive.  

One more tidbit: you should never get coffee from someone who has the back of the espresso machine turned towards you.  You should be able to see exactly what they are doing.  That's a big minus for me.

To me, their coffee takes very little risks; there's nothing wrong with it, it's just missing alot of flavor which should be there to create a great cup of coffee.
author: Rick K.

description: Why latte/cappuccino art? Well, it's not because it's pretty. The only way you're able pour those patterns is if you produce quality foam. Blue Bottle has no problem producing proper foam, every time. No need to put in a special request or order a double short cap. Their cappuccino only comes in one size, the right size. The New Orleans Iced Coffee tastes better than the best chocolate milk you've ever had, a real treat!  Minnesota winters aren't  cruel enough to make me move to SF but my longing for Blue Bottle Coffee just might get me there.
author: Kenneth A.

description:
I dunno...everyone raves about the coffee here. I think I am just going to stop drinking coffee in the US and save all my caffeine highs for trips to Europe. 
Just like every 'gourmet' coffee place, they over-roast the beans. I like to have just plain espresso and you can really taste that OD on the roasting in an espresso. I know they make all their pulls ristretto which I like IF THE BEANS ARE NOT BURNED, but again, ristretto at Blue Bottle just tastes like a charred log.
I think people rave about this place bc SF so desperately wants a 'great coffee place' to call its own, and heck, the name Blue Bottle sounds cute and catchy and Americana or something or other, and whatever. 
The beans are burned.
And no dumb arguments about SF coffee being more smoky and whatnot. That is French Roast people, not espresso.
Also, the two times I tried cappuccino here, well, I got a latte just like every dumb coffee place in SF. It is not just 1/3 espresso, 1/3 milk and 1/3 foam, all separate and stuff. The milk part has to be this kind of foamy milk melange that mixes a little w/ the espresso. Not bam, espresso up to here, then liquid milk up to here and the foam sitting on top. 
 
Take me to the Termini train station in Rome, the magazine stand near the platform that takes you to Paris. You can get the perfectestestest espresso in the world there for 90 cents. GOD SHOTS. 

I boycott American 'gourmet' coffee. If places like Blue Bottle would charge 90 cents instead of what $2 something for an espresso, then maybe I wouldn't complain.

UPDATED:
I got a message from someone who sent me info on BB's roasting processes. He was trying to explain that they don't burn their coffee. So it could be another reason why the espresso tastes charry:

It is possible then that they may not burn their coffee. The problem then might be that the baristas are letting the water be in contact too long with the espresso grinds. That could be a result of tamping way too hard or the grind being too fine. So the water sits too long, extracting all the *bad* unpleasant bitterness and masking the *good* coffee bitterness :o). Which becomes especially noticeable in a ristretto shot.

I am not sure if they have one of those machines that grinds, dispenses and tamps automatically. If that is the case then the dispensing and tamping are probably consistent, and the fineness of the grind is the variable. The grind for espresso should be checked regularly (more than once a day) because weird things like humidity affect it. 

I worked in coffee for about 8 years and learned all of this interesting (boring) stuff hehe.
author: Jackie P.

description:
i'm hooked... blue bottle is the new crack.

absolutely lives up to the hype, no question. i like this place even better than organica and ritual (although those are fantastic as well!).

the coffee here is truly exquisite. i love the set up. industrial, clean, and friendly. people weren't kidding when they said it was basically run out of a garage -- how fun and unique.

the cappuccino i ordered was otherworldly. the foam was so rich it didn't even taste like it had been made out of nonfat milk. the coffee is sweet yet bold, didn't even require one grain of sugar. seriously -- any added sweetness would have adulterated the aromatic goodness!
author: Jill M.

description: Tried this place once because I'm all about supporting local business. Even though it's half a block from my place, I wouldn't go near them again. The coffee is just COFFEE, people! And second rate, at that. But the worst offense was the bad attitude of the staff and the outright rudeness of the "barista." Bitch, don't ever ignore me and ask your coworkers twice in front of me in the course of a single transaction if "he's paid" for that. You can shove your mediocre coffee up your ass. I'll get mine from Tartine.
author: Paul T.

description: Not worth the price.  I don't know why they market it as a local micro-roaster.. their roasting operation is in Emeryville.  Yeah, the same Emeryville where Peet's coffee does its roasting.  There's plenty of small roasters that do organic fair trade coffee in the Bay Area that tastes as good or better for 1/2 the price.  Maybe I'm missing something here.  But my main gripe is that the little stand at the Berkeley Farmer's Market never has drip coffee... only espresso that they'll throw hot water into to water it down (aka "americano").  Tastes like charcoal when they serve it like that.
author: SC ..

description: The pastries and cookies are awesome.  I know their specialty is coffee, but their other offerings are just as good and shouldn't be overlooked - which include the free doggie treats.  Cupcake loves this place too.  He gives this place 5 tail wags.
author: Maria L.

description:
awful service. maybe it was a bad day but...

the place was closing at 5 and we get there at 4:55. the server looks at us with this disappointed face and says, "i'll serve you if you *promise* to never do this again. never come this late again. do you promise?" and we're thinking "huh?" but we want to try the coffee.

anyway, the coffee was good, but i won't go back because i like my coffee without attitude, no matter how good it is.
author: omar k.

description: Forget about ordering a grande non-fat decaf mochafrappalatte - the menu sticks to the basics and everything comes in one size only. It's quality, not quantity, that matters here, which is why each cup is brewed individually. Take home some of their organic, small-batch-roasted, super-fresh beans and make yourself a pot . . . or two. Once you get started, you'll definitely want more.
author: Gourmet G.

description: The freshest coffee I have ever had in my life! I wish we had one in San Diego...
author: L. C.

description: Best coffee place in Hayes Valley!  If you go there you have to try the cafe mocha!  It has the right balance of chocolate and espresso.  Truly a place to hit up if your in the neighborhood.
author: Lyly P.

description: I liked coffee before I tried Blue Bottle.  Now I LOVE coffee because of Blue Bottle.  This place helped me learn to appreciate coffee black - I finally figured out that putting too much cream and/or sugar can really ruin the body of the fine coffees they have here.  I love the boldness of their coffees, especially compared to the floral flavor of the coffee at Intelligentsia in LA.  Chiapas + Blue Bottle's Brioche = perfect breakfast pairing.
author: Mike S.

description:
So I ain't no coffee expert ... and I ain't no black coffee lover, THAT's for sure ... after reading and hearing about Blue Bottle, I HAD to give it a try ... prior to me coming here, I'm thinking... coffee is coffee, as in 1+1=2. 

I was honestly surprised how great the $2 drip coffee (black coffee) was.. very smooth which went quite well with my Citizen Cake goodies.... I swear, you could probably become a coffee addict by coming here and trying the $2 drip coffee... Thanks Joey! This isn't the ticket to get a free HOMEMADE kimchi jjigae!:) 

They are extremely friendly and easy to please.. wish they had more of a variety.. mebe I'm spoiled by starbux and their endless frapps.. =D
author: Jennifer S.

description: I love me some Blue Bottle whole beans!  My favorite so far is Misty Valley, but I have yet to meet a bag that I didn't like.  Yum!  One of the best part's of my weekend is brewing french press coffee with my boyfriend, especially if it is Blue Bottle!
author: Carolyn D.

description: Every time I stop by Blue Bottle on Linden Street I feel like I am sneaking into an alley to make-out with a secret lover. A rich, dark lover at that. Sinfully good. I believe I may be addicted...to love and Blue Bottle coffee.
author: Jessa B.

description: Great espresso drinks and coffee. The lines are a bit slow, not long but slow. It's worth the wait for possibly the finest coffee in this neighborhood. Now that Ritual has improved their espresso drinks, they represent to me the finest in the city.
author: Phil M.

description: This could be the case of hyped-up expectations. I heard so many things about this local, fresh-roasted, french-press brewed coffee in the alley that by the time I took a sip (that's about all you get for $2), I was bitter. No, the coffee wasn't bitter. I was. It was fine, but hunting for parking and waiting in line only to have a small cup of coffee that's good but not great is more work than I want to give any cup o' java. Peet's might be on every corner nowadays, but it's still my local fave.
author: sarah s.

description:
After hearing so much buzz about this place, I tried the caffe latte... and I thought it was on the slightly bitter side. Not only that, I was still tired from after drinking it. 

For SF standards, its good... but if you've been to Seattle... this doesn't compare by much.
author: Retired B.

description: Great coffee and awesome staff.  A must try for San Francisco residents.
author: K K.

description: This stuff was so not-messing-around fantastic that ordering a double latte was kinda redundant.  I love a coffee shop that looks like it's in someone's garage, right down to the dudes fixing bikes and scooters in the back.  Right f***-ing on!!  Talk about getting your motor going -- these folks can help.
author: Andi T.

description:
best damn coffee in the city - period. 
no frills, no wi-fi, no seating, no parking, no bullshit. 
friendly staff tho, and as i said - this is the best cup in the city - great idea too - basically just a kiosk.
author: bennett v.

description: I could see the dripping process for my drip coffee. I asked for the chemical-sugar, but the owner told me they only have the organic sugar there. Delicious! =)
author: Angela K.

description: This place was so hyped up so my expectations were extremely low - considering the fact that I'm such a sarcastic, untrusting bastard...but lo' and behold...the coffee WAS great. Some of you people DO know what you're talking about....damn.....  :)
author: Rich S.

description: I was lead to Blue Bottle on a weekday afternoon by a friend who HAD to take me to the best coffee in the city. After aimlessly wandering a bit we finally found it. Being a weekday there was no line (score!). I had the best drip coffee I've ever had. It's ok that there isn't anyplace to hang out because the Octavia St. park is a few steps away with beches and tables. The reason that it doesn't get five stars is that I went there recently to get my fix and after waiting in line for around twenty minutes I recieved my drip took a few sips and tasted grounds. Grounds? I prefer not to chew my coffee thank you. It hasn't happened since, so I'm hoping it was just a fluke... we'll see.
author: Trouble B.

description: Normally, I don't drink coffee, but I do from here.  I adore the pretentiousness with which they address a beverage that has largely become unappreciated, overpriced and merely a fashion accessory.
author: ben y.

description: By far, the best latte in the city, so creamy, you dont even need sugar. So good. Picked up a pound of bella donovan for my trip cross country and look forward to ordering their beans via express mail. YUM!
author: Sara A.

description: It seems a little silly to write a review of Blue Bottle when you Californians know all about it. But let me tell you, here in New York, I am not convinced that anyone knows a great cup of coffee. Yes, I have given positive reviews to my neighborhood coffee shops but I do so a bit begrudgingly.
