I don't want to admit that I have gotten used to fair-good cup of coffee, but  this is quickly confirmed when tasting Blue Bottle. It is amazing and has a flavor like no other coffee I have tried. Can I describe it? Not really but I can say it is worth the rain, the plane delays (compliments of Jet Blue) and the line at the small coffee counter. I used to believe that the coffee at Kings Road Cafe in Los Angeles was the best I have ever had, but now I am in love with Blue Bottle. New Yorkers love to hate California. I am not one of them. Thank you California for your casual but smart attitude, your quirky good nature and your damn good coffee. Now you New Yorkers, please drop the attitude, hop on a plane and go to the best city in the country. And don't forget to stop in Hayes Valley, drink some coffee and recognize  the worth of that YES that is accentuated in their neighborhood banners.
author: Tina E.

description: Pretty good coffee and good prices but I am just not cool enough to hang with the elite crowd of connosieurs populating the small mob that gathers in the alley.   This goes in the drawer filed under "status symbol"
author: Dru P.

description: OK, so there is always a line here and I've heard so much about it so I had to try it.  So I tried it, and tried it, like 2-3 times.  Each time, I wonder to myself, why is it so popular?  The coffee is fresh but to me it's just average.  Always a little bitter which I don't really like.  My favorite still is Ritual Coffee Roasters in the Mission.  The only reason I keep coming back is the location.  For Hayes Valley, it's probably the only half decent place.  Not worth the hype.
author: Mitch A.

description: Coffee Nazis? Yes, the coffee nazis are here!! The coffee is amazing I have to admit, but the wait in line and the treatment I receive when I get to the counter is unforgiveable. I think I'll take my coffee without the public humiliation, thank you. I'll be over at La Boulange. Hope to see you there.
author: Anyssa J.

description: What else can you say about this place that hasn't already been said.  Great coffee, really is. But I do have one issue, we are talking about a place that is basically run out of a back alley garage.  I don't know how some people can give this place 5 stars.  Granted I have no other back alley coffee places to compare it to, but I do occasionally enjoy sitting down while drinking my coffee.  And from time to time I would prefer not to be compelled to hold my coffee right below my belt buckle just to keep the circulation flowing in my manly parts. That's right I said it, Man-ly Parts.  When the wind whips down that alley things can get a bit frigid.  Just because the coffee is good, does not necessarily mean i feel like its a better alternative to brewing my own, where there are chairs, and interesting things to look at.
author: Andrew D.

description:
I am not a coffee snob even though I hail from the land of it. My friend happens to live close to this location so we all decided to see what all the fuss was about. I give is 5 stars because it does live up to its coffee for sure. But I would give it 4 and a half if I could because I hate waiting and sometimes waiting can be long because almost everyone is getting the drip. (you will see what I mean if you ever get a chance) 

-the nice climate in the 70's didn't make me mind waiting for a good ol cup of joe either.

I would take a blue bottle over SB's anyday.
author: Dan H.

description: WOW!! This coffee is SO good. It is not scalding hot that you have to wait to drink like some other places.
author: Michael F.

description: My favorite coffee place, it's near a cute little park my kids love going to in Hayes Valley. The Embarcadero location is nicer but more crowded. The mocha is my drink and there's always a pretty design in the foam on top! The line is always long and comes out into the not so nice alley and it's pricey but worth it!
author: Quynh N.

description: Blue Bottle serves the best coffee in the city, and quite possibly the entire country.  If you truly understand what good coffee is all about you will not be disappointed.  The baristas can not only make you a coffee that feels like a revelation, they're also the exact opposite of your average Starbucks drone: smart, funny, silly, and deeply committed to their coffee.
author: Olivia G.

description:
i probably should give this place five stars, but im just not enchanted by coffee anymore. if danny meyer can schlep this roast to the other side of the country, i decided that this place is worth checking out.

anyways, being that i  quit caffeine a couple years ago, cold turkey, no less (horrible headaches), i decided to break my sobriety and check this place out. i love the literal hole in the wall feeling, and i even love more the barista who free poured designs into my latte. i came here with my friend who is a barista of four years and even she was amazed by his free pour skill.

now, only if linden street was two-way....
author: justin t.

description: DELICIOUS COFFEE!!!!!!!  It's a very cool and interesting concept as well seeing as it operates out of a garage front.  They're very friendly and pretty quick considering the amount of people waiting to order and receive their orders.  Parking is not easy as this place is situated in an alley way.  Definitely so worth stopping by this place.  Especially on the weekends when you can take a nice stroll and have your coffee.
author: Carrie W.

description: If you can get through the self-righteousness and the hipster vibes surrounding this place, what you can get here is -the- best cappuccino imaginable. Blue Bottle also sells a limited but delightful range of cookies and biscuits to go along with your coffee - I had a snickerdoodle with saffron and a strong hint of Tahitian vanilla that was excellent, and I'll definitely be back to try the biscotti.
author: Trevor F.

description:
what?  this is the place??
is... this look like a garage??? huh?


I was sitting  in the sidewalk while sipping their cappuchino...

...hey I like this place!

YOU should check this place..
author: Lena N.

description:
good drip coffee: $2

watching a long line of coffee addicts waiting in a back alley as if they are strung out coke addicts? free

realizing you're one of them? priceless
author: Jan Michael K.

description: Best coffee I've had in the City, by far!  The shop is tucked away in an alley and is run out of a garage that has a woodworking studio in the back, maybe not ideal, but it adds a little flavor to the whole experience.  I just go for the plain drip coffee, brewed singly and to order by the friendly staff.  Be prepared to sit on the ground as there isn't much seating, but on a nice day, it's well worth it!
author: Craig E.

description: Blue Bottle's drip coffees are so amazing that I don't mind paying a little more than Philz or any other place that boasts a mean drip. I love the tucked-away location on Linden Street and the attitude of the baristas who are always busy but never rude. Like many roasters in this city, they are all organic, but I would prefer a Blue Bottle drip, latte, or vegan mocha to just about anything else.
author: Samantha M.

description: Incredible latte and the New Orleans iced coffee is delicious. Yum!
author: Wyatt H.

description: Easily the best coffee in the bay.  Very distinct taste profile, and differentiated from other more generic local coffees.  Buying a half pound of beans roasted the day of for $8 is one of the better deals around.
author: Lake C.

description:
Don't let the "scene" scare you.  The quality of espresso drinks is just superb.  Why people feel that they have to doll themselves up to stand in one of the coldest allies in San Francisco, I just can not begin to understand.  

I usually order the capp which is poured to perfection.  If I happen to stop by on a warm day, which is not often, I will order the new orleans iced coffee, which is also delicious.  The coffee is great, one of my favorite coffee spots in the city.
author: Jessica E.

description:
it gets a 4, only because philz is the only coffee in sf worthy of a 5.  their new orleans iced coffee is awesome too.  i had it the next day, still really good.  just try the drip if you havent been here before.

coffee in sf:
1) philz
2) blue bottle
3) martha bros
4) bernie's

btw my favorite latte to get was at torrefazione on battery street in the financial district before it turned into a guess what (starbucks).  sad, sad day.
author: Robert S.

description: I almost hate that I found this.  Every time I lift a cup of coffee to my lips, my heart is sad because its not blue bottle.  Yeah, there's a wait, yeah, its slightly more expensive than other places, but it it worth it.  It is so worth it.  It's $.25 more expensive than starbucks, but about 90 times better.  I have fantasies about this coffee.  Bad, bad fantasies that I should write to Dan Savage about.
author: She-Ra ..

description:
when you make it through an intense college, and i'm talking about the kind of college that feels like an entity out for blood, a place that's actually  trying to kill you (cornell), you will think you have tried coffee in every style possible, because it's a necessity you've grown sick of drinking (does caffeine breed paranoia?).

blue bottle helped me move on from my bad associations with coffee. their new orleans style chickory was a revelation. hallelujah!
author: Chelsea B.

description: How does an espresso machine located in a wood shop's garage with three seats and no food larger than a dog biscuit (which are also provided) get 5 stars? It's the coffee, of course. Blue Bottle has completely mastered the craft of converting coffee beans into beverages. Roasting only 6 pounds at a time probably helps. OK, the chocolate in their mocha is a 5-of-5 too.
author: Rick C.

description: Best coffee on the planet - yes, I said planet (and this is absolutely an unscientific assessment)!  Definitely the best coffee in the U.S. unless I missed a really good one in the Pacific Northwest since coffee on the East Coast (especially Dunkin Donuts, which is hot water with a coffee bean thrown in for flavor) and, definitely, the rest of the U.S. sucks.  It's so good that I risk my life standing in line in the street waiting for it.  Best Soy Latte I have ever had and the drip is outstanding.
author: Roy J.

description: Alright I've only been here one time so far and got the New Orleans Ice Coffee. HOLY SHIAT! that stuff is STRONG! I was looking for the equal, or sweet and Low, or splenda, or and cancer in a little packet, UH NONE! So I drank the stuff straight up and it was giving me heartburn! I need to give them another try, I like strong coffee, next time I think I'll bring my own splenda to balance out the bitterness. Also I'll cross my fingers I don't get heartburn from it again.
author: Karen T.

description: I've had Blue Bottle coffee at Tartine Bakery, and always find it delicious so I was pleasantly surprised to find this coffee stand tucked away in an alley (Linden Place) in Hayes Valley. And it is just that, a coffee stand, no bells and whistles, no tables or chairs, just a coffee stand where you can get gourmet coffee at its best. Standard for me of course is the soy latte, and just like at Tartine, here at the coffee stand my drink is beautifully crafted with a flower pattern on top resulting from a skilled mixture of frothed milk and coffee (if I can figure out how to do this myself, I could be rich).  As there was not an obvious place to sit, I ended up taking the drink  (along with assorted pastries purchased at nearby Miette) and sitting at a different sunny sidewalk cafe to enjoy the delightful experience of delicious coffee and artisan pastries  .
author: Kate A.

description: After living in Seattle for four years, it was great to find a roaster in San Francisco that could stand up to the best roasters in the country.  The Hayes Valley espresso has great body and tons of chocolate.  I always make sure to stop by BB when I visit the city.
author: Andrew C.

description: Yep.  Lives up to the buzz.  Worth a detour if you are in the area.
author: sarah k.

description: my sister loves this place, but i just don't understand.  maybe i'm not a true coffee aficionado or maybe it's the sticker shock but blue bottle is just "eh" to me.  had a pastry there that was delish but also extremely expensive.
author: G. P.

description:
The barristas at the Hayes Valley location are SO RUDE!  My mother-in-law in Taiwan tried their coffee once and loved it so much she requested we buy 10 bags for when she comes to the States over Christmas.  But the barrista acted annoyed, wouldn't simply put the coffee bags in the bag we brought (insisted on leaving them on the counter for us to pack which made us look like we were holding up the line), only gave us (and charged us for , to be fair) 9 bags, and didn't apologize when we pointed it out.   We have vowed never to go to this location again.  We noticed she was friendly to the "regualars" -- doesn't she realize that we bought an equivalent to at least 20 cups?  Wouldn't that make us regulars too?  Especially if my  in-laws lived here.

Unfortunately the snobbiness of this barrista really spoiled the delight we would have had in buying this coffee for someone who loves it.  And from the other reviews it seems it's not unusual.  We've been to the Emeryville loc and they were fantastic, run by different manager?  HAYES VALLEY LOCATION, YOU NEED TO REPLACE SOME STAFF!
author: Frances Y.

description:
hey it's a neighborhood business, and there are always some hottie fashionable-type girls in the line, so i was walking by and decided to try it out.
it was about 100 degrees out, and they refused to make me an iced americano.  for fook's sake it's not like it's hard to make, or they didn't have the ingredients!  they made me drink their chicory smoked iced coffee new orleans style instead - whatever the hell that means.  don't try to be all coffee cool guy on my ass, can i just get my espresso please?
went back again and tried their individually dripped coffee, and thought it tasted average, with a hint of funky.
author: Alfredo I.

description: Best coffee at all times. I've been driving 20+ miles to the city just to get their coffee, talk about some crazy cravings.  The line usually is not that bad, it's a bit of wait because they personalized every single cup of coffee for you, made (or dripp) to order.  My favorite is their ice coffee and mocha.  CREAMY and SMOOTH.  Not too bitter and not too strong.  AND, they play great music in a garage setting storefront.  Don't expect a place to sit here.  You can hang out on the floor with your friends across the street.  People usually just disperse elsewhere right after they get their coffee.  So don't bother to bring your laptop.
author: Carina N.

description: This coffee makes you high. no Joke.  I went to NY and tried a small coffee stand that's supposed to stand uo to blue bottle, but this is so much better.  I loveeee the ice coffee( they sweeten and milk it for you), soy latte, and cappuccino.  If your a serious coffee drinker I love the Kyoto style ice coffee
author: Josephine W.

description: I'll admit it.  I've become addicted to BB.  During a recent MOMA visit to view the Ansel Adams & Georgia O'Keeffe exhibit, I also made a trip up to the rooftop sculpture garden.  Low and behold, the rooftop cafe was actually another BB kiosk.  Even Boston-bred Grams, who was visiting, agreed that BB had made the most delicious and creamy tasting espresso she's ever had.  So there you go:  BB is officially Grams approved - and that type of approval is not gained easily.
author: Kristen H.

description: Okay, I'm giving 3 stars because the coffee deserves 5 stars and the time it takes to make the coffee deserves 1.  And I realize "that's how long it takes to individually brew each cup" but the waiting time negates the goodness over going to Citizen Cake for a cup o' joe.
author: Lee G.

description: I love these guys. Become a regular and you'll love it. Also, for all you drip coffee drinkers. A drip cost 2 bucks, but they put more care into those than the espresso drinks. Or so it seems. You can taste the difference. However, the wait can be brutal.
author: Sterling R.

description: The BEST coffee in California! Once moving to San Diego, we still only order and drink Blue Bottle Coffee. But unfortunately they don't ship in small bags such as they ones on site (come in 1lb packages) so you can't mix up the beans too often. Flavors are bold and delicious. Always makes a bold cup. I get up earlier to brew a pot at home rather than drink Starbucks prepackaged bags at work. Love and would recommend the New Orleans Iced with Non fat leche (contrary to the Hayes Valley baristas views who tend to disagree)!
author: e a.

description:
uber hip and uber good coffee!
heard about blue bottle through some friends and lonely planet, they said its the best coffee in SF. soooo i checked it out!

i am not a huuuuge coffee person but i did love the coffee here. came back 2x.

it's cool that BB is a bodega that you need to stand in line for. hayes is awesome, and BB adds to that awesomeness. 

also, i felt like i was in a lesbian bar waiting on line! so many!!!! haha. maybe that's just coffee houses tho. 

i'd like to add that they are VERY earth concious, and have separate bins for plastic, paper, and composting. wish people in NY gave a fuck about the earth too!
author: Hannah L.

description:
I had the opportunity to visit Blue Bottle's Hayes Valley shop today for espresso, and I was not disappointed.

The espresso was a darker roast, smoky but sweet with a delightful chocolaty finish. The barista expertly pulled beautiful shots from her La Marzocco GB/5. The menu is short, and the space is small, but the coffee quality is excellent. My double was rich and delicious.

The service was friendly and expedient (especially considering that the coffee is made by hand, not robots). I was, however, thankful for a warm jacket while waiting outside on a cold winter morning.

The bean selection was a bit limited in the morning, but they had a few more choices when I returned at lunch time. I picked up a bag of Ethiopian Sidamo that was roasted earlier today.
author: Mary W.

description: It could be better if i didn't have to wait 35 minutes for my coffee. Coffee is good and as well as the latte art, but staffs are very dity.
author: Kiki C.

description:
love the iced coffee and the mocha.  both are so smooth, delicious.  not very sweet, but that makes it tasty.  the lines usually take a while, but the people and atmosphere is nice.  

the only bad point is they dont have bigger cup sizes.
author: David T.

description: Very, very tasty coffee. Can see what it's a San Francisco legend (can't believe it took me so long to try it!). The fact it's in an alley is pretty cool and quaint. I'd like to come back and try a latte and a scone sometime soon! They offer soy and they accepted checks (along with cash, but no cards) which surprised me but seems like it could be convenient in a pinch. I plan on coming back!
author: Anne A.

description: Blue Bottle rocks!!  Their coffee is so good, and I love that there's wood shop behind there...  I usually get the hot chocolate -- I only wish there was somewhere to sit and hang out.  The newly finished Hayes Green is just a block away, so when it's nice, grab a coffee from BBCC and go lounge on the Green..
author: Dennis Y.

description: The coffee is certainly pretty good, but I found the service erratic and just plain slow. I ordered a plain coffee and about four lattes later, finally got it, with some of my beverage dripping down the side of the cup. A lid was tossed towards me when I asked for one. I'll go back and try this location again, because I do like the side alley vibe, but I'd be fine just having some of their beans to brew my own, thanks.
author: Nish N.

description: Ever since I visited Blue Bottle the first time, I've longed for it. Every time I'm in the city I drive there and get a latte. They're incredible and the best in the city. For those people who seem to have little understanding about how the perfect espresso drink is made, it should be drinkable as soon as you receive the cup. Overly hot espresso loses flavor, but nearly everywhere takes a hit on flavor because they assume you don't care enough and that you want to take your espresso somewhere. Blue Bottle does not make this mistake. If you don't know what you're talking about, then shut the hell up. San Francisco coffee shops: this is the bar. Play up.
author: Erik S.

description: Stunningly good latte.  In my 6 years in San Francisco, it is far and away the best I've had.  If I weren't so caffeine addicted, and if parking in Hayes Valley weren't so tough, I would refuse to drink anything else.  Alas, I am practical above all else in cars (Honda Civic EX) and coffee (Starbucks'll do).  Hopefully, the rest of the city -- and the country -- will catch up over time.  A new standard has been set.
author: Liz O.

description: You'll be stuck in line for at least five minutes, but whatever you're getting is worth the wait.
author: Sean M.

description: I don't like coffee at all (literally, I hate coffee) but somehow their lattes are pretty damn tasty. They have soy milk for you vegans. Take your coffee to the park nearby and relax for a bit!
author: Philip R.

description: Man, these people know their espresso.  It was excellent.  If I was rating these coffee places on the espresso alone I might even say it is the best (very close between Blue Bottle and Coffee to the People - I'd have to flip a coin).  But while these people know how to make a mighty fine cup, they have basically nowhere to hang out and lack the atmosphere that contributes to my very favorite coffeehouses.  But if you are just looking to grab a really great cappuccino, this is the place.
author: John D.

description: Yum!  Ordered a soy latte and a soy mocha, they were both delicious.  The coffee has nice well-rounded flavour, not bitter or sour like starbucks - bleh!  Furthermore, the mocha was the best I have ever had.  It had a nice bittersweet, rich chocolate flavour, not chalky and overly sweet. The drinks had perfect creamy foam; for soy, if the baristas don't know what they are doing, the "foam" can be bubbly and unappetizing.  They also take the time to make a pretty leaf design where many coffee places don't take the time to do anymore - nice touch blue bottle!  There's usually a line, but it's well worth the wait.
author: Miss H.

description: Blue Bottle is definitely unlike any other coffee place I've been to, and a far cry from the usual Starbucks/Petes type place.  Each drip coffee order is brewed individually, and their espresso drinks are amazing.  I especially like their mocha---good quality chocolate, and not too sweet.  Their New Orleans style iced coffee is also great when you're enjoying a rare warm day in the city.  They're tucked away on a little alley in Hayes Valley, but not to worry, they have a stand at the Ferry Building Farmers Market on Saturdays as well.  And their whole beans, roasted in small batches, are out of this world.  The line can get a little long, but it's totally worth the wait.
author: Leslie R.

description:
Maybe because it was 5:30, maybe because the barista was tired, maybe because the moon conjunction with jupiter wasn't favorable but their espresso was really acid, burnt and syrupy. The small drip coffee was really bad too. I really loved the attitude, the informal spot, the drum'n'bass spinning in the back but their coffee was as it was, cannot change it. Three stars for their policy of toasting in small batches and no selling after 48 hours + donating the remainder. We bought half a pound of Giant Steps blend, let's see if my Brikka likes it.
UPDATE: woowie! Giant Steps rules with my Bialetti!
UPDATE2: EEEEWWWW! Ok, 1 star (and even below) for their coffee preparations (espresso simply sucked and drip coffee, although hand-made was burnt and waaaaatery) but the beans are 5 stars good.
The average makes 3, good with that. How come though they have such a gap between the ingredients and the final product?
author: Dario B.

description: I'm not a coffee aficionado by any means, but their coffee is one of the best I've had here.  It's nice to end my lunch at Citizen Cake with some coffee from Blue Bottle.  I just get a cup of their individual filter drip.  I can never finish the cup.  I only can drink about half of it because I get so wired and bounce of the walls.  Their coffee is strong, but oh so good!
author: Michelle N.

description: Blue Bottle is a great example of quality not quantity.There is nothing I like more than a simple menu when its purpose is to highlight the specialties of the house. B.B. has only a small selection of items but does them so incredibly well. The Lattes & Cappuccino's hit the spot every time. The sweets are the same way, limited (in both size and variation) but absolutely delicious (I highly recommend the ginger scone).  And while it may get busy, because it's outside, the line just isn't that bad. This is definitely one of those neighborhood joints that define why I love San Francisco.
author: Meghan R.

description:
i brew their decaf at home and makes me look like i know how to make a great espresso when really i just know where to buy great beans,
and the beans were roasted yesterday,
and the bags are compostable,
and the cappuccinos they serve may just be the best in our fair city.
author: tara s.

description: Yes, you have to wait 7 minutes for your coffee.  Yes, you need to go to Hayes Valley to get the full experience.  Yes, you'll pay $3 for a drip coffee with steamed milk.  All of this is worth it just to taste the bit of heaven that comes in a cup from Blue Bottle.  Just make sure you get the drip coffee (not the espresso drinks) because the whole one-cup-at-a-time thing is why Blue Bottle is worth the hype.  It truly is the closest thing to Monmouth Coffee (at the Borough Market in London) on this side of the pond.
author: Julie H.

description:
On one of my walks to work (a coffee shop, actually) I decided to venture into the alley that boasts one of the best SF coffee spots. I accidently walked right by it--I guess I was expecting a huge line or at least a sidewalk sign or something--and had to do the ol' "oh, what the hell, I GUESS I have time for coffee" after "checking" the cell phone and seeing that the "co worker" is going to be "equally" as "late". You know what I mean? I TOTALLY didn't walk by like a mouth breather just now, staring dumbly into the crossing traffic. I TOTALLY had an excuse for doing a physical 180 in the street. Anyway. 
I've heard the baristas and clientele are a little, hmm, how do you say, not very nice, but the nice barista was, well, nice. It's obvious they know their regulars who obviously care that BB cares about them.
The coffee was very good, I thought. No bitterness, no gross aftertaste. It WAS, however, a teensy bit too lukewarm for my tastes. Then again, a lot of people like to drink their coffee when they get it. Go figure. 

I'd say try it out. It's a "San Francisco experience". 
...I guess.
author: Meghan K.

description: This place has the best coffee in town by a long shot, and the second-best coffee I've had in any town anywhere.  (IMO only Espresso Vivace in Seattle beats them.)
author: Jonas E.

description:
That barista guy Jamie at the Hayes Valley kiosk does it right!
Try your Blue Bottle there: it's a whole different experience.
His mochas are  the best I've had...no skimping on ingredients here: real Guittard Sur del lago chocolate in the bottom of the cup and then 2 serious shots of fresh espresso then the sensuous and ethereal foam crowning it : even more special when he draws cute heart-shaped patterns on the foam for you...
Starbucks people, go to hell and stay there!!! You may as well drink dishwater if Starbucks tastes like "coffee" to you!
Seriously, try Blue Bottle.
author: Sara K.

description: And it is as good as it gets. I finally got my BF to go with me this weekend. We went on this cool Sunday am. I have been to the Mint location, and i prefer the alley. We did not have to wait in line for hrs for a drip coffee. All said, maybe 10 Min's. They by far have the best coffee in town. I dig and support the blue bottle.
author: Nicole F.

description: Blue Bottle can make me dread going to work a little less and my weekend walk a little brighter. The New Orleans Style Iced coffee is my hands down fave, and after living in Louisiana for 4 years, I must say the flavor lives up to the name. Everyone is super friendly even though they are always busy and they even have treats for my pup when I drag her down the hill with me. Nothing but love from me to Blue Bottle!
author: Carmen C.

description:
i usually dont do this, but...1000th blue bottle review!  

okay, i'm off that.  moving on... theres something magic in that morning latte, and it's not just the caffeine.  one of the best parts of living in hayes valley :)
author: Julia B.

description: Was doing a shopping trip in Hayes Valley and my San Francisco hostess said we had to go here. I was really impressed with the cool modern garage door which rolled up to reveal a well-designed coffee bar. Also impressed with the locals lined up on the street to grab the coffee drinks which they imbibed standing up at small tables. Very Italiano! Excellent coffee, and a fun social scene-- Bay Area tourists must check it out.
author: Michelle B.

description: This is the best coffee I have ever had.  I crave it soo much I walk over a mile from my house for a cup.  They could charge whatever they want and I would still pay it.  Crack in a cup.
author: Liz Y.

description: best latte in the city. I love this place. Affogato is amazing too. They use humphry slocombe secret breakfast ice cream, topped with a shot of espresso. yum yum YUM!
author: Helen L.

description:
i believe the hype!!  i've never actually been to blue bottle coffee, but we have it at work, and the drip is amazingly good.  the coffee is super smooth and delicious w/ half/half.  no sugar required!!

update 1/16/08:  finally made it here for a cafe au lait today.  it takes a while to get a cup here, so don't come if you are in a hurry.  however, each cup is made w/ tlc and is deliciously strong!
author: Helen T.

description:
I love getting a perfectly fresh cup (plus a bag of beans to go please!) before heading over to Hayes Green for the perfect start to a relaxing day.
Lattes are fantastic, and the New Orleans iced coffee is even better!

Make sure to take this detour on any lazy (or not so lazy) Saturday morning.
author: A W.

description: This is like a out of the garage treasure, because it does seem like it is a shop that is out of a garage. There is mostly always a line! The co workers are awesome! The place is kind of hidden, but you will see a line of people and that will be Blue Bottle Coffee Co.
author: Janet Z.

description: If you want a place to lounge, then this place isn't for you.  But if you want a damn good cup of coffee, especially if you're going to be strolling around Hayes Valley in the afternoon, this is the place.
author: Michelle P.

description: A must-go coffee shop in town! Coffee with a strong sense of caffeine. Real Caffeine! As for latte lovers, the top layers of foams is exceptional here. It gets quite crowded usually like most delicious coffee shops, but it's worth it!
author: Janet L.

description:
blue bottle truly does make the best latte EVER!!!! (my other favorite latte is from Tartine).  
also, on a hot day try the new orleans iced coffee - it's so good. i crave it all the time.
author: Mary C.

description:
yes, the wait can be ridiculous at times. especially in the morning, afternoon, and evening of... pretty much every weekend and many weekdays.

but, without a doubt, it is worth every terribly painful second. the coffee is so good, so good. the espresso is the - dare i say - shiiiznit. yes, i said it. you can buy any of their beans by the pound. the "giant steps" blend is one of my faves. the miette cakes (chocolate morsels of heaven) are also really great.

probably the best coffee i have ever had.
author: Syd V.

description:
went here with a friend who lives in duboce during a visit to sf -- totally wouldn't have known about it otherwise. absolutely fantastic coffee.

funny to turn a corner in hayes valley to find a line of people waiting outside a garage for coffee! had a delicious drip coffee and bought some retrofit beans, which were roasted same-day!

only wish i lived closer so i could enjoy their coffee on a regular basis. glad they have online ordering as an option.
author: j h.

description: Bar none. the best coffee and espresso drinks in San Francisco.  Handcrafted, handroasted, served with pride. Plus, the alley kiosk is a fine way to spend a few minutes drinking your coffee and meeting a few new people.  Not a place to go if you are in a hurry, as there's one barista at a time and often a line. But the wait is worth it!  Note that there is variation in the drinks from barista to barista....
author: Celeste S.

description: I had read about them, didnt want to stand on the cue. But saw them at Ferry Bldg during Sat Farmers mkt and since the line was too bad decided to try it.  Boy, it was worth the wait--unbelievable coffee flavor, robust, mouth full.  My brother and sister-in-law from NYC were in town and they went crazy over the cuppa.  Well-done.
author: Nancy H.

description: Big fan.  Amazing cup of coffee, but not sure if it was worth the wait.  It was a typical windy day and the wait kinda ruined my mood helped make up for it.  For a quick cup Peet's is still my favorite but the coffee here wins the prize.
author: Marcolm A.

description: Yes, it's pretentious.  Yes, it's located in an alley garage.  And yes, the "cool" people that go there make me feel inadequate and force me to reconsider my lack of hip clothing apparel.  BUT, when that creamy, rich latte hits my tastebuds and sends me to coffee heaven, I forget all about the hurdles I had to go to get it.
author: Clara F.

description: Whatever you do, do NOT double park your car in the no parking zone in front of the building across the street.  I saw two people get tickets for this in the 5 minutes I was there.  Think about it...this coffee is so good people are willing to tempt fate and go head-to-head with a stern parking maven who is more than willing to give you her name and badge number because you, my friend, are in fact breaking the law.
author: L W.

description:
There are a lot more knowledgable reviewers for Blue Bottle, so lemme just say this:

You can drink it black. Even Starbucks-Caramel-Macchiato drinkers can. Eerie.
author: Asdf A.

description: Now that the hype has caught on, there's a creepy line of zombies at the crack of dawn, gathering like a satanic cult for the morning blood ritual. Well I'll begrudgingly admit that these zombies are only following what is good and great I guess...there's no denying that the cappuccinos are absolute perfection. Wake up zombie!
author: Jennifer O.

description: The New Orleans iced coffee is over the moon good, and always is.  You'd have to be a moron to screw up an iced coffee though.
author: Boots B.

description: Yeah, the coffee is good.  The baristas are efficient and capable.  the dogs roaming around fulfill my need for cute pet interaction on a Saturday morning.  What I really need though, even if there's no place to sit for a moment, is some sunshine while I wait in line - that permanently shaded  and chilly alley just makes me want to go home and hide under the  covers, and no amount of caffeine reverses this instinct!  Thus the Blue Bottle stand can never quite fulfill the energizing needs I seek from a coffee stop . . .
author: Natalie S.

description: Worth the wait!!! This is one of the few places I can reliably drink a cup of black coffee and love it every time. The Cappucino is amazingly, out-of-control, melt-in-your-mouth good. I have yet to be disappointed by any of their beans.
author: Ryan B.

description: The setup is hard to find and quirky in a typical SF type of way.  The staff are very friendly and it is the place for serious coffee drinkers.  I don't see myself paying that much for cups of coffee, but their baked goods are delicious.  I had a Rosemary and pine nut shortbread today that was awesome.  They also had something like a bacon brioche that looked like a life changer
author: Michael C.

description: I've been drinking Blue Bottle since I first discovered it at the Ferry Terminal.  I love that it's in my hood, and a decadent Saturday morning for me is walking down for a mocha.  I love the coffee, the atmosphere, the service.  It's a neighborhood coffee hang out place that encourages everyone to be social.  You can even ask for it for here, but then walk over to Hayes Green to enjoy your morning brew.  Can't say enough good things about this place.  To me, this is why I pay an arm and a leg to live in SF.  This is what I want from my neighborhood.
author: Alisha A.

description: Forget about it Kona, in spite of your prestigious microclimate.  Sorry Baby's Coffee, in spite of your killer Key West legend.  You tried hard, Stumptown.  Go to sleep Seattle.  Blue Bottle Coffee (you can get it at Bar Tartine or at that new chocolate shop on Fillmore in Pacific Heights, among other places like the shop itself in Hayes or the Ferry Plaza building on Saturdays) is the most superior coffee I have ever tasted.
author: Abendigo R.

description:
i dont get it. 

u ahve to wait 15-20 minutes in line for marginally better tasting coffee with good roast that's aromatic, but it's not worth the wait. 

go to peet's instead for sanity's sake.
author: Bobby B.

description:
Before going to Blue Bottle, I knew the blue bottle to be either a nasty, dirty fly, or a stinging predator of a jellyfish--not a cappuccino kiosk that serves organic milk and sugar with their strong brew.  

It's safe to say that I prefer this newfound definition.
author: Hannah J.

description: My first visit was on Memorial Day and they were open, kudos. A very creamy latte. Fun if you are not on a schedule and like standing in line with the cool kids for a decent cup of espresso.
author: Nathaniel R.

description: The best coffee ever made.  Really.  Ordering it through the mail is also AWESOME as your office/home/mailbox smells like freshly roasted beans.  Having James make you a latte is one of the biggest treats at the Ferry Plaza Farmer's Market.  YUM.
author: Melinna G.

description: I'm so homesick for Blue Bottle Coffee! Just moved to NYC from SF --- New Yorkers don't know what they're missing!
author: Heather F.

description: Robust and delightful. I was a little lost at the fact it was a straight up warehouse it was almost Spy status...  but hey, I got my New Orleans Iced Coffee and was pleased.
author: Alyson C.

description: Long line, but it always moves fast. Hands down best coffee I've ever had. It's worth the money and the walk from Fox plaza!
author: katie n.

description: All I can say is I LOVE BLUE BOTTLE COFFEE!!!  After drinking Blue Botttle, Satrbuck and Peets has nothing on them........
author: nikki p.

description: 5 stars are reserved for best in class.  Yeah, it's that good.
author: Mamoon H.

description: Finally got around to trying this the other day! Best latte I've ever had? Probably. Eager to come back and wait in line for 30 minutes behind groups of smug hipsters with perfectly sculpted "messed up hair" and skinny jeans, complaining about their financial hardships and "the man" while waiting in line for 30 minutes to fork over more than $3 for a cup of coffee (irony, anybody?), again? No , thanks. Give me a cup of Philz over this place any day!
author: Stephen L.

description: The Coffee Messiah. If the "Soup Nazi" where to make coffee, this would be it!
author: Marco M.

description:
The lines are always ridiculously long when we come here, but the coffee is well worth the wait.  Lately we have been buying beans and brewing our own at home... beans-only buyers can bypass the line and go straight to the counter to make their purchase.  We want to attempt to try all of the blends, but it's just so hard to pass up our favorites: Three Africans, Giant Steps, Bella Donavan... wait... who are we kidding... ALL of the blends we've tried always end up being on our "favorites" list.  

It's cash only and I'm not gonna lie... parking here SUCKS!  We are planning on setting up a coffee subscription soon so that we not only avoid having to stand in line in the cold, but also so that we can always have a good cup of coffee any time we want.
author: mary j.

description: Why is their coffee so good?! Perfect Americanos and silky smooth & creamy lattes. And, the barristas always have time for a little latte art to brighten my day. I couldn't ask for more.
author: Lizelle G.

description: Just moved into Hayes Valley..heard all about this particular coffee...tried it and loved it.  I think im hooked.
author: Denny R.

description: Holy Smoke Batman! I think I'm in love! This is the crack of coffee. To drink from the mother's tit, a tit that is not concerned with an over-baked ambiance, is to truly form a unique relationship with coffee. To drink from places that serve this sweet been juice is never disappointing. My hat's off to Magnolia and Chez Panisse for stocking this magical stuff. I really am floored by just about anything that comes out of this place's espresso makers or anything else for that matter. Go ahead, brave the line and the lightless alley, every quest needs a hero and every hero needs a grail. This just might be the holiest of all java grails.
author: Len S.

description: Not that Blue Bottle needs another 5 star review but I am going to give it to them!! I LOVE this coffee, I had never had it but heard through the grape vine is was the bomb, well my mom and pop's love themselves some good beans so here I am, 2 days before Christmas rushing to Blue Bottle for some beans, well they are sold out but I am informed I should come when they open for some fresh bags of coffee! Well Dec 24th and here I am in line at 7am for a soy latte a mocha for the BF and 2 bags of coffee in hand, they are super helpful and explain what beans are best for whom and all in all I just LOVE this place, it is as local as it gets and I LOVE that
author: Deidre B.

description: Peets is still my 9-5 stop on the way to work, but on the weekends I will head to Blue Bottle, where the coffee is so good, it feels like you commited a crime. I will return...every weekend until I die!
author: Johnny O.

description: I've only been to the little spot in Hayes Valley (where I feel like I'm about to buy stolen electronics off the back of a truck)...but the coffee is sure tasty. Try the iced coffee- it's perfect!
author: Emily L.

description: Best coffee I've ever had. In the words of a friend: "coffee has no business tasting this good"
author: David Y.

description: One of the best cups of black coffee I've ever had was at Blue Bottle.  I love the location, too.  As if they're hiding to avoid serving coffee to someone who simply can't find the nearest Starbucks!
author: Nobody M.

description: I love this coffee place - the space in Hayes Valley is very industrial and cool - the little coffee cart down at the ferry plaza on Saturdays is little and busy but they give out free Miette macaroons!  I agree that the coffee is pricey, but it is strong and yummy.  The people who work there are so nice as well.  I do think the wait for the drip coffee on Saturdays at the Farmer's Market is a bit ridiculous - but that's why you should buy a bag of beans and make it at home!
author: Christina S.

description: On my quest for coffee in the city, I dropped by Blue Bottle because, well, everyone on yelp said to, and I love Hayes Valley. Unfortunately, their much vaunted mocha was not worth the 4 dollars I paid, or the 10 minutes I spent in line. However, I gave it 3 stars instead of 2 because if I ever feel really uncool, this is the place to casually stand in front of a garage in an ally and pretend to be a hipster.
author: Grace C.

description: The best espresso in San Francisco.  I've been going here since they opened.  It's a busy location in the morning, people just parking on the sidewalk to find anywhere for the morning fix.  There's a great group of regulars, some of whom travel significantly out of their way.  Try the Sidamo beans at home.
author: James D.

description: I have heard many good things about blue bottle coffee, but was very skeptical when I saw the location and place. It is located in an alley way and occupied kiosk space. So how good is the coffee? The coffee is well balanced in acidity and medium-bodied for depth. The milk temperature was just right and the foam was just velvety! The unique way of roasting small batches of coffee greatly enhances taste. Ahem, Starbucks on the other hand brewed coffee is circulated for an hour (s t a l e). No bueno!
author: Billy T.

description: Truly outstanding coffee served up the the biggest shot of attitude.  The folks behind the counter seem as if the could not even give a damn if you are there or not.  It is really sad that they have such amazing coffee with such bad service.  I stopped going because no matter if I go to the Ferry building, Hayes or THE WORST 5th street! It's all the same great world class coffee with world class pains in the a-- to serve it up hot!  I hope the founders can make some changes with the service.
author: Heith M.

description: This place never disappoints!  I am an avid coffee drinker and hot damn...love the BB.  I'm happy to see that they're venturing out...some local places are serving the beans...but the OG is the best!  Highly recommended to any caffeine addict!
author: Se C.

description: Agree with most of the reviews here that the coffee is absolutely fabulous, but the service leaves a lot to be desired.  Plus, I know that they have this thing about hot coffee hurting the flavor or quality (blah, blah...), but give me a break.  I would prefer to have coffee that is hot enough to last at least 10-15 minutes.  The best method is to go there for their beans and leave the marginal service and lukewarm brew behind!
author: Darcy P.

description: The coffee is almost the best cup you'll ever have but the food is AMAZING! It's very chic very natural and amazingly Delicious! I had this pear and apple compote with Greek yogurt and toasted walnuts was absolutely sinful! The toast is the best and the raspberry jam is to die for! Its a little pricey for college student, but its worth it!
author: stephanie c.

description: Holy crap, the New Orleans-style iced coffee is crack. It's a good thing I live out in the Avenues or I'd be here every day spending $3.50 on iced coffee. It's 11pm as I write this and I want some right now.
author: Fawn F.

description: SHHHH... don't let anyone else know about this place... I now get up an extra hour earlier to enjoy my coffee before going into work.
author: Rolo T.

description:
greatest coffee in San Francisco, without a doubt.
cute offbeat garage on Linden Avenue arranged in a cool & crafted way as a to-go counter. 
su-perb!
author: lucy b.

description:
Yes, quite possibly the best cup of coffee on the West Coast.  I'm from Seattle, so there are plenty of espresso joints to get your fix.  However, for just a plain ol' cup o' joe, I just assumed once you've had Starbucks drip coffee (hard to mess up, and sufficiently consistent brew), there isn't much room for improvement from there.  I guess I've been known to be wrong a time or two....  
Echoing what others have already mentioned: speed is not part of the baristas' vocabulary, so budget extra time; BRING CASH (I made the mistake of going all the way over there with only a credit card, and uh, no they won't let you just start a tab...); can be a bit sloppy (they don't wipe off the dripping coffee on the sides of your cup)

I was going to put 4 stars, but aw hell, it's damn good coffee, and I'm willing to wait for sticky fingers.
author: Ames C.

description:
all right, *sigh*, the cat's out of the bag... Blue Bottle is sorta
like the Jefferson's -- Movin' On Up.

what used to be a bizarre, delightful hole-in-the-wall (literally: I defy you to find one other coffee shop that actually is a hole-in-the-wall, as opposed to a kiosk) now has lines that rival the DMV's.  And some of the same freaky drivers, too: my innocently parked car was backed into by some clueless dude before my very eyes... yet the coffee was so good, I accepted it with Zen-like tranquility.  

So yes, it's urban, gritty, and that's part o' the fun.

But all is forgiven, because this place is HARDCORE and you
will never walk out of here with a caramel-mint chip enema or whatever SBUX is serving up these days.  No, you will suck down a Gibraltar and get a latte or whatever for the road.  And you will freeze your ass off while you wait in line (at least in January), and you will like it.

Even Peets, dear Peets, is a corporate Goliath compared to this little David of a kickass coffee stand.

To those in the know, 3 Africans is where it's at.  Best blend, hands down.  

The baristas are fantastic -- erudite, skilled, and patient.
author: James F.

description:
Update, of sorts:
-----------------------------------------
I reviewed this place a few months ago, but forgot to mention one thing. As a frequent customer (well. whenever I'm within a 20 block radius, I'll go), I've noticed the service vary. The quality of coffee doesn't change, but depending on the day and time of day your experience will vary. Baristas are very friendly most of the time, but there have been days where I've felt a bit snubbed by the service, so beware, but don't be too critical. If you were working and nobody bothered to tip or say thanks, wouldn't you be crabby?

Still, doesn't affect the quality. 
____________________________________

I accidentally discovered Blue Bottle. Sure, I'd heard it's name whispered among well-learned coffee connoisseurs, but never thought much of it- I mean, how much 'better' could coffee get? A latte at Starbucks and a latte here would still be espresso and steamed milk, right? Well, to be cliche, wrong. My first trip here was when I cut through an alley to get to a store in Hayes Valley and noticed the small shop. The open garage door, the skinny table outside and the incredible amount of people just waiting for their drinks drew me and and I found myself in front of a smiling barista, who seemed more than happy to make me a soy latte and a small square of lemon shortbread from Miette. I walked for another block before I looked at the latte in my hand, a slight white paper cup and a flower made of steamed milk looking back at me. I sipped, sipped, and sipped again, and found myself in what I can only describe as one of the single greatest love affairs of this century: the latte wasn't just a drink- it was a work of art, carefully brewed and poured with precision. It was nothing short of wonderful (except, well, I think it'd be really cool if instead of plain cups, there'd be a small blue bottle on the cup somewhere..but that's just aesthetics for me). The coffee is great too- flavorful and bold, without making your taste buds cringe. 

The warm weather is coming so don't sell yourself short and say it's not 'coffee weather'. Their iced coffees are out of this world as well- phenomenal. Simply phenomenal.
author: Shelby C.

description:
this place is absolutely in the top 2 for coffee in san francisco no doubt.  unfortunately for you, i still am going to rant.

personally i like philz coffee better.  but i also drink decaf instant coffee because i personally think coffee is a bunch of bull-shizzy. what really is funny to me is when people say things like "best SUCH-AND-SUCH in SAN FRANCISCO" like they've been to or heard about every SUCH-AND-SUCH in san francisco.  these are always a highly suspect type of reviews. additionally, i just might add, ritual coffee is not amazing, its ok.  i gather that people who think that ritual is the 2nd best coffee around is limited to foot and pedal types of transportation in the city, and needs mapquest to navigate outside of the mission, soma, TL and downtown areas.
author: christopher a.

description:
j'aime, no... j'adore their americanos. 
no cream. no sugar. no mess needed. 
just truly, wonderfully prepared espresso w/ water. 

LE some of the most perfect 5 minutes of my day.
author: Coco E.

description:
The coffee here is STRONG.  Given its location and the clientele I've observed, this is where you go if  you're a yuppie that wants to get wired but have qualms about smoking crack or meth... actually, that's a pretty dramatic comparison, but the kick from their individually brewed coffee cups is narcotic.

I had it once and I was peeing every 20 minutes for 2-3 hours and could not fall asleep until 3 hours past my usual bed time that night (and I had this coffee at around 10am).  I also could not hold a thought since the caffeine had my brain moving too fast.

For other people I talked to, this place is great.  Maybe they get espresso drinks or just have a high tolerance for caffeine (as I have in the past).  Whatever it is, it's not for me.

Finally, there's no place to sit and that line takes forever.
author: Anx R.

description: From the moment I discovered it in Hayes Valley (my old 'hood), I fell in LOVE with this coffee.  Yes, the lines are absurdly long any day of the week, trust me it's worth the wait.  Their coffee is velvety, never bitter, and is great all on its own (no cream or sugar needed).  I get their coffee now via mail because I now live in San Diego, but there is a great feeling when you get to the front of the line on a cold San Francisco morning and take your first sip of the coffee to make you love the place you live.  Blue Bottle and San Francisco, I miss you.
author: Diana C.

description: Blue bottle coffee....   I have never liked how coffee tasted and always hated the after taste.... and you guys made me fall in love with coffee... and even addicted to your coffee now....!!
author: Sarah H.

description: Definitely a MUST to visit. Talk about a garage coffee shop idea come to life. This is it. Great location, awesome owner, and of course...great coffee!! This is what makes San Francisco unique. Whether you're a local or a visitor, you must stop by and check out the cafe.
author: benjamin c.

description: I like the philosophy of the place.  Taking time to brew each cup, the organic coffee and milk, but I just don't find it so special...The latte was not hot enough and lacked in flavor.  Tasted more like warm foamy milk with brown swirlies, and the drip coffee was kinda bland.  I would only go again if I was in the neighborhood getting a corsette next door at Dark Gardens.
author: black k.

description:
It's not that the coffee tastes horrible, it's everything else about it that ruins it. The long lines, the lazy staff, the high prices. There is a fairly new woman who works there (apparently an unbelievably bitchy assistant manager) who ruined my last coffee because she was chit-chatting with her co-worker and didn't listen to my order. Such a long wait too...then I had to wait an extra 7 minutes for the re-do.

The last good time I got coffee was when the guy with the gray hair made it (a year ago?...he's long gone). Since then, it's amateur city. The coffee is lukewarn, almost cool actually. Takes *forever* to get your order. Attitudes abound, they seem to have very high turnover. I don't mind waiting on line, but when I get to the counter I expect what I ordered. Beware of putting a tip in their huge tip jar before you receive your coffee, you might want it back after they mess up your order and then get mad at you for asking for what you really ordered. Seems fitting Blue Bottle is located in hyper-pretentious Hayes Valley. Their location on Polk Street closed almost immediately. I don't know why, but there are a lot better cafes all around them. In Hayes Valley, there are none. Perhaps that is why they have such sucky attitudes.
author: Me -.

description: I believe a cappuccino from Blue Bottle is the best I've had in San Francisco.  Baristas are artists here.  But you must drink the cappuccino quickly because it cools down fast.  If you've had better in the city, let me know!
author: Mark K.

description: OMG.  I never liked coffee before I had Blue Bottle.  Now, nothing compares...wow...I am lucky to live so close.  Shitballz, it rules.  Just sayin...
author: Suzanne L.

description: Hip, friendly and hidden away in Linden alley this place has drip coffee that will blow your mind.  They use a special brewing technique that is similar to french press coffee - the result is an inimitable bold, creamy and smooth coffee... everything I look for in a cup!
author: Katie H.

description: Simply the best coffee in the city.  Ask for a Gibraltar.
author: Jen V.

description:
yogi the chihuahua and i like to take a stroll from our house in the deco ghetto over the octavia green down to hayes valley, and when we do, we usually take a detour to blue bottle before hanging at the park for a spell.  i love the industrial look of the place, converted garage space, just flip up the door and turn on the espresso maker, and i love that i can just walk up w/ my pooch and not have to lie about him being a service dog to get in : ).  there is usually a line, but i end up talking to interesting people in line while they pet yogi and coo at how cute he is (yes, he is so damn cute...).

and i really like to support small local businesses, especially when they offer good stuff.  

my only complaint is that my coffee is usually not hot enough...gotta make sure and tell them that next time...
author: Suzanne A.

description: This is the best coffee in SF... Ritual is up there with it too, but recently Blue Bottle has been my favorite. I love the garage setup, very cool, the line actually wasn't all that long the last several times I was there, maybe I got lucky. Their cappa and latte are just perfect, the latte arts on top are always on point. Perfect weekend afternoon: cappa from Blue Bottle, shopping at Hayes Valley (mainly Azalea, Gimme Shoes, and Huf)...
author: Andrew N.

description: I know another five-star review probably won't change anybody's opinion about this place. But I just want to confess my undying love for Blue Bottle Coffee. I hate standing in line. Let's just say this is one of the few places that can make me willingly stand in line for 20 min, even if in the rain. The latte is so richly flavored and perfectly balanced for my taste. Hands down my favorite espresso drinks coffee shop in SF so far.  And I'm a huge sucker for the perfectly shaped leaf or heart they make with the foam. It always brings a smile to my face.
author: June W.

description: Blue Bottle changed my life. After years of wishing for real coffee like in Seattle or Auckland, Blue Bottle materialized out of thin air. I love that they don't serve tea or blended drinks. They focus on one thing, and they do it exceptionally well.
author: Steve S.

description: They may take forever but good things come to those who wait!  Could there really be a better cup of coffee in the city?? Fazenda Jacaranda beans are always yummy when playing the home version, but do yourself a favor and get a latte or a gibraltar.  Blue Bot kills it.
author: ROSS H.

description: Yum, love this place for its New Orleans iced coffee spiced with chicory.  I don't like their selection for pastries -- high priced and dry.  The copy for the coffee are hilarious.
author: Vera D.

description: I think that this is the best coffee in the city. Probably better than Ritual, if you don't need to sit down. My latte was perfectly smooth - not at all bitter, and beutifully poured. The milk was precisely the right texture. Just thinking about it makes my mouth water, and considering that it's a cup of coffee, that's saying a lot.
author: Dana L.

description: Excellent artisan-roasted espresso without the bitterness.  Goes down very smoothly.
author: Grace W.

description: Their house coffee is an unusal (and very good) light city roast. I had a double shot mocha and the espresso had no bitter aftertaste. It was almost like drinking a hot chocolate made with great dark chocolate. I'm sure it had espresso in it because it started with a smooth, velvety coffee flavor. Highly recommended.   They have extended their hours by 3 for summertime and have not yet updated their website.   M-F: 7am - 7pm Sa-Sun: 8am - 7pm
author: matt m.

description: I'm addicted to Blue Bottle Coffee.  The Temescal Espresso taste so good prepared on my mukka express.  I would probably go  everyday to the kiosk in Hayes Valley if I lived here.  Counting the days until I go back home and have me a fresh cup.
author: Belle M.

description: Call me a coffee snob, but usually lattes and other milk-coffee-drinks make me ill. As far as I'm concerned, Blue Bottle is top of the very short list of drinkable (re: good) coffee in SF.
author: Blaine C.

description: True barista artistry at it's best. Come here to see the professionals. These barista technicians are impressive utilizing every resource possible to provide their customers with the perfect brew. They make the best cappuccino. Experienced coffee connoisseurs would feel right at home. The experience alone is worth the trip. You can take home .5 lb whole bean bags from a variety of roasts.  They roast their beans daily. Try the Retrofit Espresso roast for starters.
author: James B.

description: Great espresso pulls, double ristretto style, just how I like them. It has a sweeter taste that unfolds on your palette, never burnt or too long of a pull. I believe they use a lighter roast which also gives a little sweeter flavor. Milk is done well, too.  A cascade of little bubbles and milk at the perfect temperature. The combination is delectable! One thing to note, be ready for a wait.  I don't think I have ever not waited in line for this little coffee stall.
author: Matthew D.

description: A very good latte.  Kinda tough to efficiently (I'm not saying quickly, there is a certain pace required for a good latte) get out of there though.  I have learned to bring exact cost and tip because getting change can take damn near 15 minutes for whatever reason.  Folks living near this little kiosk are lucky, that is for sure.
author: Lindsay B.

description: Yummy coffee. It is easy to get addicted. i have switched to tea during the week and this is my special treat on the weekend. The line is always long but the soy latte is so delightful and worth it.
author: stephanie k.

description:
Another fabulous recommendation from my friend (and fellow Yelper) Sarah C.
This is the most deliciously crafted coffee I have ever tasted.  I unfortunately don't live anywhere near the storefront in Hayes Valley...so I've been so happy to see the cart open on Tuesdays at the Ferry Building.  I just bought a pound of Giant Steps and can't wait to attempt making my own brew at home...
Definitely coffee that's worth the $ and the wait.
author: Amy C.

description:
excellent coffee, really.  i think the espresso rocks too.

but the location, (not b.c. it's in an alley, but b.c. it's in hayes valley), makes it a pretentious haven - lots of yuppies. wow. lots of 'em.
author: Erika Y.

description: Heard the wait was long, but luckily I went on a Thursday Rainy afternoon.  I can see why people wait so long to get their coffee.  Much much smoother than Starbucks and other chain coffee shops.  Of course I got the latte, and not regular coffee, so it is difficult to compare.  I will have to try this place out again!
author: M L.

description: The best cappuccino I have ever had. Period. Find this place + drink a cup = happy.
author: Nick K.

description: Stand in line on a blustery day, walk the alleys of Hayes Valley to find hidden treasures, and sip on some caffeinated piece of heaven.
author: Libby T.

description: The people that were working were the highlight of the visit, they seemed to genuinely enjoy being there!  I had heard from loads of people how good the coffee is so i was really excited. I wished that it were stronger, I tried both: their drip coffee and a cappuccino. The sun was shining and a day off as well, it fit the bill. Will return again!
author: Timothy F.

description: Really excellent coffee, but don't call this a cafe.  Read below: no seating to speak of.  Luckily there's a cute park near by.  Seems a shame they couldn't put up a few shaded tables on the street.  I bought a half pound of their espresso roast and will try it in my Saeco tomorrow and will report back.  All I can tell you now is that the mocha I ordered was perhaps one of the best I've ever had.  The 3 people I went with all ordered different things and loved them.
author: Mark S.

description: Great coffee!  What can I say?  Every hipster and their mother knows about this place.  The baristas can be snotty but they do their job well.  The perennial long line prevents me from getting coffee there everyday, but I put up with the line when I want a treat.
author: R L.

description: Hands down the BEST coffee I have ever had the pleasure of tasting. A no frills coffee joint with the freshest coffee you get. I'm craving a latte as I type!
author: Jill R.

description: I rarely give the five star, but this place gets it. Great coffee, nice people, interesting location. Its all good.
author: Emily S.

description: My favorite latte!  I usually brew my own at home but when I am feeling up for a treat, I go to Blue Bottle.  I am excited everytime and so pleased every time.  Not sure how they do it.  if I have to drink coffee someplace else, I dream of the blue bottle.
author: Alita W.

description: my god, i don't even drink coffee anymore and the smell woos me to do evil. Interesting people, coffee produced with care and hot cocoa for us trying to abstain from the bean.
author: hunter w.

description: There is only one way to make coffee.  Finely grind carefully roasted, gourmet coffee beans, transfer the ground black, powdery substance into a paper filter, drop said filter and its contents into a ceramic cone, pour extremely hot water over the grounds, allowing the liquid to fall into your mug.  Imbibe, with a smile.   These guys get it!!!
author: Cameron Y.

description: Blue Bottle is a really special find.  The coffee is great, the beans are roasted fresh locally, and the staff is always friendly.  There are dog treats from Babies and friendly people from the surrounding businesses.  Try the New Orleans Iced Coffee and stroll down to the new Hayes Green.
author: Eric M.

description: Hands down the best coffee I have ever had.  Nothing more to say, it is always fresh(roasted within 48 hours), and they use organic milk so it taste that much better.  The people that work there are very kind as well, and if you have a dog(regretfully I don't) they give you doggie treats for the pup.  good peoples at the Blue bottle.
author: brian m.

description: This coffee is OK but not worth the hype.  If you want good and unique coffee go to Philz at 24th and Folsom or 18th and Sanchez.
author: Keith B.

description: After getting some comics at Isotope there is not a better treat for the caffiene o phile than a cafe au lait made at blue bottle. So delicious and the buzz had a time release effect that lasted for hours.
author: D-E F.

description:
In my opinion, Blue Bottle serves:
1) The best cappuccino in San Francisco.
2) The best roasted coffee beans in San Francisco.  
3) The best espresso shot in San Francisco?  They might be in a tie with Ritual Roasters--I think it depends on the weather.

Everything they do is great, and the staff is very friendly and extremely knowledgeable.
author: Trevor H.

description:
Blue bottle is the best coffee in town (read: even better than Ritual and Philz). In the morning the barista slides open what appears to be a garage door and the most fantastic smell of fresh roasted beans wafts out of the unassuming kiosk. The baristas are true blue-blooded coffee snobs. They will laugh at you smugly if you ask them to grind your coffee; they will scorn your Mr Coffee, and will call your mokka pot fickle, but will be happy to engage in a lengthy discussion about the merits of the vacuum brewer--regardless of how long the line is.  The beans are roasted fresh and they won't sell you beans that were roasted more than 48 hours ago.  Even if you beg.  
The coffee is divine. The drip coffee is made by the cup in a ceramic dripper. It's caramelly, nutty and complex. The lattes are made with organic clover milk are finished with an expert leaf pattern. If you buy beans I recommend the Chiapas for a cozy companion to Sunday brunch and the Hayes Valley Espresso for your weekday am commute. 
I've been told it's addiction but I think it of it as affection.
author: sarah a.

description: My lord. The New Orleans roast or whatever I got, makes me daydream about this quaint little alleyway. Best coffee in town?
author: Tosh J.

description:
coffee by people who truly love coffee.  it's not the cozy cafe experience you'll get from other places, you have to wait, and there's frequently no wear to sit or stand, and you're outside, sometimes in the rain, but it all makes the excellent deliciousness of the coffee more worth it.  this is hardcore.

and steve makes perfect leaves in the foam.
author: josie p.

description: Simply put, the best quality coffee and espresso in San Francisco.
author: Michael A.

description: The best cup of coffee Ive ever had.  It was so good.  I woke up at 645 to get to Blue Bottle before the morning rush.  I might have gotten lucky but there was no wait at 8 am.  I got an iced coffee as well, which was really good as well.  The drip coffee I got was what really impressed me.  It just tasted perfect.  The guys behind the counter were very nice.  It definitely lived up to the hype.  I cant wait until stacks opens up right nearby so I can go to blue bottle while waiting 45 to an hour for breakfast and then go to blue bottle after.  I just can't get enough.
author: John P.

description: I have never waited less than 5 minutes, and nevertheless I stave rave about this place.  The coffee tastes so fresh, this place is going to be a San Francisco institution.
author: Dan S.

description: Why write another review about this 5 star place after seeing 877?  I have been spending time trying mochas from santa cruz to portland and find the mocha at blue bottle to be the most unique flavor in chocolate and good mix to still taste the espresso, that I have been able to find.  The chocolate used comes from "a fine chocolatier in the ferry building".  Just that description alone sparks my interest!  A must try!  Parking sucks and is usually done illegally.  Star sightings sometimes happen here.   Standing room only. A little bit expensive.
author: Andrew K.

description: I like Blue Bottle but not as much as I like Ritual. Blue Bottle would get five stars from me if this location had seating and free wi-fi. However they do not. They are only a walk up bar. Great coffee though, very decent.
author: Joy A.

description: Waiting in line on a sunny weekend, with all the other Hayes Valley hipsters, well that's 3/4 of the fun. Oh, the coffee's not so bad either!
author: John B.

description:
another five star review for blue bottle.  why?

five words:  new orleans style iced coffee 

(i.e. new orleans style = coffee that is not hot brewed and then poured over ice).

blue bottle serves it.  it's perfect on a warm day.  

the individual drip coffee and espresso drinks aren't too shabby either.
author: Eric L.

description:
delicious coffee!!!!!! I am a big fan of the individual drip coffee...my ONLY complaint is that my coffee is never very hot and by the time i add cream and walk down the alley its pretty much room temp. still delicious but not a hot cup of joe nonetheless. 
cool place to take visitors from out of town.
author: Kelle K.

description: YES! i am so excited to be the 555th reviewer of blue bottle. what can i say besides that 5:55 is the EXACT TIME I WAS BORN. the rest you already know: really good coffee, cool alley location, prettily packaged beans for purchase. i experienced a caffeine buzz that lasted no less than 10 hours.
author: julia r.

description: True. Best Latte I've ever had. And pretty, too.
author: Sally M.

description: I recently got into drinking coffee so was so excited when I came across this place on Yelp.  Overall I think the coffee is good but not as yummy as others had claimed.  My boyfriend and I were not that impressed with the latte and the invidiual dripped coffee.  Maybe I'll give this place one more try the next time I'm around the neighborhood.
author: Yvonne L.

description:
individually prepared drip coffee:
better than peet's house blend but not as great as Philz silken splendor

the parking meters at hayes accepts credit/debit cards now, so i dont have to carry change if i go there
author: Ryan B.

description: Hmmm. I've only been here once, and the latte was good, but I wasn't quite sure what all the hype was about. Given all the other great reviews, I'll have to give it a second shot (get it?).
author: beth l.

description: I finally found this place! I've heard many great things about their individually brewed coffee cups since I've moved here, and boy! they were right. Definitely one of the best cups of coffee I've had in a long time. It's in an alley by the giant wood thing in Hayes Valley. You (almost) can't miss it!
author: Veronica B.

description:
this was a tough call. blue bottle does indeed deserve much of its fame. the coffee is well balanced and quite complex with full of aromatic flavors. however, it's not particularly strong. my morning coffee must be rocket fuel. as good as it is, blue bottle coffee failed to whip up the caffeine buzz that i crave for. so i had to go back and get a second cup. i suppose i'm an addict... in conclusion, blue bottle is an outstanding place to get a cup of coffee. it's just that for some of us, we might need that second cup.

if you're in hurry, blue bottle is not a very good option due to its popularity and its one cup at a time process. you're going to wait and wait and wait...
author: frisco j.

description: I was visiting SF and focused on coffee and food the entire time because in a city like this you are very likely to find f-in great food and drink. So I find the blue bottle and I said god damn. To all you crap-ass coffee shops in Tucson, you should take a trip to learn how coffee should taste. It was intense (strong), but smooth, with a velvety finish that didn't burn or leave a bitter coffee face aftertaste. The setting is original, how often do you walk down an alley for a cup? Swanky coffee, love it, want it, think about it everyday will I drive around Tucson looking for a cup to even come close.
author: Surranna V.

description: The one and only reason I miss living in Hayes Valley. I am a coffee addict. Okay. I said it. That is the first step. My very favorite coffee in San Francisco. No. In the Bay Area. I have some pretty high standards when it comes to coffee and this surpasses my standards times two. Usually comes with a pretty long line but so worth the wait. You meet some pretty neat people there too!
author: Alexa L.

description: Simply the best drip coffee I've tasted in SF.  Bummed the price went up from $2 to $2.50 for a drip, but I'll still pay the extra 50 for this delicacy.  If you're not feeling the hot beverage, go for a NOLA iced coffee.  It doesn't disappoint!
author: Josh M.

description: i think this place is pretty excellent.  Granted, I also live in Hayes Valley.  I don't know if I would recommend it to people who have to travel.  You would have to be really into coffee to do that and be happy.  It's not even really a cafe, just a storefront (kind of).  Don't go if you are in a rush, since the do the drip coffee, and it takes some time.  It' s one of those small indie venues, where the product is excellent, but none of the convenience of a Starbucks.
author: Liz C.

description:
so the patrons occasionally leave something to be desired.  welcome to big city living, kids.  nothing can take away from the fact that THIS is what coffee is meant to be:  delicious, not laden with acid, creamy and just lovely.  i've sent bags of it to coffee snob friends all over the country and every last one of them has become a convert.

oh and FYI:  the mocha (something i usually avoid because it's usually just glorified hot chocolate) is about the world's best hangover cure.
author: nic f.

description: I have never had a better cafe au lait in my life- it tastes just like a cozy, frothy cappucino but without the crazy jitters I get from espresso sometimes.  In fact, my au lait buzz is perfect.  They make this coffee one cup at a  time, by individual drips.  A little pricey, but completely worth it.
author: Tovah S.

description: I'm not a regular coffee drinker, but I appreciate a good cup of coffee once in a while. My bf buys their beans and makes coffee in his little mokka pot. I love adding a touch of condensed milk and ice to the coffee to make my own yummy iced coffee.
author: Sarah C.

description: Went here for the first time the coffee was good the temperature was perfect.  Wish the location was larger though.  I also had a double chocolate cookie,which was less than impressive.
author: Peter W.

description: I have to say- I love the coffee, love, love, love the coffee... but so not like those who serve it.  I am not sure why those who work there, reserve the right to make you feel unwelcome.  I work at a coffee shop as well, but  NEVER make my customers feel as though they are a burden.  And that is why I will not go to the kiosk, but only order online.  If you do work there, can you just answer this question-  "why the attitude?"
author: Shelly L.

description: Drop what you are doing and go here NOW.  Order the New Orleans iced coffee (with soy) and be prepared for a little taste of heaven.  And, yes, there is almost no where to sit, but don't fret, you can just walk to the end of the block and hang out at Hayes Green.
author: Marn E.

description: This really is the best coffee in the city. I love the "house blend" and use the beans at home too. Not much else to day. It's the best. Period. End of story.
author: Eater S.

description: oh yes, i have died and gone to heavenz!
author: Jeremy D.

description: Great coffee in a cute location. You'll most likely have to wait in a line but it's well worth it.
author: Ryan C.

description: Words cannot describe the amazingness of Blue Bottle.  Even though you can now get it plenty of places around the city, nothing compares to the original stand in Hayes Valley.  I've tried just about all of the different types of coffee, and none disappoint.  In addition, the snickerdoodles with saffron are unbelievable - one of those and a cappuccino and I'm set :)
author: Katie R.
