description: i wont repeat what others have already said about the flavor of their coffee or their service, because repetition is boring... but i can assure you that i wear my "coffee snob" title proudly...nobody likes a bragger, I know...but i must brag a bit about Blue Bottle to the true diehards.  the ones that don't complain about the price, or seating area, because we don't mind waiting for perfection-after who would tell flowers to hurry up and bloom? Nor do we complain that we have to stand (in true Italian form) and wait, patiently for beautiful things to happen...all the while enjoying the company and the scene that surrounds us.  Blue Bottle is truly on point
author: Lainie W.

description: To say the coffee is WONDERFUL would be an understatment. My daily routine is a lunch cafe au lait at Blue Bottle and some reading in the park up the street.  Simply good coffee and GREAT people, what a way to break up the grind of a 9-5...
author: Joy C.

description:
i love the coffee at blue bottle. 

YES there are long lines, but they move fast.

the staff has never been anything but gracious, and i strongly disagree with the review calling them "lazy".
author: Rebecca M.

description:
Ok. i am a devotee of BB. However, I am thoroughly annoyed by the ungracious attitude of the barista this morning. He was absolutely rude and really does not like his job! 
Blue Bottle provides amazing coffee and customer service and I am a loyal customer. However, I can walk a block down and go to Ritual which I will be doing.
author: Jack F.

description: I visited the Blue Bottle Coffee Company on Linden Street (an alley BTW) and found the place by the line and smell I've heard so much about from my older brother.  In short my younger brother and I ordered mochas and we were delighted!  The espresso flavor and chocolate were incredible!  FYI they come with two shots by default and I was *flying* after the 1/2 way mark down the drink so be warned..!  ;-)
author: Colin C.

description: Blue bottle hayes valley rocks! I like this place much better than the Ferry Building kiosk. Even though the lines are way long now, I don't mind waiting. It's worth it! I just wish they have later hours so I can get my Blue Bottle fix at all hours!
author: Lily C.

description: Ok, hubby likes Philz, and for good reason, they're good, and creative, etc. But Blue Bottle made me want to touch myself. Minus one star for lacking anything but the curb to sit on, but that's a minor detail when I'm floating inches off the ground after a Blue Bottle experience....
author: Ramona L.

description: Blue Bottle Coffee may be the best in the Bay Area.  Maybe.  I haven't tasted every single roaster's product yet, but Blue Bottle is up there with the best.  It's my first choice for giving as a gift, and the kiosk on Linden Ave. is a required after-lunch stop when I take somebody to lunch in Hayes Valley.  I always get a decaf mocha.  The only reason they aren't getting five stars is because they don't brew decaf drip coffee, which is something I drink a lot of and would love to enjoy fresh brewed from their kiosk.
author: Polly M.

description:
i used to work in the coffee business and i must tell you that the blue bottle latte i had was the BEST LATTE I'VE EVER TASTED.  the milk was creamy perfection and the espresso caremelly and rich.  mmm.  absolutely worth the money and the wait in line. 

thank you blue bottle baristas & roasters for being so skilled! 

there is a blue bottle cart at the temescal farmer's market and the new orleans style iced coffee is now a part of my summer sunday morning routine.

**update**
i ordered a latte from the B.B. kiosk at the temescal farmer's market on sunday, 7/29 and it was perfection!
author: Sierra G.

description: yummm delicious coffee!  I just discovered this place and it's so good.  And very non-annoying.
author: Kate D.

description: The best goddamn coffee I've had in the States, bar none.
author: audrey b.

description: I had this coffee for the first time at the never-crowded Sunday Farmer's Market ... and that's how I discovered their secret: Good coffee like this shouldn't be easy to find. Step aside Starbucks, get out of line Peet, this stuff will knock your socks off. A New Orleans recipe, it's hard to beat its texture and aroma served up to you in a smallish brown heavy paper cup ... the perfect accessory for your morning. And their location, aside from Sunday's market? Perfectly out of the way.
author: Amanda C.

description: Best Iced Coffee Ever! I would drive up to SF from burlingame (SFO area) for just coffee there.. and its not like theres easy parking there but its worth it.. and always people lined up there every time i go.. so damn good!
author: Elina A.

description: Ok, first thing.  I'm not a coffee drinker!  Typically I get hot chocolate if I get anything.  I was in the area for a meeting, was torched from not sleeping very well, very tired and needed the caffeine to pick me up.  I ordered a Mocha and it was without a doubt the BEST mocha I've ever had.  Wonderfully flavorful of both chocolate and coffee.  They use Richetti chocolate, so that helps, I'm sure.  Nice people, always a line, but great tasting!!  Highly recommended!
author: Ron T.

description: Ok, stop writing about this place and by all means, stop going there! The lines are too long now. The stroller-pushing, half-caf double skim latte no foam no whip crowd is starting to lurk. Get out of my way!! And take your dog with you. If I've gotten up enough energy to crawl over here first thing in the morning to get the best gosh-darn cup of joe this side of the International Date Line, you'd better not get in my way ;)
author: Jen H.

description: I just moved to sac-town, and miss blue bottle dearly! I absolutly love their iced coffee. Its so perfect, not too sweet, just the right amount of ice, perfect coffee to milk ratio. If their iced coffee were a man, I would marry him. What the hell... Iced coffee, would you marry me?
author: Pete D.

description: Blue Bottle is the only thing that can bring a smile to my face in the morning. I am NOT a morning person, but the thought of their amazing coffee can get me out of bed, out the door and standing in the always long line just waiting for a sip of coffee that actually tastes as good as it smells... Pure bliss. People who complain about the long line and lack of seating are missing out. Their loss and one less person between me and my great morning....
author: Jessica M.

description:
We wait forever, but the first sip makes it all the worthwile...good things happen to those who wait!

udate 3/14: p.s blue bottle kicks rituals butt.
author: t f.

description: Wouldn't it be awesome to rent out the tiny little space on 18th St. where Hazel's used to be, before they moved into the bigger space, and put a Blue Bottle there, right f*cking next to Farley's?  Then, you could sit down on Farley's tables outside, drinking some good Blue Bottle coffee, laughing at the ridiculous jerks that work at Farleys.  Hah!
author: John Z.

description: I like pretentious coffee.  This i absolutely the most over the top full-of-itself company, and they make the finest coffee I have ever tasted.
author: California B.

description: let me start by saying that i do not like coffee.  with that said, damn, this was some good coffee!!!!  it made me want to like coffee even though i know that it isn't good for me.  the coffee roast has a very district rich flavor and there is absolutely no bitter after-taste.  it is pure and simple.  love it love it love it
author: Wayne L.

description: My favorite coffee ever--organic, 'microroasted,' and lovingly brewed one cup at a time. Used to be that I had to get it from a client in the East Bay. Now, it's in my neighborhood and I can have it any time I want. Life's black blood never tasted so good. http://bluebottlecoffee.net/
author: Kirsten B.

description: BEST coffee in the city, hands down.  If they only had some cafe seating, it would be perfect.  They also have Blue Bottle at the chocolatier on Filmore- great combo.
author: Jamie R.

description: Tasty, tasty. Hayes Valley needed this. Hell, the city needed this. I pretty much stopped drinking coffee months ago and I have a hard time saying no when I'm in the valley.
author: patrick g.

description: Ah Blue bottle coffee you are my mistress.   I am your bitch for New Orleans Style Iced Coffee... They say the main ingredient is chickory root but i know it is really crack.....OH why must the cup be so  very tiny?
author: Ellie A.

description: The iced coffee is cold steeped for 10 hours.  And it keeps you going and going for just as long!  Yum yum yum yum.
author: Leo C.

description:
Pluses: Excellent coffee (drip coffee, latte, mocha, iced new orleans coffee.

Note: I have not tried their beans, only the drinks

Minuses: No seating, difficult parking. This is basically a little kiosk so not a place to hang out, except on the street.
author: J M.

description: This place totally lived up to my expectations.  I had a latte and a small Gruyer and butter sandwhich...both of which were incredibly yummy...if you're a coffee lover, I recommend this place!
author: Amy S.

description: Cut to the chase...Great Coffee done right! If I were a coffee bean, I'd spend my days dreaming of being ground up in with my friends and placed in a cone. Then bathed in hot water where my rich complex flavor slowly seeps into a cup below.  I am talking coffee here people!
author: Travis W.

description:
i finally tried it today on a very cold foggy day.........i really wanted to love this place, but was rather disappointed   

1st to realize there's no indoor seating, so we had to wait in line in the cold.   well actually there's really no comfortable seating to chill, lounge, & shoot the breeze, there were only 2 chairs & a counter.

2nd  (my hub had the drip coffee & i had the mocha. my hub is "the coffee" person, i'm more of a tea & hot cocoa person)  my hub thought the drip coffee was "good" better than starbucks (of course, that's a given) & peet's, but not a "wow" experience for him.  he's been making drip coffee for over the 12 years i've been with him & so he loves his own drip coffee way more than blue bottle.  as for the mocha, it wasn't a wow experience for me either, it was good, but i much prefer royal grounds mocha on polk & vallejo (perfect bittersweet chocolate taste -- plus i usually ask for a little more chocolate @ royal grounds.  moreover the price is right, its about $1.50 - $2 cheaper @ royal grounds & i can wait in line & sit inside on a cold foggy day in sf)   

i did enjoy the lil macaroons from miette cafe/bakery........so would love to check out miette & our next coffee stops to try are philz coffee & rituals.
author: Cindi N.

description: I have driven waaay out of the way for a latte at this place on numerous occasions, often passing coffee shops I haunt on a regular basis just to satisfy my desire to drink the caffeinated liquid of gods.  I live in the Sunset, work in the Richmond, and make sure to drink here at least twice a week.  And I do it because I love you.
author: Charley B.

description: Strong, tasty soy latte.  Ridiculous line -  surprising for a place dispensing legal speed, but guess love takes time.  No artificial sweeteners, so don't dare ask as the purists at this joint will throw eye daggers or roll them skyward.  Have fun waiting.  I'll pass on weekends, but keep going on weekday lunch hours.
author: Esther R.

description: Coffee is solid.  The food is pretty good too.  Gets crowded but good places get crowded so you just need to accept it or don't go to good places.
author: Jo W.

description: An alley of european descent, coffee beans roasted to perfection, brewed before your eyes.  Ask for it "here" and take away a few moments to splurge.
author: Sheetal S.

description: I finally got to check out the famous Blue Bottle Coffee location in Hayes Valley. I didn't realize it was just a to-go counter and had it confused with the SOMA location I had seen featured in the Examiner previously. I tried the New Orleans iced coffee and rosemary pine nut shortbread- excellent! The aroma and taste was really fresh and vibrant. I also purchased two half pound bags (Giant Steps and Bella Donovan) of coffee for my boyfriend. When I asked if they could grind the beans, they looked at me with a snobby look and said "We don't grind our beans... but we sell grinders." Okay... Overall, my coffee experience at Blue Bottle was good taste wise but their baristas aren't so friendly. The customer service at Four Barrels Coffee on Valencia had a better vibe.
author: Kaila Y.

description: Super special extra good real coffee - espresso, mocha, or drip, you can't go wrong.  Take a cup for a stroll - one time at the pagoda--park down the alley from Blue Bottle, me and my cup ran into a tribe of naken bicyclists protesting oil.  It's worth checking out and you'll probably get hooked - on the coffee i mean.
author: Today Y.

description: I  too made a pilgrimage to sip out of the bottle solely because of the siren songs of yelpers. And it was good, however,  it lasted only about three sips (ok, gulps). Now an expensive latte is a luxury for me not a daily requirement and when I splurge I wanta alotta latte. one size doesn't fit all, all the time.  I did like the standardization of the menu without all the bells and whistles, but how about a large and a small? Also I tend to side with some of the others reviewers critique of the espressos lack of boldness, but the drink was well made which is maybe the most important feature of a coffee drink.
author: Ryan D.

description: Good coffee. Friendly people. 1 block from La Boulange. Enough said.
author: Lena W.

description: Nice people and good coffee. They can be a little testy sometimes but, hey, they've earned it. They have the best coffee in town. My only gripe is the line. Some days, getting coffee at Blue Bottle is like getting bread in 1917 Russia. So if you value coffee as much as you value foods like rice, pasta and bread, hit this place up.
author: George M.

description: This coffee is delicious. DELICIOUS!  and i think the people who work there are very nice but maybe i'm not like most who expect to be greeted with a curtsey, an early morning compliment on my sweater vest, and a kiss blown over my latte.  i'm more than happy to receive a hello and a cup of heaven.  and that's what i get.
author: pamela b.

description: It's no Espresso Vivace (in Seattle), but it's the best in the city.  I'm tempted to dock them a star for lacking a Blue Bottle Webcam so I can see how long the line is before walking over, but I don't think that's a standard I would expect other places to live up to so I shall not.  :-)
author: A A.

description:
Meh, it's not all that.

Drip coffee: The flavor is definitely better than Starbucks, but arguably not as good as Peet's. The temperature seemed a little too low. I want me a nice hot cup o' java! This was almost luke-warm as soon as I got it.

Peet's charges about $1.75 for a small drip coffee. Blue Bottle was $2.50. Was it $0.75 better? Meh, not really.
author: Marc S.

description:
After 2 mentions this week (NYT and Daily Candy), my brother and I decided to give this place a try. I try to not complain in reviews b/c I don't find it very helpful, but today I really need to comment.

Coffee: Overall, very good, very fresh, very strong. I only tried the drip coffee; I'm curious how I might like a frothy specialty coffee. 3.5 stars for the coffee.  

Baristas: Were overall professional, and after we asked why people who ordered after us were getting their lattes before us, they explained it takes longer for drip and apologized for the wait. 

Ambiance: I knew this was nothing more than a kiosk, so wasn't expecting much w.r.t. decor. But, from the moment we walked up, I felt uneasy and tense. The energy here on a Saturday morning was not good. The customers all seemed aggressive in a "I-come-here-all-the-time-who-the-f*ck-are-you" for this "super hip awesome" place...or maybe they were all in severe caffeine withdrawal. Like the yuppie couple behind me who kept pushing against me (I'm a yuppie too, but I still know about personal space and queue etiquette- like, back the f*ck off, lady), the odd woman who parked herself by the counter while drinking her coffee, to the man who walked up to the counter, w/o waiting in line, and wouldn't move so that my brother and I both had to reach over him to get our lids and sugar. All this culminated in a woman walking up to aforementioned man and yelling and calling him an "inconsiderate asshole" for hitting her car. Turns out she works at Blue Bottle! Niiiice.

I understand now, after having read a bunch of the reviews, that there is clearly a sense of entitlement to this place. I'm new to SF and still exploring. I'm looking forward to the day I feel a similar sense of smugness for a local coffee place and have no qualms about being incredibly rude and inconsiderate to my fellow customers. 

Will I go back: Hmmm...maybe but not on a Saturday. I'm actually really interested in checking out the cafe with the $20k coffee machine that is supposed to create coffee from the heavens...
author: Anju P.

description: This is the best coffee you will ever have.  The baristas are cute too.  My coworkers and I have nicknamed their coffee "crack-in-a-cup" I mean, you do get it in an alleyway...
author: Sarah B.

description: When you see a line of people, with a blank lost look, waiting to walk up to a sranger to buy some product, what do you think of?  Yep, it's Crackoffee !  If you like stong juice for your soul, this is it baby!  I think the only other place in SF that might be close is Philz Coffee.  Yes, it's worth the long wait.
author: H D.

description: Mmmmmm, I love their Iced New Orleans. I want to try other drinks, but I can never pass this one up. Its robust, and just sweet enough, I got introduced to this little establishment, when my now newly employed cousin had  become unemployed back in November. We kind of made it a bi or tri weekly run to Frijz and BB.  Too bad I live in Union City. An iced Latte Machiatto from Peet's will have to suffice.
author: Cherleen W.

description: Can't help but love the unpretentious way of the coffee bean freshly roasted, pour after pour week after week, Blue Bottle just rocks your world one cup at a time.
author: Franciscan M.

description: Can't say much more than everyone else has already...but hot damn, that's some good coffee.
author: Kara S.

description:
Yeah, this is good coffee. Tastes great, they serve individual drips (like me, har har har), it's a small operation (not necessarily local, but small in comparison to, oh, say, Starbucks), organic, fair trade, all that jazz. 

Maybe a little 'tude from the baristas, but if I was stuck in a garage all day coming down off a coffee buzz, I might have some 'tude too. I can't subtract a star for that.
author: Mich L.

description: best place in town for a steaming cup of hipster disdain.
author: kevin c.

description: Yummy. I had the mocha and it was went down so smooth and was so perfect that now I crave Blue Bottle Coffee. It is true about the bad customer service but eh, they work at a little stand for coffee and have to stand there all day long, rain or pour, to serve you.  Give 'em a break.
author: Nicole C.

description: really excellent iced coffee... so flavoursome you could almost chew on it.
author: Paul L.

description: Best espresso in San Francisco.  Not a real cafe (they have 4 chairs) so if the weather isn't great you'll need to get it to go.  Steve is a super nice guy.
author: Rudro S.

description: I cannot say this was even close to the best/freshest/most socially conscious coffee that I have ever had. I can say that my latte was good, and less expensive than I was thinking having read so much about this place. I can also say that I generally liked the industrial decor and the barista girl was friendly to the point that we exchanged more than the "hi", "how are you?" and I felt a little awkward having to walk away. Next time, I'm shopping in Hayes I could go either way in deciding to come back here for another cup of joe.
author: Midori G.

description: I'm not an avid coffee drinker by any means but there was a stint where I had mochas everyday from Starbucks for 2-3 years due to friends being baristas. Since they've moved on I never got a mocha again. That is until I came to Blue Bottle. I've been reading on yelp of this place and decided I just had to try it. Got a mocha and I have to say I'm in love again.
author: Eric L.

description: This is hands-down the best coffee option at the Ferry Building Farmer's Market...  I only know it from the Farmer's Market (but I think they also have outlets in the East Bay), where it is a much better alternative than the line for Peet's.  The coffee cart isn't typically in the same place at the market, but it makes it worth the extra challenge.
author: Todd J.

description: Few coffee shops make their coffee strong enough to handle the amount of cream & sugar I add to it.  Blue Bottle is an exception.  Their coffee makes the perfect sugar-high, caffeinated sludge.
author: Katie S.

description:
the line was too long for me to find out whether it is a damn fine cup o' joe...stay tuned...

25.jun 2006 - no line....damn, that's a fine cup of coffee! No bitterness, no suga, no cream...just smooth, black coffee. if only i lived closer.
author: Rene D.

description: It's out of a garage. The lines are always long. The coffee though is worth every time spent waiting. Hands down one of the best coffee joints in the city!!
author: Rob L.

description: So over the lines and the congestion at the sugar/milk/chocolate thingy-ma-bob area. I wish there was a separate line for those who only purchase espresso beans, so wholesomely roasted within 48 hours of purchase. At least when I brew my espressos, the strength is consistent and flavorful!
author: Cathy H.

description: Blue Bottle is to me as crack is to druggies. Their coffee is literally to die for. From their New Orleans iced coffee to lattes and cappuccinos,  there is no comparison. They also have miette cookies that are tiny bites of heaven to complement your scrumptious cup of java loving. It is worth the wait, don't let the line deter you. The baristas are pretty adorable and sweet too. I hope there is blue bottle coffee in heaven. Thank you for being around the corner from my house!
author: Shyla B.

description: Yes it's expensive, yes there's a line and yes it is the best coffee in the world made in the coolest possible way with a side of toffee to make your taste buds explode.
author: Sara W.

description: The New Orleans Style Iced Coffee that I had this morning was a perfect complement to reading the Sunday paper at Hayes Green... Super friendly staff.
author: Chris M.

description: Delicious coffee stand in Hayes Valley! My latte was so yummy. The espresso was perfect, not too strong, but with the perfect amount of caffeine. The foamy milk was the best. It was so frothy! Perfect for a cold SF day! With such great coffee, it's a shame that they don't serve any pastries. (Cookies from Miette don't count!)
author: Denise L.

description: Delicious and fresh cappuccinos. See my review for the Mint Street location for more details. My favorite coffee in the city and probably in the world. The espresso has a lovely creamy richness. This location has zero parking as well, so definitely walk/bike/public transport here. You might get lucky and find street parking, but don't bank on it.
author: Maren P.

description: Tried the hot chocolate at Blue Bottle for the first time this weekend.  Not overly sweet.  The service was friendly.  There's always a line, but it moves fast, so thats ok.
author: Aaron T.

description:
still... FIVE STARS for  BLUE BOTTLE.

wonderful little droplets of heaven

I had previously stated that I ONLY buy my whole bean coffee to brew in my home French Press from Blue Bottle.  I even gave a few bags to friends for a wedding gift, they thanked me profusely saying it's the best coffee they've ever brewed at home in their life (and they lived in Seattle... hello?!)

and now that I live in Chicago I can order 1 lbs bags online!! 
yippeee!
author: Shayna N.

description: Most days, seriously good espresso and espresso based drinks. And I seriously love the atmosphere of the alley space.
author: Scott B.

description: A visit to SF isn't complete unless I get to stop by BB for a mocha.  I love the little alleyway its's hidden in and the taste of the coffee is simply divine!  Can't wait for our next visit!
author: Emily W.

description: Nothing like a strong dark flavorful cup of coffee! Much Much better than Peets!
author: Christian S.

description: Where once the smells of urine and week old trash prevailed, it's good to find an ...umm good $5 Cafe Mocha. This place popped-up just as Hayes Valley is finally turning a corner. A good pit stop on those cold and dreary SF days.
author: Be N.

description: Before I embarked on my journey to lower my cholesterol, virtually every morning I indulged in a mocha and a ginger scone. The scones are completely addictive. Was hard to tell if I was there for the coffee or the scone. My tiff with the scones is that often times they're irregularly shaped so I had to be the very uncool person with twenty people in line behind me asking "uhhh...can i have that one...yeah...to the left...uh huh...yeah...sorry kind of hungry." the scones also don't always come in at the same time every day (or if at all?) but you know what - i didn't care that i was in an abusive relationship. they're that good. and of course the mocha...go to madeline's if you want  liquid chocolate. this mocha's choco is much more subtle. mocha + ginger scone = happy and $6.50 less in the wallet, but hey.
author: Kathy L.

description: Ok....I'll admit it...I am a sucker for the hearts and leafs...but the coffee is the best...perfect latte's....Never bitter.....4 because NO parking and always a line....and the cookies....omg!  The walnut butter cookies....sinful! I heard you can buy them by the package near by...
author: Nancy P.

description: I like the simplicity of this place. Unlike Philz, where you have a myriad of choices (this isn't a negative just different), Blue Bottle only has one choice of coffee. They also serve espresso drinks, hot chocolate, etc as well. Not much choice for snacks either. The coffee is consistently well-made, so I'd go here again if I was in the area.
author: Charlene C.

description: Strong coffee.  They also have a water bowl to lure dogs over for you to pet while you wait for the individually dripped coffee.
author: Andrew P.

description:
you'll never drink coffee the same way after here.

partially because all espresso drinks are double shots.  Now that my tolerance for caffeine is so high, I spend $30 a week on coffee.

Tip: Try staying and having your drink in a glass (Gibraltar).
author: J S.

description: Yep, it's pretty darn tasty.  Worth splurging on the beans to brew at home?  I gambled and must say that their Roman Espresso is pretty much what gets me out of bed in the morning.
author: Katie G.

description: Even the smell that hits you as you walk in is beyond your normal coffee world! The coffee is intense but not over-roasted like a certain ubiquitous coffee shop's beans. Great hot drinks - great cold drinks. They lose a star, not for over-hipness, not for the lines, not for the learning curve for a non-coffee fanatic, but for the very high noise level inside the shop. Enjoying your brew and a chat with your buds is not going to happen without resorting to yelling. Might as well be in the subway in NYC.
author: James H.

description: Coffee is pretty damn good and on par with Philz. If only they had a place to sit and sip, but alas, just wait in line for the best cup of coffee ever! They also sell the coffee in other cafes or restaurants that use their beans so they're pretty well known. It is worth waiting in line, make sure to get there early if you want to buy beans to make coffee at home, they sell out extremely fast!
author: Gina R.

description:
probably the best coffee in San Francisco! i don't care about the small store in an ally without seats or what so ever, the coffee is simple great! don't really know how to describe it, bold yet smooth... 

sometimes you found special bakery! 

they have booth in the farmers market every Tuesday at Ferry Building!
author: Florence C.

description: lines are long, but worth the drip coffee wait.  yum.
author: Sheri N.

description: I get so annoyed at the lines here on just about every morning that it makes me want to hate this place. But I can't. The coffee is life changing. The best cappucino I've ever had. Just be prepared to wrestle with other coffee fiends for your spot in line.
author: Melissa J.

description: The ground-and-brewed-to-order drip coffee is great, of course, and their espresso drinks are unbeatable. (They've got the "black as hell, strong as death, sweet as love" thing down pat.) But sometime, when it's hot, try the iced coffee. Just a little bit of chicory makes it perfect.
author: Joe G.

description: I'm always looking for that best cup of coffee, I thought I've found that best cup at Cafe Des Artistes in Puerto Vallarta, until I'd accidentally dropped in on this location.  Coffee from Blue bottle Co is possibly the best coffee I have ever had!
author: Will T.

description: I got a latte there.  It was really good.  I'm going to have get an espresso there next time.  There was line today.  I guess the secret is out.
author: Julia H.

description: Two Dollars for a (very) small cup of coffee?  Please.  But it's good, unexplainably so.  Thus, I'll deal with the emo staff and the Berkeleyites on Saturday morning and wait 5 minutes for a (very) small cup.
author: Dan S.

description: Great coffee in a tiny alley in Hayes Valley. There's usually a line but that's because it's good, honest coffee.
author: Kanna L.

description:
if you care drink it here!

4/16/ i saw god, and yes she drinks blue bottle and had to wait in line like everyone else ... no pull
author: tim y.

description: I will go long & far for a cup of coffee this awesome. Even with all the hipsters waiting around- it's worth it, every time.
author: Rhubarb M.

description:
it tastes rich and has a little thicker consistantcy than other places.
i think its great!  it seems kinda like a hipster, low key joint, but to keep people coming back just for their drip is pretty amazing.
not a dirty cup of burnt flavor... warm 12ounces of a great start to a overcasted chilly morning in sf.
little more pricier for this cup of joe but well worth it.
author: JASON L.

description: My wife discovered this place while temping in the Hayes Valley and turned me on to it upon my arrival from the Big Easy.  I love their New Orleans' style cold-drip iced coffee, it reminds me of many hung-over mornings at Rue De La Course on Decatur in the French Quarter.  I have since ventured to try their other products and always keep some for grinding at the house, super fresh and tasty!
author: Cass C.

description: Ok so the wait was not so fun.  But I just had to see what the hype was about.  It's all true Blue Bottle coffee is fantastic.
author: H Y.

description: Frankly, my cafe au lait was the best cup of coffee I've ever had in the U.S. I just hate that this glorious place is only a kiosk - I wish it were indoors. San Francisco is so cold! There is always a line, and on cold days that I crave a warm drink the most, I am in no mood to be waiting outside. However, Bluebottle Coffee Co.'s coffee is well worth the wait - and the frostbites you'll get while standing outside.
author: Christine N.

description: Coffee is excellent and the staff is pretty good.  Sometimes the drip coffee isn't that hot though--still way better than Starbucks and the lines are horrendous.
author: Hank S.

description: Maybe cause I've significantly cut back on my caffeine intake, but this coffee fucked. me. up. And I'm the kind of person who loves me a good upper. I got shaky sick for the rest of the day, as well as my law school student studying coffee fiend friend. Eh, maybe we're just weak. It does taste good though.
author: JJ W.

description: Ohhhhh New Orleans Iced Coffee how I lust for you. Ohhhhh how I long for you when I'm cruising through Hayes Valley on my lunch break, debating whether to wait in line for one little taste, just one more little taste. Damn Gina, it's good coffee. Perfection, I might say. And their Lattes are just as good.
author: Sarah L.

description: Best Latte I've ever had in my life. I'm about to change my school and bart sched to be able to go by this place every morning.
author: Chris S.

description: Best latte I've ever had. Smooth, kind of light and always creamy.
author: R B.

description: what can you say when Austrians say this is the best coffee they have had outside out Vienna?
author: Sha A.

description: I love this coffee. I love that the menu is so short. Coffee, espresso drinks, iced coffee, hot chocolate. Nothing fancy because no fancy is needed. The coffee is insanely good every single time. No frou-frou, no flavors, just straight up amazing coffee. The only reason I don't give it 5 stars is the wait, which can be long. On the other hand it's in a (now) pretty alley and there are usually cute dogs in line to help pass the time. And at the end of the wait is that coffee.
author: Lisa S.

description: Cool doors.  Cool concept.  Cool kids.  The coffee is exceptional, of course, and the single-brewed cup makes you feel special.
author: Melissa B.

description: This coffee is fantastic! My favorite is the New Orleans Iced Coffee you can get at their Hayes street location or at the Ferry Building on Saturdays. But I always keep a pound of the Hayes Valley blend in my freezer. The high lasts all day, but be careful this stuff is strong!
author: Kai H.

description: A man needs more than one favorite cafe. Add this to your list. The lines have gotten much longer from when I started drinking their stuff months ago. Get to the alley before they get too popular.
author: Esso E.

description: The iced coffee is so nice, it might be heaven on earth.  It is rich, creamy, and jolted enough to get you moving like a little worker bee.  Worth the $3.50......
author: Amy H.

description: A friend and I hunted down this coffee stand one Saturday morning, determined to have a cup of this infamous liquid with some scones we picked up at an Irish bakery. The line was long but the wait short. The coffee was smooth and not too strong. I'll be back for more, especially if I'm in the area.
author: Mary P.

description: These guys really believe in what they produce.  From the ground up, they put time and care into their coffee.  It is roasted in Berkeley, and they keep a tight lid on quality control.  They mean business when it comes to other people selling their product.  The lucky establishments that can serve their coffee are trained, and must promise to keep the standards and purity of the coffee.  I will definately wait for a few extra minutes for my cup of coffee to be individually made.  I will also wait for the barista to concoct the perfect blend of creamy, expertly made cappuccino.
author: Lauren M.

description: The baristas at Blue Bottle are my new crack dealers. After my fix today of their DELICIOUS soy mocha, I itched for another.  My co-worker who is also a loyal addict introduce me to this place; so here I am telling all you readers...it's okay to drink the kool-aid (in this case, COFFEE!).
author: Lisa L.

description: That's some damn good coffee. My roommate showed me this place the other day and I was blown away by how good it was. It was a nice environment, too. A bunch of kids that looked like regulars stopping by on their bikes. I enjoyed it.
author: Eva J.

description:
eh.  its good coffee but i like philz better and the linden location sucks unless you walk around the neighborhood.  ferry bldg also sucks unless you commute via there.  in other words, the location isnt practical as a daily caffeine fix stop.  

they also dont have any straws.  drinking coffee from a straw allows you to drink super hot coffee sooner if you cant wait a few more seconds to get your caffeine fix.  it looks ok but is serving coffee from a garage a good hygiene idea no matter how hipsterish it may be?

however, the foam flourish is top notch for people who care about such things...overall better than starbucks and ritual but worse than philz
author: X X.

description: Best coffee in SF hands down. They use an old school style of filter-drip coffee. I'm typically a latte drinker but their drip is what coffee is supposed to taste like. Also, the New Orleans iced coffee is incredible especially on a hot day. They sweeten it with a little chicory and it's truly perfect. It's really popular so the lines are outrageous but it's worth the wait.
author: Bill R.

description:
12/20:  went back again to pick up ground beans.   the gal and guy working the morning shift are super friendly!!!  in the afternoon, there are two gals and one  guy.  only one of the gals was kinda rude.   but i definitely like the morning staff much more!!

great coffee!!  now if only the people who serve it would lose the attitude.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
i don't know if you'd classify this as one of those 'whole in the wall' gems - it's more like a 'garage on the block' gems.  they run this coffee shop out of a garage down an alley street.  it makes you wonder if they're that confident the product will sell itself so it doesn't matter where they're located, or they're demure and modest about their product (which is pretty damn good) and didn't expect the reception they now have.

for a garage, it's decorated quite nicely - a contemporary muted tones hayes valley shiek.  there's a small bar counter in front of the pastry case where you can stand and drink your single espresso.  there's a dish full of water and a container full of doggie treats nearby, so happily bring your dogs along knowing they'll be well taken care of while you're loading up.  

the coffee itself is obviously something they take great pride in.  if it's not the actual taste of the espresso (some of the frothiest i've ever seen a barista wrench from a bean), to a more creative approach for the traditional mocha, or the charming design they leave in the frothy rooftop of your beverage before you lid it.

this place is a treat for me, not necessarily an every day thing - it's a little pricey but worth the money, and the wait isn't more than a few minutes.  remember - you're not supposed to rush until *after* you've had your coffee.  you're supposed to be half-asleep before then anyway, so a few minutes won't kill you.
author: Shelley D.

description: Little expensive for me....but one cup at a time work for me!!!! Great for strong morning coffee, wakes me up!!! and I love a cozy KIOSK style.
author: Erika Y.

description:
i don't what other people are talkin about with the,"rudeness" issue. i have only ever gotten smiles and thank you's when i have come here. sure you have to wait sometimes. sure the menu is limited. yes the cookies are expensive. no, there is no where to sit. 

so what, get over it. it's a grand cup o' joe.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Bare bones layout on the Linden alley. Minimal seating... git yer bean juice and go.  This joint looks like a garage at first glimpse, 'cept for the baristas slaving away at the machines churnin out the best expressos in SF.  For real, I had one of the best expressos  here.  Fuel for life.
author: Ranier D.

description:
right before hopping on the freeway, i'd park my car at walgreen's and get my cup of cappucino art.  it would make me SO happy despite my 40 minute commute south.  sigh.  It woke me up and looked so pretty and smelled so good.  And it was always the perfect temp for my mouth so I didn't burn myself.  

if you like burnt, dark roasts because you're used to the chains, you might not like this.  this is complex and smooth cawfee.
author: Emm C.

description: I heard through the grapevine that this is the best coffee in the city.I bravely went searching on a rainy day and found this small funky coffee stand in Hayes valley,off Gough.Like in an alley. It's not cheap,like half a pound was 7$...but well worth it.i got the "Giant Steps" and it was yummy,not bitter but packed a punch. Besides the taste,I've heard it's politically correct...I mean,this is SF,right?That's what we all want,right?
author: Nan H.

description: Great coffee!  I have been there several times, once on a rainy day where the line was very short, another time where the line was long.  BUT, the coffee is worth the wait.  I love the Mocha with soy milk -- very smooth!
author: Lydia T.

description:
ok ok. i know. 581 previous reviewers. blah blah blah.

I just got back from a trip home. Ahh, DC. you're beautiful but you are the home of some REALLY SHITTY COFFEE!!!!

So, in an attempt to wipe the awful coffee memories from my tiny little brain, I dusted off my bus pass and shot down to Hayes Valley. YUM. Sweet sweet coffee perfection. A latte that could make even my emotionally devoid self shed a single tear. 

Thanks for being here to welcome me home.
author: Johnny R.

description: This is delicious coffee. Mind boggling actually. Sometimes you have to wait a bit maybe 5-10 minutes but it's worth every moment. The kiosk is cute  and quirky. The staff is nice and upbeat and the prices are good. The drip coffee, yes made fresh to order is only $2. A freakin steal in this hell hole economy. Let me know if you want to meet for a cup.
author: Eryn L.

description: Beautiful beans...big fan of the Sidamo for my old school stovetop Bialetti.  Nice, slow brew.  Heat up some Strauss milk 2% (I used to use whole but still decadent with the cream top) with 3 teaspoons of organic raw sugar, two shots and you've got a bomb latte every morning.  Ahhh, what a lovely ritual...
author: D L.

description: I know that many of the other coffee roasters in the city are not as trendy. Many are as good, and some are better. Unfortunately none are as cool as Blue Bottle. Hopefully this will pass as most trends do, and the damage wont be done. Unfortunately I think that is being optimistic. Blue bottle has already successfully made you robots believe that good coffee can cost no less then 2$ a cup or 17$ a pound. In the realm of luxuries, Coffee represents the last beakon of hope we have for affordable treats. Blue bottle is hell bent on destroying low coffee prices. support your neighborhood coffee shop, don't support this ridiculously expensive trend.
author: Zach F.

description: The coffee is really good and strong but it's expensive.    But, due to the bad economic, I would rather make my own Latte or go to my friend's coffee shop, CAFE ME..
author: Rocky L.

description: I went there this morning to be greeted by a barista that really could not give a rats ass. Very dismissive.
author: Jill F.

description:
It is undeniable that this place is damn good. These people are true coffee artisans and all the words San Franciscans love apply here: 'micro' 'organic'  and 'local'.  Dig on the leaf designs rendered with espresso and steamed milk on top of many drinks.
Drawbacks: 
1)The individually prepared drip coffee has a surprisingly weak constitution. Its not worth the $2. Takes forever to prepare. Get espresso-based drinks only.
2)The wait is long. You need at least 15 minutes free if you are going to patronize this place. None of the employees hurry for anybody, long line or not.
3) If you are not the alt.lifestyle.com type, a member of the fascist left or a Burning Man type, you won't get the 'good vibes' everyone describes.
author: Andrew D.

description: My boyfriend and I make the pilgrimage to BBCC every weekend to pay homage to the greatness of Jamie, best barista in the city.  He makes it look deceptively easy - teasing out complex flavors and velvety microfoam without even looking.  I have to say though, it's not as good on the weekdays with other baristi.  Even so, it's my favorite cup of coffee, with Ritual in the Mission a close second.
author: Esther K.

description: Finally something stronger than hot fllavoured milk where quality has not been sacrficed for quantity.  May have to move to Hayes.
author: JBO ..

description: The coffee tastes very clean, unlike the usual processed coffees.  It tastes good.  There's no place to sit, unless you like sitting on the curb.  They don't have a good selection of cookies/pastries.   The ones that they do have seemed to be over-priced for what they are.  The staff is indifferent but they get the job done.  However, if one of their friend's stops by, they'll chat it up while everyone else stands and waits for their turn to order (what other customers?).
author: Miss T.

description: It really IS the best cappuccino I've had on this continent!
author: Athos K.

description: One of the best cups of coffee in SF. Always a long line, but always worth the wait. Not one of those places to post up with laptop. Coffee on the go.
author: Ryan M.

description: Love the coffee, but the help needs a clue! Hurry it up, people! We've got places to go, people to see, crap to buy!!!
author: Scott N.

description:
turn down the alley
what's everyone in line for?
the best cup a joe
author: Jessica Y.

description: The only bad thing about this place is the long line.  They drip their coffee cup by cup so it' super fresh and strong.  I get the house coffee with lots of cream and it's just deliciously bold.  It's so unique and special and feels noncorporate, non-Starbucks.
author: H G.

description: Wow. I intend on moving to hayes valley so I can drink this coffee ALL the time.
author: Pearl M.

description: I suppose the cafe latte I got was not an equal comparison to the drip coffee I usually drink, so I can't truthfully qualify Blue Bottle as the best coffee I've *ever* had, but it was definitely quite quite good. Smooth and rich. And it had coffee artwork on the top - a little leaf in the foam - how'd they do that? I think the coffee could have been a little hotter, but I like it scalding out of the pot and that's probably a safety hazard. The menu is simple - no carmel machiatos or anything - but why ruin good coffee with syrup? Save the syrup for resuscitating a Starbucks brew.
author: Caitlin H.

description: This is truly amazing coffee!  Blue Bottle has many fantastic blends of addictive organic beans.  Try the New Orleans when you're in the mood for something cold.
author: Josh F.

description: The truest, finest cup of espresso in the city.  It's entirely worth the wait, and the service staff are fantastic!  I appreciate the fact that they take their time; I can always be sure that my cup will be perfect.
author: Major M.

description:
First of all, why would some douchebag use a negative review of a business as a venue to push his rambling opinions on coffee and global warming???? I'll edit this preface when the Yelp team wisely removes the "review" in question.

Now. . .Let me tell you, I can confidently say that there is no better coffee out there on the market than Blue Bottle. I've given it a lot of thought on what they do in particular that makes their coffee so rich and also highlighting the individual varietals that they sell. The blends, especially Giant Steps and BellaDonovan are wonderful.

I buy the beans from the kiosk in Hayes Valley. There's something special about seeing a roasting date that is always 1-2 days old.
author: Horns D.

description: I was on my way to San Rafael to run an errand (yes, crazy but this is a soccer tournament check-in; a little inconvenient since the games aren't until tomorrow so I had to drive 1.25 hours to do a 10 minute check-in and turn around and drive back 1.25 hours)...anyway, to make this errand more palatable, I decided to check out Blue Bottle Coffee since it was on the way to the GG bridge. Parking wasn't bad (although the meter man parking behind me taking his coffee break made me a little nervous; I even re-read the street signs to make sure this wasn't a commute tow-away zone). I waited in line behind 5 other people. I wanted to see what all the hype was...and it was worth waiting 15 minutes to get my own individually brewed caffe latte. It was strong yet smooth-tasting, and the barrista put a beautiful leaf design into the top of the latte (which I enjoyed for 5 seconds before I poured sugar in and stirred up the latte). The coffee kiosk is in a small little alley, really a hole in the wall, with a line of customers waiting patiently for their brew. I would try this again...
author: Lulubelle L.

description: got the new orleans style iced coffee, really great, super fast service and inexpensive. however, i am caffeine sensitive and had the drink at around 2:30, I was still feeling it at midnight, just an FYI.
author: Ashley G.

description:
My second favorite coffee place. Like their beans (often buy them at Farmer's Market in East Bay and SF). Beans often sell out at all locations, so I don't always count on finding what I want. 
However, baristas are nice, and will make recommendations to suit your prep method (drip, spresso, or french press). 
Like the kiosk for its simplicity and consistently delicious macchiato and miette cookies. Nice treat if I am in the neighborhood. Parking is tough, but worth a little hike for a moment at the slim counter with my ceramic cup.
author: Robin K.

description: Some of the best coffee I've ever had. OK, so the wait can be a bit crazy. Somehow, every time, once I get my fix, it seems worth it.
author: Jay B.

description: I love this place not only because the coffee is amazing but also because I run into all of my friends here... That means all my friends like it too. Although I am obviously easily influenced by my peers, I truly think Blue Bottle has the best iced coffee in SF!!!
author: Amanda N.

description: It's good coffee that is reasonably priced.  The line's too long and I always feel a bit awkward from when I order the coffee, to when I pay, to when I receive it and leave, because there's only one point of sale but multiple people making coffee and I don't want to get in anyone else's way.  You also basically have to get it to go unless you want to sit on the street.
author: Joel H.

description: There is a God and she drinks blue bottle every day.
author: Bob M.

description:
atmosphere: open- not a lot of seating, but relaxing place to take in the view of the mint
food: n/a
drinks: latte's a pretty amazing coming from someone that's not really into coffee
price: not too much more than other coffee places but you definitely get your moneys worth
clientle: pretty snooty, local highrise soma dwellers
author: A D.

description: Best coffee in the city.  The drip coffee is totally worth the long wait.
author: She-ra Princess of power M.

description: I really hate it when people insist on one coffee shop being "the best." The amazing thing I love about coffee is that there are so many ways to enjoy it. It is, after all, an extremely diverse beverage, and I hold the greatest respect for my fellow growers, roasters, and baristas. That being said, almost any good coffee establishment does one aspect "the best." I've always loved Blue Bottle, as they opened my world to the difference between freshly roasted coffee and... everything else. But, for sure, they have the most bomb-ass iced coffee. The way that they make it is a truly unique method, with chicory root and a whole lotta lovin. And while I love the concept of simplicity, and only having one size for everything, this stuff makes me wish they sold it in Big Gulps. For real. But I am still blissfully happy with a normal size iced coffee in one hand, and one of their snickerdoodles in the other.
author: Adrienne F.

description: Quality Coffee. If there were somewhere to sit, I'd spend more time here. I Swing by once a week for beans and grab either a New Orleans Iced or a Gibraltar (half way between a cap and a macchiato, milk-wise). Yum.
author: Dylan M.

description: Why go to Starbucks when you have blue bottle.  A friend of mine told me about their coffee a few years back.  I've been a fan ever since.  Love the latte.
author: Yen T.

description: Awesome espresso.  period.  The only reason i did not give 5 stars is that sometimes it can take way too long (can only speak for Hayes Valley location) to get your drink.
author: Rachel C.

description:
while waiting in line for coffee, i overheard a conversation going on between the well dressed couple behind me.  the topic was 'confidence' and the lady was going on about how she understands why women have a tendency to be insecure but didn't really understand how men never are. the man was trying to tell her that everyone feels it, not just women.  as the line was long and they were up in my grill anyways, i went ahead and gracefully butt into their convo going on about how everyone feels it yet it manifests itself in different ways, blah blah and i went on to say how my confidence took a major hit since i've been interviewing for jobs for 6 freaking months now, always being told i was 2nd or 3rd choice or that i'm overqualified, etc.  the woman started to ask me questions about what i wanted to do and i blatantly stated that i just want an office girl job to work for the next 2 years while i save up money for grad school to become a nutritionist.  the man told me that he was looking for someone to work at his law firm, and to email him my resume.  i did.  i have an interview.  WTF?  oh, i also ran into the gorgeous olivia and steve:)

blue bottle, if you by some magical chance helped to get me hired, and even beyond that to get hired from simply being myself and being completely honest about what i want, i thank you from the bottom of my broke little heart, and even more so, i would be able to enjoy your delicious and fragrant goods on a daily basis, which would seriously rock my world.  much love - spech k.

*perhaps it is true, its not what you know, its WHO you know...
author: Karen K.

description: I am in the induction phase of this crazy diet where among other things caffeine is not recommended. I am not ingesting any kinds of sugars and large amounts of caffeine can cause your blood sugar levels to drop. Therefore no coffee for over two weeks now. I know you're thinking "why can't you just have one cup??" You can, but I have trouble with moderation. My school of thought with most everything is "if this one pill makes me feel like this then imagine what five will make me feel like." Substitute pill with your substance or food of choice and this explains why I am on the diet. Well, today I allowed myself caffeine for the first time and I did it with style. One cup of coffee from Blue Bottle and it was amazing. It is now the yardstick with which I will measure all others. Each cup is made individually using the drip technique which gives it a richer bolder taste. So much so that I wouldn't bring a coffee novice here. It would be similar to giving someone a bottle of really expensive, really dry red wine as their first taste. When in actuality they should start with Boone's Farm. I am already looking forward to my return trip to this little slice of heaven located in an alley in Hayes Valley.
author: Bucky K.

description: the only reason this place gets 4 instead of 5 stars is the lack of seating.  with coffee this good you need to sit down and focus on your drink.  meditate on the deliciousness.  and i'd rather not sit on the curb. sue me-- i like chairs.  benches work, too.  but some seating would be nice.  seating would be 5 stars.  of course... if there was seating, there'd probably be even more of a wait...
author: Samantha W.

description: I don't understand all the hype. I was suggested to go here by a friend who said it had rave reviews, but in my opinion, it's definitely not great. It's overpriced and the coffee isn't anything to talk about. I will never go here again.
author: Amy C.

description: great coffee. don't mind waiting. the staff is lame. actually stopped going because I found myself asking, 'why wait so long and pay so much for a cup a coffee made the way I make at home by a bunch of self-important knobs?' really, why would anyone do that?
author: Lamb Shanks S.

description: yum! i work at another coffee shop (part time.  i am actually a hair stylist) and on my days off, i like to go to blue bottle.  the coffee is positively orgasmic.  the little swirls on top of my latte make me smile.  i like that it takes a little time to make.  i know from experience that no one can make a good drink and also make 99 other good drinks in the same hour.   if you like your coffee fast and cheap (or you want a decaf, light, raspberry hazelnut frappuccino with caramel sauce and whipped cream.  bleh.) feel free to go elsewhere.  there will be more deliciousness for the rest of us.
author: emmie k.

description: Yummy yummy mmmm mmmmm.  When I think of coffee, I think of Blue Bottle.  After reading about it several times, I went to check it out  with a friend on a chilly grey winter day.  Our feel hurt from power-shopping all day and we were about 1 layer short of having enough clothes on.  We had to park, walk, and wait in line.  All of those things usually break my stamina, but we were determined.  I could definitely feel a Seinfeld moment coming on as everyone waited like good little soldiers for their turn and reverently enunciated their selections.  The guy before us ordered a Gibraltar which was NOT ON THE MENU. Aha!  Insider moment.  Of course we had to have that too.  What we received made all of the hurting feet, shivering torsos, and sore lower backs go away.  Rich, complex coffee in a small glass with a layer of the smoothest foamiest milk ever, and a little design fashioned onto the creamy top.  The taste was exquisite, and we were filled with warmth.  Now, I  no longer crave coffee, I crave Blue Bottle.  I will drive, park, walk and wait.  With pleasure.
author: Liz S.

description: the only place in sf that can rival philz.  get a gibraltar and become a disciple.  also the only coffee place that builds furniture that i know of, so it's got that going for it, which is nice (i guess).
author: Scott C.

description: i LOVE this coffee... and i usually am not a fan of coffee in the US... my absolute favourite is the New Orleans iced coffee which is my hangover cure, probably because there is so much caffeine in it. what i cannot STAND, though, and everyone else please note: don't park in the driveways. I live in one of the lofts in the alley and 2-3x's a week there's always inevitably someone parked in my driveway... i'm typically very mellow about this but the last time the fool was too busy waiting in line for her coffee and didn't want to admit it was her car blocking my driveway so she wouldn't lose her spot in line...(hello! how r-u-d-e) so i waited for almost 10 min (yes, it really does take that long for the coffee... but i'm telling you it's so worth it!) and nearly missed my flight. LAME woman, so others reading this please just don't park too long in the driveways. or if you do please admit and just move your car. so easy. oh, and try the New Orleans Iced Mocha... mmm mmm gooooood.
author: Nenette Y.

description: best coffee in the world.  this outlet is much faster and friendlier than the rest.
author: nick g.

description: Anyone who has ever lived in London/England may recognize this particular coffee variety. It tastes uncannily like UK chain Coffee Republic (I should know, I went on to sub-manage a branch back in '99). But that's a good thing! I like CR's coffee a lot, the bean blend could be a similar percentage of arabica/robusta beans? But either way Blue Bottle comes out on top in terms of flavor and depth. The only reason I have not granted a four star reward is due to the outside walk up counter procedure. I mean, that is partly the appeal, but somehow that appeal gets lost in the midst of of an icy January morning. It can also be a bit of a long wait, even if there is no one in line ahead of you. They also lack any sweeteners, and instead we have brown sugar only. Hmmm, my diet requires a low sugar intake so I won't frequent this place too often. But all in all it's a very great and decent independent coffee company that I hope will do very well. Just not somewhere to get coffee if you're in a hurry.
author: Jack G.

description: These guys are scientists and poets of coffee.  They do a concentrated double- so a single capp is QUITE potent (two doses into one quantity).  Don't even add sugar or cream- this is pure bliss.  I'd like to taste test between BB and Phil's on 24th.
author: Arlo J.

description: There is no other coffee like this. I am knocking the stars down for service. I had them at 5 stars but they keep on messing up my subscription and not sending us our coffee but they do answer the emails and correct the issue quickly. Thanks Kate.....maybe they are to preoccupied with their $20000 coffee machine..it is a pity that  we love it or I would cancel. We live on the peninsula and we drove up to find this place after reading about it on Televisionwithoutpity.com ....ok,ok ,we are dorks what can I say.My car does have a "Nerd Pride" sticker. My hubby ordered me a pound as a gift. We started having them deliver it and we are hooked. I just doubled our subscription as we run out every month and the Starbucks beans were just not as good. Their hook is that they deliver the beans within 24 hours of roasting and the aroma fills the whole mailbox when you open it up. The Hayes valley spot is literally a hole in the wall and parking is tough so I suggest having the beans mailed to you and I recommend the Chiapas
author: Sharon H.

description: The bees knees!  You always get the freshest roasts here.  Coffee geeks man the counter and can recommend a roast for how you intend to brew it or what is new and tasty.
author: Justin R.

description: i really don't understand why the barristas at blue bottle have such bad attitudes.  the coffe at blue bottle is...yes, very good.  but i don't go there anymore because of the total "cooler than thou" attitude.  and i'm from seattle where there's a lot more than three (blue bottle, ritual, four barrel) cafes serving good coffee, and the barristas are all really nice up there.  they are passionate about what they do, and are nice to the people that love what they make!
author: Josie B.

description: can't really add much to what's already been said.  i hate wimpy, watered down coffee.  blue bottle simple has the best drip coffee, ever.  it's not cheap but it's totally worth it.  haven't had anything else besides their drip & don't need to, either.
author: Allie L.

description: ohmygod.. yum! i had the drip... it was very strong... just the way i like it. the taste is not watered down at all. so much better than starbucks!
author: L M.

description: The secret to Blue Bottle is weekday afternoons:  find a way to slip out of work and get over there, because: wha-lah!  No line!  Like everyone has mentioned, the coffee is outstanding, the baristas are cool, and it's good people watchin'.  The lines though, especially on weekends, are killer.  Make a stop on a Thursday at 3PM: you'll be glad you did.
author: Patrick P.

description: Whenever I drove through Hayes Valley, I would see a line of people outside a garage. My curiosity was piqued. After trying their latte, I'm HOOKED! The best place ever to get a latte hands down. It just tastes so goooooooooood!
author: Winnie L.

description: coffee so good that you probably don't deserve it.
author: tim s.

description: This place is as good as it gets!   I fell in love with the my first cappuccino cup. A good friend introduced this coffee shop as I had not heard of blue bottle.  Anytime I'm in the city, blue bottle cup is defiantly in order.  Would love to have given a 5 star but the parking is anothr story.
author: Agape V.

description: aaahhhh...thanks to my dear friend brian i crave the coffee here.  as the hawaiians say ono loa!
author: Jaclyn L.

description: i like it here. its a good place to go if you have time to spare, like a sunday or a day off....the line is crazy at times. i like to get my coffee, sit across the street in the shade and just be. you will probably bump into someone you know. and if you dont, you will know someone new for next time. the service is friendly, and thats just as important as the coffee, at least for me.
author: coffeecake j.

description: wow! what a gibby Alex the barrista will make you. ask him what athlete's number he has created for you. i'm a huge fan!!!!!!
author: Jake P.

description: One of the things I miss most about living in the city is starting my weekend mornings with a walk to blue bottle for coffee.  There is always a line on weekends, but the coffee always makes it worth the wait.
author: Ali F.

description: i had some blue bottle coffee last weekend and i haven't been the same since. i can't tolerate the taste of the coffee that i make at home and i can barely drink the coffee that they roast right down the street from my apartment in north beach. all i can think about is getting back to blue bottle. i will see them this saturday and get my life back on track.
author: Katherine C.

description: best cap ever. they do not burn the milk leaving it natural sweet flavor and the coffee is smooth and creamy and amazing.
author: Jayne M.

description: love the place.  hard to find even when you get directions.  staff were really friendly and good fun.  only complaint is they don't grind the take-home coffee and i don't have a grinder at home...  lots of other stores won't offer grinding unless its their beans... what a dilemma!  argh
author: david s.

description: parking is awful, and you need to walk through an alley to get there, being extra cautious not to step on .... ahhh, anything you wouldn't want to get on the bottom of your shoe ... and i'm not talking about gum. this is not a cafe - this is a coffee stand. the line is usually short, the service is efficient, and the drip coffee is a bargain at $2.50 (compare that to starbucks). my favorite is the New Orleans Iced Coffee which doesn't need ANYTHING. the coffee is discernibly high in quality - gourmet / imported beans, and this is coming from someone who likes her coffee black.
author: D N.

description: I really like the New Orleans Ice Coffee and the Affigato. Sometimes the line is way too long.  But, they can't help being popular!
author: s v.

description: do believe the hype.
author: Sarah B.

description: this was the spot where i had my first sip of blue bottle coffee in a new orleans iced coffee.  the best till the last drop! the service was friendly and the line at that time was non-existent.  i would highly recommend the hayes valley kiosk to anyone.  a little taste of the bay area's local coffee bean.  just that its pretty pricey for coffee compared to else where for its size
author: Jacqueline H.

description: My favorite roaster right now.  At the office we brew different coffee every day.  Weeks later people were still talking about the Blue Bottle beans.
author: Malik C.

description: went this weekend for the first time, very cool!  great coffee (as always for blue bottle).  a few good pastries too..
author: G W.

description: really good coffee...but uhg the line is so long and the alley is so cold.  I would have liked a garbage can on fire to stay warm around.
author: Q J.

description: Like others have posted before, you can buy their freshly roasted beans from their website. Roughly $15 for a half-pound including USPS 2day shipping. Their coffee beans are awesome. Any of their blends are worth a try.
author: Cary W.

description: Best cup of coffee I've ever had, consistently.  Full, rich, flavorful -- spoiled me completely for other coffee.  Yes, the line is long, but life is short, and it's fun to chat and watch the groovy folks hang out
author: Dennis T.

description: I have only been to their stand at the Ferry building and I think their lattes are out of this world. Blue Bottle reminds me of Urth Cafe in LA. I absolutely love starting my morning off w/ their coffee. It is worth the price and wait!
author: CC C.

description: Not sure which one to write the review for on Yelp - all of the blue bottle locations seem to have their own listing, anyway, we have been to Oakland, Linden, Ferry Building, and 'shipped' to out of town relatives, and we love it all.  Service is great, everyone knows their coffee, they help you feel informed, but don't make you feel ignorant, and always give good suggestions.  Linden is fun, to avoid the lines, and if you are just getting beans, go Tuesday afternoon, seems to be better . . . oh Linden and Oakland, just cash BTW - On-line you can do credit cards, I don't remember Ferry Building.
author: B C.

description: Love the coffee, tolerate the lines, mixed (mostly frustrated) by the online shop.
author: Geo G.

description: I was in Hayes Valley to pick up a check, and had to see what all the fuss is about. I stood in line behind some dude (who ordered up about all the inventory in the place) for about 5 minutes, impatiently checking my watch and looking over my shoulder back towards Gough, imagining that my unplugged meter was resulting in a ticket and an unintented $40+ capuchino. When I finally did get to the front and got my small cap, I was shaking with excitement (or maybe it was caffeine withdrawal). I saw that this place, in addition to the pelthora of 5 stars here, is rated #2 in the city on coffeeratings.com. My fave - Martha Brothers - is only #35 there, so I have lots of coffee drinking to do! So, I got the cap and was a little disheartened to find that there was no splenda, or any sweetener alternative. Just regular sugar. I decided to taste it sans sweetener. It really is a good cup. It didn't need sugar. It smells nice and is smooth and easy to drink. In the end, though, I missed the more "roasty" flavors I find in Martha's and even Progressive grounds (to a lesser extent). I agree with one of the reviewers below: Nothing wrong with this place, but it doesn't really stand out for me. There weren't any pastry items to speak of (except macaroons, which I don't call a pastry item, really), and the cup was $4 for a small. I won't be going out of my way to this location, but if they opened one closer to Bernal/Mission/Noe I may stop in from time to time.
author: Scott M.

description: my favorite sunday morning destination.  believe the hype.
author: james s.

description: love their coffees, though it's impossible to purchase decaf beans for home (on a diet, trying to cut back on caffeine). my favorite cup is the 'gibraltar' which has less milk and slightly more coffee than a standard cappuccino, and is served in a glass tumbler. yummy.
author: Erik K.

description: Total perfection.  The end.  The Ferry Building and Mint locations don't compare...the careless, dopey servcice at both those locations spoil the experience.  MOMA...never been.  But, Linden...that hits the spot.  John and the other staff...I love you.
author: Andrew W.

description: Pretty good coffee...but people need to seriously relax with their attitudes. Staff AND customers! Why does everyone have to be so arrogant and pretentious? I mean, the coffee was good, but, it wouldnt hurt having a pleasant  and quick experience trying to get it.
author: Ryan K.

description: best coffee i've ever had.  friendly staff too.  i love this place.
author: mission girl g.

description: i don't understand the hype.  i went to this location a few days ago (when the arctic winds were blowing through the city) with some friends and each one of us ordered something different:  drip coffee, soy macchiato, and a cappuccino.  all three of us thought that the coffee was below average and definitely nowhere near one of the best coffees we've ever had.  the line was relatively long....the baristas were nice but unorganized....and there was no seating area.  i don't understand how so many people can love this place so much....there are so many great cafes in SF.
author: Jay M.

description: i like blue bottle and the sometimes slightly off-beat service.  i appreciate a good cup of Kaffee.  i don't think it has jumped the shark-- i think other gigantic coffee chains have or maybe they were never on the other side of the shark pool.  anyway, blue bottle is great but if i had to choose between philz and blue bottle i would pick philz.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: this place makes amazing coffee.  the bartenders are super friendly too and have helped me out when i've forgotten to bring money.  plus, the place has a chill and relaxed atmosphere despite the always present line...
author: vlad k.

description: what's up with all those people hanging out in that dingy hayes valley alley?  even though i don't drink all that much coffee, i had to see what this was all about.  the coffee was very tasty and strong - i was still shaking from the caffeine hours later.  i'll be back though...it's nice to have a neighborhood coffee joint that serves up great coffee, while supporting a small local business.
author: Vic A.

description: i like the little "ride by" Blue Bottle stand on Linden. it's such a non-descript place and i always happen to swing by when it's not so crowded. my favorite is the new orleans style iced coffee with just barely a hint of chicory (which I normally don't like) but it's perfect on a hot and sunny day and I've been riding around town for a bit. ahhhhh... refreshing! sometimes I do wish there was a place to sit and hang out but i guess the sidewalk would do.
author: ray e.

description: I LOVE bluebottle. This location is great - a nice quick pick-up *well if you dont' go during peak times*... The service is great - the people are friendly - and I love the workers! I wish it was slightly cheaper for iced coffee, but can't have everything my way~! :) The Miette cookies are great, but if I were you, I'd take a nice stroll over to the Miette retail shop right next to that playground and save yourself 50 cents. I know I know it's not that much, but that shop is really friendly and tasty as well. Macaroons - yum, with my Bluebottle...
author: Jeannette L.

description: if you're in hayes valley, stop by blue bottle.  tucked away on linden street, blue bottle has only four chairs scattered around the sidewalk and a small walk-up counter with one barrista. no frappachinos and caramel macchiatos here...  instead, you'll find the best espresso, single cup brewed coffee, and my new treat, the new orleans iced coffee.
author: wendy r.

description:
I know that making a cappuccino with soy milk is difficult.  Being lactose intolerant (damn my Asian genes) however, I am forced to look for cafes that  can create a cappuccino with that perfect ratio of espresso to hot foamed milk.  Oh, and of course, it must be topped with velvety thick foam.  I've tried it numerous times myself and it always turns out with either too much lifeless foam on top or too little foam (let's just call it a shot of espresso).  SO, I give props to anyplace that can make a good cappuccino from soy milk.  This hole-in-the-wall is one of the few places I've found that makes a decent soy cappuccino.  The taste of the espresso is actually what made the capp good--intense dark caramel-like flavors danced in my mouth.  The foam on top was not as thick as I would have liked, but again, it is difficult to achieve this w/soy milk.  At least, my soy cappuccino resembled a regular cappuccino--having the same ending artisan touch of a pretty leaf design in the foam.  

How I miss the cafes in the bay area.  Can't wait 'til I'm back there again.
author: Ji-yon Y.

description: My  new office is only 2 blocks away, and I feel my raise being insignificant compared to the bucks I will drop going here instead of Peet's.  I love Linden, something about feeling like I'm going down a back alley to get my coffee.  Yeah, it's just that good.  I may have to convert my office and buy a grinder here...  but it won't be the same as going down the alley to get my fix.
author: b b.

description: my mom introduced me to blue bottle coffee one day whilst we were attempting to find a reasonably priced dress for an event i had coming up. (i'm sure it goes without saying that it was a failed attempt- reasonably priced dress in hayes valley? as if!) in any case, i thought she was kidding when we walked down an alley and got on a looong line to buy coffee from a garage cum espresso bar. seriously? seriously. this stuff is amazing. i and the hundreds of other reviewers wouldn't lie to you.
author: oona m.

description: i had a very interesting time here. i like my cappuccino dry because i wanna see if they can make nice thick foam. but the barista refused to serve me a dry cappucino, but offered to make me a short cappucino, pulled with a ristreto shot. the espresso is amazing, best i've had in San Francisco, and i'm a barista myself.
author: Jeorge J.

description: best mf'ing latte in my life. one of three places in SF where I can actually still get a buzz from the coffee.
author: saru s.

description: espresso on the street?  this is why i want to move to san fran.
author: Benjamin C.

description: Ahhh, Blue Bottle coffee... no sugar needed, the beans taste that good!
author: Shwin S.

description: The coffee gets 5 stars, the hipster crowd and slight 'we brew awesome coffee and are cooler than you' attitude that floats around knocks it down to 4 stars. Really a good cup. You might wait to order, and some of the drinks take a while to make (single cup drip), but if you're in the hood, it's worth a few minutes.
author: drew p.

description:
what can i say, really?
no matter which blue bottle you go to, the people are friendly and the coffee is amazing and inexpensive for what you're getting. 
(cheaper than crappy starbucks which is mostly milk!!)
i recommend the individually prepared drip coffee and then new orleans style iced coffee.
author: Lily L.

description: I think I've finally become an SF resident. I finally figured out how to best navigate my way to this garage, I leave for whatever I have to do a little early so I can wait in line for this drip, and I'm a little grumpy when I don't have the time for Blue Bottle, or dismay - they are not open during open hours! (never do that to me again blue bottle).
author: meli m.

description: Delicious! Totally worth the wait. The line wasn't as bad as people made it sound. I'm definitely going back.
author: Chelsea L.

description: In all truth the pics shown here on yelp with all the fancy designs on the Cappuccinos is unimpressive to me as it's been going on it Italy since the late 1960's by a small coffee chain in Milan that set the roasting standard for high grade Arabicas and the cappuccino froth design trend accross Italy (well before illy revamped their processing plant).  To taste the true quality of an arabica roast coffee..the simple straight espresso is the way to go.  If it's overly bitter or requires more than one and a half tsps of sugar to eliminate that bitterness it's not a great coffee as the acidity levels have gotten too high which could be caused by a variety of factors, a bad barrista or old coffee or overly roasted beans.  One can have a good or bad experience here.  I was not blown away or overwhelmed.  Hype is for the sheep, so be your own judge and listen to your taste buds not by the length of the line. I will definitely check out the Ferry Building location next as my friends have spoken very highly of it to me and they know I'm one hell of a picky bastard.
author: Paul S.

description: seriously my 2nd favorite place in sf... my first favorite is the blue bottle in the mint plaza.
author: leigh o.

description: the best coffee in the city...gotta try their capuchinos...unbelievable!
author: Dan J.

description: the best coffee in SF. :) try the soy latte...even if you've never liked soy b/c it tastes like SOY. this tastes one like magic. :)
author: Michelle M.

description: this place is better than any starbucks in the city...friendly servers and they make little hearts on the foam...was exceptional
author: Ron S.
